webTitle: Media Monkey's diary

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.body:
 Rosie Boycott's biggest signing was the astrologer Jonathan Cainer, so the Express editor doubtless read his tips for Taureans over breakfast on Wednesday, the day a certain Mr Desmond came to call. "Like an Agatha Christie detective gathering suspects in a library, you are trying to force a certain drama to its conclusion. Your hope is that if you act as if you know perfectly well "whodunnit", the culprit will show his hand. But what if they happen to know you are only bluffing?" Clairvoyant words, indeed.

 Strange rumours from Scotland, where it is said the sports editor on one broadsheet rang his counterpart on a rival title and told the unfortunate fellow - unaware of any threat to his tenure - that he had just been offered his job. Bit like being manager of Celtic, then.

 Monkey is indebted to Broadcast magazine for reproducing part of a booklet guiding staff on entering BBC buildings via automatic turnstiles. Particularly tricky, apparently, is To Enter and Exit Sharing the Same Turnstile: "To improve the flow you can share the same turnstile, however each user must activate their door independently. If not all occupants will be reversed out." Clear now?

 He prefers business to soap operas, American politics to British politics and Radio 4 to Radio 1. So why is this tabloid newspaper editor so entertained by something as trivial as Beanie Babies? Apparently he has asked the paper's LA correspondent to get him the latest editions of the soft toys to add to his growing collection.

webTitle: Boro to make Venables Robson's boss

fields.headline: Boro to make Venables Robson's boss
fields.standfirst:
Match report:
Middlesbrough 2 - 2 Bradford
fields.trailText: Terry Venables may have been snubbed by the Football Association, his reputation tarnished by disastrous spells in charge of Crystal Palace and Portsmouth, but he is set to return to the Premiership today as manager of Middlesbrough.
fields.body:
Terry Venables may have been snubbed by the Football Association, his reputation tarnished by disastrous spells in charge of Crystal Palace and Portsmouth, but he is set to return to the Premiership today as manager of Middlesbrough.

Boro's chairman Steve Gibson, reluctant to dismiss his close friend and current manager Bryan Robson, has approached Venables and is understood to be optimistic that the former England coach will try and salvage the club's increasingly desperate season.

Robson did not initiate the move but has backed his chairman's decision. He will stay on as first-team coach while the current coaches Viv Anderson and Gordon McQueen will also be retained. There have been no indications of the deal offered to Venables.

Boro's chief executive Keith Lamb said yesterday: "We are hopeful something will happen within the next 24 hours."

Venables met with Gibson, Robson and Lamb on Thursday in London. Should he take up the reins it would be his first managerial post outside the south of England, though he did have a spell at Barcelona.

"There's a huge job to be done at Middlesbrough and they are struggling," he said. "I only thought I would return to management for the England job but if ever two people could change my mind it's Gibson and Robson. I have a lot of big decisions to make. I have many commitments outside football and this is something I must think long and hard about."

Venables, whose sole domestic honour remains Spurs' FA Cup success in 1991, has been out of the game since leaving Palace in January 1999. His spells at Selhurst Park and Portsmouth ended with the clubs in the lower reaches of the First Division and administration.

"Bryan and Steve are totally committed to Middlesbrough and I admire their devotion," he added. "After meeting them it is clear they are determined to bring them success."

Quite where the appointment will leave Robson, who has been in charge for six years, remains to be seen. Saturday's draw against Bradford ended a sequence of six successive defeats but left them in the relegation zone. Afterwards, moreover, Robson denied knowledge of the approach to Venables, under whom he worked during Euro 96.

"People have been talking all week about whether I would be sacked or if I would resign regardless of whether we won or lost against Bradford," he said. "But for me that is not an issue. I know I have got 100% backing from the chairman."

webTitle: Riot at Reggina forces Collina to abandon match

fields.headline: Riot at Reggina forces Collina to abandon match
fields.trailText: Brescia's Pavel Srnicek, the former Newcastle and Sheffield Wednesday goalkeeper, was slightly injured by a firework thrown by Reggina fans in a Serie A match in Reggio Emilia that was abandoned after 84 minutes when flares, staves, fruit and plastic bottles were again hurled on to the pitch.
fields.body:
Brescia's Pavel Srnicek, the former Newcastle and Sheffield Wednesday goalkeeper, was slightly injured by a firework thrown by Reggina fans in a Serie A match in Reggio Emilia that was abandoned after 84 minutes when flares, staves, fruit and plastic bottles were again hurled on to the pitch.

The game had been halted early in the second half when Srnicek was hit, though it soon restarted. But when Reggina went 2-0 down fans again threw objects on to the pitch, prompting Pierluigi Collina to suspend play for four minutes. Brescia scored a third in the 81st minute and again the Reggina fans launched their missiles.

Riot police intervened and Collina abandoned the match, though Brescia appear certain to be awarded the win.

The chances of Sven-Goran Eriksson taking early charge of England increased yesterday when Lazio were beaten 2-0 at Parma and their fans displayed a banner with the message that "Eriksson must go".

A run of four games without a win has convinced many supporters of the champions that the club are suffering because the Swede has accepted the England job.

The president Sergio Cragnotti said on Saturday that Eriksson will stay until June but the pressure to change heightened when goals from Sergio Conceicao, who joined from Lazio in the summer, and Sabri Lamouchi left the visitors, who also had Fernando Couto sent off, well off the pace.

webTitle: Ferdinand ready to prove himself Ridsdale's 'bargain'

fields.headline: Ferdinand ready to prove himself Ridsdale's 'bargain'
fields.trailText: Only time will tell whether Rio Ferdinand proves money well spent or the worst-value export from Peckham since Trotters Independent Trading ceased business.
fields.body:
Only time will tell whether Rio Ferdinand proves money well spent or the worst-value export from Peckham since Trotters Independent Trading ceased business but the new Leeds United No29 has already done enough in his short career to show, as Del Boy might say, that he is a diamond geezer.

After a week of tortuous negotiations with both Leeds and West Ham, then the most delicate talks of all with his family, the world's most expensive defender finally checked into Elland Road yesterday having put the finishing touches to an £18m move from West Ham."We've got a bargain," said the beaming Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale.

So the deal is done, although there are a good few who reckon Leeds have been, too. Ferdinand made all the right noises yesterday and, if he handles his price tag as he handled his news conference, Ridsdale's statement will doubtless ring true.

"The price doesn't bother me a bit," Ferdinand volunteered. "It's probably more of a dilemma to you lot [the press] than me. All I'm concerned about is playing well and I will leave the figures to the money men.

"If I'm honest, the hardest thing was leaving London. But it's only a flight, car ride or train journey home and this is too good an opportunity to miss."

Anyone who has accused Ferdinand of showing more loyalty to his bank balance than the club that nurtured his talents will be interested to learn the 22-year-old has written off a significant sum in owed money from West Ham.

Nevertheless his advisers have still negotiated a severance fee of £200,000 to top up the £9m he will earn from Leeds over the next 5 years. Harry Redknapp says the grass is no greener in West Yorkshire than the East End. But the money certainly is.

webTitle: The other Ferdinand finds way to his own headline

fields.headline: The other Ferdinand finds way to his own headline
fields.trailText: It is obvious that Spurs enjoy the comfort of their own home. The challenge for them now is to cure their travel sickness. This was their seventh win in eight games at White Hart Lane and it was against a side who pride themselves on being mean.
fields.byline: Simon Mann at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
It is obvious that Spurs enjoy the comfort of their own home. The challenge for them now is to cure their travel sickness. This was their seventh win in eight games at White Hart Lane and it was against a side who pride themselves on being mean.

Before Saturday's tetchy contest Peter Taylor's team had conceded only one goal away from home. Les Ferdinand must be wondering if his fellow Premiership strikers have gone soft. Leicester allowed him four attempts at goal and he scored from three of them, his first hat-trick for the club.

He was helped by the sort of defending that normally afflicts Spurs when they are away. Gary Rowett's ill-directed pass set him up to strike an excellent first and Leicester's failure to clear a corner led to his headed second. It was easier for him to score than miss his third. "I'd have settled for three tap-ins," he said. "But it was nice to start scoring goals again."

Ferdinand, though, had to go home without the match ball. It was kicked into the crowd at the final whistle and never reappeared. Spurs fans may be hard to please but they do have a conscience. A caller to a radio phone-in later promised to hand it back today.

Ferdinand's finishing highlighted Leicester's attacking deficiencies. Ade Akinbiyi and Trevor Benjamin, both in their first Premiership season, were lively but lacked composure. It might have been different if Rob Harris's view had not been obscured when Akinbiyi bundled in a 28th-minute corner. The referee ruled that Neil Sullivan was fouled by the striker but the television replay told a different story.

Harris, not for the first time this season, had an uncomfortable afternoon, unaided by vendettas that had their origin in last year's robust Worthington Cup final between the sides. In the first minute he let off Stephen Clemence after the Spurs wing-back retaliated against Robbie Savage. He then booked Savage and Gerry Taggart for offering views on his refereeing and concluded by sending off Taggart when Stephen Carr fell after his challenge on him.

Taylor has asked Harris to watch the video and think again. "I'm not the best referee in training but, as far as Gerry is concerned, he never touched him," he said. He has a point, although Taggart's reaction to Carr's stumble warranted a yellow card in itself.

The sending off after 62 minutes, and Savage's substitution six minutes later, let steam out of a disjointed match. George Graham said: "These are the type of games that are not pretty to watch but you don't want to lose them. I was hoping for a one-nil victory." Some people never change.

The defence was strengthened by Sol Campbell's return but Graham stuck with last week's 3-5-2 formation. "I just thought the extra player would give us a bit more confidence," he said. "I think it suits us."

It is a fair bet the system will be rigorously examined at Old Trafford on Saturday.

webTitle: Robson ready to take back seat

fields.headline: Robson ready to take back seat
fields.standfirst: Dominic Fifield  sees a spirited comeback but it may not be enough to save Boro's beleaguered boss
fields.trailText: With their beleaguered manager watching from the stands, their supporters streaming out of the stadium in disgust and El Tel apparently waiting in the wings, Bryan Robson's Middlesbrough at least stopped the rot on Saturday.
fields.body:
With their beleaguered manager watching from the stands, their supporters streaming out of the stadium in disgust and El Tel apparently waiting in the wings, Bryan Robson's Middlesbrough at least stopped the rot on Saturday.

The outpouring of emotion that greeted Paul Ince's late equaliser engulfed Teesside. The midfielder buried himself in a bundle of fans, stewards and team-mates. The Boro chairman Steve Gibson cast a relieved glance at his friend and manager, sitting two seats to his left, puffed his cheeks and punched the air.

But his celebrations were deceptive. Even if a draw against the worst side in the Premiership does spark a revival, Robson may have to put up with a supporting role to Terry Venables.

A change at the top has appeared inevitable for some time as Boro, sliding perilously down the table, slumped into the bottom three. The Riverside club may have been to three cup finals, enjoyed two promotions and warmed to numerous big-name signings since Robson took the reins in 1994, but the £78m spent on transfer fees, coupled with the inflated wages enjoyed by the Boro imports, has heightened expectations. Injuries have not helped, but Teesside is without a home win since March.

On Saturday, Robson already appeared to be on the periphery. For the first time in his six-year reign, the manager spurned his seat in the dug-out, watching po-faced and furrow-browed from the directors' box, mindful perhaps of the raucous reception he had received the previous week.

More significantly, it was Ince who threw the half-time tea-cups with Boro trailing 2-0. "I was angry and said a few choice words at the break," said the midfielder. "I'm not used to fighting against relegation with the teams I've played for, and it hurts me. But I got a response from the lads.

"At that stage the writing was on the wall for the manager and half the team. At 2-0 down I thought that was it: Bryan's going to walk. But it wasn't just the manager's job on the line; it was our jobs as well. The defending was appalling and if we keep conceding like that and a new man comes in, we could all be out on the dole."

The captain's reaction was understandable. Bradford, preying as much on the home side's nerve-racked start as their own new-found buoyancy under Jim Jefferies, kept their football simple and waited for Boro to make mistakes. After 110 seconds Gianluca Festa miskicked, panicked and passed the ball obligingly to Dan Petrescu. The Romanian's cross found Dean Windass, who leapt above Curtis Fleming and headed past a static Mark Schwarzer.

That was City's first league goal in 342 minutes, but seven minutes later they trebled their away tally for the season. Benito Carbone skilfully controlled Peter Atherton's punt forward and, as Ugo Ehiogu and Festa dithered on the edge of the area, fired high past Schwarzer's right hand.

Deafening boos rang round the Riverside and fans in the North Stand unfurled a banner reading: "Robson: you are the weakest link. Goodbye." With dissent all around, the home side cranked fitfully on to the comeback trail. A quartet of presentable chances fell to Alen Boksic - the Croat hit the side netting, the goalkeeper's legs, the advertising board behind the far post and the crossbar. Demoralised and hamstrung, he failed to materialise after the break.

But with Ince's words stinging their pride, Boro revived. Within three minutes of the restart Ehiogu headed over Petrescu on the line after Matt Clarke's uncharacteristic blunder. Festa struck the bar and, even after Carlos Marinelli was dismissed for a two-footed lunge on Windass, Boro continued to heave the ball forward and were rewarded when Ince thumped through Clarke's legs.

There was a sense of "so where does that leave us?" on the final whistle from both sets of supporters, although the travelling fans could at least seek solace in the fact that they had doubled their away points for the season. Bradford's counter-attacking during the first half should have won them the game; it was only when the nerves swung that they were reminded of their own desperate plight.

"The new manager has made a difference," said Windass. "He has told players that if they don't work hard they won't play. It's as simple as that. We got out of it last season because we had 11 players working their bollocks off every week and now we can't afford any passengers. If we don't have passengers I honestly think we can get out of trouble.

"But Boro probably deserved a draw today - you could see their spirit and quality. They didn't stop and crumble. They just need some luck." Unfortunately for Robson, his appears to be out.

webTitle: Ranieri finds trouble in translation

fields.headline: Ranieri finds trouble in translation
fields.trailText: Anyone who supposed that the saturation of the Premiership by overseas players had irrevocably diluted, if not eliminated, those great British footballing traditions of team spirit and work-rate, will have been much heartened by Everton's successive home victories over Arsenal and Chelsea.
fields.body:
Anyone who supposed that the saturation of the Premiership by overseas players had irrevocably diluted, if not eliminated, those great British footballing traditions of team spirit and work-rate, will have been much heartened by Everton's successive home victories over Arsenal and Chelsea.

With 10 English, Welsh and Scottish players out of 11 in Walter Smith's makeshift team on Saturday, Goodison's deep distrust of foreign mercenaries was vindicated and the even more potent dislike in the north of all things Chelsea was gleefully celebrated.

It has long been a contention that all football managers should have a translator at their side after a match (not to mention a psychiatrist) and Claudio Ranieri has duly complied. Yet it has also generally been assumed that no matter what tripe a manager may offer in the way of public explanations and excuses, once back in the masonic world of the training pitch many wrongs are put right in more trenchant language.

Clearly Ranieri has problems here, as Dennis Wise admitted before the match. Footballers are simple souls at the best of times, and if you choose words beyond their grasp they either tune out or take the piss. Confronted with a manager whom most of the Chelsea players do not understand at all, they may be tempted to do both. Dr Jozef Venglos, nice man that he was, had similar problems at Villa in the early 90s. For Doug Ellis read Ken Bates.

Quite how the Chelsea chairman ever expected such an appointment to work is a mystery. Except, Bates being Bates, it isn't. Signor Ranieri already has the permanent look of a man who has just smelled something unpleasant, and there are no prizes for guessing what it might be. Once more the Bates motel is a place of doubts, uncertainty and fears. Ranieri should be careful in the showers.

There was one glorious moment in the second half, a cameo of all that is currently wrong with Chelsea, when Dennis Wise, having watched Winston Bogarde strike a long pass straight to an Everton player, screamed at the top of his voice "clear the ball", with the appropriate expletive thrown in. Bogarde looked at Wise as if he were mad.

So bad are Everton's injury problems that Smith is more concerned about finding 11 fit players than the niceties of tactics. An excellent individual goal by Sam Dalla Bona, his first for the club, had sent Chelsea in at half-time in optimistic spirit, and their optimism might have been transformed into genuine belief had Paul Gerrard not deflected Eidur Gudjohnsen's left-foot shot against the inside of a post, and thence into his arms, at the beginning of the second half.

Almost immediately Danny Cadamarteri equalised thanks to the perceptiveness of Scot Gemmill. Thereafter Chelsea turned into passing strangers. webTitle: Iron signposts still look good

fields.headline: Iron signposts still look good
fields.trailText: No wonder Harry Redknapp looked delighted. His West Ham side have sped from last to 11th and find themselves with £18m in the bank. The manager wants to spend that on two or three players. Normally it would stretch to two or three squads.
fields.body:
No wonder Harry Redknapp looked delighted. His West Ham side have sped from last to 11th and find themselves with £18m in the bank. The manager wants to spend that on two or three players. Normally it would stretch to two or three squads.

Yet beneath the smile Redknapp must feel Rio Ferdinand's sale has left him under pressure of increased expectation and at a crossroads. If he spends wisely West Ham should be capable of qualifying for Europe and winning cups. Then the transfer will look great business.

But squander the money, see it held back by the board or find that Ferdinand's departure prompts Joe Cole, Frank Lampard, Michael Carrick and others to clamour for the exit, and the progress of recent years will be undone.

Lampard's agent Steve Kutner has said that his client feels "deeply upset" and "double-crossed", having been promised West Ham would not sell their top players when he signed a long-term contract. The midfielder's post-match comments were less forthright but he is clearly concerned by his close friend's move to Leeds.

"The last thing we want now is to start going downhill when all we've been doing in the last few years is going uphill," said the 22-year-old, who departed on a stretcher with a knee injury that should clear quickly. "I was surprised to see Rio go and slightly disappointed.

"We have been saying we're not a selling club and everyone's going to start jumping on now and saying our players are going to leave. The point of bringing good young players through the youth team for us is to put a strong team together and we need to make sure we keep doing that. Rio's departure doesn't help but we have to carry on."

If Lampard was hoping to see an immediate statement of ambition from his manager he will be disappointed. The Liverpool defender Rigobert Song should join today but Redknapp says he will wait until the transfer system has been resolved before spending large chunks from the "crazy offer" that was too good to turn down.

Not that West Ham's prospects look bleak in the meantime. They fully deserved their fifth win in six matches, and the turnaround since mid-September has been as dramatic as Redknapp promised.

Frédéric Kanouté was strong and quick up front, heading in a cross by the impressive Trevor Sinclair to equalise a fantastic early strike by Matt Oakley. In midfield Carrick rarely wasted possession. Stuart Pearce was typically determined at the back.

The 38-year-old drilled West Ham into the lead shortly after Kanouté's goal, and although James Beattie neatly pulled Southampton level, Sinclair ran on to a Paolo di Canio flick to prove that life can be a beach without Rio. They are now looking to the top six.

Defences were hardly convincing but Redknapp will search for Ferdinand's replacement in the belief that he has a natural successor, 16-year-old Glen Johnson, only 18 months from the first team. "He's going to be special," he said.

Redknapp played down the significance of his new wealth - "People have got to be careful with what they expect from West Ham; the club's been top half 14 times in 105 years" - but the fans and players will want the money spent and spent well. Otherwise there could be a queue to follow Ferdinand out of Upton Park.

webTitle: Ipswich ruddy and rising

fields.headline: Ipswich ruddy and rising
fields.trailText: Joe Royle almost got it right with the pre-season assertion that his Manchester City side would be good enough for a place in Europe in their first year back in the Premiership.
fields.body:
Joe Royle almost got it right with the pre-season assertion that his Manchester City side would be good enough for a place in Europe in their first year back in the Premiership.

Certainly, one of the three teams promoted last season is in the hunt for a Uefa Cup place; it is not, however, the runners-up City, nor the champions Charlton, but George Burley's Ipswich.

A bizarre refereeing performance at Portman Road in last season's play-off semi-final against Bolton may well have earned Ipswich a place in the Wembley final. Yet six months on they look not only look capable of competing in the Premiership but of succeeding - a distinction that, as Leicester have proved, can secure stability for clubs whose destiny might otherwise be to yo-yo between divisions.

"It's down to hard work and teamwork and everyone knowing what job they have to do," said Burley. "We've worked on this over the last three years and the confidence and spirit of the players has grown with it.

"Missing out on the play-offs as we did can make you stronger but the reality of the First Division was that by failing to gain promotion we had to sell players. This year we haven't had to do that."

Ipswich have been aided in the transition by being probably the bestfootballing side outside the Premiership in recent years. They proved the point with three well-taken goals here, two by the irrepressible Marcus Stewart, one from Hermann Hreidarsson, in the opening 53 minutes.

Yet while Ipswich are bucking one trend - the newly promoted team as relegation fodder - City are in danger of fulfilling another cliche: the team too good to be relegated.

City have lacked the continuity Ipswich have enjoyed and have had only questionable success in the transfer market. They bought poorly in George Weah and installed three new faces in a defence that has allowed nine goals in their past two away league games, in addition to three against Ipswich.

There have been pluses: Paulo Wanchope came off the bench to spark City's recovery, scoring in the 71st minute with a deflected shot before Steve Howey headed in a free-kick 10 minutes later. But Wanchope's strength is his unpredictability and such luxuries are not for a club in City's predicament.

The murmurs of discontent at Maine Road were only stifled by the endeavours of the 19-year-old Shaun Wright-Phillips, responsible for most of City's better moments. "He got the crowd off our backs and was instrumental in keeping the crowd awake," said Royle. Yet a teenager with three Premiership starts to his name cannot be expected to provide all the answers. If only his adoptive father, Ian Wright, was a couple of years younger.

webTitle: Hadji goal papers over the cracks

fields.headline: Hadji goal papers over the cracks
fields.trailText: After five successive defeats the scrappiest point would have been enough to please Coventry's support. And that is what they got, after a match that was more about vigour than vision, more muddy than memorable.
fields.body:
After five successive defeats the scrappiest point would have been enough to please Coventry's support. And that is what they got, after a match that was more about vigour than vision, more muddy than memorable.

Neither team, in truth, would have been entirely satisfied with the result but the game at least saw the end of a pair of miserable runs. Not only did Coventry fail to lose, just, but Dion Dublin took the opportunity of a game against his former club to put an end to a scoreless streak that had entered its third month.

It took Dublin only eight minutes to score his goal, created by Ian Taylor after Paul Williams had stumbled over a simple interception. "He was trying to make out that there was nothing wrong," said John Gregory, "but you know deep down that he's been very concerned. Without doubt he's very aware of his responsibilities but he's not allowed too much to get to him."

With Julian Joachim and Darius Vassell injured and Gilles de Bilde still warming the bench, Dublin is the only goalscorer Villa have at present. "I want someone to come in and put pressure on him," said Gregory. "I'd like competition for places but we don't really have that here at the moment. We need to spend some cash but I might have just one opportunity to spend money, so I've got to get it right."

Gordon Strachan decided to leave his £6.5m signing, Craig Bellamy, on the bench on Saturday after he had scored once in 12 games. "Young Craig will do a fine job eventually," said Strachan, "but it was a day when another player suited the team. He'll be back, no doubt about it, and he'll learn from that."

Sadly Bellamy's omission left a place in the side for the plodding Cédric Roussel, whose performance was mercifully curtailed by the half-time arrival of John Aloisi. Coventry may have given their all but they showed little ability, generally choosing to panic rather than pass, and should have been out of the game before their late comeback.

Villa were little better. Paul Merson alone stood out for his control and vision; he presented Lee Hendrie with a chance to finish the game early in the second half, only to see the midfielder blaze wastefully over. It appeared, though, that Villa would be able to withstand what pressure Coventry created until Mustapha Hadji met Aloisi's flick-on with a crisp, left-foot finish.

"It was great to score," said Hadji. "It was a great relief because it stops all the talk about our run." But Coventry have still won only once in 12 league games and hover perilously close to the bottom three. If they want to end talk of bad runs, they will have to do better than this.

webTitle: Dyer douses Liverpool's fire

fields.headline: Dyer douses Liverpool's fire
fields.trailText: Nerves jangling and not a calm head in sight, Newcastle survived a frenetic second-half onslaught yesterday to beat Liverpool for the first time since Kevin Keegan was king of Tyneside. Having gorged themselves on such rip-roaring entertainment, the Toon army left purring in rowdy satisfaction. The visitors, losers for the fifth time in eight away games this season, departed the north-east in disbelief.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at St James' Park
fields.body:
Nerves jangling and not a calm head in sight, Newcastle survived a frenetic second-half onslaught yesterday to beat Liverpool for the first time since Kevin Keegan was king of Tyneside. Having gorged themselves on such rip-roaring entertainment, the Toon army left purring in rowdy satisfaction. The visitors, losers for the fifth time in eight away games this season, departed the north-east in disbelief.

"I just cannot work football out," said the Newcastle manager Bobby Robson. "We've beaten the best side to come to St James' Park this season but we've lost to lesser teams. The moment I do work it out I'm going to retire."

Robson spent last week trying to persuade his board to follow Leeds's example and splash out on a centre-half. In comparison with the £18m spent on Rio Ferdinand, the £2.5m needed to prise the 5ft 10in Pablo Paz from Tenerife seems like small change; although all Robson received for his troubles was short shrift.

With his other options stuck on the treatment table, Robson assembled his ninth defensive partnership of the season by employing Warren Barton at centre-half. "We rode our luck and had to fight hard," said Robson, "but this was a gigantic result for us."

The home side's blistering start illustrated its importance. Newcastle tore into their visitors and, on the rare occasions they escaped Liverpool's offside trap, prospered. After only three minutes Jamie Carragher's attempted clearance ricocheted against Nolberto Solano, who advanced and slotted beneath Sander Westerveld.

The Dutchman was then grateful to clasp Rob Lee's volley and watched Gary Speed fire first wide and then over, as Liverpool's pretty passing merely added to the congestion in their own half.

"We don't have a defensive jinx or anything," their manager Gérard Houllier insisted. "We are trying to play more attacking football and it leaves us unbalanced occasionally. I will not sacrifice that style; we just need everyone to be better at closing down and challenging the second ball."

Liverpool's early inability to threaten in attack prompted puzzled looks from both dug-outs. Dietmar Hamann saw his volley blocked by Robbie Fowler, but it took half an hour for the visitors to find their rhythm.

With the home rearguard crying off-side, Steven Gerrard's clever angled cross found Fowler unmarked, but his downward header was clawed away by Shay Given. Barely a minute later, Sami Hyypia's flicked effort from Nick Barmby's corner was tipped on to a post, Fowler spearing the rebound wide of an open goal, his blushes spared by an assistant referee's flag.

Newcastle, becalmed and increasingly unconvincing, were spared on half-time as Barmby's shot under Given was cleared off the line by Andy Griffin. But the barrage continued. Gerrard's cut-back was hopelessly missed by Vladimir Smicer and Given dived smartly to block Marcus Babbel's venomous follow-up. Sprawled on the turf he deflected the shot away, only for the ball to pinball off Didier Domi and fly inches wide.

Newcastle were in a panic, exemplified by Barton's bizarre back-pass that bobbled in the mud and had Given clearing desperately from under the crossbar. Then, from such chaos, they broke swiftly when Alan Shearer nodded on for Kieron Dyer to chase. He sprinted from the halfway line, turned inside Hyypia and, to gasps of delight, planted the ball beyond Westerveld.

Emile Heskey's brave lob over the goalkeeper reduced the arrears, the England striker latching on to Hamann's pass. Then with tension gripping the stands, Fowler chased down Aaron Hughes's back-header and was denied at the last by Given.

"I'm a little bit frustrated," Houllier admitted. "We created more chances and produced more attacking football than them. But the ball wouldn't fall our way. In the end, silly errors cost us points."

webTitle: Derby's frightening glimpse of the chasm

fields.headline: Derby's frightening glimpse of the chasm
fields.trailText: The temptation while the champions are in this sort of mood is to believe the title race is about to be suffocated by anticlimax as never before. Look to the relegation zone for bursts of nerve-shredding tension, the quest for Europe for sudden twists and turns but do not expect anything but another Old Trafford celebration next May.
fields.body:
The temptation while the champions are in this sort of mood is to believe the title race is about to be suffocated by anticlimax as never before. Look to the relegation zone for bursts of nerve-shredding tension, the quest for Europe for sudden twists and turns but do not expect anything but another Old Trafford celebration next May.

It may come sooner. United won the title by 18 points last season and the way they are beginning to dispose of opponents with a shrug of indifference and the occasional snort of derision suggests it could be another country mile this time around.

As Derby can testify after an afternoon of United keep-ball in which the home side could not muster a single effort on goal, never mind an attack worthy of the description, the gulf between the best and the rest is expanding all the time. Soon it will be a chasm.

"They won the European Cup two years ago but they're an even better side now," said the Derby manager Jim Smith. "If you ask me, they're the best team in Europe, if not the world.

"On the scale of who you could get points from it's getting to the stage now where Manchester United are zero. Most of them have been playing together since the age of 12 and now they're coming to their peak it's awesome to watch.

"You think they are going along in third or fourth gear and then it's bang, bang, goal. You just can't get the ruddy ball. For the rest of us, it's frightening really. When you look out there, who's going to stop them?"

After eight successive wins it is hard to answer that. After seven it was hardly likely to be Derby. Manchester United may be in the same league but they look as if they are from a different stratosphere from some of their Premiership opponents.

This was exhibition stuff, the only surprise being that Sir Alex Ferguson's team were made to wait so long before turning their superiority into the hard currency of goals. The first half was perhaps one of the most comprehensive 0-0 thrashings the Premiership has witnessed as Derby were being tickled to death.

Teddy Sheringham got things rolling just after the hour with an adroit finish to a typical United move combining equal measures of fluency and creativity; and with that an air of inevitability descended on Pride Park.

"I felt at half-time it was going to be difficult to score here," said Ferguson, "but once the first goal was scored the doors opened and it was very comfortable for us."

webTitle: Curbishley waits to hear the call for national service

fields.headline: Curbishley waits to hear the call for national service
fields.trailText: The Charlton manager Alan Curbishley is still waiting for a call from the Football Association that might explain exactly what role they have in mind for him for the national side.
fields.body:
The Charlton manager Alan Curbishley is still waiting for a call from the Football Association that might explain exactly what role they have in mind for him for the national side.

Following England's defeat by Italy in Turin earlier this month the FA said that they wanted to involve Curbishley and Alex Ferguson's assistant at Manchester United, Steve McLaren, as well as the current caretaker manager Peter Taylor, even though they had given the top job to Sven-Goran Eriksson.

It looks like a classic case of too many cooks and, as Eriksson has yet to clarify his own plans, it seems likely that some will have nothing more than a peripheral part to play.

Curbishley, meanwhile, does not yet know whether Charlton will give their permission for him to join the set-up because he has been unable to give his full-time employers a job description of his role at Lancaster Gate.

After a dull Charlton performance that did little to enhance the international credentials of their manager, Curbishley said: "If it is feasible, I would love the chance to get involved. But I am waiting to see what they have in mind.

"Because Bobby Robson was not given permission by Newcastle to talk to the FA the job description may have changed. And when I was offered the chance to get involved with the Under-21s in the summer Charlton said no because we felt the job we had to do at the Valley should have priority.

"Nothing has changed there. Charlton will still come first. But I will have to see what the FA have in mind."

Curbishley is attracted by the notion of doing for Charlton what Peter Reid, his opposite number on Saturday, has done for Sunderland.

"Sunderland are the sort of club we should look to when we are reminding ourselves where we are going," he said. "They have moved to a new ground and doubled their gates. We can give our crowds a boost by building a new stand. Big crowds help you stay up."

Curbishley is unsurprised by the fact that, contrary to modern history, the three promoted clubs all have a good chance of surviving in the Premiership, despite Manchester City's poor run recently.

"I think that's because the three clubs that came up last season were the ones that actually finished one, two and three in the First Division. In the past, we have had clubs promoted who finished sixth, some 12 points behind the champions."

This match was such an ordinary affair that it left many wishing the game had been called off, as it nearly was because of concerns about the safety of the East Stand. Sunderland, though, were always the more impressive side and at least the goal that gave them their second successive away win was worth waiting for.

It came in the 58th minute when Alex Rae ended Charlton's unbeaten home record with a left-foot shot from almost 30 yards. It was Rae's first goal of the season and Sunderland's first win in London for three years.

Peter Reid said afterwards: "After the euphoria of the derby win we could have come here and not performed. But I always had a feeling we were going to win.

"If we are winning without Kevin Phillips scoring then I will take that."

webTitle: Third Division round-up

fields.headline: Third Division round-up
fields.trailText: The league leaders Chesterfield found their 13-match unbeaten record under threat at Halifax , who went two goals up through Steve Thompson and Steve Kerrigan. But Roger Willis maintained the Spireites' record of scoring in every league match this season and five minutes from time Rob Edwards made it 2-2 and 14 games without defeat.
fields.body:
The league leaders Chesterfield found their 13-match unbeaten record under threat at Halifax , who went two goals up through Steve Thompson and Steve Kerrigan. But Roger Willis maintained the Spireites' record of scoring in every league match this season and five minutes from time Rob Edwards made it 2-2 and 14 games without defeat.

Brighton made up ground at the top with a 4-0 thrashing of Shrewsbury , who had the on-loan Matthew Redmile sent off for violent conduct. Bobby Zamora scored twice for the Seagulls as they moved to within three points of Chesterfield.

Leyton Orient are in third place, goals from Ahmet Brkovic and Steve Watts giving them a 2-1 win over Macclesfield, while Rochdale , another team at the top, had their game at home to Plymouth postponed because of rain.

Cardiff's clash with Hartlepool came alive with three goals in the last two minutes. Pool led 2-1 after 89 minutes but Mark Bonner equalised for the Bluebirds in the last minute before Kurt Nogan made it 3-2 in injury time to protect their unbeaten home record.

Southend lost 1-0 at home to Cheltenham , who broke a five-game streak without a win. Scunthorpe won 6-0, their best result of the season, against Mansfield , who had Lee Williams sent off. Guy Ipoua, who struck a hat-trick last week in the FA Cup, went one better with four goals, taking his season's total to 12.

Barnet's mini streak of two wins and a draw in three games ended at Torquay , who won for the first time in five games. Tony Bedeau and Habib Sissoko scored for Torquay.

Carlisle are now five points adrift at the bottom of the table after a 2-1 defeat at Hull . David Brown and Ian Goodison scored for the Tigers.

Darlington suffered a fifth consecutive defeat, going down 2-1 at Blackpool , who led through Brett Ormerod and Paul Simpson before Jesper Hjorth pulled one back. York also slipped down the table with a 3-1 defeat at Kidderminster , who won for the first time in four home games.

Lincoln also won for the first time in four games as Peter Gain scored twice and Paul Smith once in their 3-1 victory at home to Exeter .

webTitle: Second Division round-up

fields.headline: Second Division round-up
fields.trailText: Millwall's rejuvenation under their new manager Mark McGhee continued as they became the new Second Division leaders following a 1-0 win at Oldham . The Australian midfielder Tim Cahill scored the goal in the 79th minute.
fields.body:
Millwall's rejuvenation under their new manager Mark McGhee continued as they became the new Second Division leaders following a 1-0 win at Oldham . The Australian midfielder Tim Cahill scored the goal in the 79th minute.

But McGhee knows his side will face intense competition in one of the tightest divisions of recent years. Walsall , who comfortably beat Northampton 3-0, are a point behind in second place while Rotherham are also close on the heels of the leaders, following a 3-0 win over Peterborough thanks to goals from Guy Branston, Paul Hurst and Mark Robins.

Luckless Cambridge are now 10 games without a win after throwing away a three- goal lead against Swansea . The home side had seemed set to win after goals from Paul Wanless, Tom Youngs and Paul Connor but Swansea hit back, with Giovanni Savarese scoring twice before Steve Watkin grabbed a late equaliser to move his side out of the bottom three.

Cambridge's bad luck pales in comparison with that of Oxford United . The financially impoverished club remain four points adrift at the bottom of the table after losing 3-2 to Notts County .

The Manor Ground faithful saw their side take a first-half lead thanks to two goals from Matt Murphy before Danny Allsopp scored twice, the second from the spot, and Adam Newton grabbed an away win for County three minutes from time to condemn United to their seventh home defeat of the season.

Luton also remain deep in trouble after losing 3-0 at Port Vale, who are now unbeaten in four matches. The recently appointed Luton manager Lil Fuccillo afterwards apologised to his team's fans and admitted he was worried by his team's second-half collapse.

"I feel disgusted," he said. "A great number of our fans travelled here and gave us tremendous support and we repaid them by producing a terrible second-half performance. We looked like novices at times and we defended poorly; we didn't pass the ball."

There was a change of fortune for Stoke , FA Cup victims of non-League Nuneaton, who restored a measure of pride with a 3-0 win at Swindon . Wrexham , also first-round losers, beat Bristol Rovers 1-0.

"I was disappointed with the performance," he said. "Normally when you play so badly you do not pick up three points."

webTitle: Wilson's charges match their Wigan peers

fields.headline: Wilson's charges match their Wigan peers
fields.trailText: These two sides have the best unbeaten records in the Second Division and they demonstrated why with unabated endeavour, an attacking style, and creative bent that belong to a more elevated station. As Wigan's manager Bruce Rioch said: "This was an outstanding performance by two teams very much in form."
fields.body:
These two sides have the best unbeaten records in the Second Division and they demonstrated why with unabated endeavour, an attacking style, and creative bent that belong to a more elevated station. As Wigan's manager Bruce Rioch said: "This was an outstanding performance by two teams very much in form."

Ashton Gate crowds are noisily partial by nature. Rioch noticed the way they rose in warm acclaim at the end. "I was particularly impressed that they also cheered my team."

Both clubs have emotional points to make. Wigan were walking away with promotion last season, yet in the end dissipated their clear advantage and finally, in extra-time, play-off agony, bade a needless goodbye to First Division aspirations. There was not much about this display to suggest they will repeat the mistake.

Bristol City, also with a new manager, started the season as if there was little prospect of better times. The results were bad, the gates dropped and the directors washed the dirty contents of the boardroom with unedifying public vigour.

They have now gone 14 games without defeat, pulling dramatically up from near the bottom. And Saturday's draw took Wigan off the top, though their all-round balance and the precision in their passing implied special qualities.

The two goals came in the first seven minutes. Louis Carey, chasing back, could only bundle Andy Liddell's teasing, angled cross into the back of his own net. City, with almost their next raid, were level. Mickey Bell, who has rediscovered his former verve, made the burst on the left, pulled the ball back and Lee Peacock slid in to score. It was almost another own-goal.

The pace was unrelenting, but never too much for young players like Simon Clist and Matthew Hill. For Wigan the newly arrived Dane Stefan Bidstrup was strong and dangerous, even if twice he might have netted. It was a joy that a game, devoid of niggle, was based unreservedly on fluent intent. Rioch can take his share of the credit for that.

Wigan finished stronger. Yet they were almost beaten by two special 30-yard shots in the second half. Aaron Brown's, with his left foot, spun off the foot of the post; Carey, doing quite enough to nullify his earlier contribution, saw his equally well-directed shot saved by Derek Stillie.

"If we can play like this, we're a problem to any team in the division," said City's Danny Wilson, who nearly became Wigan's manager in the summer. He was brought up near the town and used to play for them. The style of this draw must have eased any conflicting sense of allegiance for him.

webTitle: Rampant Rangers re-ignite race

fields.headline: Rampant Rangers re-ignite race
fields.trailText: In their apparent death throes Rangers have clung to life in this season's title race. This was a do-or-die moment for Dick Advocaat's men: had Celtic won they would have gone 18 points clear of their rivals. Instead the Premier League race has been re-ignited.
fields.body:
In their apparent death throes Rangers have clung to life in this season's title race. This was a do-or-die moment for Dick Advocaat's men: had Celtic won they would have gone 18 points clear of their rivals. Instead the Premier League race has been re-ignited.

The emphatic scoreline probably distorts the initial equality between the two sides with Celtic failing to recover following Alan Thompson's red card in the 64th minute. But, given their hideous pre-match pressure, Rangers were still deserving winners.

These Old Firm clashes are rarely for the faint of heart, and the referee, Kenny Clark, had a job and a half keeping order. There were seven bookings on top of Thompson's red card, and with a 50,000-strong crowd belching hot air down the players' necks, the game was often embroiled in dissent.

This spectacle, though, deserves to be remembered for some vivid performances. After months of injury and disharmony, too many Rangers players came good on the day for Celtic. Barry Ferguson, the young Rangers captain, scored a beautiful opening goal and was the imaginative architect of much of his side's mayhem.

Ferguson has often been guilty of being a great player on an insignificant stage but yesterday his leadership was imperial for 90 minutes. In Ronald de Boer and Lorenzo Amoruso, Rangers also had players whose excellence was timely. De Boer has failed to impress since his arrival from Barcelona but his presence here gave Rangers some lustre. Amoruso, so often the anti-hero of Ibrox, has always had a capacity for unlikely spurts of heroism and this was one such moment. The Italian was monumental in Rangers' defence, arriving with clattering stealth whenever danger lurked in front of Stefan Klos.

Celtic, by contrast, were a side of uncertain instinct. With a half-fit Chris Sutton repeatedly robbed by Amoruso, Martin O'Neill's team were also hindered by the inability of Bobby Petta and Didier Agathe to get anywhere on the flanks. Johan Mjallby also limped away at half-time. It all made Henrik Larsson's headed equaliser after 56 minutes a solitary flash on a black day for his side.

"We didn't play well and they did," O'Neill said afterwards. "It's hard enough trying to play Rangers with 11 men on the park, never mind 10. I thought we were still in the game when Thompson went off but then he was sorely missed. This isn't the end of the world, though... or is it?"

Thus went Celtic's chance -maybe thankfully for O'Neill given his reverence for "the Big Man" - of beating Jock Stein's famous record of an opening unbeaten run of 16 league matches.

Ferguson's opener after 34 minutes for Rangers was exquisite; in design and execution it will be hard to see it bettered all season. With Celtic in disarray following a prompt and dubiously positioned free-kick that Rangers quickly worked, Ferguson serenely lobbed the goalkeeper Robert Douglas and placed the ball inside a post.

Larsson's header gave Celtic hope but they swiftly became unravelled and out-numbered after Thompson was asked to walk. Two goals followed within the space of eight minutes. Tore Andre Flo prodded the ball home from a yard following De Boer's corner and De Boer then headed a Jörg Albertz corner past Douglas. Amoruso added another header before Michael Mols scored late on to complete the rout.

fields.bodyText: In their apparent death throes Rangers have clung to life in this season's title race. This was a do-or-die moment for Dick Advocaat's men: had Celtic won they would have gone 18 points clear of their rivals. Instead the Premier League race has been re-ignited. The emphatic scoreline probably distorts the initial equality between the two sides with Celtic failing to recover following Alan Thompson's red card in the 64th minute. But, given their hideous pre-match pressure, Rangers were still deserving winners. These Old Firm clashes are rarely for the faint of heart, and the referee, Kenny Clark, had a job and a half keeping order. There were seven bookings on top of Thompson's red card, and with a 50,000-strong crowd belching hot air down the players' necks, the game was often embroiled in dissent. This spectacle, though, deserves to be remembered for some vivid performances. After months of injury and disharmony, too many Rangers players came good on the day for Celtic. Barry Ferguson, the young Rangers captain, scored a beautiful opening goal and was the imaginative architect of much of his side's mayhem. Ferguson has often been guilty of being a great player on an insignificant stage but yesterday his leadership was imperial for 90 minutes. In Ronald de Boer and Lorenzo Amoruso, Rangers also had players whose excellence was timely. De Boer has failed to impress since his arrival from Barcelona but his presence here gave Rangers some lustre. Amoruso, so often the anti-hero of Ibrox, has always had a capacity for unlikely spurts of heroism and this was one such moment. The Italian was monumental in Rangers' defence, arriving with clattering stealth whenever danger lurked in front of Stefan Klos. Celtic, by contrast, were a side of uncertain instinct. With a half-fit Chris Sutton repeatedly robbed by Amoruso, Martin O'Neill's team were also hindered by the inability of Bobby Petta and Didier Agathe to get anywhere on the flanks. Johan Mjallby also limped away at half-time. It all made Henrik Larsson's headed equaliser after 56 minutes a solitary flash on a black day for his side. "We didn't play well and they did," O'Neill said afterwards. "It's hard enough trying to play Rangers with 11 men on the park, never mind 10. I thought we were still in the game when Thompson went off but then he was sorely missed. This isn't the end of the world, though... or is it?" Thus went Celtic's chance -maybe thankfully for O'Neill given his reverence for "the Big Man" - of beating Jock Stein's famous record of an opening unbeaten run of 16 league matches. Ferguson's opener after 34 minutes for Rangers was exquisite; in design and execution it will be hard to see it bettered all season. With Celtic in disarray following a prompt and dubiously positioned free-kick that Rangers quickly worked, Ferguson serenely lobbed the goalkeeper Robert Douglas and placed the ball inside a post. Larsson's header gave Celtic hope but they swiftly became unravelled and out-numbered after Thompson was asked to walk. Two goals followed within the space of eight minutes. "I have said all along that with all my players fit I think we are a good side and today we proved that," he said. "Our play was excellent right from the very start." webTitle: Fulham are the men for all seasons

fields.headline: Fulham are the men for all seasons
fields.trailText: Wind, rain and shine, Fulham's pillaging of the First Division continues apace. Temperament, tackling and the terrors of winter have all been suggested as reasons why Jean Tigana's side will falter. The cracks, however, are yet to appear.
fields.body:
Wind, rain and shine, Fulham's pillaging of the First Division continues apace. Temperament, tackling and the terrors of winter have all been suggested as reasons why Jean Tigana's side will falter. The cracks, however, are yet to appear.

Fulham extended their lead in the league to nine points on Saturday with a performance in which they showed the patience not to panic or change their style when all was not going their way, the strength to dominate the midfield and no frailty in the face of a biting wind and driving rain.

The remainder of the season seems a formality, especially when Tigana is able to afford the luxury of resting first- teamers. Both Louis Saha, the division's top scorer, and Andy Melville started on the bench on Saturday, while Fulham's striking riches will be bolstered by the arrival of the Latvian international forward Andrejs Stolcers, who awaits a work permit. However an £8.25m bid for Anderlecht's Jan Köller has been turned down.

Stolcers will relish the chance to face Arsenal next season having just completed a loan spell at Spartak Moscow from Shakhtar Donetsk, both of whom have humiliated the Gunners in recent weeks.

The likelihood of such fixtures come August, however, is not being conceded yet by Fulham. "If you get complacent you end up with nothing in May apart from egg on your face," said the midfielder Lee Clark. "I have been at the other side of it at Newcastle when we were 12 points clear at the top of the Premiership and still lost out to Manchester United. That's why we do not come out and say stupid things about getting promoted."

Yet for all that, Fulham look a class apart and it is difficult to envisage Tigana having to face the camera in April saying "I would love it, just love it, if we beat Watford."

Grimsby would love to beat anyone at the moment. This was their fourth straight league defeat. But they were not disgraced here, their commitment matched that of the home side and they deserved to be level at half-time.

The Grimsby manager Lennie Lawrence blamed Fulham's opening goal on the half-time substitute, the aptly named Matthew Bloomer, who was tying up his laces as Luis Boa Morte ran on to Clark's ball and chipped Danny Coyne. The Grimsby goalkeeper was equally powerless when Saha, who had come on after 56 minutes, wriggled through to double Fulham's lead.

Kevin Donovan, whose goal in a play-off semi-final had denied Fulham the chance of promotion from the Second Division in 1998, gave his side the goal they deserved, scoring with three minutes remaining.

But he was unable to deny Fulham this time and it is doubtful whether anyone will. Derby County visit Craven Cottage on Wednesday in the Worthington Cup and the shock will be if they win.

webTitle: Careless Rovers add to Souness' stress levels

fields.headline: Careless Rovers add to Souness' stress levels
fields.trailText: Graeme Souness accepted this unexpected reversal in the manner you would expect from a man who has recently undergone further heart surgery.
fields.body:
Graeme Souness accepted this unexpected reversal in the manner you would expect from a man who has recently undergone further heart surgery.

Souness, as gritty as they come during his playing days with Liverpool and Scotland, realised eight years ago, when he had his first major heart operation, that perhaps there is more to life than simply winning football matches. And you suspect there was no teacup-throwing in the Ewood Park dressing room after a defeat that ended a run of seven wins and a draw in eight league games.

The Blackburn manager went to Ohio five weeks ago to have an artery blockage cleared. "It has not affected me," he joked. "I still play badly in five-a-sides." More seriously he added: "There's a risk every time you have an operation but I feel fine."

Some Blackburn fans may prefer to follow Bill Shankly's maxim on life, death and football but Souness's studied, balanced approach looks likely to benefit Blackburn as they bid to repay a final instalment on Jack Walker's legacy and return to the Premiership.

Souness, however, had every reason to feel agitated as his full-back John Curtis negligently turned the ball into his own goal for Gillingham's winner before David Dunn, arguably the best player on the pitch, was sent off for a second bookable offence.

But in the home camp the defeat was regarded more as a timely boot up the backside than a serious blip. Souness knows he has a decent team with potentially the best midfield in the division, and it was not as though Blackburn played badly.

Only the brilliance of Vince Bartram in the Gillingham goal prevented Rovers cruising into a three or even four-goal lead after Mark Hughes, the wily warhorse, had put them ahead after 12 minutes.

But slack marking led to Gills player-manager Andy Hessenthaler grabbing a 43rd-minute equaliser before Curtis suffered his rush of blood to present the visitors with an unexpected away win, only their second this season.

The defender was contrite. "I've got to take the blame," he confessed. "It was my mistake and I've apologised to the fans and players. I heard Brad Friedel shout but I thought he wanted me to pass him the ball."

Both sides finished with 10 men after Paul Shaw followed Dunn down the tunnel. In both cases the punishment meted out by the referee Mark Warren looked excessive.

Souness fears the game will go soft if referees do not offer players more latitude. "Joe Public won't like it if you take physical contact out of the game," he said. "I know it's a fine balancing act but you can't make football a non-contact sport.

"David is extremely upset because he feels he let everybody down. But we didn't lose because he was sent off. Three or four players took their eye off the ball in footballing terms and we were punished for it."

webTitle: Week -1: Dorchester to Heathrow

fields.headline: Travelling light, fast-track visas, and a six-month summer
fields.standfirst: In the first of her weekly diaries, Milly deals with the practicalities that stand between her and paradise. And it finally sinks in that she isn't dreaming . . .
fields.trailText: In the first of her weekly diaries, Milly deals with the practicalities that stand between her and paradise. And it finally sinks in that she isn't dreaming . . .
fields.body:
Well, this will be the last time I write from England. Who knows what I'll be doing, saying and seeing next week? How exciting does that sound? - not knowing what I'll be doing tomorrow, never mind next week!!! Well, back to my preparations for now.

I've done a lot in the past few weeks which, while not being particularly exciting, might come in useful for any other potential travellers. The first thing was buy a diary, so I can scribble down useful info, or what I've been up to. I've also got a place to write down addresses and numbers, and it's covered with photos of friends and family, for when I feel homesick! It's already become my travelling bible to me, and it's something that I hope to keep forever (if I don't lose it!).

I thought that the most difficult thing to get would be an Australian visa. Basically, the postal application process takes four-five weeks, but I had less than three. So, the easiest thing to do was go directly to Australia House in London. I got the form I needed from the internet (www.australia.org.uk) so I was prepared with all I needed when I got there. There are loads of different types of visa: my one allows me to work, and is valid for a year. Australia house opens at 9am. We arrived at 9.30 and it was already packed, so go early! Still, it was only an hour and half wait and I got an instant visa which was brilliant.

The same day I bought my bag. It's basically my walking house and wardrobe for the next six months, so I decided it was worth splashing out on a really comfy well strapped bag (actually, that was a gift from mum, so thanks again!). I'll tell you how much I love or hate it later!

One tip that everybody has given me in every shop, is to travel light. Someone told me to lay out everything you're going to take, then halve it. I don't know about that - the idea of only taking enough underwear for a week is bad enough, along with the realisation that I'm going to have to do my own washing! On the other hand, I do plan to shop while I'm away. If I travel light to start with, I've got space to create an international wardrobe!

Everything's been happening pretty quickly in the last week - in fact, this whole month has zoomed by. I've had my last day at work, and I've said a lot of goodbyes already to friends and family. It's beginning to sink in that I'm really going - every time I say 'see you in summer' it reminds me that this isn't just a big dream. It also reminds me that I should have a nine-month summer this year. (From Hawaii on, and then back to England for summer). I bet you wish you were going too now?!

I've now got my tickets and camera and equipment, so basically everything's actually come together, which I was never quite sure it would. It was really exciting seeing the web site up and running, although a little scary to think my picture/writing is literally accessible to everyone. I got my first few bits of advice through recently, and I was really relieved by how friendly the feedback has been. The first guy that wrote to me was from Sydney and passed on a fantastic amount of travelling knowledge - thanks Steve. I like to think that I'll be doing the same; passing on first-hand info to anyone with an interest that might help them to make the most of their travels. Or at least I'll be keeping my family entertained.

Til next time in the cold (?) of Vancouver,
Milly

webTitle: From: Rebecca Leyland (27 Nov)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: Rebecca Leyland
fields.trailText: As I'm writing from New York I can tell you it's quite cold out here - bring lots of jumpers! I suggest heading straight for the Village. This is the really cool part of New York. It's nice just to wander around the brown stone buildings and visit coffee bars and jazz clubs.
fields.body:
As I'm writing from New York I can tell you it's quite cold out here - bring lots of jumpers! I suggest heading straight for the Village. This is the really cool part of New York. It's nice just to wander around the brown stone buildings and visit coffee bars and jazz clubs. Some of the buildings are amazing. Visit the Woolworth's building. There are stone statues worked into the ceiling that tell the story of Woolworth counting out his money to have the building made. I also recommend the art deco Chrysler building. It's used as an office block so the public can go in - try one of the lifts, even if it is just to go up and down - they're beautiful.

While you're on 42nd St, pop into Grand Central Station. There's a great shop selling cheesecake called 'Juniors' - I suggest stopping for a coffee and slice. There is also a really good Oyster Bar downstairs in the basement, with reasonable prices and great food.

For cheap food, I suggest going to Chinatown - similar to London, but bigger. The food is amazing. If you get the subway to Canal Street you'll find really good knock off CDs, watches, wallets and handbags. Always try and barter - you can probably get them down a dollar or two.

I should warn you about ordering food out here; it's a nightmare. I've only managed to order a salad once, and I've been working out here for five months! I tend to memorise my order to make it easier and decide before walking into the deli. The delis do a 'make your own' salad which is really daunting; there are 101 ingredients to choose from, and they shout "Next, next!" as you are desperately trying to decide what you want. Another thing to remember is to make sure you have more money than you think you need. In a bar you tip $1 per drink. They also make things even more difficult by taking the money for drinks in bars after you have drunk them, so make sure you don't get caught out. Good luck!

webTitle: Train collision in Glasgow

fields.headline: Train collision in Glasgow
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: A commuter train collided with stationary carriages at a busy mainline station today.
fields.body:
A commuter train collided with stationary carriages at a busy mainline station today.

The low-speed collision happened at Glasgow Central station shortly after 4pm when the 3.20pm service from East Kilbride hit the stationary train.

Nobody was seriously injured in the accident, which happened as the slowly moving train stopped at a platform.

A spokesman for train operator ScotRail said all the passengers had walked off the train while the driver had suffered a "very minor" injury.

"It was a low-speed collision which is being investigated," said the spokesman.

The accident had forced the cancellation of some services to East Kilbride, in Lanarkshire, but all other services were unaffected, he added.

The collision came less than 24 hours after a Euston to Glasgow Central express service carrying 400 passengers was derailed near Motherwell, seven miles from the completion of its journey.

webTitle: Analysis: Globalisation: it's all or nothing

fields.headline: Globalisation: it's all or nothing
fields.standfirst:
The green lobby wants to curb the World Bank and the IMF yet expects the Hague climate summit to come up with solutions. You can't have it both ways, says economics editor Larry Elliott

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText:
The green lobby wants to curb the World Bank and the IMF yet expects the Hague climate summit to come up with solutions. You can't have it both ways, says economics editor Larry Elliott.
Special report: global warming
fields.body:
There was deep gloom among green activists at the weekend when John Prescott's walkout from the Hague talks on climate change marked the collapse of attempts to piece together a binding deal to cut greenhouse gases.

It was all a far cry from the celebrations a year earlier when negotiations designed to lay the foundations for a new round of global trade talks collapsed in Seattle. On that occasion the environmentalists were delighted that the 140 countries represented had failed to settle their differences.

The connection between Seattle and the Hague is the failure of the multilateral system to deliver. A framework established in the aftermath of the second world war no longer seems capable of finding solutions to the problems that an increasingly integrated and connected world throws up. Far from moving forward to a more cooperative world, we seem to be reverting to one in which powerful countries and strong regional blocs look after their own interests at the expense of the weak and poor.

Why is this? In part it is something to do with the growing power of corporate capital. When the postwar international system was created, business had been tainted by the Depression and fascism. Statesmen, fresh from running planned wartime economies, were in the ascendancy and were able to set the terms of the debate - policies that ensured full employment and redistribution but put controls on capital.

The past quarter century has seen big business recover much of the ground it had lost. This is particularly true in the United States, where the powerful corporations have been pressing hard for trade liberalisation but have lobbied against tougher environmental controls.

In part, also, it has something to do with the failure of the international system to adapt to a changing world. Many of the problems that now exist - the environment and debt, for example - were not on the agenda 50 years ago.

So what is to be done? One answer is to turn our backs on the multilateral institutions altogether as a way of rolling back globalisation. Given the way some of the institutions have been run this is a natural reaction, but it is a blind alley. If we want a deal on greenhouse gases, if we want debt relief for the poor and if we want trade rules that do not just benefit the rich countries then we need multilateral institutions.

The real task is to set up new institutions - a world environment agency would be a good start - and to invest older bodies such as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund with some different thinking. A pick'n'mix approach to multilateralism is not the answer.

The connection between Seattle and the Hague is the failure of the multilateral system to deliver. A framework established in the aftermath of the second world war no longer seems capable of finding solutions to the problems that an increasingly integrated and connected world throws up. Far from moving forward to a more cooperative world, we seem to be reverting to one in which powerful countries and strong regional blocs look after their own interests at the expense of the weak and poor. Why is this? In part it is something to do with the growing power of corporate capital. When the postwar international system was created, business had been tainted by the Depression and fascism. Statesmen, fresh from running planned wartime economies, were in the ascendancy and were able to set the terms of the debate - policies that ensured full employment and redistribution but put controls on capital. The past quarter century has seen big business recover much of the ground it had lost. This is particularly true in the United States, where the powerful corporations have been pressing hard for trade liberalisation but have lobbied against tougher environmental controls. In part, also, it has something to do with the failure of the international system to adapt to a changing world. Many of the problems that now exist - the environment and debt, for example - were not on the agenda 50 years ago. So what is to be done? One answer is to turn our backs on the multilateral institutions altogether as a way of rolling back globalisation. Given the way some of the institutions have been run this is a natural reaction, but it is a blind alley. If we want a deal on greenhouse gases, if we want debt relief for the poor and if we want trade rules that do not just benefit the rich countries then we need multilateral institutions. The real task is to set up new institutions - a world environment agency would be a good start - and to invest older bodies such as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund with some different thinking. A pick'n'mix approach to multilateralism is not the answer. webTitle: Poll reveals fears over advance of gene science

fields.headline: Poll reveals fears over advance of gene science
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Seven out of 10 people in Britain have no confidence that government can keep up with science. The same number say that they do not have enough information about controls on biological developments, according to new research by the Human Genetics Commission.
fields.body:
Seven out of 10 people in Britain have no confidence that government can keep up with science. The same number say that they do not have enough information about controls on biological developments, according to new research by the Human Genetics Commission.

The study is published as the commission launches a huge public consultation on the future use of genetic information. It reveals that most people believe that human genetic information could and should be used for research into disease or to identify criminals or to test for paternity. But they also believe it should not be used to set insurance premiums or help parents choose "designer babies".

The commission, established a year ago to advise health and science ministers, based its preliminary findings on Mori interviews with 788 people. But the full impact of research into human genetic information is only now beginning to become clear. In June scientists announced the completion of the "first draft" of the entire 3bn letters of the DNA of one representative human being. A consortium of universities and drugs companies is now identifying the tiny changes in DNA that make one individual different from another - and one individual more susceptible to one kind of illness than another.

Genetic makeup influences everything from personality to life expectancy, but there have been fears, ever since the project began, that this was dangerous knowledge which could somehow be used to determine an individual's future.

"People understand that advances in human genetics will have a big impact on our lives, and much good could come from that," said Helena Kennedy QC, chair of the commission. "But most of us are nervous and confused about where technology might be leading, and the potential challenge to privacy and confidentiality."

Members of the commission will launch their consultation document today at the International Centre for Life in Newcastle upon Tyne. It puts questions about how society should manage such knowledge, and about how to push forward new treatments for disease while preventing unfair discrimination or exploitation.

The debate is urgent: academics and biotech companies are racing ahead to find new diagnostic tests and gene-based cures.

Most people, according to the Mori research, were prepared to trust doctors, the NHS and the police with genetic information, but not consumer groups, insurance companies, employers or industrial scientists.

Most agreed that DNA samples should be taken to solve sex crimes, murders and burglaries, but fewer than half wanted to see samples taken for drink-driving offences, shoplifting or fraud.

"You couldn't, obviously, put science back in the bottle. But you can do your best to ensure it takes the right direction, and is aware of, and takes into account, human values," said Alexander McCall Smith, deputy chairman of the commission and professor of medical law at Edinburgh. "There is one view that big science is really beyond the control of anybody. But I do think we can have some impact on it."

The commission wants people to talk about whether genetic information is different and special, compared with other kinds of data, whether it needs special protection, and whether there should be controls on access to it by insurance companies.

The consultation exercise is welcomed today by the charity Breakthrough Breast Cancer. One breast cancer case in 20 could be caused by mutations in two already identified genes, and there are already diagnostic tests. But knowledge of a predisposing gene also raises social and ethical problems.
