webTitle: Air traffic controllers urge Lords to resist sell-off

fields.headline: Air traffic controllers urge Lords to resist sell-off
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Air traffic controllers today asked peers to stand firm against mounting government pressure to drive through its plan to partially privatise national air traffic services.
fields.body:
Air traffic controllers today asked peers to stand firm against mounting government pressure to drive through its plan to partially privatise national air traffic services.

Paul Noon, general secretary of the Institute of Professionals, Managers and Specialists Union, which represents 3,300 air traffic controllers, urged a rethink and warned that safety and efficiency could be jeopardised.

Mr Noon wants peers to delay the partial privatisation of air traffic control when a vote on the transport bill is held in the House of Lords today.

"Air traffic control is almost the only part of the UK transport structure in working order and is both efficient and safe," he said. "It is downright irresponsible to embark on an experiment in which the public, professionals and so many members of all parties have no confidence."

The plans have sparked backbench rebellions in the House of Commons by Labour MPs concerned that the sell-off might undermine safety.

Last month, the Lords put a potentially fatal obstacle in the way of the sale by voting to delay it until after the next general election. But the government insisted that it would seek to overturn that vote in the Commons and press ahead with a sale in spring 2001, amid warnings that further rebellions would endanger the whole transport bill, which includes vital legislation on congestion charging and the strategic rail authority.

The rebel Labour peer Lord Brett said he could not see why the government was risking its transport bill for the sake of the flawed proposals.

"I think sometimes policies get a life of their own," he said. "There is a need to do something, so standing still in that sense is not an option."

He accused ministers of showing "benign neglect" to a report he had compiled on the Canadian not-for-profit trust, which runs air traffic control in that country. "Public sector, private sector is not the issue. The issue is that safety is paramount," he said.

But transport minister Lord Macdonald said a letter from airline owners, published in today's Times, should allay safety fears.

"If parliamentarians will not accept the assurances of government on this point, we ask them to accept the word of those [in] whose interests the air traffic control system is run," he said.

webTitle: Full text of George W Bush's 'victory' speech

fields.headline: George W Bush: 'we are honoured and humbled to have won the state of Florida'
fields.standfirst: Special report: US elections
fields.trailText: The last nineteen days have been extraordinary ones.  Our nation watched as we were all reminded on a daily basis of the importance                          of each and every vote.  We were reminded of the strength of our democracy - that while our system is not always perfect, it is                          fundamentally strong and far better than any other alternative.
fields.body:
The last nineteen days have been extraordinary ones. Our nation watched as we were all reminded on a daily basis of the importance of each and every vote. We were reminded of the strength of our democracy - that while our system is not always perfect, it is fundamentally strong and far better than any other alternative.

The election was close, but tonight, after a count, a recount and yet another manual recount, Secretary Cheney and I are honoured and humbled to have won the state of Florida, which gives us the needed electoral votes to win the election. We will therefore undertake the responsibility of preparing to serve as America's next President and Vice President.

During the past year and a half of the presidential campaign, I have had the privilege of travelling America and meeting so many of my fellow Americans: the teachers who mold our future, the volunteers who take time to help neighbours in need, the police and firemen who risk their lives to protect ours, the workers who keep our economy strong and growing. These experiences have confirmed that ours is a strong and vibrant nation, full of people whose hearts are bigger than even our most bountiful harvest. As our country ends its Thanksgiving weekend, we have so much to be thankful for - beginning with the fundamental freedoms that are the birthright of every American: life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness. And with our freedom comes responsibility, for all of us. Once our elections are behind us, once our disagreements are expressed, we have a responsibility to honor our Constitution and laws, and come together to do the people's business. Two hundred years ago, after a difficult election, President Thomas Jefferson reminded his fellow citizens that "every difference of opinion is not a difference of principle." Vice President Gore and I had our differences of opinion in this election, and so did many candidates for Congress. But there is broad agreement on some important principles: Republicans and Democrats agree we need to provide an excellent education for every child at every public school. Democrats and Republicans agree that our seniors deserve a secure retirement, and prescription drug coverage in Medicare. Already, there is some bipartisan groundwork on efforts to reform Social Security and Medicare. We have a duty to find common ground to reform these vital programmes for the greatest generation and for future generations. Republicans and Democrats want a strong military to keep the peace, and a foreign policy that reassures our friends and restrains our enemies. There is growing consensus in Congress and America on the need to reduce taxes by reducing the marriage penalty and eliminating the death tax. And I will work with members of Congress from both parties to reduce tax rates for everyone who pays income taxes in America. Progress on all these issues will require a new tone in Washington. The path to progress is consideration and fair dealing. I have worked with Democrats and Republicans in Texas, and I will do so in Washington. I will listen and I will respect different points of view. And most of all I work to unite and serve all Americans. This has been a hard fought election, a healthy contest for American democracy. But now that the votes are counted, it is time for the votes to count.

The Vice President's lawyers have indicated he will challenge the certified election results. I respectfully ask him to reconsider. Until Florida's votes were certified, the Vice President was working to represent the interests of those who supported him. I didn't agree with his call for additional recounts, but I respected his decision to fight until the votes were finally certified. Now that they are certified, we enter a different phase. If the Vice President chooses to go forward, he is filing a contest to the outcome of the election, and that is not the best route for America. All of us, in this election, fought for our views. Now we must live up to our principles. We must show our commitment to the common good, which is bigger than any person or any party. We cannot change yesterday, but we share a responsibility for tomorrow. Time runs short and we have a lot of work to do. Tonight, I am naming Secretary Dick Cheney to chair our transition effort, and Andy Card to serve as my chief of staff. I have asked Secretary Cheney to work with President Clinton's administration to open a transition office in Washington, and we look forward to a constructive working relationship throughout this transition. The end of an election is the beginning of a new day. Together, we can make this a positive day of hope and opportunity for all who are blessed to be Americans. Thank you very much and God Bless America.

webTitle: Climate talks failure 'real disappointment': Prescott

fields.headline: Climate talks failure 'real disappointment': Prescott
fields.standfirst:
European ministers trade insults after climate conference failure

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText:
European ministers trade insults after climate conference failure.

Special report: global warming
fields.body:
The outcome of the Hague summit on climate change was today dubbed "a real disappointment for all concerned," by deputy prime minister John Prescott.

In a commons statement on the failed conference talks, Mr Prescott said: "We all did our best and we came very close to agreement."

Despite the breakdown "all parties remained committed to reaching an agreement when they meet again in May next year," he told MPs.

After exchanging sharp words with French environment minister Dominique Voynet over blame for the failure of the talks, Mr Prescott was in a more emollient mood in the Commons. "I have worked and negotiated with Dominique Voynet for three years now. Her commitment to securing an agreement is as passionate as mine. We will both work together to ensure that agreement is reached," he insisted.

But shadow environment secretary Archie Norman mocked Mr Prescott's handling of the negotiations, accusing him of "misreading" the situation and "petulantly" storming out of the talks on Saturday.

Mr Norman said, that after the recent rail chaos, the episode marked the "the final collapse of credibility" in the deputy prime minister and warned the world would pay "a heavy price" for the breakdown.

French and British ministers had traded bitter, personal insults over the weekend.

Ms Voynet, who led the 15-nation European Union delegation at the conference, replied sharply today to Mr Prescott's remarks.

He had portrayed Ms Voynet as a woman at her wits' end, weak and exhausted. Ms Voynet retorted that he was a confirmed macho.

The Hague talks ended in failure on Saturday, sparking the Franco-British tit-for-tat verbal spat. Mr Prescott told BBC Radio 4's World this Weekend yesterday that Ms Voynet was too tired to push through a deal. webTitle: Alternative health therapies under fire

fields.headline: Alternative health therapies under fire
fields.standfirst: Industry faces tighter regulation after Lords inquiry
fields.trailText: Industry faces tighter regulation after Lords inquiry.
fields.body:
The booming complementary health medicines market is to be brought under full regulation by the government following a damning report to be published next week by a parliamentary committee.

The 18-month inquiry by the Lords science select committee has left peers shocked at the haphazard standards and lack of even self-regulation. They have also found that the information produced on alternative medicines is of hugely variable quality and sometimes dangerously misleading.

Nearly 20% of the population use alternative or complementary medicines, such as acupuncture, reflexology, homeopathic dentistry, or herbal remedies, spending more than £500m annually in the process.

The government is likely to set a timetable for statutory regulation, starting with acupuncture and herbal medicine. The regulation is likely to be brought in on an ad hoc basis using the Health Act passed last year.

Only two therapies are at present statutorily regulated - osteopathy and chiropractic - but even they have encountered difficulty bringing all their training bodies into one regulatory authority.

Ministers are reluctant to provide alternative remedies on the NHS until there is clearer evidence of their efficacy and proper regulation. There is virtually no serious evidence-based research into their effectiveness, largely because the big pharmaceutical companies are unwilling to fund the research. The companies cannot patent the research findings and therefore make a profit.

Advocates of alternative medicines have argued that their individualised and holistic approach makes it difficult to carry out traditional scientific research, but the committee is expected to reject this claim. It will call on the government to make research a priority and suggest the industry has a responsibility to fund research.

The committee was told that some therapies had as many as 12 different associations making it possible for a therapist, struck off for incompetence from one voluntary register, to carry on practising by joining another. The only sanction is criminal law.

Yvette Cooper, the minister for public health, who has used complementary medicines to combat ME, told the committee that she was disturbed by the lack of proper regulation in the field.

Liam Donaldson, the chief medical officer, told the committee: "It is important, as the complementary professions form themselves into recognisable professional bodies, that they are also brought into a statutory framework."

He said the move would ensure only professional and trained practitioners could practise. They could also be formally trained on the limits of alternative medicines, and the need to cooperate with orthodox medicine.

The committee will warn that some invasive techniques, such as the use of acupuncture needles, need to be closely overseen.

It will also warn that such treatments can be dangerous if they are seen as an alternative to conventional medicine, so leading patients to be deprived of the necessary orthodox medicines.

The committee is expected to grade all the various therapies into three categories according to the usefulness and level of regulation. It will propose the regulatory bodies should eventually be funded and include lay members in the same way as the General Medical Council.

webTitle: Bloody Sunday lawyer criticises McGuinness

fields.headline: Bloody Sunday lawyer criticises McGuinness
fields.standfirst: Special report: Bloody Sunday
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness came under attack at the Bloody Sunday inquiry today for not having the "courage, integrity or respect" to co-operate with the new investigation into the killings.
fields.body:
Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness came under attack at the Bloody Sunday inquiry today for not having the "courage, integrity or respect" to co-operate with the new investigation into the killings.

A lawyer representing most of the soldiers who were on duty in Londonderry that day said it was "galling" to see the leading republican, now Mid Ulster MP and the Northern Ireland education minister, attending the opening of the inquiry's public hearings earlier this year.

Mr Edwin Glasgow QC, also acknowledged that innocent people were killed on January 30 1972, and told the tribunal he would not argue that any of the known dead and injured were armed with guns, nail bombs, petrol bombs or acid bombs.

However, up to 34 other people were also shot dead or seriously injured in the military operation 28 years ago - casualties he said were never publicly acknowledged and who probably included the gunmen and bombers attacking the soldiers.

Mr Glasgow's comments came as he made his opening submissions on behalf of 440 soldiers, who ranged from teenage recruits on the ground to high-ranking officers, on the day 13 men were shot dead during a raid by Paratroopers on Derry's Bogside district during a civil rights demonstration.

Mr Glasgow also hit back at complaints by lawyers for the victims about non-disclosure of evidence by political and military authorities of the day.

He said the process of handing information to the inquiry had so far been "wholly and exceptionally" one-sided, with no statements from the leading republicans of that era, including Mr McGuinness.

Mr McGuinness responded later saying: "I will treat the comments of Mr Glasgow with the contempt they deserve."

He claimed Mr Glasgow's words were an obvious attempt to deflect attention away from the weight of evidence that continued to be presented indicting the soldiers who opened fire on Bloody Sunday and the military and political authorities.

The inquiry, chaired by Lord Saville of Newdigate, was established in 1998 and has been sitting in public at the Guildhall, Derry, since March this year.

It has so far been concerned almost entirely with opening presentations, and is only to start hearing live testimonies from witnesses tomorrow, its 52nd day of oral hearings.

Mr Glasgow spoke today about the opening remarks of the counsel to the inquiry by Mr Christopher Clarke QC, who had said evidence had been sought in all continents of the globe, save Antarctica.

Mr Glasgow went on: "I have to say it was pretty galling to see that statement witnessed by Mr Martin McGuinness, who so far as we know does not live in Antarctica and who, despite the obvious importance of the matters which Mr Clarke had objectively laid out in his careful explanation, that witness, despite the relevance and importance of those matters, has neither the courage nor the integrity nor the respect for this tribunal to co-operate with this inquiry, which he personally pressed for and which he was at pains to be seen in company with the Tribunal on the very day that it opened."

Earlier this year intelligence documents were presented to the inquiry which alleged that Mr McGuinness fired the shot which precipitated Bloody Sunday - a claim denied outside the hearing by Mr McGuinness.

Mr McGuinness said in his statement issued later today that he had already had a number of meetings with his solicitor to determine the most adequate way of presenting his evidence.

He added: "When that is decided I will inform the families." The tribunal and the media would then be notified, he added

Mr Glasgow referred to claims by Mr McGuinness that leading republicans had given assurances before the ill-fated march that there would be no republican presence there.

The QC maintained that the soldiers he represented who opened fire "aimed at, shot at, only those who they believed to be using firearms or those threatening lethal violence against themselves or others".

He spoke of 40 people believed by the inquiry to be members of or connected with the IRA in the city at the time of the catastrophe, to whom the tribunal had written more than a year ago.

The "vast majority", apart from "honourable exceptions", had not replied, he said.

He said: "I have to say that it would have been good to hear that we had support from everyone in this room, or even from someone in this room in expressing the hope that you (the tribunal) would be told by those who are actually in a position to tell you openly and truthfully what both wings of the IRA were doing on Bloody Sunday."

Mr Glasgow's position in not pursuing allegations of wrongdoing by the 13 known dead and 14 known injured flies in the face of the findings of 1972 inquiry into the shootings in which the then lord chancellor Lord Widgery concluded there was "strong evidence" that some had been firing weapons or handling bombs.

However Mr Glasgow's stance was at odds with a second legal team representing other military witnesses, which persisted in linking two identified casualties - Gerald Donaghey, who was killed, and the wounded Joseph Friel - with weaponry allegedly used on the day.

The inquiry will resume at 9.30am tomorrow.

webTitle: NHS trusts face penalties over junior doctors' hours

fields.headline: NHS trusts face penalties over junior doctors' hours
fields.trailText: More than 200 NHS trusts face financial penalties running into millions of pounds for failing to reduce the number of hours worked each week by overstretched hospital junior doctors. Patrick Butler reports.
fields.body:
More than 200 NHS trusts face financial penalties running into millions of pounds for failing to reduce the number of hours worked each week by overstretched junior hospital doctors.

Trusts whose junior doctors work more than 56 hours a week limit will be forced under new rules that come into force on 1 December to pay them substantial "overtime" penalties of nearly two thirds of salary.

The Department of Health's figures show that 229 trusts will have juniors working more hours than the weekly limit when the arrangement comes into force as part of the new junior doctor's contract.

There are 30,300 junior doctors working in the NHS. They earn between £26,000 and £52,000. DoH figures suggest 11,600 of them will qualify for the extra payments.

The penalties were described by ministers as a "sharp financial incentive for all trusts to ensure junior doctors do not have to work excessive hours".

But it is likely that trusts will feel that they are being punished for circumstances beyond their control - a general shortage of junior doctors, coupled with ever-increasing public demands on the NHS hospital system.

Alastair Henderson, policy manager at the NHS Confederation, said that although the penalties might persuade trusts to improve junior doctors' hours it would also "impose financial difficulties" on some of them.

Paul Thorpe, deputy chair of the British Medical Association's junior doctors committee said that the government figures underestimated the number of juniors working more than 56 hours a week.

DoH figures show that numbers of junior doctors working more than recommended maximum has risen over the last six months, providing further evidence of the strain on the NHS. They reveal that 38% of junior doctors working in English hospitals were breaking the limit in September, compared with 36% in March.

The BMA estimates that non-compliance on juniors' hours has risen from around 25% two years ago, and will continue to increase as trusts improve their monitoring of how long each doctor is working.

Health minister John Denham glossed over the figures, saying they showed that "while a substantial number of trusts have all their junior doctors working a maximum 56 hours, much more needs to be done".

The figures show that of 319 trusts, less than one third can claim a 100% record of compliance with the limit, while at 72 trusts, more than half of all junior doctors are working more than 56 hours a week. At eight trusts all of the junior doctors are working more than 56 hours a week.

Most of the trusts with a 100% success rate are community trusts, with relatively few junior doctors. Yet at England's biggest trust, Leeds Teaching Hospitals, 395 of its 655 juniors breach the limit.

The area with the worst record is London, where more than half of the 7,000 junior doctors do not comply with the limits.

webTitle: Knesset holds peace hopes in its hands

fields.headline: Knesset holds peace hopes in its hands
fields.standfirst: A parliamentary vote tomorrow could unseat the Israeli prime minister and destroy the peace process, writes Derek Brown
fields.trailText: A parliamentary vote tomorrow could unseat the Israeli prime minister and destroy the peace process, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
Israel's parliament, the Knesset, holds the fate of the Middle East peace process in its hands.

Tomorrow morning, a vote takes place which could unseat the fractious minority government of the prime minister, Ehud Barak, and open the door to a new rightwing administration, which looks bent on a military solution to the Palestinian uprising.

Events are conspiring against Mr Barak and the dwindling band of Israelis who believe the peace process can be revived.

Five more Palestinians were killed this morning. They were shot by Israeli soldiers manning a checkpoint in the occupied West Bank.

Palestinian Muslims began observing the holy month of Ramadan this morning. Militants have warned that if Israeli forces prevent worshippers from reaching mosques and other sacred sites, there will be serious confrontations.

Likud, the main rightwing bloc in the 120-seat Knesset, is claiming that it has mustered the 61 votes it needs to bring down the government in tomorrow's vote.

The United States has taken a back seat in the negotiations due to the impasse in the presidential race.

The only small spark of hope is that security force chiefs have reportedly renewed contact, in the hope of reopening lines of communication and liaison.

The head of Shin Bet, Israel's internal secret service, met the Palestinian intelligence chief, Mohammed Dahlan, in Cairo.

However, that could be too little, too late. In both Israel and the Palestinian territories, tempers are inflamed and politics dominated by talk of war and revenge.

Mr Barak is trailing badly in the polls, and has little chance of winning a general election, should Likud win tomorrow's vote. For weeks, the prime minister has been trying to defuse the political crisis by recruiting Likud ministers to a new government of national unity.

But the leader of Likud, Ariel Sharon, who is Israel's most notorious hawk, put too high a price on unity. He held out for more draconian military measures against Palestinian rioters and, in effect, demanded that the peace process itself be unravelled.

Mr Sharon has long championed a more aggressive Israeli approach and strongly supports more colonisation of the West Bank, where about 170,000 Jewish settlers live in fortified cantonments among 2m Palestinians.

The Likud leader was the main author of Israel's disastrous invasion of Lebanon in 1982, which led to the 18-year occupation of the south of that country. Israeli troops were finally pulled out of the occupation zone earlier this year.

Hizbullah guerrillas based in the territory are stepping up operations and killed an Israeli soldier on Sunday.This has further raised the emotional and political temperature in a region braced for war.

webTitle: Lastminute offers upgraded service

fields.headline: Lastminute unveils upgraded service
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: Online retailer lastminute.com is upgrading its website by offering speedier transactions and more specific targeting of customers, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Online retailer lastminute.com has unveiled improvements to its website after a series of delays over the past few months.

Technological improvements will allow the site to target specific customers and allow speedier transactions.

Brent Hoberman, chief executive of lastminute, said: "This is a launchpad from which we can grow the business further, particularly through greater personalisation and highly targeted offers which enhance the customer experience."

The relaunch of the website had been hit by delays throughout the summer owing to technical hitches.

Lastminute's shares have fallen by around 40% over the past four weeks to a new low of 72p. The delay in implementing the changes has been cited as one of the factors behind the stock's free-fall.

The company floated in March at a price of 380p per share, rising to 550p, but since then it has born the brunt of negative investor sentiment towards technology stocks.

However, the few analysts that follow lastminute are bullish about the company's prospects due to its £90m cash pile, leaving the company free to concentrate on expansion and ignore its waning competitors.

Heidi Fitzpatrick, analyst at Lehman Brothers, said: "It is really grim out there, as the market does not differentiate between those companies who can make it and those who can't.

"I still think the cash balance will take lastminute through to breakeven, where it can really start to grow."

This morning, lastminute shares showed slight signs of recovery by rising 7%, or 5.5p, to 77.5p.

webTitle: Songwriters gunning for free music sites

fields.headline: Songwriters gunning for free music sites
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: British songwriters will today launch a campaign against free down-loadable music on the internet, warning that it threatens a British industry worth more than £3.2bn.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
British songwriters will today launch a campaign against free down-loadable music on the internet, warning that it threatens a British industry worth more than £3.2bn.

Musicians used to worry about punters with concealed tape recorders under their Afghan coats selling bootleg tapes of concerts. But the internet has created a staggering change in the scale of copyright violation. Worldwide sales lost, because the music can be accessed free, have recently been estimated at £2bn a year.

This week has been declared Music Awareness Week. The "respect the value of music" campaign has the backing of Sir Paul McCartney, and Elton John, who are among the many high profile music industry figures whose recordings have been targeted.

The British musicians are following the lead of their American peers, where a dozen expensive law suits are rumbling through the courts. In July Madonna's new album appeared on the net four months before the planned release.

Frances Lowe, director general of British Music Rights, which is organising the campaign, said: "The impact of new technology is a significant issue for everyone who cares about the future of music and the livelihood of those creating the music we enjoy."

David Arnold, award winning composer of film scores including Independence Day, Godzilla, the most recent James Bond films and the remake of the 1970s classic Shaft - all to be found at free sites - put it more bluntly: "It's a little bit crap, actually."

Andy Heath, an independent music publisher, director of the Beggar's Banquet publishing group, and a member of the government's music industry forum, said: "People's work, people's livelihood, people's creativity is being stolen. It is a fundamentally unjust position, and that is all there is to it."

He said one of the problems in raising consciousness of the issue was the self evident wealth of some of the victims.

"Frankly it's hard to feel a stab of guilt over a Madonna track. Elton John really doesn't need to get any richer, and it's very difficult for anyone to sincerely shed a tear over Universal or Warners.

"So at the moment there's quite a cuddly feeling about it all, that this is freeing music from the clutches of huge powerful corporations. But I think we are seeing the benevolent start of something that will become quite pernicious."

He added: "If it is not possible for all the smaller musicians and composers, living pretty ordinary lives, to earn any kind of a living from music, then they will stop making music. Without the small ones the big ones, the stars, are never going to pop up out of the system.

"The net is a fantastic thing, it has returned power to the people and to the young musicians who can bypass the whole studio system and put their work straight up there.

"Napster is a brilliant tool, I've used it myself, and I have no problem with music being free to the consumer - but there has to be a way of getting something back to the people who make that music."

Napster, the biggest and most famous of the free music sites, has struck an out of court deal in the last few weeks, to pay royalties to the record company BMG, the music side of the German media giant Bertelsmann.

Bertelsmann was one of several companies with lawsuits pending against Napster. The rock group Metallica almost got an injunction last summer to shut down Napster, but the case only proved that the spread of free music is now unstoppable: within days half a dozen sites had sprung up offering a similar service.

Mr Heath said there was still time for musicians to get a grip on the phenomenon, probably through punters paying small monthly license fees to access the sites - such as Napster is now proposing - with royalties distributed by the Performing Rights Society.

"The only protection for the music industry now is that the quality of the digital sound you download is still not quite as good as buying a commercial recording. It's not brilliant if it's free, it would be crap if you have to pay for it. But the technology is evolving so fast that difference is going to disappear."

Mr Arnold, who has also worked with composers such as kd lang, has had the experience of his work in progress turning up on the net. "On Godzilla, we were booked in for 10 days' recording, and on day five the work we'd done so far was up there. When we did Randall And Hopkirk Deceased the theme was up the day after we'd finished the master: there were only three people who could have had access to it, including me. It's a very weird feeling. There's stuff of mine out there that I haven't even got."

In general, however, he is trying to combat the idea that free music is a victimless crime.

He added: "If I set up a stall selling bananas at 40p, and somebody sets up beside me giving bananas away, how many people are going to buy my bananas? And why would I keep on trying to sell bananas?"

Cheap and easy listening
 "Music" has replaced "sex" as the most entered word on the internet's biggest search engines.
 At the heart of this change is a technology, MP3, and a service, Napster.
 MP3 is a computer file standard which allows music to be stored and transmitted over the internet without a dramatic loss of sound quality. Napster is the free service which makes it easy for millions of users to swap those MP3 files between themselves.
 Napster was founded last year by a shy American teenager, Shawn Fanning.
 It now finds itself embroiled in lawsuits with the big record labels for breach of copyright while being courted by some, including Bertelsmann of Germany, because of its ingenious technology. Its user-friendly face has made downloading music simple, decentralised and hugely popular.
Neil McIntosh

webTitle: Disadvantaged students still not overcoming barriers to university

fields.headline: Disadvantaged students still not overcoming barriers to university
fields.trailText: While poor exam results are seen to be the most obvious reason why disadvantaged students are not breaking into higher education, those that are qualified tend to shy away from applying to university, according to a report published today.
fields.body:
While poor exam results are seen to be the most obvious reason why disadvantaged students are not breaking into higher education, those that are qualified tend to shy away from applying to university, according to a report published today.

The report, by Alasdair Forsyth and Andy Furlong of Glasgow University and compiled for the Joseph Rowntree Trust, concludes that poor exam results at school, not bias by university admissions officers, is the primary reason that more disadvantaged young people are not entering university.

On the other hand, those that do qualify are put off applying to prestigious universities by fear of debt and the costs of travel. They tended to apply for more vocationally oriented courses to ensure a job when they graduated and to stay at home or nearby to reduce costs,

The report's conclusions raise questions about whether the governmentês policy of urging elite universities to recruit more working class and ethnic minority students can work. The study was carried out in Scotland but Forsyth and Furlong believe it is applicable to the UK as a whole. The abolition of tuition fees north of the border would not affect the poorest students who would not have been liable to pay them anyway.

The report says: "Policy might better be focused on improving school achievement rather than on university entrance policies. Increasing quotas of pupils from schools in deprived areas entering the most prestigious institutions is unlikely to be particularly effective, as this seems likely only to reach the more advantaged minority who attend such schools.

"There is a need to encourage all disadvantaged young people to value and aspire towards post-compulsory education. Young people from disadvantaged backgrounds currently face a range of deterrent factors to continued participation in higher education, beyond the minimum point necessary to 'get a job'. Financial assistance might help such people (who would not benefit from the abolition of up-front tuition fees). Such measures might include housing or travel assistance (particularly for those from remote areas, but also to encourage enrolment at often distant prestigious institutions) and the introduction of non-repayable bursaries. "

Five hundred 17 year olds in Scotland were interviewed at schools which were either remote or in socially disadvantaged areas and sent relatively few pupils on to higher education. Within these schools it was the children of more middle class families - primary teachers, nurses or sales assistants - who fared better.

"The existence of pockets of relatively advantaged residents within disadvantaged school areas masks the true level of educational disadvantage experienced by less affluent young people in such communities," adds the report.

See Joseph Rowntree Foundation

 The full report, Socioeconomic Disadvantage And Access To Higher Education by Alasdair Forsyth and Andy Furlong is published for the Foundation by The Policy Press (ISBN 1 86134 296 9, price £12.95).

webTitle: Identica hired for Wembley Stadium rebrand

fields.headline: Identica hired for Wembley Stadium rebrand
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: Wembley Stadium has hired brand consultancy Identica to create a fresh identity for the venue when it reopens in 2004. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The owners of Wembley Stadium have hired brand consultancy Identica to create a fresh identity for the venue when it opens in 2004.

Wembley chiefs are ploughing £500m into a new 90,000-seat state-of-the-art stadium to be called the English National Stadium.

Identica, which has been responsible for the images of Powergen, Universal Studios and Alliance and Leicester, is being hired to ensure the new venue gets a positive image from the start.

The stadium plans to attract 2.7m visitors a year - 1.7m from major events and a further 1m from smaller attractions.

But sceptics say these projections are over-ambitious and could create a repetition of the Dome fiasco, with the government forced to bail it out if it hits financial problems.

The stadium is being designed by Lord Foster's Foster & Partners.

Identica's task will be to create a new brand for the stadium. Wembley Stadium had become shabby and outdated by the time it closed last month and the English National Stadium will have to ensure it distances itself from its previous incarnation.

The new identity is likely to be based on a 133m arch, which replaces the famous Wembley twin towers.

webTitle: New Media Markets round-up

fields.headline: New Media Markets round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 24.
fields.trailText: November 24: No immediate regulatory action seems likely over the secret agreement by which BSkyB has an option to take a 10% stake in ONdigital if it floats.
fields.body:
No immediate regulatory action seems likely over the secret agreement between BSky and ONdigital, under which BSkyB effectively has an option to take a 10% stake in ONdigital if and when it floats. The secret agreement was drawn up in 1997 after the ITC kicked BSkyB out of what became the ONdigital consortium.

Cable operator United Pan-Europe Communications is a company under pressure after its share price collapsed. Analysts think the company lacks a clear message and it needs to restore confidence.

Nickelodeon UK says the BBC's plans to launch a raft of children's channels could force commercial channels to close and reduce investment in independent production by up to £400m over the next five years.

ONdigital last week discreetly launched its adult pay-per-view service, ONrequest adult, which starts at 11:30pm every day.

Pearson TV Enterprises is planning to launch a new interactive game show channel in the second half of next year. The channel will run across ADSL, digital satellite, digital terrestrial and digital cable.

webTitle: It ain't over until it's over, say US papers

fields.headline: It ain't over until it's over, say US papers
fields.standfirst:
The front pages are dominated by the Napoleonic self-coronation of George W Bush. But nobody is convinced - the fat lady has not yet sung.

Special report: US elections
fields.trailText: The front pages are dominated by the Napoleonic self-coronation of George W Bush. But nobody is convinced - the fat lady has not yet sung.
fields.body:
From the Floridian capital, the Tallahassee Democrat has a vivid word-picture of the scene as the latest certified tally was announced: "A mighty roar went up at 7:29pm, when secretary of state Katherine Harris announced official certification of county-by-county returns that showed Bush leading [Vice President AlGore by 537 votes, but the noise never really stopped all afternoon.

"Chanting rhythmically like football fans in opposing grandstands, the pickets bunched behind television reporters doing live shots outside the Senate Office building. Many waved signs like outdoor spectators at a morning TV show, saluting hometowns as far away as Edmond, Okla."

The piece leads, rather movingly, with a description of a couple in the crowd who held a non-partisan placard reading simply "God Bless America".

The brash New York Daily News urges Gore to fight on in the courts. Its editorial summarises the muddle and intimidation which flawed the Florida recounts, and concludes: "The winner must be the man who received the most votes, which is why every vote must be counted - the hand-counted ballots, the dimpled ballots, the disputed ballots, the military overseas absentee ballots. For the law - indeed, democracy itself - dictates that the will of the voters must be followed."

In more measured terms, the venerable Boston Globe also pleads for popular patience with the never-ending legal gavotte: "Gore is expected to address the nation today to explain his decision to contest the certification. This is necessary if he is to continue to hold the good will of the American people, who so far seem fairly patient with all the political and legal skirmishing. With so much at stake, Americans should indulge the process a bit longer so that the best effort can be made to count the votes that were actually cast."

The Atlanta Journal believes that public patience with the process is running short, and chides the opposing camps for hurling around inflammatory accusations of cheating: "It ought to stop. Nobody is cheating. Both sides are using the legal systems and institutions that were put in place to deal with situations such as this, and that's exactly what they ought to be doing.

"Those institutions - slow and creaking as they sometimes are - will inevitably give us a final answer. If the American people are to accept that eventual outcome as legitimate, the workings of those institutions must be respected and treated as credible."

The newspaper that Mr Gore once worked for, Tennessean, carries news of another tight election, embroiled in legal wrangles. In a referendum in Trousdale County on November 7, voters approved a merger with the city of Hartsville, by just two votes. Now opponents of the consolidation have filed a lawsuit challenging the validity of 13 "yes" votes. Such is US life.

The best line of the day comes from Washington Post writer Michael Powell, in a wry commentary recalling the robust methods used by 16th century rulers of the Ottoman empire to eliminate challenges to the legitimacy of a new emperor: "When a new sultan was crowned, a trusted eunuch was sent to find the next closest rival - and strangle him with a bowstring. It probably beat watching them fight over chads."

Powell goes on to burrow into the heart of the matter: "The American president is a powerful creature. He derives his full power from the cultural assumption that he is prime minister and monarch rolled into one. Our strongest presidents, men such as Franklin Delano Roosevelt, Ronald Reagan and Dwight D Eisenhower, are no mere parliamentary figures. They tap into something iconographic and essential about the nation. Such legitimating authority could prove elusive for the next president."

webTitle: Yahoo hit by Japanese police raid

fields.headline: Yahoo hit by Japanese police raid
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Lawyers at Yahoo are set to return to the courts following a child porn case that has rocked its Japanese operation, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Lawyers at Yahoo are set for a swift return to the courts following a child porn case that has rocked its Japanese operation.

Yahoo's Tokyo office was raided by police today following the alleged sale of child porn videos on the company's auction website.

The inspection was part of an ongoing effort to compile information on 38-year-old Shinichi Hori, who was arrested this month for allegedly selling the videos through Yahoo's auction site since June.

Yahoo Japan has so far declined to comment on the investigation. A statement is due later today.

The move comes less than a week after Yahoo France lost a case over the sale of Nazi memorabilia on one of its sites.

webTitle: Jane Martinson: The end of the old media/new media affair

fields.headline: When the old tire of the new
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Old media companies spent much of last year having a mid-life crisis. Made to feel dull and grey, they willingly gave their name to younger, funkier, online rivals in a vaguely desperate attempt to look cool. Now they're not so sure it's a good idea, writes Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
Old media companies spent much of last year having a mid-life crisis. Made to feel dull and grey, they willingly gave their name to younger, funkier, online rivals in a vaguely desperate attempt to look cool.

Now, the morning after the internet party of the night before, many of these grey-beards are suddenly seeing their once-cocky adolescent partners in a whole new light. Why put up with all the whining and the blemishes when time, money and reputation now seem much more attractive?

Few old media companies underline this new confidence in maturity as much as the Old Grey Lady. The New York Times and TheStreet.com, in a little-noticed sidebar to the news that a financial website was closing its UK operations and sacking 40 people in the US, announced that their joint newsroom was to be shuttered.

The collapse of this 18-month-old experiment marks a new chapter in the development of online news operations. The partnership between the New York Times and TheStreet.com was one of the earliest efforts to amalgamate the best of the new and the old in the rush online. The newspaper wanted the pizzazz and speed of the newcomer, while the website craved more credibility.

In stilted comments made at the time of the announcement, both companies said they had learned a lot from each other and had ended their relationship by mutual consent. The New York Times still has a 5.7% stake in TheStreet.com.

Money was not the cause of the split, in spite of signs of retrenchment on both sides. Problems arose because of editorial rather than financial values: the New York Times felt it no longer needed to be told how to write fast business news for its online readers by an outfit that did not share its values or ideals.

Bill Keller, the managing editor of the newspaper, says that the world now recognises that inventiveness and energy are no longer the province of the new. "This has definitely been a learning experience," he says of the joint newsroom, before adding: "It has underscored that we old media folk can actually do new media ourselves. We don't have to do it in partnership with a dot.com."

The seven journalists of the joint newsroom who sat in the Wall Street offices of TheStreet.com were pulled in different directions by the two partners. Simply put, one wanted fast and furious news to use for investors, while the other wanted considered exclusives and analysis. Neither side was ultimately happy with what was produced.

Executives at TheStreet.com had hoped to be able to work more closely with their colleagues at the NYT, but it was not to be.

Research into the readership of both organisations could have highlighted the gulf between them. TheStreet.com provides waves of instant financial news and aggressive analysis in a format prized by market professionals and investors. Readers of the New York Times have more general but perhaps more sophisticated interests.

Keller highlighted the gulf between the two when he compared the ambitions of TheStreet.com with the financial equivalent of a sweatshop. "TheStreet.com conceived of [the joint venture] as a boiler-room, while we conceived of it more as a newsroom."

The newspaper intends to appoint two or three of the joint newsroom journalists to something it calls a continuous newsdesk, an eight-strong operation which files online stories. These journalists are all fully fledged members of NYT staff, unlike those in the joint newsroom. The continuous newsdesk, established 18 months ago, was also an experiment. Set up in the heart of the NYT's own newsroom, it was one that worked, however.

The collapse of one of the earliest affairs between old and new media companies raises questions for other partnerships. Few, however, are showing any outward signs of such a culture clash.

Indeed, just a few days before, FTMarketwatch.com, a joint venture between the Financial Times and Marketwatch, a US website, announced its intention to expand into Germany. Both the FT and CBS, the US television network, own significant stakes in Marketwatch, although the transatlantic ventures are managed separately.

Other partnerships, notably that between the Washington Post and MSNBC.com, are sharing editorial rather than financial resources. The situation is fluid, with many media companies still toying with the go-it-alone versus the alliance route in the US. Larry Kramer, the chief executive of Marketwatch.com, says: "Everybody is trying to figure out how to get to where they want to be and how best to manage their business in a changing climate."

For the New York Times, where they want to be for now is left alone to their own considerable resources.
fields.bodyText: Old media companies spent much of last year having a mid-life crisis. Made to feel dull and grey, they willingly gave their name to younger, funkier, online rivals in a vaguely desperate attempt to look cool. Now, the morning after the internet party of the night before, many of these grey-beards are suddenly seeing their once-cocky adolescent partners in a whole new light. Why put up with all the whining and the blemishes when time, money and reputation now seem much more attractive? Few old media companies underline this new confidence in maturity as much as the Old Grey Lady. The New York Times and TheStreet.com, in a little-noticed sidebar to the news that a financial website was closing its UK operations and sacking 40 people in the US, announced that their joint newsroom was to be shuttered. The collapse of this 18-month-old experiment marks a new chapter in the development of online news operations. The partnership between the New York Times and TheStreet.com was one of the earliest efforts to amalgamate the best of the new and the old in the rush online. The newspaper wanted the pizzazz and speed of the newcomer, while the website craved more credibility. In stilted comments made at the time of the announcement, both companies said they had learned a lot from each other and had ended their relationship by mutual consent. The New York Times still has a 5.7% stake in TheStreet.com. Money was not the cause of the split, in spite of signs of retrenchment on both sides. Problems arose because of editorial rather than financial values: the New York Times felt it no longer needed to be told how to write fast business news for its online readers by an outfit that did not share its values or ideals. Bill Keller, the managing editor of the newspaper, says that the world now recognises that inventiveness and energy are no longer the province of the new. "This has definitely been a learning experience," he says of the joint newsroom, before adding: "It has underscored that we old media folk can actually do new media ourselves.
