webTitle: Can Desmond really make things OK! at the Express?

fields.headline: Can Desmond really make things OK! at the Express?
fields.standfirst: Richard Desmond, the new owner of Express Newspapers, models himself on Lord Beaverbrook and hopes to become a media billionaire. But success in top-shelf magazines is no guarantee of success in the press, warns Roy Greenslade
fields.trailText: Richard Desmond, the new owner of Express Newspapers, models himself on Lord Beaverbrook and hopes to become a media billionaire. But success in top-shelf magazines is no guarantee of success in the press
fields.body:
That irascible old windbag, Randolph Churchill, once appalled the second Lord Rothermere by calling him "pornographer royal" for his ownership of the Daily Sketch and Sunday Dispatch. It was an unfair jibe since neither paper, even during those more buttoned-up times, contained what most people considered salacious material. But Rothermere, nervous about public reaction, immediately fired both editors.

Now, almost 50 years later, a real "porn king" has bought three national newspapers and the public reaction, so far as one can gauge it, has been muted. No journalist has resigned as a matter of principle. Some readers have cancelled their orders, but not many. Advertisers have not announced a boycott.

It is, of course, early days. Everyone is waiting to see just what Richard Desmond, publisher of Asian Babes and Nude Readers' Wives, has in store for the Daily and Sunday Express and Daily Star. His first statements, and actions, suggest that his ownership of the meretricious celebrity magazine OK! is going to play a greater part in his transformation of the papers than his pornography empire.

Before we contemplate the future, though, let's take a brief look at the events that led to Desmond's surprising takeover. The deal may be done, but there could yet be a twist that makes his life somewhat difficult. Desmond paid £125m for the papers after secret negotiations with Clive Hollick, chief executive of United News & Media. The sale included 50% of the West Ferry printing plant in east London, the other half of which is owned by Hollinger, owner of the Telegraph titles and one of the potential bidders for the Express.

Hollinger's joint-ownership agreement with United News includes a clause in which it has pre-emptive rights to buy its 50% if there is a change of ownership. My understanding is that Hollinger's bosses, Conrad Black and Dan Colson, are "looking closely" at exercising its right because the formula which sets the purchase price is said to be "attractive".

If this happens it will severely dent the profitability of Desmond's new property, because most of the £10m a year currently made by Express Newspapers comes from West Ferry. Colson, Hollinger's vice-chairman, has no axe to grind with Desmond but he is upset that his company was prevented from obtaining enough information from United to make a competing - and probably higher - bid for the Express. "We are outraged by the completely unprofessional process used by Hollick and his advisers," he said. "We are astounded that they decided to sell when they might have got a better price for their shareholders."

Two other bidders, the Daily Mail & General Trust, and the Barclay brothers' Press Holdings, take a similar view. Senior executives at all three companies were using language about Hollick last week that could never appear in a family newspaper, and probably not even in Asian Babes. But United's board has an answer: if it had agreed a deal with any of the three paper groups it would have faced a competition commission inquiry which might have lasted up to six months, and during that time there was every likelihood that the value of Express Newspapers would have declined. Selling to Desmond was therefore quick and, so to speak, clean.

However much sense it makes commercially to United, senior Express journalists - and this certainly includes editor Rosie Boycott - still believe Hollick has betrayed them. They have never been able to understand why he bought the papers in the first place. He showed very little interest in them and never provided them with adequate investment.

Given his shabby involvement in the post-Maxwell takeover of Mirror Group along with David Montgomery, his name is now mud among a legion of journalists. No wonder he was booed from Ludgate House last week. One executive said: "Hollick likes to be known as a Labour peer, but what kind of socialist is it who presides over four years of cost-cutting and under-investing, and then sells us to a man like Desmond?"

There are plenty who believe, without a shred of evidence but lots of understandable prejudice, that Hollick's choice of buyer is his ultimate act of cynicism towards the Express staff. If a newspaper company with a good track record had bought the titles it might just turn their fortunes around. By selling to Desmond, who has no experience and expertise, the chances of reviving the papers are lower. So, should they go to the wall, Hollick will be able to boast that he didn't do such a bad job after all, and managed to extract £125m in the process.

I very much doubt that scenario, but it does show the depth of feeling among Express journalists. "It's depression city here," one told me on Friday morning. He had arrived to find that within 24 hours of Desmond's team moving in, the front page had been changed behind the editor's back. When Boycott left the evening before she had approved a front-page blurb for an article on Paula Yates. Next morning she discovered that Desmond's editorial director, Paul Ashford, had demanded that the night editor replace it with a blurb about OK! magazine's court battle over pictures of the Michael Douglas-Catherine Zeta Jones wedding with its rival Hello!. While Boycott consulted solicitors, doubtless contemplating a possible action for constructive dismissal, Ashford lamely explained to one of her assistants that he didn't realise he had done anything wrong.

The chances of Boycott staying long are remote. Her background as a founder of the ground-breaking feminist magazine, Spare Rib, and her continuing adherence to its principles, cannot be squared with those of Desmond, whom she regards as an exploiter of women. She will not be mollified by the reply to this last point by one of Desmond's lieutenants. "We don't exploit them," he explained. "The girls get paid."

Anyway, Desmond is intent on distancing himself from the activities that created his considerable personal fortune. "We do not publish pornography," he told the Sunday Express yesterday, "because pornography is illegal. We publish adult magazines."

Semantics aside - dictionary definitions of pornography refer to it as a descriptive word in which legality plays no part - there is no doubt that Desmond's top-shelf magazines, along with Television X and the Fantasy Channel, are his major source of revenue. He may have hived them off into a separate company but there can be no doubt that, for the foreseeable future, the Daily Express will be funded by soft porn.

There is, of course, a positive side. In four days Desmond has shown more interest in the papers than Hollick showed in four years, even circulating a morale-boosting memo of praise on Friday. He has increased the print run by more than 250,000 copies a day, and launched a £1m TV promotion campaign based on the slogan "It's OK! at the Express". He says he will release big money for book serialisations and buy-ups. He will also axe four unprofitable internet sites this week, diverting the saved £8m into the papers.

He has enthused Daily Star editor Peter Hill, pledging a tie-up with his Fantasy Channel, though I'm uncertain whether a plunge downmarket by the Star will work: it has done better since it became less tacky. Nor do I think Desmond's supposed plan to launch a Sunday Star too clever. These are not promising beginnings.

Similarly, his boasts in yesterday's Sunday Times that he plans to engage the Daily Express in head-to-head combat with the Daily Mail, emulate its most famous owner, Lord Beaverbrook, and become a billionaire ring particularly hollow. Too much has been made of his singular celebrity magazine success. Former OK! editor Sharon Ring says: "He was very clever to see that Hello! had lost the plot and could be overtaken by OK!, but I can't see the same happening with the Express and the Mail."

Indeed, there is a great deal of naivety about Desmond's initial statements. He may have, as everyone keeps saying, tremendous energy, enthusiasm and determination, but those are the very minimum requirements for a newspaper proprietor. However wide he opens his chequebook, the Mail can afford to spend more if necessary. Celebrity pictures may sell, but does he think the Mail doesn't know that? Newspapers are different from niche magazines. They must ration their entertainment content, ensuring that they do not lose their credibility. The Mail's success depends on its editor, Paul Dacre, following his instinct about how to strike a balance.

If Boycott departs, Desmond will need to find an editor who really understands national papers. There have been suggestions that either the former Daily Record and Scotsman editor, Martin Clarke, or the ex-News of the World editor, Phil Hall, would be in the running. Ian Monk, one-time deputy editor and now handling Desmond's PR, might be in with a chance. Martin Dunn, the former Today and New York Daily News editor, should also be considered.

The important factor would, of course, be the relationship between editor and owner. Desmond comes across as a Maxwellian figure, having shown an enthusiasm for intervening in the editorial affairs of OK!. He is also notoriously offensive, using the F-word frequently. At his first dinner in a Chinese restaurant with the Express and Star editors and deputies, he tipped back in his chair, took a cigar from his mouth and said: "Well, this is fucking brilliant, fucking great!"

He can be charming, said one of his former executives, but "he is a ruthless man, driven by money and status". Since he is already a multimillionaire at 48, it may be the latter that has compelled Desmond to become a newspaper tycoon. But it's unclear whether he will find a warm welcome in Downing Street. He says he is a socialist and a pro-European, makes much of Tony Blair as "a businesslike prime minister who's doing a good job", and disparages William Hague.

For all that, he has let it be known that he regards the Express as "too leftwing". What he probably means is that it tends to wear its heart on its sleeve, criticising the government over pensions, for instance. Again, this doesn't sound too hopeful for Boycott's future. I have a hunch that she would have walked on Friday but for her genuine respect for her favoured staff. She doesn't want to feel she is abandoning them.

She was none too pleased with Desmond's demand that the 40-strong OK! editorial team should be quartered on the same floor as the Daily Express. That move was still being resisted at the weekend by Express executives citing health and safety regulations.

Another bizarre consequence of the takeover is the appointment of Stan Myerson as advertising director. He left the Express under a cloud some years ago. Now he is in charge of a department which includes people who sat on the disciplinary panel which led to him being fired. His ex-wife also works on the paper.

All in all, the prospects for the Express titles still look gloomy. In recent years it was common for Express journalists to say that "anyone would be better than Hollick". There aren't many saying that now.

webTitle: Mail and Express go to war

fields.headline: Mail and Express go to war
fields.trailText: 9.45am: The battle of the mid-market tabloids began in earnest today, with the Daily Express offering money off OK! magazine, while the Daily Mail touted free copies of Hello!. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The battle of the mid-market tabloids began in earnest today, with the Daily Express offering exclusive pictures of the celebrity wedding of the year as well as money off OK! magazine, while the Daily Mail touted free copies of rival gossip magazine Hello!.

But the Express's coverage of the wedding of Catherine Zeta Jones and Michael Douglas offered little that avid gossip-followers had not already seen. Only three of the photographs of Ms Zeta Jones published in the paper had not already been published in OK!.

Express readers were offered £1 off this week's OK!, which promises "more exclusive pictures and interviews". Readers would have to buy the paper all week to benefit from he offer.

But the Daily Mail trumped this with the offer of a free copy of Hello! magazine in exchange for just two tokens, published in the Daily Mail today and tomorrow.

The collaboration is expected to be the first of many between the two publications.

Sally Cartwright, publishing director of Hello!, told MediaGuardian.co.uk on Friday that she had held talks with the Mail about joining forces to combat what she described as their "common enemy".

The Mail's tie-up with Hello! is a sign of how worried the paper is about the threat from a revitalised Express.

For the past 10 years, the Mail has dominated the middle market, but new Express owner Richard Desmond has made it clear that he wants to see the paper back on top, and has pledged to spend "whatever it takes".

webTitle: Political editor leads Express exodus

fields.headline: Political editor leads Express exodus
fields.trailText: 2pm update: The Express has lost its political editor and two senior commentators less than a week after it was bought by Richard Desmond, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The Express today lost its political editor and two senior commentators less than a week after the paper was taken over by Richard Desmond, publisher of OK! magazine and a number of soft porn titles.

Anthony Bevins, who has headed the political team at the Daily Express for two years, said he could not work for Mr Desmond. He has no other job lined up.

Mary Kenny, the staunchly moralistic columnist, has also left.

The paper's science editor, Michael Hanlon, handed in his notice this morning after deciding to accept a job as science feature writer at the Daily Mail.

Mr Bevins, 58, joined the Express from the Independent two years ago.

He said today: 'I don't want to work for Mr Desmond. I joined the Express because I thought that it was worthwhile to try to move the Express from being a rabid right-wing Thatcherite organ to something more responsive to a mood in the country.

"All that sounds terribly pompous and I don't mean to be, but I am a serious journalist. I don't want to be doing anything that is not journalism."

Mr Bevins, who has worked on national newspapers since 1973, said this was the first time he had left a job with no job to go to.

He said he had "no idea" what political direction Mr Desmond would take the Express, but said he did not want to be part of the new regime.

Rosie Boycott, editor of the Express, is said to be determined not to quit of her own accord.

She has told associates that if she is sacked, the new owners will have to honour the pay-off terms in her £350,000, two-year contract.

"She doesn't want to make it easy for them," said one.

webTitle: Desmond to axe Express websites

fields.headline: Desmond to axe Express websites
fields.standfirst:
Nov 23: MegaStar stays at United
Net news
fields.trailText: Richard Desmond plans to axe four websites with the loss of 40 jobs as the first part of a ferocious attack on costs at Express Newspapers which he bought last week for £125m. By Terry Macalister.
fields.body:
Richard Desmond plans to axe four websites with the loss of 40 jobs as the first part of a ferocious attack on costs at Express Newspapers which he bought last week for £125m.

The new proprietor is unimpressed that Express websites have burned up £8m and take up half a floor of the headquarter building but bring in only £100,000 worth of advertising, a well-placed source said.

Other staff are likely to go in circulation, marketing and distribution as departments from newspapers and magazines in his expanded empire are amalgamated.

"The Daily Express has eight people on syndications and yet OK! has only one person for a greater amount of work. It is inefficiencies such as these that he wants to get rid of," said the source.

And in moves which are likely to be unpopular internally and could endanger the position of journalists, Mr Desmond wants publications such as the Daily Express, Daily Star and celebrity magazine OK! to cooperate on key stories.

"He is a great believer in 'cross fertilisation' and thinks when OK! gets a big celebrity interview there is no reason why all the others [newspapers] should not have a treatment of that."

The future success of the Daily Express and others is to be built primarily through the promotion of showbusiness throughout the newspapers using OK! as the primary source. The weekly celebrity title is to be moved into the Blackfriars headquarters of the Express.

The new proprietor is also planning to invest heavily, too. He wants to launch a Sunday version of the Daily Star and last night opened a heavy marketing campaign for the Express with the first of a £1m television advertising blitz.

But Mr Desmond is aware he faces a serious challenge in trying restore the Express to anything like its former glory. The decision to buy the group has forced him to postpone plans to move for a stock market listing for Northern & Shell, publisher of OK! and a other magazines.

Mr Desmond appointed stockbroker Seymour Pierce in the summer to handle what he hoped would be a £1bn float. But sources close to the company admitted this was on the back burner. "He [Mr Desmond] still wants to do that but he accepts that investors will want to see him make a success of his new titles."

webTitle: Mary Kenny speaks out

fields.headline: Catholic Kenny hits out at Desmond
fields.standfirst: Express exodus begins
fields.trailText:
Monday 6pm: Express columnist Mary Kenny quit the paper because she wasn't comfortable working with someone who "coarsened culture", writes Lisa O'Carroll.
Express exodus begins
fields.body:
Daily Express columnist Mary Kenny said she quit because she wasn't comfortable working with someone who "coarsened culture".

She said: "I just feel the new regime would not be compatible with my identity as a Catholic writer.

"That is the only real standing I have in my life. I don't think that fits comfortably with Mr Desmond's stable of magazines."

The staunchly opinionated columnist, who also writes a column for the Catholic Herald, wrote to Express editor Rosie Boycott today to break the news that she would be retiring from the paper after four years.

She took the decision to leave following last week's dramatic takeover by Richard Desmond, the millionaire publisher whose magazine empire ranges from OK! to top-shelf titles such as Forum and Asian Babes.

Ms Kenny said she was not calling for the closure of Mr Desmond's soft-porn empire, which also includes The Fantasy Channel.

"I accept that there is a market there and that there are lots of people who think Mr Desmond is a good businessman," she said.

However, she added: "What concerns me is the coarsening of the culture and from that point of view I cannot wish him well.

"If he succeeds, you are going to open the door to more porn barons."

Ms Kenny admitted that she had never seen any of Mr Desmond's top-shelf magazines and couldn't remember if she had ever flicked through OK! magazine other than by accident.

But she added: "I am not asking for censorship or for Mr Desmond to close down his titles. But I don't have to be part of his business.

"I am still entitled to make my own choices. It is entirely possible that he could have fired me too."

Ms Kenny had been on a freelance contract with the paper since earlier this year and is currently writing for the Spectator.

She hopes to get a job on another newspaper but said the fact that she no job to go to did not concern her.

"I am being realistic and I have taken the financial considerations on board. I can always work as a teacher if it comes to that."

webTitle: Malcolm Wall interviewed

fields.headline: Wall looks forward to 'exciting' times at United
fields.standfirst: Wall reunited with Hollick
fields.trailText:
12.30pm update: Malcolm Wall tells David Teather he had done some hard soul-searching before leaving TV but had become intrigued by the business-to-business model.
10am: Wall reunited with Hollick
fields.body:
12.30pm update: Malcolm Wall said he had done some hard "soul-searching" before leaving television but had become "intrigued" by the business-to-business model.

Mr Wall, who is rejoining United News & Media as chief operating officer and executive director on January 1, said: "United is still a very large group with a fantastic balance sheet and considerable resources to draw on for expansion.

"It could easily call on £1.5bn to £2bn and that makes life very exciting."

Mr Wall joined United in 1992 as one of the first employees of its then newly-formed broadcasting division.

"Culturally, United has always been spot on for me," he added. "Clive [Hollick] has been derided in the past but his fast thinking and unsentimental attitude toward business has returned extraordinary value to shareholders and people are starting to recognise that."

Mr Wall moved with the ITV franchises to Granada Media where he worked on the integration into the new group. He left Granada earlier this month with a year's salary.

Lord Hollick said he was "delighted" to welcome him back.

webTitle: The British Museum's Great Court: one of the world's most extraordinary covered squares

fields.headline: A feast for the eyes
fields.standfirst: So this is how Gulliver felt on his travels!  Jonathan Glancey  is dwarfed, transfixed and dumbstruck by the Great Court in the British Museum - one of the world's most extraordinary covered squares
fields.trailText: So this is how Gulliver felt on his travels! Jonathan Glancey is dwarfed, transfixed and dumbstruck by the Great Court in the British Museum - one of the world's most extraordinary covered squares.
fields.body:
Sumerian. Mesopota-mian. Byzantine. The politics of the British Museum have long been as arcane as this august institution's labyrinth of stuffed galleries. But in recent months, the vicious carping surrounding the construction of the museum's magnificent new Great Court has been less the stuff of ancient civilisations than fodder for tabloid headlines. Great bitching in the Great Court.

The reason is the row over who is to blame for the £100m lottery-fuelled project falling into disfavour with English Heritage because the wrong sort of stone was used on the south facade of the Great Court. A new Ionic portico, the principal gateway to the two-acre Great Court, has been erected here to replace an original demolished 125 years ago. The contractor supplied a couple of thousand tons of Anstrude Roche Claire limestone for the task, instead of good old Portland stone. The former is French and, therefore, in the eyes of the Heritage chaps, a bad thing. There have been tantrums and calls for resignations in the exquisite halls of one of the most popular museums in the world.

No doubt something a little dodgy has been going on somewhere along the line between the French quarries and Bloomsbury but, for visitors to the Great Court, this storm in a wine goblet will mean little if anything. In 10 years, few will know or care what all the fuss was for. What they will know, instead, is one of the most extraordinary covered squares to be found in any city, ancient or modern.

Designed by Foster and Partners and engineered by Buro Happold, the Great Court is the largest covered square in Europe. Entered from the controversial portico, it takes the breath away. It is not just the scale of what has, for nearly 150 years, been Britain's most secret courtyard that takes the visitor aback. It is the almost surreal effect of seeing the former Reading Room - the haunt of Marx and Mumford, Ruskin and Rossetti, Yeats and Sun Yat-Sen - looking quite so small in this Brobdingnagian space. At 140ft in diameter, the dome of Sydney Smirke's Reading Room is just 2ft smaller than that mother of all domes, the Pantheon in the heart of Rome. Here, though, surrounded by the restored Portland stone walls of Robert Smirke's chaste Grecian courtyard, and under the billowing new Foster/Happold glass roof, the younger Smirke's famous library seems almost dwarfed.

This astonishing sight reminds me of Piranesi's daunting engraved vision of the Temple of Vesta (from his book, Prima Parte, 1762); here a great circular Corinthian temple appears to be growing up inside a much larger Pantheon-style temple. Citizens in togas mounting the stairs that wrap around the temple-within-a-temple seem quite dwarfed: as in Piranesi's imaginary ancient Rome, so in contemporary Bloomsbury.

This extraordinary telescoping of space really is an odd experience; it's rather like being Gulliver on his travels. Step inside the painstakingly restored Reading Room with its distinctive cartwheel of 35 long desks and, far from being small, it feels immense - which it is. The Great Court truly lives up to its name. This newly excavated and brilliantly remodelled courtyard is likely to become one of the most popular, and certainly the busiest, meeting places in London this side of the concourses of Waterloo and Victoria stations.

Even then, what you see walking under the curved, crisscross-patterned glass roof of the Great Court, through which Sydney Smirke's copper dome blooms voluptuously into the London cloudscape, is only a small part of the huge reconstruction that has taken place behind the walls of the British Museum in just 33 months and without the building having to close to its teeming public. Below the new courtyard floor are new lecture theatres and study rooms: Smirke's Reading Room is truly the tip of an architectural iceburg. It is also the hub around which visitors will trace new routes through the museum and where they will find an intriguing new cafe that wraps around the drum of the Reading Room and is approached by stone stairs (the Heritage chaps will have to avoid these; they're made of Galicia Capri limestone from Spain, a foreign country) that echo those of Piranesi's Temple of Vesta.

The Reading Room at the centre of the Great Court thus becomes the new heart of this cultural behemoth. This helps visitors to the museum enormously. To date, because of the museum's linear plan, they have had to retrace their tracks several times to get from one gallery to another. From next week, when the Great Court opens, they will be able to criss-cross the museum, making new cultural connections and stopping under the great glass roof for a break. During museum opening hours, the Great Court will also act as the centre of a pedestrian route from north to south across Bloomsbury through the museum: handy on a wet day.

The roof of the Great Court is a triumph. Foster is not the first archi tect to come up with plans for a glass roof here. In 1852, just two years after the completion of Robert Smirke's grand Greek Revival design, Charles Barry, joint architect of the Palace of Westminster, proposed roofing over the courtyard - then a garden - with sheets of glass supported on 50 iron pillars. This new space, inspired by Paxton's Crystal Palace of the year before, was to have served as a Hall of Antiquities.

It never happened, largely because the Reading Room did. This opened in 1857. Together with its attendant book stacks, it filled in the courtyard which then disappeared from public view, until now. Most of the tens of millions who have pushed and shoved their way from the Egyptian mummies to the last sad pages of Captain Scott's manuscript diary will have had no idea that the biggest space of all in the museum - 40% of the entire museum site - was entirely hidden from them.

It was freed up again when the British Library finally moved to its new premises up the road on the old Somers Town goods yard site at Kings Cross in 1998. Glazing over the courtyard was no doddle. For whatever reason, Smirke minor positioned the drum and dome of his reading room some way off centre. As a consequence, the geometry of the Foster/Happold roof is complex. And yet it looks effortless, a gently billowing cloud of almost ethereal geometric steel and glass contrasting elegantly with the British (hurrah), French (shame) and Spanish (poor show) stone of the classical architecture and statuary below. The antique sculpture on display in the Great Court will be joined by Anish Kapoor's stainless steel eyecatcher titled Turning the World Upside Down. This tall, mirror-like sculpture is set in front of the entrance to the Reading Room on an axis with the controversial south portico. It promises to play a clever and delightful game with the immensely grand, if not solemn, architecture and mesmerising geometry of the Great Court.

Schemes for remodelling and extending the British Museum and rehousing the British Library date back many years. Yet, by waiting the best part of 40 years, the Museum appears to have done the right thing. Earlier plans would have meant a big new British Library building in the heart of Bloomsbury and the destruction of the dense old streetscape Robert Smirke's chaste masterpiece inhabits.

Instead, with the British Library removed to a daunting brick palazzo a few hundred yards to the north, we can enjoy Smirke at his best. While the Great Court has been remodelled, the Regency interiors have been restored to their original decorative scheme. We can enjoy, too, the old streets here that act as a chatterbox backdrop to the silent screen of Ionic columns (based on those of the temple of Athena Polias at Priene in Asia Minor) that have characterised the BM for the past 150 years.

Foster won the Great Court commission in 1993 after an open competition entered by 132 firms of architects worldwide. While work was in progress in Bloomsbury, he was also at work on the reconstruction of the Reichstag, the new seat of the German parliament, in Berlin. This, too, consists of a grand classical building (although not nearly as refined as Smirke's) topped with a huge dome.

The heart of both these great civic statements are now open to their respective publics. The way in which we are learning to open some of our greatest, yet far too often most secret, buildings to the public is encouraging. There are many more to come, yet as we begin to uncover and reveal these secret worlds, we will involve an increasing number of people in an intelligent discussion of how we might nurture our architectural heritage. In the design of the Great Court, Foster and his team have shown how the design of one era can be enhanced by that of another.

When the bitching stops and the petty emporers of our Byzantine cultural establishment put away their sharp, ambitious knives, the public en masse will see just how great the Great Court is.

· The Great Court at the British Museum, London WC1, opens December 7. Details: 020-7323 8000. Open Court at the British Museum, aTV documentary, is on BBC2 6.45pm, December 2.

webTitle: Army shells out £20m as its medics get it wrong

fields.headline: Army shells out £20m as its medics get it wrong
fields.trailText: Army medical blunders 'kills and maims' soldiers
fields.body:
Soldiers are being maimed and killed because of medical blunders by Army doctors, The Observer can reveal. The scale of the problem has led to record compensation payouts.

Since 1998 the Ministry of Defence has paid out more than £20 million to 191 members of the armed forces, more than £11,500 a year for each doctor employed in the Defence Medical Services.

The total compensation has trebled since 1997 and is now six times higher than in the National Health Service, which last year paid out less than £2,000 per doctor.

For £20m the MoD could have refurbished all the homes on a military base, upgraded 50,000 of its rifles or bought 10 Challenger battle tanks.

Legal experts believe the rapidly dwindling number of medical specialists in the armed forces is one reason for the soaring number of medical blunders, with late and wrong diagnosis a major problem. The Defence Medical Services are losing more than 700 trained doctors, nurses and specialists a year.

Two years ago, father-of-three Stephen Stewart died after developing skin cancer during a tour of duty in Belize with the former Queen's Own Highlanders Regiment.

After suffering from severe sunburn, a mole on his neck began to bleed. An Army doctor confirmed the growth was malignant and it was surgically removed. Stewart was then given the all-clear, but after leaving the Army in 1997 he began to have pains in his neck, suffered a dramatic weight loss and began vomiting regularly.

Doctors confirmed the cancer had returned and told him he had less than a year to live. His widow, Paula Stewart, is suing the MoD, claiming her husband was not given radiotherapy treatment after the cancer first appeared. Lawyers say that this amounted to a crucial lapse in care that would have prevented his premature death.

Lesley Herbertson, head of clinical negligence at law firm Alexander Harris, claims that there is anecdotal evidence of soldiers being made to feel 'weak' if they complain of health problems.

Herbertson has recently acted for a young soldier who had been complaining of chest problems that made it difficult for him to breathe. His medical unit dismissed his complaints and did not take a chest X-ray. Days later he collapsed and was rushed to hospital, where he was diagnosed with pneumonia and required a major operation to save his life. The soldier was left with massive scars around his body and the MoD had to pay out £20,000 in compensation.

In another case, a soldier collapsed into a coma and was left with brain damage after being forced to go on a long run despite complaining of breathing difficulties. It turned out he had pleurisy.

Families of soldiers are also having problems. Last July a Wiltshire family won more than £2m in damages from the MoD after Army doctors in Aldershot failed to carry out a prompt Caesarean birth. The baby was left with cerebral palsy and cannot speak.

Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrat spokesman on defence, said: 'Those joining the armed services are entitled to expect the best when it comes to medical treatment. Without a proper standard of care, units could easily be left well short of their full complement, adding to the burdens of overstretch.

'The Defence Medical Services are still paying a heavy price for the cack-handed reforms introduced under the last Conservative Government. But it is time the present administration put things right.'

Earlier this year Admiral Sir John Brigstocke sparked a political row by writing of his concern about the 'parlous state' of the forces' medical service, complaining that the budget for the Surgeon-General's Department, which treats service personnel, had been cut by £1.5m.

In February, the Armed Forces Pay Review Body described manning levels as 'critically low, particularly in the numbers of deployable medical officers'. Since the end of the Cold War in 1989, Britain's armed forces had been cut by a third, but the manpower strength of the Defence Medical Services had fallen by more than half.

Last year the Commons Defence Select Committee reported a 30 per cent staff shortfall, with only 50 per cent of the necessary doctors and 75 per cent of the nurses.

webTitle: Titanic heads BBC Christmas blitz

fields.headline: Titanic heads BBC Christmas blitz
fields.trailText: The BBC has spent millions to secure the blockbuster film Titanic for its Christmas schedule, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The BBC has spent millions to secure the blockbuster film Titanic for its Christmas schedule. Television industry sources believe it has agreed to pay up to £7m for the movie as the autumn ratings war with ITV reaches its peak.

Titanic is likely to be screened on Christmas Day, regarded as a crucial time in the battle for viewers between BBC1 and ITV.

The deal allows the BBC to screen the movie several times and spread the cost over more than one year's budget. The full amount would not be paid in one go - the BBC would have to make a payment for each time the film is shown. But the corporation's readiness to set aside such a large amount of money, even in principle, is the latest sign of its ratings-chasing strategy.

BBC1 schedulers had previously planned to show Men in Black at Christmas, but were forced to bring it forward earlier in the autumn when Greg Dyke, director general, started the ratings war by moving the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm.

The BBC will announce full details of its Christmas Day line-up next week, but released some advance details of its winter programmes yesterday.

A follow-up to the series Walking With Dinosaurs and an all-star version of the historical romance Lorna Doone are among the highlights.

The award-winning team which created the successful dinosaur series has used the same computer special effects to bring extinct lizards back to life for a one-off programme.

Martin Clunes, Barbara Flynn, Michael Kitchen, Anton Lesser and Aidan Gillen star in Lorna Doone. The title role is played by newcomer Amelia Warner.

For the first time, the royal family's traditional Christmas Eve service at Sandringham will be televised live in a special edition of Morning Worship.

Also on BBC1, Colin Firth returns to the screen five years after playing Mr Darcy in Pride and Prejudice. He stars in Donovan Quick, a drama about a mysterious stranger who transforms the lives of a dysfunctional family when he becomes their new lodger. There is also a Victoria Wood special, and Christmas editions of regular BBC series.

On BBC2, Anne Robinson will be treating celebrities to a dose of her famous rudeness on a special edition of The Weakest Link. The channel also screens the last-ever Fast Show, an Arena documentary on Clint Eastwood, and a documentary on the history of British spy fiction.

ITV, which announced its Christmas line-up last week, will present a modern version of Dickens's A Christmas Carol, with Ross Kemp as Eddie Scrooge, a loan shark on a council estate. It will screen Tim Burton's animated film A Nightmare Before Christmas, and this year's now-traditional ITV pantomime stars Martin Clunes, Griff Rhys Jones, Patsy Kensit, Julian Clary and Ed Byrne in Aladdin.

webTitle: Radio 1 tears up daytime schedule

fields.headline: Radio 1 tears up daytime schedule
fields.trailText: BBC Radio 1's daytime schedules have been torn up following the announcement that DJ Simon Mayo is leaving the station after 14 years, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC Radio 1's daytime schedules have been torn up after DJ Simon Mayo decided to leaved the station after 14 years.

The 42-year-old DJ, who arrived in 1986 as a fresh-faced antidote to veterans such as Simon Bates and Dave Lee Travis, is switching to Radio 5 where he will host an afternoon current affairs show.

Mr Mayo's departure heralds the first big shake-up since Chris Evans quit Radio 1, with Mark Radcliffe being parachuted into the lunchtime slot and Jo Whiley getting an extended show.

BBC chiefs are moving Radio 5's Ian Payne to the evening show Sport on Five to make way for Mr Mayo.

Established names in the Radio 1 schedule are also being given extended slots to fill the gap left by Mr Mayo's departure from the morning show, which goes out for three hours from 9am daily.

He will present his farewell Radio 1 show on February 16 and begin broadcasting on 5 Live in May.

Jo Whiley will then move from lunchtime to a 10am start and add an extra hour to her show, which will finish at 1pm.

Mark Radcliffe is to begin an hour earlier, at 1pm. Chris Moyles' show, extended by 60 mintues, will follow at 3pm and run up to Newsbeat at 5.45pm.

In the morning, Scott Mills' Early Breakfast Show is being extended by 30 minutes and will be on air from 4-7am.

Breakfast Show host Sara Cox will start half-an-hour later at 7am, but run for an extra hour, finishing at 10am.

Lorna Clarke, Radio 1 head of mainstream programmes, said: "This is Radio 1's strongest daytime line-up for years. It combines huge appeal to a young audience with an all-consuming passion for music."

The Simon Mayo Show on 5 Live will be built around his current Radio 1 daily format, which includes a major interview, live discussion of current news issues and high-profile guests, as well as new features such as going live to Prime Minister's Question Time and sporting events.

New Radio 1 daytime schedule from Monday February 19, 2001

 Scott Mills - 4-7am
 Breakfast Show with Sara Cox - 7am-10am
 Jo Whiley - 10am-1pm
 Mark Radcliffe - 1pm-3pm
 Chris Moyles 3pm-5.45pm

webTitle: Suchet to star in BBC1 police drama

fields.headline: Suchet to star in BBC1 police drama
fields.trailText: 8am: David Suchet is to play a modern-day detective in BBC1's spring 2001 blockbuster drama, National Crime Squad, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
For years, he entertained the nation as the languid Hercules Poirot, but now David Suchet is switching channels and generations to play a modern-day detective.

He will lead a crack police team in a blockbuster new BBC1 drama designed to match the success of ITV's long-running hits, Heartbeat and Peak Practice.

Mr Suchet will take the lead role in National Crime Squad, being lined up for a BBC1 post watershed slot next spring.

The show, which is expected to be transmitted as a series of self-contained two-part stories, is being executive produced by Jane Tranter, the newly appointed BBC controller of drama commissioning.

BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey will be looking for new dramas such as National Crime Squad to succeed in the newly created 9-10pm slot, which was opened up by the move of the late evening news bulletin to 10pm.

Greg Dyke, BBC director general, has already demanded more popular, returning 9pm dramas, to sustain a competitive edge in the new-look BBC1 schedule.

webTitle: Royal Liver back with Publicis after pitch

fields.headline: Royal Liver back with Publicis after £8m pitch
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Royal Liver Assurance is increasing its advertising spend and is about to embark on a new TV campaign, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Royal Liver Assurance is increasing its advertising spend and is about to embark on a new TV campaign.

Following a statutory review of the business, Publicis will continue to handle all of the brand's corporate communications. It beat CDP and Bates UK for the account, which is expected to be worth up to £8m.

The campaign will involve new TV advertising and potentially an integrated direct response campaign via Dialog, Publicis's direct marketing arm. Media buying is retained by Optimedia.

Publicis first took the brand on to TV in 1997 with its 'Lean on the Liver' advertising. The ads featured a series of vignettes of everyday people of all ages whose lives had been made easier by the products Liver offers.

David Roberts, corporate planning and development manager for Royal Liver, said: "We have been through a searching review process and we are pleased to announce our decision to go forward with Publicis and Optimedia.

"They demonstrated the strategic and creative ideas and integration we need to continue to raise our profile and deliver response."

Founded in 1850, Royal Liver has grown to become the country's second largest friendly society. It provides a range of products in the pensions, savings and insurance markets.

webTitle: Grinch tops US box office for second week

fields.headline: Grinch tops US box office for second week
fields.trailText: In a record-breaking Thanksgiving weekend, family films 102 Dalmations and Rugrats in Paris lost out to the continuing appeal of The Grinch Who Stole Christmas, while Unbreakable failed to equal the success of M Night Shyamalan's previous blockbuster The Sixth Sense
fields.body:
Ron Howard's The Grinch Who Stole Christmas (pictured) remained at the top of the US box office in a bumper weekend that saw a record Thanksgiving take.

The Dr Seuss adaptation grossed $73.8m (£52.6m) from Wednesday to Sunday, according to studio estimates, bringing its total so far to $137.4m (£97.8m, and with no new country-wide releases this week, the film looks set to make the top spot three weekends in a row.

Meanwhile, after disappointing ticket sales this year for many highly-touted Hollywood movies, the top 12 films took $236.3m (£168.5m) over the same period, beating the previous $225.5m ($160.8m) record set last year, when Toy Story 2 grabbed the top spot with a mighty $80.1m (£57.1m) debut.

In second place this year, earning $47.2m (£33.6m) over the same five-day period, was M Night Shyamalan's Unbreakable, a supernatural thriller in a similar vein to his hugely successful The Sixth Sense, also starring Bruce Willis.

But this time around reviews have not been anywhere near as favourable. Salon denounced the final twist, another feature in common with last year's sleeper hit, as "barking mad", while the LA Times said: "Unbreakable seems to have encouraged all its actors to emulate Willis' lugubrious pacing, meaning that usually vibrant actors such as Wright, Penn and Jackson are not shown to their best advantage."

Fellow Disney release 102 Dalmatians, starring Glenn Close, lost the battle for American kids' hearts and wound up in third place with $26.8m (£19.1m), confirming the mighty sway of the Grinch. Rugrats in Paris, another victim of the Jim Carrey vehicle, held its own in its second week, finishing in fourth with $22.8m (£16.2m).

A surprise success was Philip Kaufman's Marquis de Sade flick Quills, which made a tidy sum despite its limited release. The film, which stars Geoffrey Rush as the libidinous aristocrat, took $314,000 (£223,933) in just nine theatres; its average of $34,889 (£24,881) per venue was better than both The Grinch with $23,548 (£16,793) from 3134 theatres and Unbreakable $17,430 (£12,430) from 2708.

Critics were also generally approving of Kaufman's saucy picture. All "participants" were left "satisfied", according to E! Online, while the New York Times thought that while occasionally "pretentious and shrill", the film attained a kind of "euphoric stylishness".

While Disney lost out to the Grinch this year, the company could well take the Thanksgiving crown next year as Monsters, Inc., the latest film from Pixar, the creators of Toy Story, is due for release over the holiday weekend next year.

webTitle: Profile: Nick Partridge, Britain's 'Mr Aids'

fields.headline: Power of positive thinking
fields.standfirst: The public no longer cares about the disease, so Britain's 'Mr Aids' is glad Prince Charles visited HIV patients - no matter what the cynics say. Euan Ferguson meets Nick Partridge, chief executive of the newly merged Terrence Higgins Trust and London Lighthouse project.
fields.trailText: The public no longer cares about the disease, so Britain's 'Mr Aids' is glad Prince Charles visited HIV patients - no matter what the cynics say. Euan Ferguson meets Nick Partridge, chief executive of the newly merged Terrence Higgins Trust and London Lighthouse project.
fields.body:
Can there be anything less sexy than what happens after sex? The guddling through ashtrays, the naked traipse through to a grim kitchen to put the kettle on, the furtive binning of the condom, the twilight, the recriminations and, according to one's circumstances, the resumption of telly or the guilty phone call or the long awkward drive back to the zoo. And, for the past two decades, and least sexily of all, people getting very ill, and then very ill indeed, and then dying.

This is less sexy now - in the sense in which the word's been shanghai'd by commercial marketing types - than any other kind of dying. In a definitive recent survey of 24 different health charities, and the public's willingness to give to them, Aids charities expected to come below the popular killers, your cancer and hearts and strokes. They didn't necessarily expect to come absolutely last, somewhere after goitre research and chlamydia relief.

So Nick Partridge, chief executive of the newly merged Terrence Higgins Trust and London Lighthouse project, Britain's Mr Aids, is perhaps the least cynical man in the country about Prince Charles's much-publicised visit last week to the Lighthouse hospice, where he cuddled babies and chatted to HIV positive mothers and invoked the memory of Diana. The Prince received plenty of welcome publicity, of course - though Nick insists he was 'absolutely genuinely interested in what was going on with Aids - as, to be honest, any father of teenage children in Britain today should be.' But Nick and his staff and patients got their names and pictures on the front pages too, and jumped at the chance: for this is Britain's forgotten charity. Stupidly, needlessly forgotten: for there are, today, more HIV positive people in Britain than at any time before.

Nick explains the problem as he sits in Oxford Street's Selfridges organising determined-looking volunteers into the drizzle for a day of bin-rattling ('Selfridges have been very good to us. They've got a good corporate policy. Also, bluntly, they've got a lot of gay staff.') He is a very well-preserved 45, easy to smile and slow, these days at least, to anger.

The problem's simple. The drugs do work. Aids is no longer the genuinely terrifying gorgon it was in the Eighties and early Nineties. Since CT - combination therapy - was introduced experimentally a few years ago to treat HIV, it has proved astonishingly good at saving lives. 'Since 1996/97, the number of people dying from Aids has dropped by 70 per cent,' Nick explains.

'What that's meant is phenomenal. There are all the changes in our services, of course. We teach people to readjust to expect to live, rather than teaching them to plan to die. And many lives have been saved. But what it also means is - ' he sighs - 'a huge complacency. It is still such a problem. It is still transmissible. People still die. But we have to raise £8m a year to keep these charities going, and yet, because of the generational thing, and prejudice, people will always leave their money to animals, or children, a long long time before they leave it to us.'

I ask about the swiftness of the new mood. Can he remember actually feeling a sea-change in the battle against Aids, a new hope?

'Absolutely. It was at the International Aids Conference in Vancouver in 1996, the one that heralded the combination therapy revolution. Being an American/Canadian event, they were deliberately, relentlessly upbeat - there had to be good news every day. But that didn't stop me suddenly realising there genuinely was something new. I'd been involved with Aids work since 1983 - 13 years, in which there was so much, death, illness, loss and grief. Suddenly, after all that, being able to dare to be at all optimistic, even though we were cautious, it was such a joy.

'For me, however, it was also tinged with sadness. At the same time as the CT news was breaking, one of my colleagues, Paul, who managed the hardship fund, was dying back here in London. He was 31. He died on the final day of conference; the first thing I had to do when I returned here was to lead his funeral. So the renewed hope that combination therapy has given to so many people will always for me be coloured with the memory of those who died.'

The last Aids-related funeral he went to was in early 1998. Before that, he was at about one a month. The change is 'unimaginable, even five years ago'. But the drugs won't cure everyone - about 500 will still die this year in Britain - and infection is on the increase once more.

'One of the main barriers is the number of people who won't get tested, even though they suspect they might be positive - they'll be diagnosed too late and the drugs can only halt decline by then, they can't rebuild the immune system.' Today, he added, one of the two communities most affected - gay men and drug-injectors - is much safer, as the shared-needle epidemic has been largely contained, 'thanks to good public health, needle exchanges and the rest.

'But there is real concern at the increase in new infections among young gay men. It's hard to know exactly what the figures are, but I think I know why it's happening. Remember that we're 19 years into this: an 18-year-old man now coming out and exploring his sexuality was only one or two years old when our screens were filled with the iceberg campaign.

'But it's not just young people's ignorance: for older generations now, with the new drugs, there's a sense of wanting to try to forget, to forget the years of difficulty and misery and death. Some will behave as if they have forgotten. And, put bluntly, whether it's ignorance or complacency, both of them still kill. There are about 30,000 people in Britain today living with HIV, but only 20,000 of them know they have it.

'I do know, of course, that being tested is still such a difficult thing to do.' (Has he been tested? 'I don't really want to talk about my own health.') 'You can have it done much faster, within a day, but the result can still devastate, even with these drugs. And there is that whole horrible thing of having to think who you may have infected, and contact them - that's what makes this so different to any other fatal illness.'

There is, I seem to feel from him, a real and vicious anger against the virus: against its suddenness, its capriciousness, the personal devastation it has had on too many friends. He nods, quietly. 'And it's also been a useful touchstone, if you like, against prejudice. There are those who have always had difficulties with gay men and drug users and sex and death, and black Africans' - for this last class, he has explained, is the other group among whom the virus is still raging: on a recent visit to QuaZulu/Natal he found 25 per cent of the adult population were infected. 'The success of the drugs has, if you like, given them new permission to ignore these things.'

He is still worried, he admits, even now at this late stage, of a backlash against gay men: and worried, too, 'that we might still lose against this very stupid virus.'

Stupid?

'Well, you're right, it is just a virus. It just goes where it is allowed to go. But, actually, yes, I do hate it. I try not to personalise it, but it's hard not to hate. And it is stupid: it has its own inbuilt defect, which is that it has to mutate - so the question, over the next few years, is whether pharmaceutical companies can keep up with its mutations: it's a race.'

webTitle: Further action planned in World Service dispute

fields.headline: Further action planned in World Service dispute
fields.trailText: 11.30am: BBC World Service staff are meeting this week to discuss further industrial action following a strike this weekend. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The NUJ and Bectu are planning a joint meeting of BBC World Service members later this week to discuss further industrial action, after this weekend's strike hit the service hard.

Around 240 World Service journalists took part in the strike over night working conditions and pay.

A 48-hour stoppage had been planned from 4pm on Saturday. But the action was suspended early - at 9.30pm on Sunday night - to allow coverage of the US presidential election.

The strike had been called over union demands for better pay and a shorter working week for World Service News staff working night shifts.

The early end to the strike action followed informal talks between union leaders and BBC management.

An NUJ national official said the decision to shorten the stoppage "was a gesture of respect for the World Service's 150m listeners".

The unions will hold a joint chapel meeting of World Service News members later this week to consider their next move.

webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours look empty and vacous. A bit like President G.W.Bush then...
fields.trailText: Terry Venables will be offered £1.5m to keep Middlesbrough in the Premiership, reports the Daily Mirror. The package will include a basic salary, a £500,000 incentive for keeping Boro up, and further cash bonuses depending on how high up the table they finish. The paper claims that Venables is currently mulling over the decision and could be in charge in time for Saturday's game against West Ham. However the Sun is more sceptical, saying that Venables "looks increasingly likely to deliver an agonising snub to the troubled Teessiders."

webTitle: The strong silent type: Volvo S60

fields.headline: The strong silent type
fields.standfirst: It's a Volvo, but it doesn't look like a crate on wheels and it's as quiet as a mouse.  Giles Smith  eases into luxury
fields.trailText: It's a Volvo, but it doesn't look like a crate on wheels and it's as quiet as a mouse. Giles Smith eases into luxury.
fields.body:
A curvacious Volvo. Who would have thought it? Volvos never used to do curves. These cars were interested, above all, in the safe carriage of their contents. It is what Volvo built its reputation upon. The cars tended accordingly to look like crates. There is no vehicle in existence so thumpingly square as an old Volvo estate, unless it is an articulated lorry.

Recently, though, the company has brought us the V70 Cross Country - an amazingly smooth, all- terrain estate car that doesn't look like a Portacabin on wheels. And now here's the Volvo S60, nudging its way into the crowded executive saloon sector, but doing so with rounded shoulders rather than with hulking great elbows.

The S60 is designed to lure the fans of the BMW 3 series, the C-class Mercedes and the Audi A4. Up to a point, it plays those rivals at their own game - the continuous, softly flowing lines from boot to headlamp, the sporty tilt - but then it adds a couple of twists that are strictly Volvo, namely the sober attention to slightly grey, practical matters such as space and safety.

The boot, for instance, seems to have been designed to accommodate a small guest house. The interior is, similarly, created with roominess in mind - and, by extension, with elegance somewhere further down the list. And - having a reputation to live up to - the car positively bristles with airbags and anti-roll bars and anti-shatter curtains, all of which are invisible and yet whose presence is somehow felt in the vehicle's tangible atmosphere of studious good sense. There isn't a single part of this car, one feels, that won't, upon impact, produce an abruptly inflating safety device. It's a balloon festival waiting to happen.

As a result, the S60 carves itself a niche - a deep, safe one. It's considerably less ostentatious than the Mercedes, altogether less wide-boy than the BMW, and nowhere near as discreet as the prince of this sector, the Audi A4. And though it's slopey and rounded, it's most definitely a big lump of Sweden, from its "egg-crate" grille (Volvo's own description), right the way back to those almost comically vast rear-light mouldings. One morning you will wake up and those brake lights will have carried out their plan, which is to take over the whole car.

Actually, they may have to fight for supremacy with the front doors, which also seem to have their sights set on total domination. The doors are apparently adapted from the openings to a meat locker. At any rate, nothing else would appear to explain their breadth, thickness and weight. Volvo describe these doors as one of the car's reassuring features, maintaining that they enhance, by their sheer heft, your sense of ease within the car. This can't really be denied, though at the same time, the doors - opened wide into traffic - would appear to increase your scope for maiming a passing cyclist by, I calculate, 15%. Clearly, one man's safety is another man's visit to casualty.

Once you've closed the door and got your breath back, however, you will soon be twisting the key and noting the following coming from the engine: absolutely nothing. Ticking over, the engine works at a whisper. The whisper of a very shy person indeed. On one occasion, forgetting that I had already started the car, and hearing nothing whatsoever coming from the engine to contradict this impression, I turned the key in the ignition for a second time. (Now, then you do hear an interesting noise. But this is not recommended practice in any of the manuals.) Numerous other times, before pulling away, I found myself, in a slightly neurotic manner, depressing the accelerator in order simply to provoke a response from the engine and prove to myself that the thing was alive and well.

At speed, the engine noise rises from a whisper to a barely audible murmur. I have only rarely heard an engine so quiet. Or rather, not heard one. And it was in cars at least three times the price of the S60. It should be noted, however, that almost total silence from an engine does have its drawbacks. Though clearly excellent news for anyone intent on carefully exploring the capacity of the car's stereo, the absence of audible information from under the bonnet makes those reckless acts of speeding, which are almost inevitable in a compact executive saloon, far harder to curb, or even notice. You can be up to 50 in an S60 before you know it, and certainly before you hear about it.

And thus one wafts along in silence, in a car that feels so well bolted-together that no vibration could ever loosen it. And somehow one feels better bolted-together, as a person, for driving it. Meanwhile, one's on-board pleasure is enhanced by the usual range of flattering devices. The pricier variants of the S60 offer a satellite navigation screen which rises out of the top of the dash, like an organist coming through the floor of a cinema and which will doubtless provide the busy executive with bottomless amusement for at least a fortnight. And if the two cup-holders behind the gearstick aren't enough for you, you can pop another one out of the dashboard - an unprecedented provision, I think, but not the only thing about the S60 that would qualify as a surprise.

The lowdown

Volvo S60

Price: from £19,995

Top speed: 140 mph

Acceleration: 0-62 in 8.8 seconds

Consumption: 30.7 mpg combined

At the wheel: Steve Rider

On the stereo: Bryan Ferry

En route for: The Golf Warehouse

webTitle: Order a BSkyB movie from your mobile

fields.headline: Order a BSkyB movie from your mobile
fields.trailText: 8am: BSkyB customers will soon be able to order movies, check their account or upgrade programme packages from their mobiles, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Satellite TV viewers will soon be able to manage their subscriptions on the hoof.

Customers with Wap mobile phones will be able to order movies, check their account status or even upgrade their programme packages.

The technological breakthrough is being driven by BSkyB, which is making a multimillion pound investment upgrading its customer services department.

The service is scheduled to be launched in the second quarter next year.

The deal comes in the wake of BSkyB's announcement in February that it was upgrading its customer contact facilities in Scotland with state-of-the-art technology and processes.

The system will let Sky Digital customers use devices, from interactive television and the internet to Wap and the usual call centre method, to order movies and other dial-up services from home.

The modernisation plan is part of BSkyB's announced £50m investment in customer service this year.

When the customer centre is launched next year, subscribers will be able to choose which device to use to pay their bills, check account status and upgrade their programming packages.

The move is aimed at speeding up the whole customer service process in order to cope with the 7m digital customers BSkyB anticipates having by 2003.

Mike Hughes, managing director of Sky Services, said: "Not only will Sky's investment in customer service let customers contact us by the device they find convenient, it will also enhance efficiency and allow us to introduce and support new services."

webTitle: Aussies take ostrich approach to eco threat

fields.headline: Aussies take ostrich approach to eco threat
fields.standfirst: They are mopping up in New South Wales after serious floods, but, as Patrick Barkham explains, global warming remains low down the political agenda
fields.trailText: They are mopping up in New South Wales after serious floods, but, as Patrick Barkham explains, global warming remains low down the political agenda.
fields.body:
The deep brown water that has been lapping against millions of sandbags and thousands of doorsteps in Australia for the past week started to ebb away today.

Days of torrential rain led to almost one third of New South Wales being submerged last week - an area as large as England, Scotland and Wales put together.

While many residents of Wee Waa, Gunnedah and Narrabri, small towns in the state's north east, have been stranded or washed out, most of the waterlogged land has been vast acres of spring crops.

Australian farmers are a notoriously tough breed but, with more than $600m worth of crops lost, many have been reduced to tears, facing no income for another year and likely bankruptcy.

Australia's prime minister, John Howard, said that the bush was "down on its knees through no fault of its own". The federal government today announced an aid package worth up to A$100m (£37m) to help the farmers.

But there has been no attempt by Australia's political classes to link the catastrophic floods to global warming and question the government's responsibility for the latter.

The irony that the floods came in the week that the Hague summit subsided has gone unmentioned in mainstream political debate.

Environment groups are not surprised: Australia's right-wing government lined up alongside the US and Canada at the Hague in demanding the right to continue dumping carbon dioxide into the atmosphere in exchange for planting forests as carbon sinks.

In part, however, the failure to link global warming to the latest floods is simply because Australians are far more familiar with natural disasters and extreme weather conditions than Europeans.

The country is susceptible to a cycle of floods and droughts caused by the El Nino weather system.

So, although the miles and miles of ravaged crops are the worst disaster to hit agriculture for 20 years, most farmers and politicians see nothing new in them.

For generations, they have battled to tame the bush, as the 100-year old ruins of farms across Western Australia, where farmers gave up their precarious settlements, are testimony to.

For many, the latest floods are the third successive season in which heavy rain has hit their yields.

But the absence of global warming from the floods debate is also because of the government has a better bogeyman to blame - Australia's banks.

Mr Howard led the charge against Australia's big four banks at the weekend, telling them they have a "moral obligation" to help out farmers.

His government's aid package is generous, but it is feared that it much of it will simply offset farmers existing debts, rather than help them plant new crops and repair damaged land.

In the last financial year, Australia's main four banks made A$9.2bn (£3.4bn) profit. So far, just one bank has donated $100,000 (£37,000) directly to the relief effort.

They have offered some concessions to the farmers. The Australian Bankers' Association has said that banks will waive fees on new loans, while ANZ bank has agreed to a 12-month freeze on the repayment of loans (although not on the interest on those loans).

Other banks are promising to help "restructure" farmers' debts. "Repayment" is not on their lips yet.

As in Britain, Australia's banks have also courted controversy recently with the widespread closure of rural branches. In some small towns, this means the nearest branch could be 100 miles away.

Internet banking remains a science fiction for many, while Australia's whopping bank fees have also incurred the wrath of consumer groups.

With an election looming in the next 12 months, the federal government's popular crusade against the banks is politically crucial.

Once again, there are significant parallels with the British experience. The government is sitting on a large budget surplus, courtesy of petrol taxes.

But, because of the widespread hostility towards those taxes, its spending programmes - most recently, on flood relief and on rural roads - have failed to ignite any affection for the government.

The Liberal government's fate will largely depend on the electoral choices of 1m voters who expressed their disillusionment with mainstream politics by backing Pauline Hanson's extreme right-wing One Nation party at the last election.

They are likely to vote differently this time given that One Nation has imploded in scandal and infighting, leaving both the two main parties, Liberal and Labor, to pursue Ms Hanson's fans by aping elements of her agenda.

The prime minister's populist bank bashing response to the floods recalls Ms Hanson's crusade against globalisation. His refusal to raise the issue of global warming is also a rejection of globalisation's ecological arm.

If it wasn't so flooded, John Howard's head would be in the sand.

fields.bodyText: The deep brown water that has been lapping against millions of sandbags and thousands of doorsteps in Australia for the past week started to ebb away today. Days of torrential rain led to almost one third of New South Wales being submerged last week - an area as large as England, Scotland and Wales put together. While many residents of Wee Waa, Gunnedah and Narrabri, small towns in the state's north east, have been stranded or washed out, most of the waterlogged land has been vast acres of spring crops. Australian farmers are a notoriously tough breed but, with more than $600m worth of crops lost, many have been reduced to tears, facing no income for another year and likely bankruptcy. Australia's prime minister, John Howard, said that the bush was "down on its knees through no fault of its own". The federal government today announced an aid package worth up to A$100m (£37m) to help the farmers. But there has been no attempt by Australia's political classes to link the catastrophic floods to global warming and question the government's responsibility for the latter. The irony that the floods came in the week that the Hague summit subsided has gone unmentioned in mainstream political debate. Environment groups are not surprised: Australia's right-wing government lined up alongside the US and Canada at the Hague in demanding the right to continue dumping carbon dioxide into the atmosphere in exchange for planting forests as carbon sinks. In part, however, the failure to link global warming to the latest floods is simply because Australians are far more familiar with natural disasters and extreme weather conditions than Europeans. The country is susceptible to a cycle of floods and droughts caused by the El Nino weather system. So, although the miles and miles of ravaged crops are the worst disaster to hit agriculture for 20 years, most farmers and politicians see nothing new in them. For generations, they have battled to tame the bush, as the 100-year old ruins of farms across Western Australia, where farmers gave up their precarious settlements, are testimony to. For many, the latest floods are the third successive season in which heavy rain has hit their yields. But the absence of global warming from the floods debate is also because of the government has a better bogeyman to blame - Australia's banks. Mr Howard led the charge against Australia's big four banks at the weekend, telling them they have a "moral obligation" to help out farmers. His government's aid package is generous, but it is feared that it much of it will simply offset farmers existing debts, rather than help them plant new crops and repair damaged land. In the last financial year, Australia's main four banks made A$9.2bn (£3.4bn) profit. So far, just one bank has donated $100,000 (£37,000) directly to the relief effort. They have offered some concessions to the farmers. The Australian Bankers' Association has said that banks will waive fees on new loans, while ANZ bank has agreed to a 12-month freeze on the repayment of loans (although not on the interest on those loans). Other banks are promising to help "restructure" farmers' debts. "Repayment" is not on their lips yet. As in Britain, Australia's banks have also courted controversy recently with the widespread closure of rural branches. In some small towns, this means the nearest branch could be 100 miles away. Internet banking remains a science fiction for many, while Australia's whopping bank fees have also incurred the wrath of consumer groups. With an election looming in the next 12 months, the federal government's popular crusade against the banks is politically crucial. Once again, there are significant parallels with the British experience. The government is sitting on a large budget surplus, courtesy of petrol taxes. But, because of the widespread hostility towards those taxes, its spending programmes - most recently, on flood relief and on rural roads - have failed to ignite any affection for the government. The Liberal government's fate will largely depend on the electoral choices of 1m voters who expressed their disillusionment with mainstream politics by backing Pauline Hanson's extreme right-wing One Nation party at the last election. They are likely to vote differently this time given that One Nation has imploded in scandal and infighting, leaving both the two main parties, Liberal and Labor, to pursue Ms Hanson's fans by aping elements of her agenda. The prime minister's populist bank bashing response to the floods recalls Ms Hanson's crusade against globalisation. His refusal to raise the issue of global warming is also a rejection of globalisation's ecological arm. If it wasn't so flooded, John Howard's head would be in the sand. webTitle: BT gears up for Yell float

fields.headline: BT gears up for Yell float
fields.trailText: 10.30am: BT is a step closer to completing the first phase of its restructuring after hiring a financial director to its Yell subsidiary. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
BT is one step closer to completing the first phase of its restructuring programme after appointing a financial director to its Yell subsidiary.

John Davis, formerly finance director of Yahoo! Europe, will guide the international directories business towards a stock market flotation.

Yell publishes telephone directories and runs an internet service in the UK and US.

BT plans to float up to 25% of the company before April next year, raising £1bn towards reducing the company's £30bn debt pile.

John Condron, chief executive of Yell, said: "John has first class credentials for us - working at senior level in an internet business and media.

"His achievements in adding value to those businesses are impressive and we know he will bring a lot to us."

Mr Davis previously worked at Financial Times owner Pearson and for magazine publisher Emap.

The jury will remain out on BT until it has completed its revamp, which includes the ambitious partial flotation of its wireless operation.

Any flotation of a BT subsidiary faces a crowded marketplace over the next six months, with the likes of European rivals France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom planning similar sell-offs.

The mobile arm of Spanish rival Telefonica had a rocky ride on the stock market when it floated last week, as investors shied away from telecoms operators saddled with mounting debts.

Concern continues to mount that European telecoms companies have paid over the odds for next generation mobile phone licences on the continent, and they may have difficulty repaying the money they borrowed to pay for the franchises.

A Yell spokesman said: "Yes, we have seen a lot of changes in the markets over the last few months, but Yell is a really established business with strong revenue streams. Hopefully it will do very well."

webTitle: New Media Diary

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: Amy Vickers
fields.body:
 Not a good week for dot.coms. Persistent rumours about ShopSmart burning through cash keep cropping up. More than a month ago the company said it was negotiating for more venture capital and would announce something imminently, but, so far, nada. What is the problem? On diary's calculations: ShopSmart's 3.5m page impressions (MMXI) bring in, at best, £85,000 a month in ad revenue which pays for little more than the staff bill. Regardless of how much it has been spending on advertising and minuscule sales commissions, industry insiders are questioning its sustainability. One consolation is that there is so much dot.com gloom at the moment that ShopSmart is not the only big player being questioned.

 So the Millennium Dome is going to be made into a hi-tech business park. If Legacy goes ahead with its plan, it will have to find 14,000 people to work there. No mean feat, considering that the Dome was recently voted the most depressing building in London, and that the number working in this industry is tumbling by the day.

 Anyone who has just been given a p45 could sign up to ijustgotfired.com - a US resource for people who have lost their regular work email address and want to make a song and dance about joining the growing list of dot.com redundancies. Not that sacked dot.com workers often have to spend long looking for a job - diary's spies suggest that just a week after thestreet.co.uk laid off staff, most have found work. See, it's not all doom and gloom.

 Dot.com support industries are also suffering - the conference business has definitely seen better days. First the World Internet Forum was cancelled because no one wanted to go, then last week it was Smi's offline marketing conference (funny that no one is interested in offline marketing anymore). The next could be e-Loyalty 2001, planned for the end of January, with speakers from Boxman.com, Petspark.com, QXL and Razorfish. On second thoughts, I'm sure people would pay to hear Razorfish talk about loyalty, having just sacked loads of employees.

 New media types are notoriously unkempt but guests at Marketing magazine's first Connections awards last Monday took the biscuit. While Modem Media picked up the award for best use of interactive TV, a more apt award would have been noisiest, naughtiest table on what was something of a restrained night. Modem's Simon Jefferson should have won the award for scruffiest new media type and marketing director Brian Blair was a surefire winner of the weirdo of the evening award - he was clocked standing on a chair holding two candles aloft as part of an award celebration. Some strange Scottish tradition, I'm told.

 Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com. amy.vickers@theguardian.com
