webTitle: My new media: Gary Morrison, joint MD of webRewards.co.uk

fields.headline: My new media
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Gary Morrison, joint MD of webRewards.co.uk
fields.body:
Favourite sites? A company called balthaser.com - it's a flash design studio in America. There's a kind of pre-war style video about how the internet is coming alive and we must fight html. Another is DogDoo.com which will send "PooPoo packages of a size of your choice". It reminds me of coffee shops because they've got an Econo-poop, PooPoo Special and PooPoo Grande. The latter is 2lb of messy material from a 110lb dog, apparently.

Last online purchase? Some flights up to Newcastle.

Most recent technological faux pas? The most recent, and probably the most embarrassing, was a conference call with some colleagues and another lady in the US. At the end, we thought one of the three of us had hit the off button when she put the phone down. We carried on the discussion, which was extremely complimentary, and then realised it was being recorded.

Main news sources on the web? I use three on a regular basis. BBC news to get a view of what's going on in the UK. I use the ft.com digest to get very focused news on media, finance or IT. And I use the Revolution daily update to find out what's going on in the industry.

Most persistent spam emailer? Somebody who offers to take on county court judgments in the US. I keep getting these court judgments on people in Alabama. I've never even been to Alabama.

Time spent on the web? Unfortunately, all day - and 95% of stuff I do on the web is to do with work.

Next boo.com/clickmango? If you're an online retailer and you can't clearly differentiate yourself from a well known offline retailer with an online presence, then I think you've got a problem.

Least useful site/s on web? Those sites that basically spend their time grouping affiliate buttons.

Most useful site/s on web? It's probably streetmap.co.uk. I go to meetings a lot and it's really useful to know where you're going.

What screensaver do you use? None at present. They're quite entertaining for a while but I've had so many virus attacks I tend to use my PC for work.

Most irritating thing about the web? The fact that it's so huge and you know that something is out there but you just can't find it. It really is needle-in-a-haystack stuff.

Do you bother with old media? Oh yes. I listen to John Humphrys in the morning and sometimes you just want to read a paper.

 Gary Morrison is joint managing director of webrewards.co uk.

webTitle: Downey Jr on new drugs charge

fields.headline: Downey Jr on new drugs charge
fields.trailText: The actor Robert Downey Jr, who was released from prison only three months ago, is in trouble again for alleged drug abuse.
fields.body:
The actor Robert Downey Jr, who was released from prison only three months ago, is in trouble again for alleged drug abuse.

Downey, 35, who has just won a role in the television show Ally McBeal, was released on police bail early yesterday after being arrested by the police in Palm Springs, California, late on Saturday and charged with possession of cocaine and methamphetamine.

Officers responded to an anonymous telephone caller on Saturday night who said there were drugs and guns in a hotel room at the Merv Griffin Resort, the Palm Springs police department said.

They found Downey alone in the room with the cocaine and methamphetamine. He was arrested without incident, the police added.

A police spokeswoman said he was released on $15,000 (about £10,718) bail yesterday morning.

Downey was arrested three times in 1996. One one occasion his urine tested positive for morphine/heroin, marijuana, Valium and cocaine, according to court papers.

Less than a month later he was arrested again after wandering into a neighbour's Malibu home, where he was found unconscious.

In June last year he admitted that he had violated his probation by failing to submit to drug testing, and was sent to the California state prison in Corcoran.

He was freed in August on $5,000 bail after an appeal court ruled that a lower court had erred in sentencing him, and that Downey had served more than enough time to complete his prison term for drug possession.

After his release, Downey registered at a treatment centre outside Los Angeles.

webTitle: From start-up to dot woe

fields.headline: From start-up to dot woe
fields.standfirst: Are dot.coms an endangered species? Following a recent wave of closures, as backers pull the financial plug,  Imogen O'Rorke  looks at the future of the industry
fields.trailText: Are dot.coms an endangered species? Following a recent wave of closures, as backers pull the financial plug, Imogen O'Rorke looks at the future of the industry.
fields.body:
The dramatic irony is too rich, even for the scriptwriters of the over-the-top dot.com soap Attachments: while the need for quality interactive content has never been so pressing, the companies that are producing the sticky stuff - the e-content and commerce producers - are being abandoned en masse by their financiers.

Indeed, the much-maligned dot.com is rapidly becoming an endangered species. At the current rate - one closure a day, according to www.Webmergers.com; or 30 last month, 75% of which were Business to Consumer or e-commerce - analysts are predicting there will only be a handful left by this time next year, apart from monster brands, such as Yahoo and AOL and those owned by media giants.

Last week, financial news site TheStreet.co.uk, which launched with £10.6m in the spring, was cut off by its American parent TheStreet.com because of "failing to meet profitablity timetables". Closure seemed the only option, despite the fact it was bringing in a respectable £200,000 a month and had closed syndication deals with AOL, Compuserve and Lycos, as well as having 80 advertisers.

In addition, Dobedo, the teenage chat site, announced 23 staff cuts; Citykey, a proprietary WAP city guide application, had to call in the liquidators; and it was reported that upmarket gossip site People News.com had laid off staff and lost its chief executive.

The previous week, Wowgo.com, the teenage girls' portal, was left high and dry by backers Unilever, Durlacher and Eureka after just six months of operations. Sponsorship coups with Capital Interactive, Sure deodorant and celebrity endorsement from popsicle Billie Piper were not enough to persuade the consortium that Wowgo.com had a future as an independent entity.

This month's catalogue of dot woe also includes Ebop, the trendy youth lifestyle site, which has laid off all its staff except for its founders; Ready2, the upmarket shopper's advice portal fronted by Daily Telegraph columnists Susannah Constantine and Trinny Woodall, are back down to three mugs and freeze-dried coffee from a peak of 40 at launch; and finally Switch2, the music, sport and internet service launched by Tim Southwell (former editor of Loaded) and Adrain Pettett (founder of soccer title 90 Minutes), have been dropped by Edison Interactive because the "penetration of ADSL into the market is too slow".

Since the Boo.com debacle in May, it is true to say that there has been carnage. But Boo's very public fall was a black-and-white case of bad management, poor research and overspending. The same cannot be said of The Street.co.uk or Boxman, the CD retailer which closed down without warning this autumn. Many of the recent victims had perfectly sound long-term business models but were unable to bridge the gap between the first and second round of financing.

Mike Murphy, MD of Ebop, claims that the company was eight weeks from breaking even when the liquidators were called in. Two unsuccessful attempts to float on AIM had not helped their market value. He says: "Our backers took the view that the net wasn't enough to sustain a business model such as ours [which included a record label and a popular Italian TV show, which is now being sold off]. In the past, people looked at the internet as a whole new business model when really it was just another delivery medium."

On the day Murphy had to break the news to their staff, Ebop reported their highest-ever user figures. "It is very disheartening for entrepreneurs - we know we created good businesses in their own right," he says. The only thing to do is "batten down the hatches and wait for a sale". Flotations are now very out of fashion.

Speak to any "serious" venture capitalist these days and he will tell you that the B2C model of sponsorship and advertising has been completely discredited. Those, like Ready2, who did not wake up and smell the emergency-board-meeting-coffee and change their business models months ago, have had to suffer the consequences.

Trinny Woodall might complain that the venture capitalists they approached for a further £7m funding, "preferred not to make a decision they could be fired for rather than take the risk", but the backers don't see it in such emotional terms.

"They have a fiduciary duty to their clients. If they think they are throwing good money away after bad, that's their decision," says Peter Bradshaw, analyst from Merrill Lynch Associates, in their defence. He explains the phenomenon in unequivocal Darwinian terms: "What we are seeing is the end of the beginning. That was the pre-Cambrian growth phase and this is the great extinction phase. When it is all over, good companies will emerge, but only a handful of them, and that's been the real eye-opener for these dot.coms - it's a winners-take-all market. Only those who are number one or two in their particular market will survive."

Far from thinking that the internet has been overhyped, most analysts believe we are underestimating the effect it will have on our lives. Online shopping has tripled in the last year (Internet Monitor BMRB figures show that consumers spent £2.5bn online compared with £860,000 last year) and mobile commerce and TV commerce is predicted to outstrip even internet forecasts.

Ironically, this should be the time for a spurt of growth among content providers. The telcos, who have paid a painful £22bn for their UK 3G licences, are looking for compelling applications, services and commerce partners to justify their expenditure. Without the likes of Wowgo, how is Nokia going to persuade teenage girls to buy their new generation of phones?

Without cool broadband entertainment and short-film sites such as Pseudo, Den or Dreamworks SKG-backed Pop.com - victims of the US's recent dot.com "inverse hysteria" - how are the broadband providers ever going to make ADSL attractive to the customer, offering them something they can't get on the TV?

Where will the new generation of dot.com service providers come from if there is no funding? Venture capital matchmaking events, which were once buzzing with ambitious young entrepreneurs wanting to change the world, are now focused on pure infrastructure plays and dull enabling technologies.

Jerome Moll, chairman of tornado-insider.com and CEO of internet incubator GorillaPark, which specialises in early stage start-ups, claims it is "now more difficult than it was 10 years ago to raise money for a dot.com. Venture capitalists are running scared from B2Cs."

Even ivory-tower media companies such as News Networks, Emap Online, Associated Newspapers and UNM have been affected by the dot rot, and are dumping their ailing sites and modifying their new-media strategies in order to avert future embarrassment. Only last week, United axed uTravel, their leisure destination site. Andrew Nugee, head of Xilerate, said at the time, "We are not afraid to act decisively when it's clear that long-term success is not within our grasp. Our strategic emphasis is now to develop our considerable B2B assets."

New economists predict that the investment market will pick up again in six months. Can we then expect a new breed of leaner, meaner dot.com start-ups - if only for our further amusement? "Unlikely - unless they have seriously divergent business models," says Merrill Lynch's Peter Bradshaw. "The AOLs and Yahoos are developing very quickly and have all the use of the bright-brains fallout from the dot.coms. In a few years, it will be unlikely that anyone will challenge them. Also, don't forget that offline brands are beginning to ramp up online and buy up 'shell' B2Cs very cheaply." Despite these negative forecasts, the wireless market is already throwing up some interesting hybrids, such as Cheeky Monkey, which began as a WAP competitions site and has now developed into a direct marketing medium, gaining revenues from SMS share as well as B2B; and iBalls, a video-messaging station service launching next year which plans to expand into shorthand dotTV broadcasting and dotShop retail.

And despite last week's doom-mongering, PeopleNews is pleased to report that they are "getting in shape" for the new year (the staff cuts were no more than a winter detox) and are in fact "hiring aggressively". It will be interesting to see who makes it to New Year 2002 for the annual Dot.com Staying Alive party.

Indeed, the much-maligned dot.com is rapidly becoming an endangered species. At the current rate - one closure a day, according to www.Webmergers.com; or 30 last month, 75% of which were Business to Consumer or e-commerce - analysts are predicting there will only be a handful left by this time next year, apart from monster brands, such as Yahoo and AOL and those owned by media giants. Last week, financial news site TheStreet.co.uk, which launched with £10.6m in the spring, was cut off by its American parent TheStreet.com because of "failing to meet profitablity timetables". Closure seemed the only option, despite the fact it was bringing in a respectable £200,000 a month and had closed syndication deals with AOL, Compuserve and Lycos, as well as having 80 advertisers. In addition, Dobedo, the teenage chat site, announced 23 staff cuts; Citykey, a proprietary WAP city guide application, had to call in the liquidators; and it was reported that upmarket gossip site People News.com had laid off staff and lost its chief executive. The previous week, Wowgo.com, the teenage girls' portal, was left high and dry by backers Unilever, Durlacher and Eureka after just six months of operations. Sponsorship coups with Capital Interactive, Sure deodorant and celebrity endorsement from popsicle Billie Piper were not enough to persuade the consortium that Wowgo.com had a future as an independent entity. This month's catalogue of dot woe also includes Ebop, the trendy youth lifestyle site, which has laid off all its staff except for its founders; Ready2, the upmarket shopper's advice portal fronted by Daily Telegraph columnists Susannah Constantine and Trinny Woodall, are back down to three mugs and freeze-dried coffee from a peak of 40 at launch; and finally Switch2, the music, sport and internet service launched by Tim Southwell (former editor of Loaded) and Adrain Pettett (founder of soccer title 90 Minutes), have been dropped by Edison Interactive because the "penetration of ADSL into the market is too slow". Since the Boo.com debacle in May, it is true to say that there has been carnage. But Boo's very public fall was a black-and-white case of bad management, poor research and overspending. The same cannot be said of The Street.co.uk or Boxman, the CD retailer which closed down without warning this autumn. Many of the recent victims had perfectly sound long-term business models but were unable to bridge the gap between the first and second round of financing. Mike Murphy, MD of Ebop, claims that the company was eight weeks from breaking even when the liquidators were called in. Two unsuccessful attempts to float on AIM had not helped their market value. He says: "Our backers took the view that the net wasn't enough to sustain a business model such as ours [which included a record label and a popular Italian TV show, which is now being sold off]. In the past, people looked at the internet as a whole new business model when really it was just another delivery medium." On the day Murphy had to break the news to their staff, Ebop reported their highest-ever user figures. "It is very disheartening for entrepreneurs - we know we created good businesses in their own right," he says. The only thing to do is "batten down the hatches and wait for a sale". Flotations are now very out of fashion. Speak to any "serious" venture capitalist these days and he will tell you that the B2C model of sponsorship and advertising has been completely discredited. Those, like Ready2, who did not wake up and smell the emergency-board-meeting-coffee and change their business models months ago, have had to suffer the consequences. Trinny Woodall might complain that the venture capitalists they approached for a further £7m funding, "preferred not to make a decision they could be fired for rather than take the risk", but the backers don't see it in such emotional terms. "They have a fiduciary duty to their clients. If they think they are throwing good money away after bad, that's their decision," says Peter Bradshaw, analyst from Merrill Lynch Associates, in their defence. He explains the phenomenon in unequivocal Darwinian terms: "What we are seeing is the end of the beginning. That was the pre-Cambrian growth phase and this is the great extinction phase. When it is all over, good companies will emerge, but only a handful of them, and that's been the real eye-opener for these dot.coms - it's a winners-take-all market. Only those who are number one or two in their particular market will survive." Far from thinking that the internet has been overhyped, most analysts believe we are underestimating the effect it will have on our lives. Online shopping has tripled in the last year (Internet Monitor BMRB figures show that consumers spent £2.5bn online compared with £860,000 last year) and mobile commerce and TV commerce is predicted to outstrip even internet forecasts. Ironically, this should be the time for a spurt of growth among content providers. The telcos, who have paid a painful £22bn for their UK 3G licences, are looking for compelling applications, services and commerce partners to justify their expenditure. Without the likes of Wowgo, how is Nokia going to persuade teenage girls to buy their new generation of phones? Without cool broadband entertainment and short-film sites such as Pseudo, Den or Dreamworks SKG-backed Pop.com - victims of the US's recent dot.com "inverse hysteria" - how are the broadband providers ever going to make ADSL attractive to the customer, offering them something they can't get on the TV? Where will the new generation of dot.com service providers come from if there is no funding? Venture capital matchmaking events, which were once buzzing with ambitious young entrepreneurs wanting to change the world, are now focused on pure infrastructure plays and dull enabling technologies. Jerome Moll, chairman of tornado-insider.com and CEO of internet incubator GorillaPark, which specialises in early stage start-ups, claims it is "now more difficult than it was 10 years ago to raise money for a dot.com. Venture capitalists are running scared from B2Cs." Even ivory-tower media companies such as News Networks, Emap Online, Associated Newspapers and UNM have been affected by the dot rot, and are dumping their ailing sites and modifying their new-media strategies in order to avert future embarrassment. Only last week, United axed uTravel, their leisure destination site. Andrew Nugee, head of Xilerate, said at the time, "We are not afraid to act decisively when it's clear that long-term success is not within our grasp. Our strategic emphasis is now to develop our considerable B2B assets." New economists predict that the investment market will pick up again in six months. Can we then expect a new breed of leaner, meaner dot.com start-ups - if only for our further amusement? "Unlikely - unless they have seriously divergent business models," says Merrill Lynch's Peter Bradshaw. "The AOLs and Yahoos are developing very quickly and have all the use of the bright-brains fallout from the dot.coms. In a few years, it will be unlikely that anyone will challenge them. Also, don't forget that offline brands are beginning to ramp up online and buy up 'shell' B2Cs very cheaply." Despite these negative forecasts, the wireless market is already throwing up some interesting hybrids, such as Cheeky Monkey, which began as a WAP competitions site and has now developed into a direct marketing medium, gaining revenues from SMS share as well as B2B; and iBalls, a video-messaging station service launching next year which plans to expand into shorthand dotTV broadcasting and dotShop retail. And despite last week's doom-mongering, PeopleNews is pleased to report that they are "getting in shape" for the new year (the staff cuts were no more than a winter detox) and are in fact "hiring aggressively". It will be interesting to see who makes it to New Year 2002 for the annual Dot.com Staying Alive party.

webTitle: CIA lands £70m Cartier business

fields.headline: CIA lands £70m Cartier business
fields.trailText: 10.15am: London ad agency CIA has won the battle for control of the world's best-known luxury brands, Cartier and Montblanc, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
London advertising agency CIA has beaten some of the world's biggest media agencies in the battle for control of the world's best-known luxury brands, Cartier and Montblanc pens.

CIA has won the much sought-after £70m account for media planning and buying for the entire portfolio of brands for Swiss group Richemont across Europe.

The appointment will cover all of Richemont's exclusive brand names, including English menswear brand Alfred Dunhill, Cartier jewellery and watches, French fashion house Chloe, British menswear label Hackett, and Montblanc pens and watches.

CIA beat three of the world's largest media planning and buying networks to secure the £70m European appointment including Omnicom Group-owned OMD Worldwide, WPP Group's MindShare and Interpublic's Initiative Media Worldwide.

The move is effective from January 1 when CIA will be charged with retaining Richemont's first class status among Europe's more discerning shoppers.

Previously, each of Richemont's brands worked with different media buyers on a local level.

webTitle: Brand aid: Heinz Tomato ketchup

fields.headline: Brand aid
fields.standfirst: Heinz Tomato Ketchup
fields.trailText: Claire Cozens reports on Heinz Tomato Ketchup's aims to be cool as well as the market leader.
fields.body:
What is it? A tomato-flavoured red gloop that has, for some reason, become the nation's favourite condiment. Heinz sells more than 120m bottles of the stuff in the UK every year.

So what's the problem? Well, nothing, really. Heinz Tomato Ketchup is the UK market leader with an impressive 58% share. But Heinz is not content with being popular - it wants to be cool as well. In fact, the food group has resolved to make its sauce "as famous as Coca-Cola".

And what is it doing about it? Launching a series of new labels bearing witty messages about the famous ketchup. The limited-edition bottles, available from the end of the month, look just like the real thing but carry lines such as Are Your French Fries Lonely? and Best Worn With Food. Sharon Ellis, category manager for Heinz Tomato Ketchup, says: "Heinz Tomato Ketchup is cool and confident. As one of the world's leading brands, it deserves the chance to speak up and show what a great sense of humour it has."

Marketing : Heinz recently briefed its ad agencies to target teenagers without alienating the rest of the population. Earlier this year the company launched a £30m global advertising campaign that played on the notoriously slow process of getting ketchup out of its bottle. "Heinz Tomato Ketchup won't come out until it's ready," said an actor in one ad. "No one knows what it does to get ready. It's not like it's putting on make-up or getting dressed, but it does seem to need some time." In July, Heinz announced plans to launch a green version of its ketchup in the US. The company expects the new sauce to be a hit on St Patrick's Day.

History: Heinz Tomato Ketchup was first made in 1876 in Pittsburgh. It arrived in the UK in 1886, when Fortnum and Mason began selling it, but it was not manufactured here until 1946. It achieved mass popularity in the late 1900s, when Henry J Heinz hit on the then novel idea of guaranteeing that his products did not contain artificial additives. It may be hard to believe, but Heinz's Ketchup has always been free of artificial colourings.

What about the competition: Daddies Ketchup has 6% of the market, the rest is own-label.

The future: Heinz caters for the fashion cognoscenti by launching black ketchup - the only colour to be seen eating.

webTitle: Wall reunited with Hollick

fields.headline: Wall reunited with Hollick
fields.trailText: 10am: Malcolm Wall, former chief executive of United Broadcasting & Entertainment, is rejoining United News & Media. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Malcolm Wall, former chief executive of United Broadcasting & Entertainment, has been reunited with his old boss Lord Hollick three weeks after he quit.

Mr Wall is rejoining Lord Hollick's United News & Media as chief operating officer and executive director from January 1.

He will be responsible for the business media companies that now form the core of United's business, following the sale of most of its TV interests and Express newspapers.

These include business-to-business media outfit CMP Media, market research company NOP and PR Newswire.

Mr Wall said: "United has gone through an incredible transformation over the past year and now has a brilliant future as one of the UK's most exciting media companies."

Mr Wall left Granada Media earlier this month after failing to find a suitable position within the company after the integration of United, which was sold to Granada Media.

The company is being renamed United Business Media to reflect its new focus on business communications as opposed to TV and newspapers.

Wall originally hooked up with Mr Hollick in 1992, who was then heading MAI, as one of the first employees of the company's newly formed TV division, which had just acquired the ITV Meridian franchise.

webTitle: New Deal to scour streets and set homeless to work

fields.headline: New Deal to scour streets and set homeless to work
fields.trailText: Drug addicts and the homeless will be rounded up by benefits advisers for the most radical expansion yet of Labour's programme to drive welfare claimants into work. Gaby Hinsliff reports.
fields.body:
Drug addicts and the homeless will be rounded up by benefits advisers for the most radical expansion yet of Labour's programme to drive welfare claimants into work.

Hostel places for rough sleepers could even be made conditional on joining job-preparation schemes, under plans being considered for Labour's second term.

But the proposal to target homeless people living in hostels was last night condemned by Louise Casey, the Government's homelessness tsar. 'You have to get people away from drugs and their problems before trying to get them to work. Forcing them on to the New Deal will not necessarily achieve this.'

New Deal personal advisers would be sent to shelters and on to the streets to find rough sleepers, alcoholics and others currently overlooked by the flagship welfare-to-work programme, in an effort to reach the hard core of Britain's underclass.

Initially, they would be offered benefits and help with housing, medical problems or illiteracy on voluntary grounds, before entering the New Deal proper.

'What we need to look at for this group is something like a pre-New Deal programme to address their needs, in order that they can get enough of their lives sorted to start even thinking about work,' said a senior source. It will be about personal advisers going out to people, rather than waiting for people to come to them.

'People who might be on incapacity benefit because of problems, or on no benefit at all, don't qualify for the New Deal, and that is another issue we have got to face.'

Tony Blair will this week announce that the election pledge to get 250,000 unemployed young people into work has officially been met.

Meanwhile, Social Security Secretary Alistair Darling will trumpet savings of £8 billion on unemployment benefits, thanks to the New Deal and fraud crackdowns.

But amid criticism that the Government has only skimmed off the 'easier' cases of relatively employable young people, Ministers are looking for ways to crack problems at the bottom of the pile. Benefits advisers are already due to be sent into GPs' surgeries to target those on long-term sick leave. And in future Ministers want personal advisers to find other hard-to-reach cases. The New Deal currently identifies those claiming jobseekers' allowance, but the chaotic lives of the most marginalised groups means they may not even be able to claim and so fall through the net.

A report from Labour's influential Social Exclusion Unit argues that, once a New Deal for the homeless is established, Ministers could eventually make hostel places dependent on participation.

Six ground-breaking pilot projects were set up in London last month offering help with housing, addiction treatment and careers advice to homeless people. They then pass on to the full New Deal, with options for the 18-24 age group of a job, training, voluntary work or benefit sanctions if they won't co-operate.

The first phase will target people attending job centres, but in future it is likely to use volunteer outreach workers to find rough sleepers. If the pilots work, they are expected to be extended nationally.

The charity Shelter gave a warning last night that, while it welcomed attempts to get the homeless back on their feet, compulsion would backfire. 'Our view is that compulsion can be counter-productive. We would want New Deal advisers to work in such a way that actually supports people and encourages them,' said a spokeswoman.

'Just saying to people "well, here's a job" will not necessarily be helpful.'

Research from the United States shows that its welfare-to-work schemes miss a hard core of about 10 per cent of their target audience - including lone parents who refuse to buckle under US benefit sanctions, drug addicts and rough sleepers.

But programmes teaching the so-called 'four Rs' - not just reading, writing and arithmetic, but 'readiness for work' skills like communication or punctuality - before entering work have had some success in the US, offering a model for the UK.

The standard New Deal will also emphasise 'work-readiness' skills to help candidates get better jobs with promotion prospects.

A key theme for Labour's next term will be not just getting people into work regardless, but creating 'good' jobs where employees are trained and treated well.

webTitle: The electoral ad campaign trail

fields.headline: Poster power
fields.standfirst: Who will really fight - and win - the next election?  Stephen Armstrong  follows the ad campaign trail
fields.trailText: Who will really fight - and win - the next election? Stephen Armstrong follows the ad campaign trail.
fields.body:
Imagine you work for an advertising agency. It is time for the worst brief you have ever had. You have to sell the public a product that they usually moan about and in which they can rarely see any point. You have about two months to do it and only get one opportunity to buy every five years. The client will think they know how to do the job better than you and a significant part of the national media will deride your work. Want the job? Doesn't pay much, by the way.

The new Labour poster campaign, based around the slogan "If you voted for change in 1997 - thank you", means that a May general election looks likely. The campaign has a touchy-feely feel. "Over 450,000 infants in smaller classes. That's down to me." And "I'm responsible for the lowest inflation for over 30 years." It's close to the Conservative Party's 1997 "Yes it hurt. Yes it worked" which sought to persuade us that the nation's weakness during a global downturn was part of their strategy for realigning the economy.

This is unusual in Labour's history of advertising. Obviously, that is partly because a Labour government has rarely looked close to winning a second term at this stage in office. But it is also because of the party's relationship with the ad world. For a start, since its inception most of the party has thought of advertising as the very devil. The Labour party has also had very little money to spend on election campaigns, and has usually relied on volunteers from Soho.

For much of the 80s the solution lay in the hands of the Shadow Communications Agency, a gang of creatives headed up by Chris Powell, the P in BMP. Powell himself has worked for the party since 1974. It was his agency, working on a conventional commercial basis for the first time, that steered the advertising campaign for the 1997 election.

"Actually, it was a bit of a nightmare," Powell says. "It was incredibly hard work running an election campaign full-time from the agency and the commercial relationship meant that we were at the party's beck and call rather than doing everything on a favour basis. After the election, we asked if we could go back to the old way of doing things, but the party is happy with the commercial set-up so they recruited another agency for the next election."

Since April, therefore, the party has placed its electoral life in the hands of Trevor Beattie and his agency TBWA as a result of a pitch overseen by Peter Mandelson.

Beattie's media shorthand form is the man who invented Wonderbra's Hello Boys ads and also did the FCUK campaign for French Connection. Less widely known is his work for women's charities on domestic violence. Beattie's intention was to use the softly-softly stuff to counter allegations that the government is arrogant and out of touch and then to move up a gear as the election approaches.

His preferred strategy is to counter public cynicism about politics by proving that not all parties are the same - the Tory party is worse than all the rest. "Labour's record in government is phenomenal but people don't like bragging so it's better to run a negative campaign," he says.

Over in Smith Square, the Tories are claiming that Labour's pre-pre-election campaign shows that the party is rattled. They claim the spend is roughly £1m and that the Labour party gained poster sites when an advertiser pulled out to allow them in. That's something of a pot-and-kettle situation as the Conservative campaign of 1992 was boosted when Imperial Tobacco handed over poster sites to the Saatchis for use in the election. (Of course, one thing no one mentioned at the time is that the Labour government banned tobacco advertising was that it would also deny the Tories any similar assistance in the future.)

There remains, however, something of a mystery over who the Conservatives will use to fight back against Beattie's blitz. Six months ago, the Newcastle and Edinburgh-based creative agency Yellow M landed the business.

Now adland is filled with rumours. Three London agencies recently claimed they had been approached by the Tories but the party has dismissed rumours that chairman Michael Ancram is unhappy with the agency.

The party says it has had positive feedback from Yellow M's October poster campaign which showed ordinary people feeling fed up with Labour under the strapline "Is this what you voted for?", in a eerie precursor to Beattie's campaign. Aside from this work, political analysts searching for a yardstick by which to measure Yellow M will have to look north of the border.

Yellow M fought the Scottish parliament campaign using guerrilla tactics such as installing a bed of nails in a hotel room to protest at tourist taxes, depicting Alex Salmond on a poster as the Teletubby La-La, and perching David McLetchie, the Scottish Tory leader, on top of a crushed car to moan about car taxes. It may not be "Labour isn't Working", but Ancram says he believes that Yellow M has the drive to become the Saatchi & Saatchi of the 21st century, pointing out that Saatchi & Saatchi was a young agency when it handled the Thatcher account.

However, Yellow M will not have the advantages enjoyed by the Saatchis: the spending rules will have changed for the next election. In 1997, an astonishing £30m was spent on political advertising, breaking down to £7m spent by the Labour party, £7m spent by the Referendum Party, £3m by the Lib Dems and a whopping £13m by the Tories.

"During the election, Maurice Saatchi basically told the Tories that they were in the shit but that if they gave him the money he could win the election for them," says one agency head. "They called a lot of favours in from overseas and spent like mad with absolutely no discernible effects on the opinion polls whatsoever. That's one of the reasons the party split with the agency."

It's also one of the reasons that this government acted to prevent such election spending ever happening again. The maximum any party can spend at a general election has been capped at £5m - still far above the Lib Dems' peak but a considerable restriction on the Conservative party which has always tended to spend the greatest amount on advertising. None the less, Michael Ashcroft, the party treasurer, is trying to raise £10m to fund the campaign.

webTitle: My media: Jacqueline Gold, chief executive of Ann Summers

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Jacqueline Gold, chief executive of Ann Summers
fields.trailText: By Jacqueline Gold, chief executive of Ann Summers
fields.body:
Newspapers: The Sun for football results and a quick news overview, the Express when I have more time, and occasionally the Guardian. I don't really have much time to read newspapers.

Magazines: Cosmopolitan for fashion and features - OK! for the latest celebrity gossip, glamour and what's going on. Health and Fitness because I like to take care of myself.

Books: Factual books and autobiographies. One of my favourites is The Jigsaw Man by Paul Britton, about how a criminal psychologist puts together a profile of a murderer. I'm a big fan of boxing and enjoyed a biography of Prince Naseem by Nick Pitt called Paddy and the Prince. I liked Bridget Jones and Does My Bum Look Big In This?.

Radio: Chris Tarrant in the morning on Capital Radio, a station that has won my loyalty. At work we listen to Heart FM, which appeals to everyone.

Films: I prefer actioners to slush. Gladiator was brilliant, though I had my head in my coat for the gory bits. I also loved The Silence of the Lambs for the detective element.

Television: I'm a footy fanatic, mostly via Sky Sports. I prefer watching the news - Sky again - to reading it. Overall, though, I prefer listening to music to either of those.

Adverts: Most people would say there are too many adverts, but one that's really caught my eye is for Heinz tomato soup, and shows a man and a woman making love. After two minutes you hear a microwave ding. It's really funny but a bit cruel on the guy, saying he's only lasted two minutes.

New media: Our very busy company website provides a more confidential and convenient service for our customers. I still get frustrated with the time it takes to get where you want to go on the internet. I'm into technology and don't know how I coped before mobile phones and email.

 Jacqueline Gold, chief executive of Ann Summers, appears on Back to the Floor (BBC2, Wednesday)

webTitle: Maggie Brown on more money for regional TV programming

fields.headline: Local shows for local people
fields.standfirst: With increasing evidence of regional viewing disparities, Maggie Brown applauds                                                                  Greg Dyke's decision to spend £50m on programmes aimed well away from                                                                  London.
fields.trailText: With increasing evidence of regional viewing disparities, Maggie Brown applauds Greg Dyke's decision to spend £50m on programmes aimed well away from London.
fields.body:
The BBC's governors agreed last week to the single biggest boost to new programme production - £50m a year - targeted at people living outside London and the south-east. The money, to be divided between Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and neglected parts of England, will be spent to woo audiences with new comedy (Ireland), a soap (Scotland), music, arts and drama (Wales), popular factual programmes and sports, all made specifically for local audiences by local talent.

These will be shown mostly in primetime BBC1 slots, substituting for poorly performing nationally networked programmes. The autumn has been dominated by the ratings war between ITV and the BBC.

But crude figures are disguising huge differences in regional audience tastes and a growing rejection of what is seen as programmes reflecting a metropolitan or south-east agenda. EastEnders has been taking an average share of 50% in recent weeks, but ranges from 56% in London and the south-east, to 42% in Northern Ireland and the north-west.

Conversely, The Royle Family took a 33% share overall, but scored 27% in London and 40% in the north-east. Coronation Street, with a recent average of 57% share, ranges from lows of 44% in the west of England to a peak 65% in the north-west.

Meanwhile when Chewin' the Fat, a hit BBC Scotland comedy series, is screened only in Scotland - the first series was later broadcast throughout the UK - it is winning audiences upwards of 45%, while Give My Head Peace, a breakthrough Northern Ireland sitcom about intertwined, dysfunctional Republican and Loyalist families, is also scoring over 45%.

No one is suggesting every success from the so-called "national regions" should be shown in London, just that there should be more backing for longer runs and for similar initiatives. In the Belfast headquarters of BBC Northern Ireland, controller Anna Carragher ticks off what makes her audience switch on - comedy, quiz shows, big films - and what makes them switch off - Never Mind the Buzzcocks and Have I Got News For You feature. Both BBC1 and BBC2 tend to underperform by about two percentage points on national averages in the region, which also receives services from the Republic, while multichannel homes are growing fast and ITV remains a firm favourite. "The further away from London you go, the market gets extremely competitive but different."

Comedy with a darker tone is, she says, a unifying thing, extremely important in a divided society ("we laugh at ourselves"), while her audience, with little tradition of growing up with BBC drama, love stand-up comedy, the culture which produced Patrick Kielty. Time Challenge, an It's a Knockout type of programme, is also a local favourite, while Radio Ulster, which mixes music, news and phone-ins has a stunning 35% share.

"Coronation Street is set in a northern industrial city, that ethos and culture has more in common with Belfast than the east end of London. Even the architecture is similar, parts look like Salford," Carragher muses. "There's a huge following for Manchester United, Liverpool, Celtic and Rangers. Supporters travel on the ferries frequently at weekends for the matches. We work very closely with BBC Scotland".

Patrick Loughrey, director of BBC regional broadcasting says: "Devolution was not just a political event, it's a cultural event too. Viewers are not an amorphous mass, we have to be more subtle, there are geographical factors at work."

In the past two years, the BBC has invested significantly to increase political coverage, with the start of new assemblies. Now comes the turn of entertainment. "We are convinced we can help the performance of BBC1 and BBC2 by investing," says Loughrey, the former controller of BBC Northern Ireland, who is giving sustained opportunities, through long runs, to indigenous talent, building up relationships.

Greg Dyke has already promised his most rebellious outpost a Scottish soap costing around £14m a year and due to launch by 2002, describing it as gritty and contemporary, more in the genre of Tinsel Town than Take the High Road.

webTitle: Did Who Wants to Be a Millionaire rig the big win?

fields.headline: Is that your final answer?
fields.standfirst: For £1m, did Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? rig the questions to get a jackpot winner?  Maggie Brown  quizzes the show's creator, Paul Smith
fields.trailText: For £1m, did Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? rig the questions to get a jackpot winner? Maggie Brown quizzes the show's creator, Paul Smith.
fields.body:
How much longer can Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? dominate our screens and continue to capture the public's imagination? "I don't know, I don't know," says Paul Smith, whose company, Celador, created the ITV series. "There will come a point when people begin to tire of it. It's bound to plateau. I think it's there now - the highest audience was £19.2m on a Sunday night 18 months ago . . . though it's being used differently by ITV now. Alan Yentob, BBC's director of drama and entertainment, described it as an Exocet missile. I don't say that with a sneer. It's virtually indestructible, but it won't last."

Smith, a fit-looking 53-year-old dressed in trainers and jeans, is full of compressed but genial energy. His other enduring contribution to ITV is the comic clips veteran, It'll Be All Right on the Night.

His office is at the top of a tall, thin townhouse in Long Acre, Covent Garden, where Celador and the ever-expanding team behind the show and its trail of merchandise are based. On the wall is a trophy, an amazing thing for British broadcasting, a framed Nielsen TV ratings chart for the week of February 9 2000, showing ABC's version of this British format taking the top four slots on American TV.

So, did Smith cheat to make Judith Keppel the first person to hit the jackpot on Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?, destroying Victor Meldrew's last bow over on BBC? "No, our producers don't cheat. No reason to. Truly, may I be struck down dead. Coincidence does take place." Keppel, he says, demonstrated what David Briggs, who devised most of the show's key features, always says: "To be successful you have to know a little about a lot, not a lot about a little" - the opposite of Mastermind.

"We've nothing to hide," Smith adds, opening up his desktop computer which holds the gritty details of every ITV Millionaire show - 122 to date. It logs the number of premium phonecalls made by contestants by day; the revenue raised (the cost of calls went up this autumn from 50p to 60p a minute); the prize money won in each programme - and the size of the remaining prize fund. And there's a stunning entry: after last Monday's £1m win, ITV had to pay in £1.5m first thing on Tuesday, to honour Keppel's cheque.

On Monday as news of the win leaked, Celador received 138,000 calls, raising £69,396 towards the prize fund. After 27 months on air, there have been 5.87m calls. Demand is down from the 300,000 callers for the first shows - hence the rise to 60p a minute - although that didn't stop one couple making 700 calls on a recent Sunday. So far the programme has paid out £5.35m prize money, and ITV has paid in £3.1m. The prize fund, post Keppel, stands at £407,000. "The idea that ITV is creaming off money is offensive," says Smith.

Celador has installed a permanent set at Elstree film studios and ITV pays a production fee of around £100,000 per edition. When the programme started, Smith said insurers were beating a path to Celador's door, and for a premium of £40,000 a year they were able to insure themselves against several £1m pound winners draining prize funds. Not now. Smith says the show became uninsurable before Keppel. In the US, there have been six millionaire winners, so the broadcaster claimed the money from the insurers making it uninsurable. (There have been other millionaire winners: one in Portugal, one in South Africa, two in France, one in Spain). "There is a learning curve," observes Smith. "The average [UK] winnings are higher than a year ago, by £8,000. It was about £48,000 per person this autumn, before the £1m win. Now it's £83,000."

Is there a point at which the rise in winnings makes the show unsustainable? "Yes, I'm sure there is. I don't know what it is. The cost of the show now (with the prize money) is nearing £200,000" for ITV. But that is still cheaper than making an hour of original drama or comedy. The obvious ploy is to make the questions harder, so winnings fall, but that would ruin the accessible fun of it. "There are a lot of serious players out there. It's the focus of their lives, like the lottery, but it's a game of skill, not luck. People making the calls, they really want to go into the chair, for a variety of reasons.

"I was at home watching TV when it [Keppel's win] happened, on Sunday. I was called by our head of entertainment, Colman Hutchinson, who said, 'There's a lady in the chair and she's going for £1m, we know she's got it right. Do you want to stay on the line?' I said, 'No, enjoy the moment.'"

So what about the controversy over the timing of the win? "Our figures are absolutely solid. The suggestion is that we had to [have a winner] because we wanted to beat the last edition of One Foot in the Grave. We were already beating them."

But were the questions tailored? There were no questions for Keppel on sport. "The simple answer is that it would be possible for us to choose questions, but we don't. But if we decided to, we could only make a value judgment based on someone we'd met a couple of hours before, and the likelihood that we would be successful in taking them through a route of 15 questions . . . well we'd be very clever to do so. Whatever happens, the rules are that the computer selects the 15 questions from 15 (out of 40) different categories, so the likelihood is that there will be a category you don't know anything about. It was not rigged at all.

"The point about Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? is that it doesn't use the conventions of quiz shows and game shows, where selection is the judgment of the producer or researcher. We're not allowed to. This is a competition people pay an entry fee to participate in. Everyone must be treated equally. When we conceived the show, we thought that would be a problem, but it's become a virtue. The wonderful thing is we do get such a diverse range of individuals. Some wonderful, some quite tedious.

But at the end of the March series, we analysed the people who got through as the 10 finalists and then to the seat, and by a stroke of luck it followed a perfect pattern - it was totally representative regionally. It was luck because we can't engineer it."

And as soon as someone has won it, there is the reaffirmation that, yes, it can be done. The £1m prize has nothing to do with people watching, it's what I call the billboard, what attracts people initially. But if the substance of the show had been rubbish people would not have watched it, even if we gave away £10m. webTitle: Cybercrime: Invasion of the identity snatchers

fields.headline: Invasion of the identity snatchers
fields.standfirst: One of Britain's leading record producers had his name stolen by a conman using the internet. Jonathan Maitland reports on the latest form of cybercrime
fields.trailText: One of Britain's leading record producers had his name stolen by a conman using the internet. Jonathan Maitland reports on the latest form of cybercrime.
fields.body:
Steve Levine first realised something Very Strange Indeed was happening at 3.20pm on Thursday November 9. That was when he picked up the phone to be told by Stephen Budd, his manager: "You've got an impostor."

Levine, one of Britain's most successful record producers (he counts Culture Club, The Beach Boys and The Honeyz among his credits) didn't take it too seriously at first. "We actually had a laugh about it," he says. "It was only when I went back to work that the consequences began to sink in. That was when it got scary."

At that stage, he knew only a few facts: a man, passing himself off as Steve Levine, had negotiated a production deal with a would-be pop star in America. It had all gone sour and the pop star's lawyers had taken up the cudgels on their client's behalf. They had tracked down (the real) Levine's manager in England. Hence that fateful phone call.

That Thursday night was to be the first of several sleepless ones for Levine. After spending 14 hours on the phone to the States, a fuller picture had emerged. "The guy had been wreaking havoc in my name," says Levine. "It turned out he'd been introducing himself to several people in the business over there and trying to do deals with them. I'm almost certain he got money out of them. It seems he's left a trail of very important, very pissed off people behind him, who now think Steve Levine is a bullshitter and a fraud. He's in danger of destroying my career, my reputation: that's everything I've worked for over the past 25 years."

Levine isn't exaggerating: if you're a record producer, your reputation is your most valuable asset. Big money deals are often signed on the basis of a producer's name alone. Levine's current project, for example, a young male duo called Hush, only came his way after someone recommended him to the boys' parents. They were impressed by Levine's reputation: he was a man they could trust. It's this reputation that the fake Levine has been exploiting: the worry now is that he may have destroyed it.

Levine has the dubious distinction of being the first known victim of the newest form of cybercrime: identity snatching. It is a cunning and insidious variation on cyber squatting: unscrupulous net "entrepreneurs" buy the domain rights to famous people's names and then exploit them for financial gain. (Zoë Ball is a classic example: last year cyber squatters set up a website with mocked-up pornographic pictures of her on it.)

But identity snatching is more sinister and more sophisticated than mere cyber squatting: the fraudsters aren't just taking their victims' names and images, they're stealing their entire personalities and careers. And people like Levine are particularly susceptible. This is because while their names and achievements may be well known within certain circles, their faces are not. Which means it's much easier for the fraudsters to get away with it.

Levine is in no doubt that his impostor used the web as the basis of his deceit: "My entire CV and career details were on three different websites," he says. "All the bloke had to do was to type my name into a search engine, and he had it all there in front of him: everything he needed to know. There are things he's told people that he can only have learned from my details on the web."

(The horse may have bolted but none the less, Levine has shut the stable door: he's removed his personal details from his own website, www.stevelevine.co.uk, and replaced them with a contact address - info@record-producers.com - and his picture.)

What should worry well-known - but not famous - professionals everywhere, is the ease with which this scam was perpetrated; and the potentially catastrophic fallout it could entail.

"All I can do now is try and limit some of the damage he's caused, but it's going to be difficult," says a tired looking Levine. "The music business, like most creative industries, runs on gossip: if one person out there is bad-mouthing me, and saying 'Don't touch Levine with a bargepole', then word soon gets round. Rumours are very powerful things, unfortunately."

Levine, however, is fighting back, using the only weapons he has: words. "I'm hoping this article will start tilting the balance back in my favour," he says. "My impostor has been using cyberspace to get what he wants but I'm banking on good old- fashioned printed words to redress the balance."

Defiant he may be, then, but Levine is also a little frightened: it is psychologically unsettling, to say the least, to know that someone has stolen your persona. And he is also concerned about practical issues. His legal bills are mounting up. Frustratingly, he knows the money could well turn out to be wasted. "There's no guarantee that they'll catch this guy, and even if they do, it may be too late, in terms of the damage he's already done."

Only one thing, he says, could cure the frustrating powerlessness he now feels. He would love to come face to face with his cyber alter ego on a dark night. "Not very constructive I know: but it would make me feel a whole lot better."

webTitle: Over-50s rail at TV stereotyping

fields.headline: Over-50s rail at TV stereotyping
fields.trailText: 9.15am: Older people resent being stereotyped as either grumpy or sweet in TV comedy and drama, according to a new survey, writes Jason Deans
fields.body:
Just days after curmudgeonly Victor Meldrew was killed off and Inspector Morse had a fatal heart attack, a new survey has found that older people resent being stereotyped as either grumpy or sweet in TV comedy and drama.

The study of the over-50s also found a lack of interest among older audiences in programmes specifically aimed at them.

And it found that older viewers believe that over-50s were under-represented on TV programmes aimed at mass audiences.

The advertising industry in particular is criticised by 50-somethings for portraying a narrow, idealised version of consumers.

People in the 50-60 age group felt strongly that advertisers should change their attitudes and the images they use during the next five to 10 years to reflect the profile of their changing market.

The survey, Age in the Frame, which was drawn from the results of focus group sessions is published today by the Independent Television Commission and Age Concern England.

While many over-50s enjoyed One Foot in the Grave, they found it unfortunate that Victor Meldrew's grumpy character was the best-known old person on TV.

Last of the Summer Wine also came in for criticism, though again some older people said they still found it funny.

But one focus group participant described the long-running sitcom as "patronising".

He said: "It's just a bunch of daft old gits running around and fancying a woman with wrinkled stockings around her ankles."

The report found that older viewers resent being pigeon-holed as the Songs of Praise generation, when they have a wide range of interests and viewing habits.

One respondent said: "We like the same things we liked when we were younger. I like The Royle Family and Have I Got News For You just like my grandson."

A lady in her 60s added that she liked "a good violent American thriller. The type of thing with Al Pacino in it".

Over half of over-65s, and 40% of over-50s, thought there should be more older people on TV, with a belief that older women are particularly under-represented.

webTitle: Simon Hoggart at the parliamentarian of the year awards

fields.headline: Better than a knighthood
fields.standfirst: Simon Hoggart reports from this year's parliamentarian of the year awards.
fields.trailText: Simon Hoggart reports from this year's parliamentarian of the year awards.
fields.body:
The annual presentation of the Spectator/Highland Park parliamentarian of the year awards at the Savoy hotel went well this year. As they always do. The magazine's editor, Boris Johnson, who will almost certainly be a Tory MP this time next year (though perhaps not instantly an award-winner), was magnificently Borisovian, part of his continuing attempt to turn himself into one of the great characters of English fiction.

Ken Livingstone, whom Boris called Godzilla, was conceited in his attractively dry way, and Ted Heath announced that he would not be going to the House of Lords. The reason, we assume, is that there is a special ex-prime ministers' bench. He wouldn't mind sitting next to Jim Callaghan, but never buttock-to-buttock with Lady Thatcher.

As one of the judges, I was once again surprised and gratified by how seriously the winners take these gongs. I genuinely think that for many MPs they rank somewhere between a knighthood and a junior government post. Recently, to my astonishment, I watched a cabinet minister weep gently after receiving his award - and I don't think it was just the effect of the sponsor's whisky.

Several weeks before the Savoy, a dozen of us political dinosaurs lumber into the upstairs room of the Gay Hussar Hungarian restaurant for boar's head salad and roast goose. There is little cosy or clubby about the discussion. "I honestly don't think we can give an award to someone for whom English is clearly a second language." "Your loyalty to a friend is admirable, but the fact that he gets pissed with you doesn't make him any bloody good." These are not Wildean ripostes, but they illustrate the depth of feeling that goes into the two-hour debate.

Elinor Goodman of Channel 4 news, usually the only female judge, often takes umbrage at the Spectator's political editor, Bruce Anderson, known universally - mostly to his face - as The Beast. Once he described a woman MP as "looking like a stoat's snatch". Elinor replied angrily, but coolly, "Do you spend much time looking at that part of a stoat, Bruce?"

To be fair to The Beast, four years ago he bullied us into giving Minister of the Year to the little known but much-reviled Ann Widdecombe, on the grounds that she had spent years doing Michael Howard's dirty work. It was a daring choice, since she was already something of a joke - but a joke we now take seriously.

It's not always easy. By the end of a parliament, we have usually picked over the best talent. And sometimes the Member To Watch category becomes the Member To Explode. Long before my own time, the judges spotted Donald Dewar, Charles Kennedy, and in 1988 an obscure backbencher called Tony Blair.

But other choices have been much less felicitous. David Mellor won in 1991. And the annual menu still confesses that in 1987 the panel chose Jonathan Aitken, following up this triumph in 1988 with Neil Hamilton.

Wednesday's speeches maintained the generally non-party spirit: only one recipient, Backbencher of the Year Andrew Tyrie, mentioned wallpaper to the guest of honour, Lord Irvine, although Boris did chip in: "That's right!" In 1998, however, John Prescott was definitely not gruntled to find he had to hand the top award to William Hague: "High on humour, but low on facts," as he called him.

To be fair to The Beast, four years ago he bullied us into giving Minister of the Year to the little known but much-reviled Ann Widdecombe, on the grounds that she had spent years doing Michael Howard's dirty work. It was a daring choice, since she was already something of a joke - but a joke we now take seriously. It's not always easy. By the end of a parliament, we have usually picked over the best talent. And sometimes the Member To Watch category becomes the Member To Explode. Long before my own time, the judges spotted Donald Dewar, Charles Kennedy, and in 1988 an obscure backbencher called Tony Blair. But other choices have been much less felicitous. David Mellor won in 1991. And the annual menu still confesses that in 1987 the panel chose Jonathan Aitken, following up this triumph in 1988 with Neil Hamilton. Wednesday's speeches maintained the generally non-party spirit: only one recipient, Backbencher of the Year Andrew Tyrie, mentioned wallpaper to the guest of honour, Lord Irvine, although Boris did chip in: "That's right!" In 1998, however, John Prescott was definitely not gruntled to find he had to hand the top award to William Hague: "High on humour, but low on facts," as he called him.

webTitle: The strange world of Japan's chatshows

fields.headline: How to avoid making an **** of yourself on TV
fields.standfirst: The TV chatshow may be predictable but at least it's safe - compared to how the Japanese do it, says  Mark Borkowski
fields.trailText: The TV chatshow may be predictable but at least it's safe - compared to how the Japanese do it, says Mark Borkowski.
fields.body:
Nobody in the UK is so daft as to think that celebrities appear on chatshows because they are intrinsically interesting. What is interesting is the work they are doing; and if they are doing nothing, they are not interesting so they don't appear on chatshows.

Chatshows should be subtitled like QVC, the shopping channel: name of the product/show, price, central telephone number to order or dates and times to watch. That would remove all the tortuous fencing as Clive Anderson pantomimes protest at Goldie Hurley Harrison Willis's charming but ploddingly obvious attempts to bring the casual conversation round to the release of Lethal Blair Gladiator VII.

This is minor nitpicking. Chatshows in Britain are civilised affairs, fully comprehensible to the guests, working within clear stylistic parameters. You know you will be fawned over by Richard and Judy, you will be asked to suck four different kinds of vibrator by Graham Norton, Clive Anderson will insult you, and you will have to listen to Frank Skinner talking about Frank Skinner.

You know what you are letting yourself in for - and the chat and publicity process rolls forward happily for all. News from the other side of the world, however, is not so good. Gavin Robertson and Andrew Dawson wobbled into my office the other week. As the stars of the live and life-size stage version of Thunderbirds FAB (they do the show with spaceships stuck to their heads), they had just returned from a long tour of Japan.

The Japanese, they tell me, are frighteningly, interminably polite. After each show, they were mobbed by a long and orderly queue of bowing autograph hunters. They found these scrupulous good manners touching, but wearing. The downside is that - in the tabloid TV media at least - they take huge delight in being incomprehensibly vile and violent towards each other, and this extends to chatshows.

They arrived at the studios of Fuji TV to take part in a prime-time, early evening programme which they remember was called Ooga Rooga (phonetically). Following a two-minute briefing, they were dumped into the studio for the live broadcast.

They were introduced to the host, grabbed a quick chance to slip in a plug for their show in the 30 seconds available, and were then dispatched to sit on a judging panel made up of celebrity guests.

Members of the audience came up to do comedy routines. Anyone on the celebrity panel who laughed was immediately stuffed inside a plastic booth, which had a plastic arse, four feet in diameter, pointing into it, and was subjected to a 20-second squirt of sulphurous yellow gas.

It was the most perplexing promotional experience they had ever undergone: an inverse gong-show that humiliated celebrities on the back of performances by talentless punters. There is no conceivable explanation for this.

As Scott and Virgil Tracy, Gavin and Andrew fearlessly save the universe from the potentially unpleasant attentions of Mars-based Mysterons in the thrall of Mr X. But as two actors out to make a quiet living, after two weeks in Japan they were terrified of watching TV, let alone appearing on it. The farting arse was just one of a series of charming PR opportunities strewn before them. They were interviewed in a hot tub. Two goons with buckets of boiling water kept raising the temperature, and as long as they could stand the heat, they could say what they wanted about their show.

Other essential props for the ambitious chatshow host in Japan include cockroaches and rats (talk up your new show from a glass box filled with insects and vermin), and water, jelly, and - preposterously - buckets of toothpaste. Relax on a sofa of nails, warm your arse on a hot seat, and - in one case - string yourself upside down from the studio ceiling.

Perhaps achieving abject public humiliation on a regular basis is the mark of a true star on the Japanese celebrity circuit. In which case, Gavin and Andrew simply can't cut it out east. But curiously, Thunderbirds FAB attracted excellent reviews during its run; more curious still, after enduring the hysterical baying of TV studio audiences, the audiences at the live shows saw it as their duty to maintain a dignified silence throughout the performance. Only when it was explained to them that they were permitted to laugh did they do so, and then with a vengeance.

There is one interesting possibility that emerges from this Japanese approach to conducting interviews, and I will be talking to Jeremy Paxman later today.

webTitle: Blair plans ministry for the poor

fields.headline: Blair plans ministry for the poor
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is considering the creation of a Department for Social Inclusion, headed by a cabinet minister, to spearhead a revived anti-poverty drive in the most deprived areas if Labour wins a second term.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is considering the creation of a Department for Social Inclusion, headed by a cabinet minister, to spearhead a revived anti-poverty drive in the most deprived areas if Labour wins a second term.

The formation of the Whitehall ministry to coordinate policies intended to help the "underclass" is under discussion within Downing Street as the prime minister considers what should be in Labour's election manifesto.

Mr Blair plans to make poverty a key election issue, a commitment that would be welcomed in Labour's heartlands and establish clear blue water between the government and Tory leader William Hague.

A No 10 official said the new ministry would be carved out of John Prescott's sprawling Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions.

Hilary Armstrong, minister for local government and the regions in the department, who is highly rated by the prime minister, has been tipped in government circles for promotion to the post.

The department would take over and expand the role of the cabinet office's social exclusion unit and work closely with other ministries, including social security, health and education, as well as the Treasury.

The department would be named social inclusion rather than social exclusion to put the emphasis on positive efforts. It could be responsible for community regeneration and town hall affairs.

The environment department classifies 1,370 estates as "run down" and suffering from multiple problems including high unemployment, bad housing, low education standards and ill health.

Establishing the department would be seen as an acknowledgment that the social exclusion unit has not been as successful as the prime minister envisaged, as well as evidence of Mr Blair's commitment to tackling poverty.

Headed by Moira Wallace, a former Treasury high-flyer and Downing Street private secretary, the social exclusion unit is staffed by some 40 of the brightest civil servants.

A string of studies and initiatives, including an £800m neighbourhood renewal scheme, have been produced but the unit has been the vic tim of "turf wars" with departments.

A review last year by cabinet office officials and KPMG consultants concluded the unit's work "has been on the whole less enthusiastically received inside government than outside".

Appointing a cabinet minister to run a new department, said the No 10 official, would "send a clear signal to the rest of Whitehall as well as the country at large that Labour is serious about ending social deprivation and exclusion".

With an election expected in May after Labour's three byelection victories last week, a decision on whether to create the department could be taken early in the new year.

Mr Blair has shown a marked reluctance to reform Whitehall but setting up a social inclusion department would partly undo one of the changes he did introduce after merging the environment and transport departments.

Created specifically for Mr Prescott as deputy prime minister after the last election, it faces another shake-up after the next election. In addition to the possibility of urban affairs being transferred to a new department, Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, believes the eight regional development agencies would fit into the Department of Trade and Industry.

Some ministers in other departments believe the environment and transport portfolios should be separated to reduce the department to a manageable scale while others think they should remain united.

Ms Armstrong and Mr Prescott have clashed over English elected mayors, which she is keener on than he is, and regional government. She was slapped down by her boss in public early this year after voicing doubts about English regional assemblies.

Some advisers close to the environment department, who could see the logic of an all-embracing department when it was formed, now believe it is running out of time because it is too big.

One longstanding Westminster ally of Mr Prescott said: "John has had to deal with flak from N0 10, and its policy wonks, while pulling together a lot of other things, and frankly he's knackered. After the election we all expect he'll move on to something else, maybe the party chairmanship, while keeping his deputy's role in the cabinet."

webTitle: 'It's over. We have a winner'

fields.headline: 'It's over. We have a winner'
fields.standfirst: Special report: US election race
fields.trailText: She has been vilified as Cruella de Vil and tipped to be an ambassador to the court of St James if George W Bush takes the presidency. Last night all eyes were on the secretary of state for Florida as she entered the cabinet room in the Capitol building to make her dramatic announcement.
fields.body:
She has been vilified as Cruella de Vil and tipped to be an ambassador to the court of St James if George W Bush takes the presidency. Last night all eyes were on the secretary of state for Florida as she entered the cabinet room in the Capitol building to make her dramatic announcement.

Katherine Harris, flanked by her sober-suited colleagues on the state election canvassing commission, made a striking figure in a red jacket as she entered the room to the clicking of camera shutters.

There had been great interest in the election, said Ms Harris, 43, the circus heiress who has been thrust into prominence by her role as the state official effectively charged with anointing her friend and colleague as the next president of the United States. For that reason the media had been invited into the heart of the state government to hear the result. She explained that Palm Beach had presented her with two counts and that she was taking the previous machine recount of 14 November.

She then took part in a certification process in which a solicitous official handed various documents to her, much as a waiter at the George V in Paris might proffer the wine list to an esteemed client. The press, who had been waiting for more than two hours for the ceremony, speculated among themselves whether she was going to announce the result and whether she would be rewarded with Paris or London as the ambassadorship she is said to seek.

Finally she looked up and read out the result: George W Bush 2,912,790, Al Gore 2,912,253. "I hereby declare governor George W Bush the winner of Florida's 25 electoral votes for the president of the United States."

No calculators were required to work out that Mr Bush was still ahead. Cheers could be heard from outside where hundreds had gathered throughout the day with placard-wielding Republicans outnumbering Democrats in this rather reserved little town by around four to one.

Bob Crawford, the Democrat commissioner of agriculture and Bush supporter who sits on the commission with Ms Harris, said: "This has been a tough election. It has not always been pretty _ After all the jokes, I think it's over. It should be over. We have a winner."

Ms Harris smiled once more for the cameras as she thanked the "thousands of people throughout the country" for their "letters, faxes, flowers and emails and ... especially for their prayers."

Ms Harris paused. "The true winner is the rule of law. Thank you and may God bless America."
