webTitle: The decline of tabloid political cartoonists

fields.headline: Art of the political hit job
fields.standfirst: Is the writing on the wall for tabloid political cartoonists? For serious lampooning, editors now prefer to use photomontage, says John Dugdale.
fields.trailText: Is the writing on the wall for tabloid political cartoonists? For serious lampooning, editors now prefer to use potomontage, says John Dugdale.
fields.body:
Britain's cartoonists meet for their annual awards ceremony on Wednesday and they are entitled to feel that in the broadsheet press the political cartoon has rarely, perhaps never, been in such good shape. The specialists in full-size visual commentary - the Guardian's Steve Bell and Martin Rowson, the Observer's Chris Riddell, the Times's Peter Brookes and the Independent's Dave Brown - alone constitute a squad unrivalled even in the satirical 60s, the heyday of Scarfe and Steadman.

But here is a tricky test: can you name a single political cartoonist on a daily national tabloid? Only if you see one of these papers regularly are you likely to remember, probably after prompting, that the Mail boasts Mac and Mahood, the Express Paul Thomas, the Sun Dave Gaskill and the Mirror Tom Johnston. These are not exactly names to conjure with, and ploughing through a week's worth of their work suggests why: a genuinely imaginative tabloid cartoon is as rare as a female cartoonist.

Out of close to 50 images, only Thomas's drawing of Putin and Blair boozily discussing women - the latter drooling about Thatcher - struck me as fresh in conception and distinctive in technique. The Mail on Sunday's Heath is by far the most original stylist on the tabloids, but his talents seem unsuited to the single-joke requirements of the commentary page cartoon.

But you don't have to believe me: believe their editors. While in the quality press single cartoons still occupy their time-honoured slots - "pocket" gags on the front page, bigger images at the op-ed heart of the paper - they have been marginalised in the pops. Since the mid-market titles went tabloid, none of the national dailies has found room on the front page for a pocket cartoon (the nearest equivalents are Mahood's stamp-size offerings in the Mail, which cling on precariously at the foot of page two).

And only the Express still regularly puts its cartoonist amid its leaders and rent-a-rant opinion articles - the Mail banishes amiable, apolitical Mac from the feral arena where Paul Johnson and Simon Heffer roar and paw the ground to the grey wasteland of page 15, while the Sun varies the cartoon's position from day to day, sometimes dropping it altogether, and the Star rarely runs one. In the Sundays, the Sunday Mirror also opts out, the People has no cartoonist of its own and the News of the World's Charles Griffin is confined to illustrating Sion Simon's on-message musings.

Most eccentric of all is the Mirror, which eschews the usual sizeable cartoon in favour of a vertical strip of four separate, smaller efforts, all by Tom Johnston. With this Stakhanovite producing 28 gags per week (he also labours for the People) quality inevitably suffers. Editors traditionally choose the best joke from "roughs" presented by the cartoonist; here, instead, the roughs all make it on to the page, with weak and passable ideas run indiscriminately side by side.

Still, these jokesmiths can at least not be accused of betraying a distinguished tradition, for the fact is that a great cartoonist, at the top of his form, has never worked on a popular national daily. Neither of the two giants who dominated the decades between the 30s and the 60s, Low and Vicky, did so. David Low, the New Zealand-born creator of Colonel Blimp, was unsettled during his brief period (1949-52) on the Labour-controlled Daily Herald, despite his left-wing views. His final years were spent on the then Man chester Guardian and his devastating attacks on Hitler and militarism were produced while on Beaverbrook's Evening Standard.

The German-Hungarian emigré Vicky, also a socialist, was similarly unhappy when working in the 50s for a Daily Mirror then selling 5m copies per day, worried that he could no longer influence the powerful. His best work appeared in the Standard, the New Statesman and - throughout the 30s and 40s - the News Chronicle, a Liberal paper with a circulation of 1-1.5m.

Both men, however, were popular cartoonists, producing simple, potent images and backing the underdog against menacing tyrants abroad and amoral arms traders and a fossilised establishment at home. There was nothing subtle or arty about "Very Well, Alone", Low's 1940 image of Churchillian defiance, or Vicky's Macmillan as "Supermac".

Similarly, Steve Bell's versions of Major, Hague and Prescott are not inherently "broadsheet" in style - and tabloid editors would give up their chauffeur-driven cars to get their hands on them. But the fact that they appeared in the Guardian says a lot about trends in political caricature over the intervening years. With no significant successor emerging in the popular press since Vicky quit the Mirror, if someone asks you if you saw a cartoon in one of the tabloids, they almost certainly mean a strip cartoon (even in that genre standards have declined markedly, with most funnies pages combining strips past their sell-by dates with desperate attempts to extract humour from sex and football).

In the broadsheets, meanwhile, the decisive figure was Gerald Scarfe, who signalled a return to the viciousness of Rowlandson and Gillray with such memorably grotesque 60s work as his Private Eye depiction of Labour's supine backing of the US during the Vietnam war: Harold Wilson, tongue lolling, is preparing to lick the arse of LBJ, who observes: "I've heard of a special relationship, but this is ridiculous." In moving from the Eye to the Sunday Times, Scarfe foreshadowed the way today's stars typically hone their art in work for magazines with niche readerships before making the jump to broadsheet titles: Bell, for example, made his name in the London listings press and the New Statesman before joining the Guardian. Not content with starting two trends, Scarfe also pioneered full-colour sculptural caricatures photographed for magazine covers - a technique also adopted by Fluck and Law, who later reworked it into the television series Spitting Image.

What Scarfe, the supreme draughtsman, could not have foreseen in the 60s was that this shift away from drawn caricature would play a major part in sapping the health of the traditional cartoon. Various diagnoses of the present malaise are possible, including the bewildering changes of political stance by all the tabloids since the rise of New Labour and a (clearly related) general failure to produce an image of Tony Blair as indelible as Bell's John Major as anti-Superman - a distant, mocking echo of Vicky's Supermac - with baggy Y-fronts worn outside his trousers. Overridingly, though, Spitting Image and the new, merciless style of caricature that produced it have made the old-fashioned approach look pallid and impotent.

If a tabloid editor today wants a major front page or op-ed page political hit job, he no longer orders a drawn image à la Low and Vicky. Instead he turns to another tradition, also generated by the anti-fascist and anti-war struggles of the 20s and 30s: photo-montage. The Sun's jeering stunts - Kinnock with a lightbulb head; Hague as a parrot; and, on the back page, Graham Taylor as a turnip - were mimicked in Thursday's Mirror by Sun alumnus Piers Morgan, depicting Hague as Thatcher's poodle.

The whole concept was itself ironically poodle-like, dutifully echoing Blair's Commons attack on Wednesday, and the execution was gratingly crude. But tabloid political cartoonists will not have missed its subtext: for them, the writing is on the wall.

And only the Express still regularly puts its cartoonist amid its leaders and rent-a-rant opinion articles - the Mail banishes amiable, apolitical Mac from the feral arena where Paul Johnson and Simon Heffer roar and paw the ground to the grey wasteland of page 15, while the Sun varies the cartoon's position from day to day, sometimes dropping it altogether, and the Star rarely runs one. In the Sundays, the Sunday Mirror also opts out, the People has no cartoonist of its own and the News of the World's Charles Griffin is confined to illustrating Sion Simon's on-message musings. Most eccentric of all is the Mirror, which eschews the usual sizeable cartoon in favour of a vertical strip of four separate, smaller efforts, all by Tom Johnston. With this Stakhanovite producing 28 gags per week (he also labours for the People) quality inevitably suffers. Editors traditionally choose the best joke from "roughs" presented by the cartoonist; here, instead, the roughs all make it on to the page, with weak and passable ideas run indiscriminately side by side. Still, these jokesmiths can at least not be accused of betraying a distinguished tradition, for the fact is that a great cartoonist, at the top of his form, has never worked on a popular national daily. Neither of the two giants who dominated the decades between the 30s and the 60s, Low and Vicky, did so. David Low, the New Zealand-born creator of Colonel Blimp, was unsettled during his brief period (1949-52) on the Labour-controlled Daily Herald, despite his left-wing views. His final years were spent on the then Man chester Guardian and his devastating attacks on Hitler and militarism were produced while on Beaverbrook's Evening Standard. The German-Hungarian emigré Vicky, also a socialist, was similarly unhappy when working in the 50s for a Daily Mirror then selling 5m copies per day, worried that he could no longer influence the powerful. His best work appeared in the Standard, the New Statesman and - throughout the 30s and 40s - the News Chronicle, a Liberal paper with a circulation of 1-1.5m. Both men, however, were popular cartoonists, producing simple, potent images and backing the underdog against menacing tyrants abroad and amoral arms traders and a fossilised establishment at home. There was nothing subtle or arty about "Very Well, Alone", Low's 1940 image of Churchillian defiance, or Vicky's Macmillan as "Supermac". Similarly, Steve Bell's versions of Major, Hague and Prescott are not inherently "broadsheet" in style - and tabloid editors would give up their chauffeur-driven cars to get their hands on them. But the fact that they appeared in the Guardian says a lot about trends in political caricature over the intervening years. With no significant successor emerging in the popular press since Vicky quit the Mirror, if someone asks you if you saw a cartoon in one of the tabloids, they almost certainly mean a strip cartoon (even in that genre standards have declined markedly, with most funnies pages combining strips past their sell-by dates with desperate attempts to extract humour from sex and football). In the broadsheets, meanwhile, the decisive figure was Gerald Scarfe, who signalled a return to the viciousness of Rowlandson and Gillray with such memorably grotesque 60s work as his Private Eye depiction of Labour's supine backing of the US during the Vietnam war: Harold Wilson, tongue lolling, is preparing to lick the arse of LBJ, who observes: "I've heard of a special relationship, but this is ridiculous." In moving from the Eye to the Sunday Times, Scarfe foreshadowed the way today's stars typically hone their art in work for magazines with niche readerships before making the jump to broadsheet titles: Bell, for example, made his name in the London listings press and the New Statesman before joining the Guardian. Not content with starting two trends, Scarfe also pioneered full-colour sculptural caricatures photographed for magazine covers - a technique also adopted by Fluck and Law, who later reworked it into the television series Spitting Image. What Scarfe, the supreme draughtsman, could not have foreseen in the 60s was that this shift away from drawn caricature would play a major part in sapping the health of the traditional cartoon. Various diagnoses of the present malaise are possible, including the bewildering changes of political stance by all the tabloids since the rise of New Labour and a (clearly related) general failure to produce an image of Tony Blair as indelible as Bell's John Major as anti-Superman - a distant, mocking echo of Vicky's Supermac - with baggy Y-fronts worn outside his trousers. Overridingly, though, Spitting Image and the new, merciless style of caricature that produced it have made the old-fashioned approach look pallid and impotent. If a tabloid editor today wants a major front page or op-ed page political hit job, he no longer orders a drawn image à la Low and Vicky. Instead he turns to another tradition, also generated by the anti-fascist and anti-war struggles of the 20s and 30s: photo-montage. The Sun's jeering stunts - Kinnock with a lightbulb head; Hague as a parrot; and, on the back page, Graham Taylor as a turnip - were mimicked in Thursday's Mirror by Sun alumnus Piers Morgan, depicting Hague as Thatcher's poodle. The whole concept was itself ironically poodle-like, dutifully echoing Blair's Commons attack on Wednesday, and the execution was gratingly crude. But tabloid political cartoonists will not have missed its subtext: for them, the writing is on the wall.

webTitle: Florida declares Bush the winner after recount

fields.headline: Florida declares Bush the winner after recount
fields.standfirst:
Gore refuses to give in despite official declaration of 537-vote majority

Special report: US elections
fields.trailText: Gore refuses to give in despite official declaration of 537-vote majority
fields.byline: Martin Kettle  in Washington and Duncan Campbell  in Tallahassee
fields.body:
George W Bush was early today declared the winner in Florida - and stood on the threshold of the White House after the most fiercely disputed presidential election in more than a century.

Nineteen days after polling day, the local secretary of state, Katherine Harris, certified a Republican victory over Al Gore in Florida by just 537 votes, enough to finally take Mr Bush past the winning post in the electoral college if the result is allowed to stand.

But the Gore campaign and the Democrats flatly refused to give in. Instead it signalled a defiant fusillade of legal challenges. Mr Gore will call on the Florida courts today to order judicial recounts of thousands of disputed votes, a move which would take the battle for the White House deep into December.

Under plans being prepared in the Gore camp, the vice-president's lawyers will today trigger a formal "contest" of the results in Florida. They will ask a state judge to order court-appointed "special masters" to complete interrupted recounts of about 2,000 uncounted votes in Palm Beach county and 10,700 uncounted votes in Miami-Dade county.

They will call for an inquiry into the returns from Nassau county, and perhaps challenge the legality of Palm Beach's "butterfly ballots", which may have confused voters.

"We're preparing contest papers that will be filed Monday, as early in the day as we can get them done," a Gore lawyer, David Boies, said yesterday. "Until these votes are counted, this election cannot be over."

Mr Gore's new legal moves were being readied last night as the deadline passed at 5pm local time for Florida counties to submit their hand recount votes to Ms Harris.

Only one of three critical south Florida counties proved able to meet yesterday's recount deadline completely.

Ms Harris formally certified the end of the presidential election in Florida, declaring Mr Bush the winner of the state's 25 electoral college votes.

That in turn would allow Mr Bush to declare himself president-elect and to claim the White House by a 271-267 margin in the electoral college. Mr Bush might demand the keys to Washington offices reserved for the incoming administration's "transition" team as early as today, some reports said.

Republicans believe that these events would be a turning point in the battle and that Mr Gore would come under increasing pressure to end his fight, irrespective of the legal options.

With such a scenario in prospect last night, the Gore camp made clear that they would refuse to concede the election to Mr Bush, and would instead continue efforts to have all the votes fully examined.

The central objective of the new legal moves remains the same, to have a complete hand recount of disputed machine-punched ballot papers in three counties believed to be rich in excluded Gore votes.

Only Broward county completed its latest recount in time to meet the Sunday dead line set last week by the Florida supreme court. In the completed Broward recount, which took 11 days, Mr Gore made a net gain of 567 votes.

A second county, Palm Beach, announced at midday yesterday that it would not be able to complete its recount by the 5pm deadline and sent a letter to Ms Harris requesting an extension to 9am today.

With two hours still remaining to the deadline, Ms Harris refused the request, at which point Palm Beach officials prepared to submit their returns on the basis of what they had recounted.

That left more than 2,000 ballots not examined, which officials continued to scrutinise after the deadline had passed.

Mr Gore was said to have gained about 46 net votes in county's recount as of yesterday morning.

A third and more heavily populated county, Miami-Dade, had been expected to yield a large harvest of extra votes for Mr Gore before officials called off the recount last Wednesday under pressure from Republican protesters and for lack of time.

Mr Gore's new court action today aims to reopen the status of 10,700 uncounted papers that were rejected in a machine recount.

Twelve other counties also submitted amended recount figures to Ms Harris yesterday, even though they have not conducted full recounts.

In Tallahassee, where Ms Harris has her office, there was feverish activity as the deadline approached. Placard waving demonstrators from both sides gathered outside the Florida state capitol building.

Anxious to prevent Mr Bush from gaining a public relations advantage from the certification, Democrats wheeled out a new heavy hitter on Mr Gore's behalf, when former Senator George Mitchell appeared in Tallahassee and called for patience on all sides.

In addition to going back to court himself today, Mr Gore will be closely watching a hearing that is due in Seminole county, where a suit alleges that 4,700 postal votes that were included in the count should be thrown out because of irregularities.

If that complaint is upheld, it could swing the election in Florida back to Mr Gore on its own.

webTitle: Newspapers plan to dump WH Smith deal

fields.headline: Newspapers plan to dump WH Smith deal
fields.trailText: A national system of newspaper distribution is on the verge of collapse as other groups threaten to follow the example of Associated Newspapers which has terminated a £100m agreement with WH Smith. By Terry Macalister.
fields.body:
A national system of newspaper distribution - the lifeblood of thousands of small shops in rural areas - is on the verge of collapse as other groups threaten to follow the example of Associated Newspapers which has terminated a £100m agreement with WH Smith.

Newspaper publishers News International and Telegraph Newspapers said last night that they were reviewing their plans in the light of the Associated move.

News International, which publishes the Times and the Sun, gave indications of its intentions last week when it trebled the size of its own prototype distribution system in Birmingham.

Industry experts had expected News International to lead a revolt against WH Smith by cancelling its contract with the wholesaler. Ian Jackson, circulation and sales director at the company owned by Rupert Murdoch, declined to comment on whether it planned to do this in future. He admitted the Birmingham operation was designed to learn wholesaling skills and added, ominously for WH Smith: "I support Associated's move."

Jeremy Deedes, managing director of Telegraph Newspapers, believed widespread change was inevitable. He said last night he would be sitting down with his colleagues to discuss what they should do. He admitted: "There is going to be a shake-up [industry wide]."

Carolyn McCall, managing director of Guardian Newspapers, said she was continually reviewing distribution deals but added: "We have no plans to change our arrangements [with WH Smith]."

WH Smith declined to comment on the issue but it will underline the serious nature of the revolt when it tells the Stock Exchange today that the Associated Newspapers decision could cost it £7m in profits this year. Its profitability in this sector is already on the slide.

Newspapers and magazines are distributed via three leading wholesalers led by WH Smith and John Menzies plus a number of small independents which each have a particular geographical monopoly.

This system was thrown into confusion last April when WH Smith announced plans to take on magazine distribution of all Tesco and Safeway stores wherever they are.

The newspaper publishers have been trying to get WH Smith to change its mind, fearing that the loss of magazine revenue will put the future of small retailers in doubt. They are also worried that if the magazine plans are successful, then a similar national deal for newspapers with big stores would follow.

Associated Newspapers - publisher of the Daily Mail - revealed at the weekend it was giving six months' notice that it planned to cancel two-thirds of its supplies through WH Smith.

The contracts, worth £100m, are expected to go to Menzies and others while the remaining one third will be staying with WH Smith only because it cannot find suitable alternative arrangements.

Mike Newman, circulation director at Associated Newspapers and chairman of the circulation executives of the Newspaper Publishers Association, said the moves by WH Smith threatened the livelihoods of small retailers which in turn endangered newspapers themselves.

Despite the pressure at WH Smith for a change of heart, well placed sources think this is unlikely and not everybody wants to take their business elsewhere even if they are opposed to the deal with Tesco.

webTitle: ITV orders new run of Ross Kemp drama

fields.headline: ITV orders new run of Ross Kemp drama
fields.trailText: 8.15amITV controller of drama has recommissioned Ross Kemp detective series Without Motive, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Life outside soap opera has proved a struggle for many actors and actresses.

And when Ross Kemp's second prime-time drama, In Defence, flopped in the ratings there were more than a few whispers that ITV would not renew Mr Kemp's £1.2m golden handcuffs deal when it expires next year.

But Nick Elliott, ITV controller of drama, has confidence he has finally found the right vehicle for him and has recommissioned Ross Kemp detective series Without Motive.

As DC Jack Mowbray, the former EastEnders actor made his first convincing effort to portray someone who didn't go by the name of Grant Mitchell.

The show had an initial run of six episodes and is expected to come back early next year.

Mr Kemp's first series, Hero of the Hour, pulled in 11.7m viewers when it was first screened.

Millions had switched off by the time he appeared in his second guise as a barrister in In Defence.

Similar difficulties were faced by Nick Berry, who started his career in EastEnders.

After he left Heartbeat, ITV tried a number of shows none of which resulted in returning series including one in which he played a boxer and the other a paparazzi photographer.

webTitle: Waitrose launches  Christmas campaign

fields.headline: Waitrose launches veggie Christmas campaign
fields.trailText: 8am: A Father Christmas made of vegetables forms part of Waitrose's Christmas campaign, which launches today, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Waitrose, the upmarket supermarket chain, is gearing up for Christmas with the launch of a new press and poster campaign.

The face of Father Christmas made entirely of vegetables forms part of a new Christmas press campaign breaking nationally today.

The campaign is intended to appeal to all food lovers and demonstrate the supermarket's commitment to everyday food expertise.

Waitrose sells itself on being able to provide customers with the widest possible selection of quality products at a fair price.

The ads feature everything from the humble potato to the supermarket's own secret recipe Christmas puddings.

Another part of the campaign, by Banks Hoggins O'Shea FCB, shows a close-up of a man's belt that has been undone a notch for each course he has indulged in throughout the annual Christmas day feast.

The campaign was written by David Wolff and art directed by Jon Grainger with photography by Olivia Beasley.

webTitle: Brown insists tax control isn't an EU issue

fields.headline: Brown insists tax control isn't an EU issue
fields.standfirst: Special report: EU integration
fields.trailText: Britain will not hand over tax controls to the European Union, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, insisted before key talks between EU finance ministers today.
fields.body:
Britain will not hand over tax controls to the European Union, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, insisted before key talks between EU finance ministers today.

He said that taxation was a matter of national identity and stated that he would hold on to the British veto at the discussions in Brussels.

His comments signal that there will be a battle ahead on the issue for the prime minister, Tony Blair, when he attends a crucial summit in Nice in a fortnight.

Mr Brown was today expected to block moves to switch to majority voting for five key management policies affecting economic and monetary union.

The UK is under pressure to agree to give up the veto in dozens of areas to make decision making simpler as the EU expands in the next few years.

However, tax - like social security, external trade, and immigration and asylum policies - are sacrosanct, the government says.

One of the flashpoints is an EU-wide tax on the interest on savings - a tax Britain has fended off thanks to the need for unanimous approval.

Instead of accepting the tax, the UK is agreeing to exchange information with other member states on tax liability.

The French finance minister, Laurent Fabius, in a jibe at the UK, said that things would have been much easier if the savings tax issue had been subject to qualified majority voting, instead of unanimity.

But Mr Brown said that it was the power of the veto which blocked the others from imposing a damaging savings tax on the City of London.

And he set out bluntly the government's position at the forthcoming Nice summit.

He said: "Tax decisions reflect national values and the national identity - choices people want to make at a national level.

"This should not be subject to qualified majority voting or harmonised tax rates. We have got to continue to push our case.

"We have always said on tax matters that these are issues reflecting national identity and they are decisions best made in the UK parliament."

The chancellor went on: "I believe it is in Europe's interest not to have tax harmonisation but tax competition. We want to compete with our colleagues.

"Tax competition for income and corporate taxes is in the best interest of Britain and of Europe as whole.

"People understand that we have a very strong position on this. We cooperate where necessary, but tax harmonisation is not the way forward."

Mr Brown emphasised that it was only because of the veto that the City of London had been spared the EU-wide savings tax, with the government agreeing instead simply to swap information on taxes due on savings interest accrued by foreign nationals investing in the UK.

The UK veto obliged the rest to abandon plans for a uniform tax regime - although some member states will apply uniform EU tax levels on savings interest for the next seven years, until the information exchange system applies in all 15 member states.

The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, said: "Labour's tough talk on tax is designed to distract attention from the many areas where Labour are planning to give up the veto at Nice.

"Whatever Mr Brown may say, Britain will be put under constant pressure to give up the veto on tax matters.

"The fact that Labour is willing to give up the veto on so many issues will only encourage such federalist ambitions.

"Our partners cannot take seriously the Labour government's so-called resistance to tax harmonisation, because they are committed to joining the euro which seems bound to bring greater tax harmonisation."

webTitle: Cold comfort from Saudi oil minister

fields.headline: Cold comfort from Saudi oil minister
fields.standfirst:
Opec members fear that slowing world economy could hit prices.
Special report: the petrol crisis
fields.trailText: Saudi Arabia dashed hopes yesterday that oil exporting countries would pump more crude to ease sky high world energy prices as the northern winter begins to bite.
fields.body:
Saudi Arabia dashed hopes yesterday that oil exporting countries would pump more crude to ease sky high world energy prices as the northern winter begins to bite.

The country's oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, said in an interview over the weekend that Opec, the oil producers' cartel, should wait before increasing production quotas, even though world oil prices remain stuck at $32-$33 a barrel, well over the cartel's $22-$28 target price.

In an excerpt from an interview with the Saudi-owned pan-Arab newspaper al-Hayat, Mr Naimi said that although oil prices were beyond the up per limit of the cartel's target, that "does not mean we will increase supplies, because the dangers for the instability of the market are big".

Western policymakers are worried that with oil reserves drying up and refineries running full tilt to meet demand, shortages this winter are likely to send prices for heating fuel rocketing, particularly in the US where most homes have oil-fired central heating.

The Saudi minister said the current level of oil prices did not reflect low supplies, however, but instead were the result of speculation and the inability of refineries to produce enough for the market.

The price of Opec's basket of seven crudes reached $31.63 per barrel on Thursday.

Under the Opec price stability mechanism, if the price stays above $28 for 20 working days or below $22 for 10 working days, crude production is adjusted by 500,000 barrels a day either way to stabilise prices.

The mechanism triggered a 500,000 barrels per day output rise last month after an unbroken 20-day cycle of basket prices of more than $28.

Mr Naimi said the Opec price mechanism "exists and will be used", but added that the cartel had the option "not to abide by it to the letter."

He said the latest rise in production by Opec of 500,000 barrels per day from October 1 had not fully reached the market, and the effects of the increase must be watched.

Pressure from the west has led to Opec raising its production quotas four times this year, adding a daily total of 3.7m barrels of extra oil to the market. Some cartel members fear that with the world economy expected to slow, cutting demand for oil, prices could tumble in the spring.

Saudi Arabia's stance on quota increases is key because it is the only Opec country with spare capacity. Mr Naimi has said that in an emergency his country could put an extra 1.8m barrels of oil a day on the market within 90 days.

webTitle: Architects urged to go for 'wow factor' for new public buildings

fields.headline: Architects urged to go for 'wow factor' for new public buildings
fields.trailText: Architects are to be encouraged to "delight" the people who use, work in, and live with new buildings in an initiative designed to help sweep away the legacy of souless municipal architecture and improve the quality of Britain's public buildings.
fields.body:
Architects are to be encouraged to "delight" the people who use, work in, and live with new buildings in an initiative designed to help sweep away the legacy of souless municipal architecture and improve the quality of Britain's public buildings.

Under a new set of performance indicators being produced by the Construction Industry Council, architects and bodies commissioning new buildings will be encouraged to consider whether the planned building has "the wow factor" as well as the more traditional concerns of function and cost.

The project, being developed at Sussex University, will ask interested parties to consider the "effect on the mind and the senses" of new developments. In an attempt at produce a "delight rating" for a given building architects, clients and the intended users of the building will be encouraged to ask: "What do passers-by think of the building?", "Does it provide a focal point for the community?", and "Can you have a party in it?"

The move is an attempt to encourage local authorities and spending bodies to move beyond a cost-only consideration of new buildings and consider the wider implications. It is also a response to public perception that many modern structures are overly functional and somewhat souless, intended to be of use and pleasure only to those that work in them.

The "delight detector" project coincides with government initiatives to try to ensure that the promised increase in public sector spending will leave a legacy of high quality public-friendly buildings.

Last month, Tony Blair stressed the need for architects and public sector clients to consider more than cost and pure function when reviewing the quality of designs, in a foreword to a Department of Culture, Media and Sport report, entitled Better Public Buildings.

The report concluded that thoughtful high-quality public buildings could bring about dramatic social benefits. On housing estates crime and vandalism could be discouraged, while quality school and hospital buildings could help reduce truancy rates and improve recovery from illness.

Robin Nicholson, deputy chairman of the CIC, said that even potentially mundane structures can bring a little pleasure.

"There is always room for delight, whatever that may mean. In education and health buildings it is an absolutely fundamental economic benefit - a good, well-designed school enables kids to be more social and provides a better environment for learning," he told the trade magazine Building Design.

"That is not always immediately apparent to those buying hospitals and schools. The government is extremely keen on having something like this; they realise that least-cost projects leave long-term cost consequences.

"The project is about raising awareness among clients of the things that really matter but are not immediately apparent. Lots of people dismiss measuring but we are not trying to measure, we are trying to raise awareness," he said.

One project widely praised both for having a positive effect on its immediate environment and community is the new Peckham library in south-east London, commissioned by Southwark council. Designed by architects Alsop & Stormer, the library is an example of the community-minded municipal building the government has in mind. Attractive, innovative and distinctive it lies at the heart of the regeneration of the centre of Peckham, and public consultation was a crucial part of the design process.

Jonathan Leah, an associate director at Alsop & Stormer, welcomed the CIC initiative. "Often one finds that price is at the top of the list of requirements and architecture way down at the bottom," he said.

"We have striven as a practice to get the question of quality and image considered more by clients, as was the case in Peckham. Value for money is always going to be a concern whether you are dealing with a public sector or a private client but that is no reason why you have to create dull, grey buildings that are only of use to the people who work in them.

"We welcome the view that says quality of design is important, but it can be a difficult area. We are dealing with subjective judgments here."

Comment, Jonathan Glancey

No one can measure the pleasure or delight buildings give in precise, mathematical terms.

Maybe we could all be wired up and our body heat or heart rate measured to see by what degree these rose or fell when faced by the raw concrete Brutalism of London's Hayward Gallery or the super-refined Sainsbury Centre for the Visual Arts at the University of East Anglia.

But, what if the art on display in the former, normally considered a beast, was very much better than that on show in the latter - by general acclaim, a modern beauty? Surely our experience of the two buildings would then be very different from the way we might have perceived them when empty?

For better or worse, buildings are normally containers for a range of human activities. We judge them as much by the way they look as how they behave. So many elegant Georgian and operatic Victorian buildings have gone the way of the bulldozer and been replaced by soulless modern office blocks because their looks were never enough to make society care for them in their old age.

In any case, one generation's eyesore is another's delight. Could anyone, aside from a few be leagured architects and wilful critics, have imagined that Trellick Tower, Erno Goldfinger's pugilistic west London tower block, completed in 1973, would have been considered an achingly hip place to live today?

One thing we can all agree on is that new buildings should not be mean-spirited. They should be well and generously built.

But if some future official "delight factor" measurement led to the end of radical design that might appear to offend the public's eye before it, finally, wins its fickle heart, then it is to be given as wide a berth as any post-modern office block of the 1980s or dismal distribution centre or call centre of today.

· Jonathan Glancey is the Guardian's architecture critic

Delightful

Guggenheim Museum, Bilbao (Frank Gehry)

Voluptuous, clad in titanium scales and fronted by Jeff Koon's potty flower puppy.

Great Court, British Museum, London (Foster and Partners)

Supremely refined new covered public square at the heart of one of the world's busiest museums

Jewish Museum, Berlin (Daniel Libeskind)

A three-dimensional bolt of lightning that has had queues waiting to see inside its deconstructivist zinc skin.

Kansai International Airport, Osaka Bay (Renzo Piano/Building Workshop)

A tidal wave of a building, airy and light. Breathtaking.

Peckham Library, London (left) (Alsop & Stormer)

Jaunty winner of this year's Stirling Prize; a local authority building with wit and intelligence.

Dismal

The great British executive estate (housebuilders nationwide)

Dreary rows of cynical, mean-minded pseudo-vernacular and neo-Georgian stuff

MI6 Building, London (below) (Terry Farrel and Partners)

The baddies in the latest Bond film had the right idea, although one mustn't encourage real terrorist groups.

Canary Wharf Tower, London (Cesar Pelli)

Priapic symbol of Thatcherite enterprise.

Portcullis House, Westminster (Michael Hopkins and Partners)

Lumpen monument to the arrogance of today's out-of-reach parliament.

Metro Centre, Gateshead

Dumbed-down cathedral of commerce.

webTitle: Comment: the failure of the climate change talks

fields.headline: The hot air balloon
fields.standfirst:
Paradoxically, such a failure of the climate change talks is the best chance to get the issue noticed.
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Paradoxically, such a failure of the climate change talks is the best chance to get the issue noticed
fields.body:
The collapse of the climate change talks in The Hague at the weekend was the best possible thing that could have happened. This was precisely the kind of shock everyone needed. When did climate change last dominate the headlines? Coverage of the conference was making little impact, being relegated to a few paragraphs inside the newspapers - until it all disintegrated.

Then, thanks to John Prescott's fiery temper and his flouncing out, some drama was finally infused into the tedious technicalities that had dominated the conference. When all the talk is about how much carbon is released by different ploughing methods, you don't have a cat's hope in hell of impinging on the public consciousness, but when Prescott throws a dramatic tantrum ("I'm gutted") and the mudslinging is gets nasty, then people take notice.

With any luck, The Hague's collapse will nail one important popular myth - namely, that the international community has the matter in hand, and one can leave the politicians to sort out the details. Nothing could be further from the truth. Kyoto was a botch from the start, and it was inevitable that it would come unstuck. For several months, environmentalists have been warning that the conference would collapse. Many of them were so disillusioned by Kyoto and the talks since, that they argued no deal would be better than some of the compromises being suggested.

One thing is for sure, The Hague was never going to be the conference to "save the planet". The most obvious criticism of the Kyoto agreement in 1997 was that the targets agreed to cut carbon emissions were always pathetically inadequate; a mere 5% over 1990 levels while scientists were unanimous that cuts of 60-80% were required. But that could be countered by the argument that at least it was a first step. The far more damning criticism of Kyoto was that the whole international effort had been hijacked and corrupted by America's ideological obsession with the disciplines of the market as a panacea for all ills. Ironically, it was the Europeans whom Mr Prescott was accusing of "political purity" and lack of pragmatism at the weekend.

Such a charge better applies to the US which insisted on a market for carbon trading which would enable them to buy the right to carry on polluting. Under this rubric, they wanted to plant forests to absorb carbon in so-called carbon sinks, and even claim carbon credits for changing the way they ploughed their fields.

What that did was firstly to drive the international negotiations into a quagmire of mind-boggling detail - much to the fury of the Europeans who justifiably claim that regulation rather than a market approach to environmental pollution reaps better results. Negotiators got stuck over questions such as how this market was to be monitored and regulated without corruption.

None of that was made any easier by the fact that scientists are very uncertain about how and whether carbon sinks work at all; some estimated that the US proposals would lead to massive increases in emissions. Secondly, the consequences of the US market-based approach (perhaps intentionally) with its highly technical negotiations, alienated any sustained public interest. It has become a textbook case of how to kill off public participation.

Arguably, it was the last which has proved most destructive of the international effort. There is no point blaming the politicians for their failure. What has been singularly lacking over this issue has been any widespread popular campaign. We've had no Seattle-style protests. Instead we've had the fuel tax campaigns and a public stubbornly recalcitrant about changing its own lifestyle, unwilling to turn out for a demo on climate change. Politicians respond to pressure. When they have big, angry demonstrations outside their conference centres, it focuses their minds. When their mailbags are bulging with outraged voters, they respond.

What's needed now is the kind of global protest movement which Jubilee 2000 developed over debt relief. That movement spawned a mass economics lesson on the global finance system, so now we can start on another bit of the curriculum: geography. As Jubilee 2000 draws to a close next month, climate change has been mooted as a possible successor issue. The potential for a comparable coalition of non-governmental agencies is there. It is as much a matter of concern for the Red Cross and Oxfam as for the Royal Society for the Preservation of Birds and Greenpeace.

Such coalitions are not easy to assemble; they involve overcoming rivalries, but together, they would have far greater impact in a world crowded with good causes. Jubilee 2000 is a powerful example of how old-fashioned campaigning, of letter-writing and petitions combined with email succeeded in pushing debt relief up the international agenda and getting reform.

It is only this kind of mass campaign which has any hope of shifting the US. Between now and next May when the climate change talks resume in Bonn, much attention will be focused on persuading the US and its allies in the Umbrella Group to give ground. That task will not be made any easier if George W Bush is ensconced in the White House with his oil industry chums at his elbow; he doesn't believe there is such a thing as global warming.

But curiously, while news reports from The Hague have cast the US envoy Frank Loy as the villain of the piece, opinion polls indicate that the US public has one of the highest levels of environmental awareness in the world. They give generously to environmental causes and some states such as California and Arizona have pioneered important environmental initiatives. The puzzle is why this environmental conscience doesn't feed into the federal political system in the same way as it often does at a state level.

Is it because this conscience doesn't determine voting (Ralph Nader, the Green party presidential candidate, won only a pitiful 3% of the vote) or because the Washington establishment is paralysed by special interests such as the oil companies and fear of jeopardising the US economic boom? If, and it's a big if, such a political block could be shifted by mobilising public concern, the US could play a very different role, leading efforts on climate change rather than sabotaging them. Forest fires in the Rockies, tropical diseases in New York and violent hurricanes on the East Coast will all help in bringing home the consequences of climate change.

Meanwhile, it's business as usual in The Hague's international conference centre this morning. Oil industry executives are settling down for an international get-together. Rest assured, their conference is unlikely to collapse in bitter disagreement and this evening, they'll have plenty to celebrate over their cocktails. If that doesn't outrage, what will?

webTitle: Lynda Lee Potter calls for the renationalisation of the rail network

fields.headline: Lynda and her lawn-mowers
fields.standfirst:
Calls for renationalisation are coming from an unlikely quarter
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Calls for renationalisation are coming from an unlikely quarter
fields.body:
Over the past 30 years, I have become something of an authority on the writing of Lynda Lee-Potter. My study of this admittedly recherché branch of English literature began when Ms Lee-Potter wrote a profile of me for the Daily Mail. Her brief interest in my life and work had been stimulated by a speech in which I had promised that a future Labour government would "initially reduce and eventually abolish" fee paying education in this country. So I was lucky that the profile was never published. But for some weeks I read the Lee-Potter column in the hope of a mention. And I came to realise why its author is an almost indispensable asset to Lord Rothermere.

Ms Lee-Potter has a genius for articulating the hopes and fears of the emergent middle classes. In both style and substance she reflects the principles and prejudices of men and women who, like her, have risen from humble beginnings to conspicuous prosperity. She is the authentic voice of the suburbs. And my meticulous post-structural examination of her work has revealed a second defining attribute. Her writing never reveals anything which might arouse the suspicion that she is a secret socialist.

Imagine, therefore, my surprise last Tuesday when I found a fascinating item of biography in her column. "I began commuting when the rail service, while not perfect, bore no relationship to the squalid shambles we have today. The stalwarts of the old British Rail were dignified proud men who had grown up in railway families." I know from careful textual analysis of her prose that Ms Lee-Potter can be sentimental as well as savage. But she expressed more than nostalgia for "porters in immaculate uniform and fires in waiting rooms". The railways, she wrote "were our assets and they've been sold off to exploiters who care more about profits than services". Those sentiments would not have been out of place in a Labour party conference during the era of leftwing lunacy.

Take it from me, if Ms Lee-Potter believes privatisation to be a ghastly mistake, the British middle class believes exactly the same. What we read in the Daily Mail last Tuesday was the heartfelt opinion of the men and women who commute with her when she makes her daily journey to London. It is also the passionate conviction of the thousands of other passengers (known as "customers") who are forced to travel by rail because no alternative is available. Those unhappy people want the railways to be nationalised again. So, to my delight, does Ms Lee-Potter.

The implication of her complaint is clear. "Six years ago the Labour party promised that when they came to power they would reverse privatisation. But they've reneged on that pledge". Thanks to Railtrack, public ownership has become popular for the first time in 50 years - though I doubt if the people whose opinions Ms Lee-Potter reflects were nationalisation enthusiasts even during the lifetime of the Attlee government. Ironically, Tony Blair - who is so determined not to lose votes by behaving like a socialist - may sacrifice popularity because of his refusal, or inability, to implement one of old fashioned socialism's classic principles.

The hope of renationalising the franchise holders - Virgin, Midland, Mainline and the rest - is clearly unrealistic. But can the same be said of Railtrack? We know that John Prescott is a great believer in public-private partnership. Why not (as well as selling off part of the air traffic control system and a large slice of the London Underground) buy a controlling interest in a company which, by any reasonable test, should be more concerned with service than with profit? While Railtrack remains a private company, profit will be its principal objective -more easily obtained by building shopping arcades round stations than by creating a safe and efficient rail network.

It would be unreasonable for Railtrack to behave in any other way. The first duty of a private company is the protection of its shareholders' interests. If railways in general are losing money, conditions will be improved until passengers are attracted back to the trains. But the improvements will be a marketing exercise not a genuine attempt to provide the best possible service. The railways were a mess before Hatfield and a mess they will remain.

Meanwhile the government will be held responsible for the inherent failures of monopoly capitalism. Ministers who, in Lynda Lee-Potter's words, "are ferried everywhere in chauffeur driven cars", will be excoriated for "becoming distanced" from long suffering railway passengers. I advise Mr Prescott to listen and heed. For once it is both right and expedient to respond to the wishes of the lawn-mower belt. It would be absurd if this were the one occasion when Tony Blair chooses to ignore them.

webTitle: Tories draw up plans to 'privatise' adoption agencies

fields.headline: Tories draw up plans to 'privatise' adoption agencies
fields.standfirst: Existing system is failing, says Fox
fields.trailText: The tories are drawing up secret plans to privatise adoption services, including the vetting of would-be parents and running of care homes.
fields.body:
The tories are drawing up secret plans to privatise adoption services, including the vetting of would-be parents and running of care homes.

The controversial move would hand unprecedented powers over the lives of vulnerable children to private agencies, charities or religious organisations. It raises serious questions about the protection of youngsters.

But shadow ministers argue that after a string of abuse scandals, and controversy over adoptive parents being rejected by 'politically correct' social workers, the existing system is failing.

Shadow health secretary Liam Fox is drawing up the blueprint with home affairs spokesman David Lidington, who oversees the new US-style Renewing One Nation taskforce aiming to involve religious groups and the private sector in welfare.

Fox told The Observer he was considering all options for adoption reform including bringing in the private sector.

'What we want to have is a properly regulated service, and I don't think it matters so much who actually does it,' he added.

'I want a proper national register for all prospective adoptive and fostering parents with an objective set of criteria, so that if you were on the register you would be considered suitable anywhere in the country.

'And we want to make sure that all children in care over a certain length of time, probably a year, would get an adoption plan drawn up for them.

'I am all in favour of not having it an exclusively state sector, as long as we have protection for children and get suitable monitoring.'

The running of children's homes could also 'potentially' be contracted out to private firms, he added, and be state-regulated as private nursing homes are.

Fox has studied a forthcoming report from the influential right-wing think-tank the Bow Group, which condemns the state as 'the worst parent in Britain'.

It suggests that private providers be paid by results such as educational achievements for children in care, while the private sector should 'take over entirely the vetting of adoptive parents and the placement of children'.

Shadow ministers are not prepared to go that far, arguing for a mix of public and private sector provision.

But their plans were condemned as 'grotesque' by Shaun Woodward, the ex-Tory MP who defected to Labour and is a trustee of Childline.

'The state does not have a record without blemish. But to move from a recognition that something needs to be fixed to saying we completely give up on it and we are prepared to put it into the private sector, which at the end of the day is about profit, is fundamentally wrong.'

He conceded that involving the voluntary sector in some areas could work if regulated. Ministers are expected to expand the role of children's charities in their forthcoming adoption white paper.

A Tory spokesman said different solutions would be expected in different areas of the UK depending on who could provide the best outcome. 'What we need to do is find the method that is best rather than getting hung up on ideology.'

The plan will be seen as evidence of the influence of George W. Bush's 'compassionate conservatism' policy of devolving welfare to charities and private firms.

webTitle: Britons in Cuba spy mystery arrive home

fields.headline: Britons in Cuba spy mystery arrive home
fields.trailText: A British private detective held in Cuba for 48 days on suspicion of spying arrived back in the UK yesterday, and immediately added to the mystery of exactly what he and his colleagues had been up to when they were picked up by secret police in Havana.
fields.body:
A British private detective held in Cuba for 48 days on suspicion of spying arrived back in the UK yesterday, and immediately added to the mystery of exactly what he and his colleagues had been up to when they were picked up by secret police in Havana.

Ken Lodge, who runs his own private investigation firm in east London, was arrested in the Cuban capital in October with five male colleagues and the girlfriend of one of the men. They were all released after the Cuban president, Fidel Castro, intervened.

Mr Lodge denied being hired by the wife of a rich Panamanian businessman who suspected her husband of marital infidelity, claiming instead to be gathering information on a particular individual for a client who lived in the United States.

Mr Lodge was the only one of the seven to face the press at Gatwick airport yesterday, although he said some of his colleagues had been on the same flight.

He said he had been "well treated" during his captivity, where he lived on a diet of rice, beans and chicken, and passed the time reading Richard Branson's autobiography three times, a book which he described as "brilliant".

The Britons were arrested on October 8 on suspicion of working for US intelligence agencies. The Cuban authorities initially refused to allow the British government consular access to the seven, provoking a diplomatic incident.

"We were not working for the government. We were not spying," Mr Lodge said yesterday. "Some of the reports I have heard about what we were doing are the biggest load of bullshit in the world."

Criticising "inaccurate" press reporting which said the group had been bundled into cars in an alley, he said they had just finished playing squash and were drinking orange juice at a hotel when the secret police arrived. "They were very polite," he added.

Mr Lodge said the group members had almost been released 10 days after their ar rest, but then reports that he and his colleagues may have been working for the Chechen government or for the wife of Mike Nahmad - a Panamanian businessman who ran Cuba's only foreign-owned power plant - found their way to the Cuban police.

"We have never had contact with Mrs Nahmad and would like to apologise for any embarrassment caused. It took us days to reconvince the authorities," he said.

During a three-month surveillance operation, which Mr Lodge admitted included tailing Mr Nahmad, they had used hi-tech miniature cameras and transmitters, but it was the 1,000 mobile telephone calls they made on a single day that led to their downfall.

"The mobiles we use in the UK or in the US do not work in Cuba. We had to hire mobiles out there. I was told that it was one of the ways they found us," he added.

Mr Lodge said he and his colleagues wanted to pull out of Cuba four days after Mr Nahmad had left the Caribbean island, but his firm's client insisted that they stay for a fourth month to gather more information.

"The whole job was a calculated risk. We are not infallible. We have protected a president before and several ambassadors. We knew there were dangers," he said.

Intriguingly, Mr Lodge said the girlfriend of one of his colleagues had been used in the investigation. "We decided our target, who was staying in a villa, should have some female company. I can't say more."

Mr Lodge said he would now go back to work to try to repair some of the damage the affair may have done to his company, SIP Investigations.

"Looking back, I do not think we were bungling. We were not spying," he said. "I have no regrets."

webTitle: Charlie Chaplin: The great composer

fields.headline: The great composer
fields.standfirst: When Charlie Chaplin won an Oscar in 1973, it wasn't for his acting, but for one of his scores. Charlotte Higgins reports on the film-makers other life
fields.trailText: When Charlie Chaplin won an Oscar in 1973, it wasn't for his acting, but for one of his scores. Charlotte Higgins reports on the film-makers other life.
fields.body:
Nothing is more exciting than to hear the tunes one has composed played for the first time by a 50-piece orchestra," wrote Charlie Chaplin in his autobiography. Perhaps because he was so multifaceted - a comic actor of extraordinary imagination, an untiring, perfectionist director, the co-founder of United Artists - it seems unfair that Chaplin had one more talent. But, though it is largely overlooked today, the creator of the Little Tramp was an accomplished musician who wrote soundtracks for nearly all of his films - although he wasn't always credited, as in the case of The Great Dictator, whose score he co-wrote. His music for Limelight won him an Oscar; Petula Clark even had a massive hit with Chaplin's This is My Song, a tune from A Countess from Hong Kong.

Chaplin's scores have a foot-tapping catchiness; they get stuck in your head and you find yourself whistling the tunes. His feel for music sprang from a childhood submerged in the songs and waltzes of the music hall. As a child, Chaplin worked on the stage as part of a clog-dancing troupe, the Eight Lancashire Lads, and later for the successful comedy company owned by impresario Fred Karno. He played the piano, and as a boy he had acquired a violin and a cello (strung in reverse, as he was left handed). As he could not read music, he played all his instruments by ear. He wrote in his autobiography that "since the age of 16 I had practised from four to six hours a day in my bedroom. Each week I took lessons from the theatre conductor or someone he recommended_ I had great ambitions to be a concert artist, or, failing that, to use it in a vaudeville act."

But why did Chaplin end up composing? The clinching factor was the introduction of sound to the movies. He conceived of his film City Lights as silent, but sound became an option while the movie was being made. According to Carl Davis, who conducts Chaplin's score of The Gold Rush in London on Saturday, "he made an astonishing decision - to keep City Lights a 'silent' film, that is, without dialogue. But he took advantage of the new technology to write and record a score, and sound effects too. That is when the idea of Chaplin as composer evolved."

This arrangement must have suited the talkies-resistant Chaplin down to the ground. Before the introduction of sound, Chaplin had himself selected the music to be played in cinemas with his films. But the invention of the recorded soundtrack gave him absolute control - a concept that was of prime importance to Chaplin in his film-making. Sound allowed him to create an ultimate artwork, complete in every way. Nothing would be left to chance; everything would now be perfectly, ineffably, Chaplin. The technique was so successful that later Chaplin went back to his earlier silent movies and rereleased them with soundtracks - which is how the The Gold Rush, originally made in 1925, acquired its score in 1942.

Because Chaplin could not read music, when it came to writing soundtracks his hums and improvisations had to be taken down and orchestrated by collaborators. "His assistants had a terrible time," says Davis. "It must have been torture. He was very, very moody." Chaplin himself wrote about this process: "Sometimes a musician would get pompous with me, and I would cut him short: 'Whatever the melody is, the rest is just a vamp.' After putting music to one or two pictures I began to look at a conductor's score with a professional eye and to know whether a composition was over-orchestrated or not. If I saw a lot of notes in the brass and woodwind section I would say: 'That's too black in the brass,' or 'too busy in the woodwinds'."

Chaplin's early experience of music hall also informed the way he worked with music. As he said in a 1952 radio interview: "I use music as a counterpoint, and I learned that from the Fred Karno Company. For instance if they had squalid surroundings with a lot of comedy tramps working in it, they would have very beautiful, boudoir music, something of the 18th century, very lush and grandiose, and it would be satirical, a counterpoint."

That technique is certainly evident in The Gold Rush, particularly in the famous scene in which the Little Tramp and a gold prospector are stuck in a remote, snowbound hut without food. It is Thanksgiving Day, and the Tramp comes up with the idea of boiling his boot for dinner. Says Davis: "The boot is produced, and Chaplin handles it as if he is a maitre d' at the Savoy. He carves it exquisitely as if it is a gourmet dish, a roast rib of beef. The nails are treated as if they are elegant little bones; the shoelaces are like delicate spaghetti. To support this performance he gives us the music of a palm court trio - of just the sort you could hear at the Savoy. The humour lies in the contrast between the elegance of the performance and the music, and the scene of desolation and despair."

In his autobiography Chaplin wrote, "Musical arrangers rarely understood this [technique]. They wanted the music to be funny. But I would explain that I wanted no competition, I wanted the music to express sentiment." It does, and sentimentality too. In The Gold Rush, Chaplin has invited his heartthrob, Georgia, to New Year's Eve dinner (Georgia herself has a charming love theme, adapted from a piece of Brahms piano music). Georgia accepted the invitation only as a joke, and she doesn't show up. Instead she celebrates with her friends in the local dance hall. The strains of Auld Lang Syne just reach the Little Tramp's hut, where the table lies set and the candles are burnt down.

Chaplin's celebrity existence in prewar California brought him into contact with a starry collection of classical musicians, by whom he seems to have been much admired. There is 1930s film footage of him improvising duets with the composer and pianist Germaine Tailleferre. He was friendly with composer Hanns Eisler (and had a sticky time at a press conference after the release of 1947's Monsieur Verdoux, when he was asked to respond to allegations that Eisler was a communist). He was photographed with the great violinist Yascha Heifetz, and he was on dining terms with Horowitz, Rachmaninov and Schoenberg.

Stravinsky was struck with the idea of making a film with Chaplin; over dinner Chaplin invented a surrealist scenario, involving a decadent nightclub that would include a depiction of Christ's crucifixion. Stravinsky was shocked - he regarded the idea as sacrilegious. Chaplin soon lost interest in the thought.

"Composers had a very strange idea of how they might work with Chaplin," says Davis. "Schoenberg, for instance, thought he could write a score first and have Chaplin write the scenes around it. But it is natural that these great artists should have been attracted to Charlie. He was one of them. His scores, within the boundaries that he set himself, are perfect. I would not change a note of them."

 The Gold Rush, with a live score conducted by Carl Davis, will be screened at the Royal Festival Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), on Saturday.

There is 1930s film footage of him improvising duets with the composer and pianist Germaine Tailleferre. He was friendly with composer Hanns Eisler (and had a sticky time at a press conference after the release of 1947's Monsieur Verdoux, when he was asked to respond to allegations that Eisler was a communist). He was photographed with the great violinist Yascha Heifetz, and he was on dining terms with Horowitz, Rachmaninov and Schoenberg. Stravinsky was struck with the idea of making a film with Chaplin; over dinner Chaplin invented a surrealist scenario, involving a decadent nightclub that would include a depiction of Christ's crucifixion. Stravinsky was shocked - he regarded the idea as sacrilegious. Chaplin soon lost interest in the thought. "Composers had a very strange idea of how they might work with Chaplin," says Davis. "Schoenberg, for instance, thought he could write a score first and have Chaplin write the scenes around it. But it is natural that these great artists should have been attracted to Charlie. He was one of them. His scores, within the boundaries that he set himself, are perfect. I would not change a note of them."  The Gold Rush, with a live score conducted by Carl Davis, will be screened at the Royal Festival Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), on Saturday.

webTitle: The best appointment scene

fields.headline: The best appointment scene
fields.standfirst: Little Nicky
fields.trailText: Little Nicky
fields.body:
Satan (Harvey Keitel) has gathered his three sons, Adrian (Rhys Ifans), Cassius (Tiny Lister) and the hapless Nicky (Adam Sandler) in his throne room. The three sit before their father.

"This," he announces, "as some of you might know, is my 10,000th year as prince of darkness. So I think the time has come to discuss who will succeed me."

Nicky stares blankly at his father, while Cassius and Adrian gaze at him avidly, their eyes sparkling.

"This was a very difficult decision," Satan continues. "Because I have three wonderful sons."

He gestures toward Adrian.

"Adrian... so strong, so ruthless."

"Wears make-up," mutters Nicky.

"And Cassius... so strong, so tough."

Beaming, Cassius flexes his muscles.

"Don't forget clinically insane," Nicky whispers.

"And Nicky... such a sweet boy."

Nicky laughs nervously.

"But after much thought and careful consideration," the devil goes on, "I've decided that the ruler for the next 10,000 years is going to have to be..."

He settles back into the throne.

"Me."

See also: Repo Man, Jerry Maguire, Dead Man

Don't see also: Look Who's Talking Too

Pointless trivia: Tiny Lister (6ft 7in) started his showbusiness career as a professional wrestler, working under the name Z-Gangsta.

webTitle: The end of Jubilee 2000

fields.headline: Candle lit for debt relief's unfinished business
fields.standfirst:
Special report: debt relief

Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: Staggering though the success of Jubilee 2000 has been, Saturday will still have an air of melancholy, because the goal of wiping out the unpayable debts of the world's poorest countries has not been achieved.
fields.body:
Tears will be shed this Saturday as the candles are snuffed out at the end of Jubilee 2000's torchlight procession down Whitehall. Saying goodbye always has its own special sadness, even though those running the campaign said from the outset it would only be effective if it had a deadline. That deadline is fast approaching and, from the end of December, Jubilee 2000 will be no more.

For the past four years the terms of the debate have been set by the debt campaigners, who little by little have forced the plight of the world's forgotten people onto the political agenda. Not only has Jubilee 2000 been comfortably the most successful mass movement of the past 25 years, but it has also shown how the process known as globalisation is nurturing its own opponents.

Staggering though the success of Jubilee 2000 has been, Saturday will still have an air of melancholy. Why? Because the goal of wiping out the unpayable debts of the world's poorest countries has not been achieved. Victory remains tantalisingly just out of grasp. There is still plenty of unfinished business.

The case of Uganda, which has had $1bn (£715m) worth of debt relief and used it to double primary school enrolment, shows what can be done. So does Bolivia, where the money is going on the poorest municipalities, and so does Mozambique, where the reduction in its annual payments from $127m a year to $52m is allowing more to be spent on hospitals and housing. Debt relief works.

But elsewhere in the world's poorest countries, children are still dying for lack of food, still falling ill for lack of basic health care, and having their futures blighted for lack of education. Despite all the pressure, despite the mobilisation of political will, despite all the promises of speedier and more generous help, that is the brutal truth. People are dying and suffering when they do not need to.

That is why the campaign has to continue, which it will with Jubilee's offspring, Drop the Debt, aiming to put pressure on the G8 summit in Genoa next year. The need for the struggle to continue is highlighted by the case of Zambia, which will be considered for debt relief under the enhanced heavily indebted poor country (HIPC) initiative by the executive boards of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund this week.

Late last week officials at the T reasury were trying to find a way of ensuring that Zambia does not end up paying more to its creditors next year, even after receiving HIPC relief, than it does this year. The fact that they were doing so is itself a tribute to the strength of the campaign. But the attempt to piece together a last-minute fix to tide Zambia over for a couple of years also highlights the weaknesses of what is on offer.

At the heart of the problem is that Zambia is about to be granted debt relief by its creditors but will end up paying more next year. Although this sounds paradoxical, it is actually quite simple. Zambia borrowed money - mainly from the Fund - but was given a long period of grace before repayments would start to fall due. This period of grace runs out at the end of next year, and as a result Zambia's debt payments are set to rise sharply.

According to IMF figures released in the summer, without HIPC relief they would rise from $136m in 2000 to $440m in 2001; even with HIPC they would rise to $225m. For a nation which has a total budget of around $800m and has seen per capita incomes drop by 30% in the past 25 years, any increase in debt repayments would be disastrous.

So, there have been efforts to find a way of getting Zambia over the hump, which in all likelihood will end with it receiving front-end loaded debt relief to cover the extra payments. The upside of this approach is that it would prevent any further cuts in spending on health and education in a country which is already running on empty.The downside is that it merely postpones the problem. Front-end loading would mean that Zambia's debt payments would simply rise later on, with only the scantiest of hopes that it will be able to use the short breathing space to turn round its moribund economy.

If the creditor nations are looking for reasons to deny Zambia the help it so desperately needs, they are not exactly thin on the ground. In the past, Zambia has been one of the more corrupt sub-Saharan regimes, with early resistance to the Jubilee 2000 campaign motivated by the fear that any debt relief would merely line the pockets of the political elite.

It would be foolish to pretend that corruption has been eradicated in the poor countries of Africa, not least because history suggests that poverty breeds corruption, and the worse the poverty the worse the corruption. When Britain was awash with squalor and disease during the Industrial Revolution it had its rotten boroughs, where elections were bought and the ballot was neither secret nor fair.

But things are starting to improve, in part because governments are so desperate for assistance that they will do anything that is required of them and partly because Uganda's creation of a designated anti-poverty fund for resources generated by debt relief shows what can be done.

However, rooting out corruption and ensuring debt relief is well spent is only one part of making sure that the poverty reduction strategies work. If it is incumbent on poor countries to admit that they have made mistakes in the past so it is also time for the donor countries and the Bretton Woods institutions to show a little humility as well. It is obvious, for example, that cost recovery - the process whereby budget cuts have meant those living on subsistence incomes being forced to pay fees for health and education - has been a disaster. The unbending insistence on fiscal retrenchment - whatever the impact on countries with non-existent social safety nets - should be re-thought.

Henry Northover, policy adviser at the Catholic aid agency, Cafod, says the Bank and the Fund should own up to past policy failures, and allow other agencies - including the UN - a greater role in judging the efficacy of nationally developed poverty reduction strategy papers.

"Macroeconomic and structural reforms should enhance economic growth prospects at the outset of the adjustment phase. This will require higher levels of investment in human capital and institution building. Hitherto the Fund's target for fiscal deficits have been unnecessarily restrictive because they have excluded donor aid in definitions of government revenue. The Bank and the Fund must develop the ability to assess ex ante the impact of macroeconomic and structural policy positions on vulnerable groups."

But even this will not be enough. At some point, probably before too long, there will be a call for a third HIPC initiative, then a fourth, before eventually the inevitable will happen and all the unpayable debts will be written off. At some point it will be recognised that if Zambia were a corporation rather than a country it could file for bankruptcy and start afresh. At some point, the West will have to realise that making globalisation work for countries short of investment and dependent on commodities means boosting aid flows and re-writing trade agreements. For all the successes, that still seems a long way off, which is why - as one campaigner put it recently - Jubilee 2000 must become 2001 compliant.
