webTitle: When sex abuse can lead to murder

fields.headline: When sex abuse can lead to murder
fields.standfirst:
Award-winning journalist Nick Davies concludes a series looking at the evils of paedophilia by confronting the grim mysteries of snuff movies. Today: The Amsterdam connection
Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Award-winning journalist Nick Davies concludes a series looking at the evils of paedophilia by confronting the grim mysteries of snuff movies. Today: The Amsterdam connection
fields.body:
A year after Bristol detectives finally started to unravel the ring of paedophiles who had been abusing children there for up to 20 years, they found an informant with an alarming story. The man, whom we will call Terry, had a long history of sexually abusing boys. He did not come from Bristol but, by chance, he had come across some of the paedophiles the detectives were investigating - in Amsterdam, where he said they had become involved with a group of exiled British child abusers who had succeeded in commercialising their sexual obsession.

The exiled paedophiles were trafficking boys from other countries; running legitimate gay brothels and selling under-aged boys "under the counter"; they had branched out into the production of child pornography. And they had killed some of them. One boy had simply been shot through the head, Terry said: he had been causing trouble and had been executed in front of several pae dophiles. Another, he believed, had been thrown into one of the canals. But the one about whom he spoke the most was a boy who had been tortured and killed in the most painful fashion in the course of producing a pornographic video.

Terry said he had seen most of the video himself and had vomited before he could reach the end. The few detectives who specialise in the investigation of child abuse invariably say the same thing about "snuff" movies: they have often heard of them, sometimes pursued them but never found one. The videos remain one of the great unsolved mysteries of the burgeoning underworld of international sexual exploitation.

Twice told tale
Terry's account was so hideous as to invite disbelief. It was clearly possible that he was inventing the story in an attempt to curry favour with the detectives as they turned over Bristol's paedophile subculture. And yet the detectives discovered that the allegation had been made before.

Not just once but repeatedly, evidence had come to the attention of police in England and the Netherlands, that, for pleasure and profit, some of the exiled paedophiles in Amsterdam had mur dered boys in front of the camera. Some of the evidence had been pursued. Some of it had been ignored. None of it had led to a murder charge. For a short while, the Bristol detectives thought they might be able to make progress in tracking down the truth; but when two of them flew to Amsterdam in the autumn of 1998 to pass on their information to Dutch officers, they hit a wall.

Terry had described the flat in Amsterdam where he had seen the video; he had named the owner of the flat who was, by implication, also owner of the video; he had provided the name of the man who carried out the killing; he had described events on the video in detail; he had provided the approximate age and the first name of the dead boy.

Dutch police said it was not enough: without the full name of a victim, they would not begin an investigation. Having fought their way through the swamp of inertia which surrounds British policing and prosecution of child abuse, the Bristol detectives had now hit the deeper swamp of virtual paralysis that afflicts its international policing. Within their own jurisdictions, there are now specialist paedophilia detectives - for example, in London and Amsterdam - who will work relentlessly to lock up predatory child abusers.

But when they try to move abroad, the potentially powerful machine starts to misfire. The result is that there is now a flourishing underground trade in boys who are being exported from the economic chaos of eastern Europe, as well as from the streets of London, to be put to work in the sex industry of western Europe. And no effective police operation to deal with it.

Predatory paedophiles cross whatever borders they like in order to pursue their obsessions; the police who might follow them are almost always trapped within their own narrow jurisdictions, partly by differences in law and procedure, partly because they lack the manpower and money to work internationally. There is an exception to this rule of parochialism, in the highly funded war against drugs, but in the perverse world of modern policing, the trafficking, rape and alleged murder of children has a far lower priority.

We have uncovered an international paedophile ring whose roots spring from Amsterdam, where, in the late 1980s, a group of British paedophiles set up a colony, exploiting the freedom of the city's gay community as cover to make a business of their fantasies.

Legal front
One of the first to do so was Alan Williams, the "Welsh Witch", who already had a vicious history of abusing boys in south Wales. Williams arrived in Amsterdam in 1988, aged 21, and soon set himself up as the manager of a gay brothel called Boys Club 21 at 21 Spuistraat, near the central station. Across the road at number 44, another British paedophile, a chubby Londoner named Warwick Spinks, then aged 25, was running a similar club called the Gay Palace. Both clubs had a legal business, running a bar and offering the services of adult male prostitutes.

But Williams and Spinks had much crueller interests. Williams had fled to the Netherlands after being convicted in Britain of indecent assaults on boys. In Amsterdam, he boasted of the day in south Wales when he had seen a 10-year-old boy on his bike, grabbed him, raped him, and, when he cried, strangled him. From Boys Clubs 21, he organised the importing of boys from Cardiff and London, inflicting intense violence on any who defied him.

Spinks had been running a mail order pornography business from Brighton, before he moved to Amsterdam, where he pioneered the trafficking of boys as young as 10 - first, from the streets of London, and, after the collapse of the Soviet Union, from the poverty of eastern Europe. Having brought them to Amsterdam, he used these "chickens" himself, sold them into the brothels or through escort agencies and put them in front of the camera. Some resisted, some ran away, but most were made to comply through the removal of their passports and doses of drugs and violence.

By 1990, these two clubs on Spuistraat, together with Boys for Men, De Boys, the Blue Boy and the Why Not, had become the busiest watering holes in the international paedophile jungle. Dutch police estimated there were 250 paedophiles involved in the production of child pornography in Amsterdam with an unknown floating population of child sex tourists from all over the world - and it was the British who formed the hard core consumers: Stephen Smith, who had helped to found the Paedophile Information Exchange, fled there when police in England prosecuted the organisation; Russell Tricker, now 58, a former private school teacher who was convicted of child sex offences in the UK, used his job as a coach driver to ferry suitable boys from London; John Broomhall opened a porn shop on Spuistraat and was caught with more than 1,000 copies of videos of under-aged boys; Mark Enfield, now 41, sold a video of himself abusing a drugged boy.

Alan Williams introduced two paedophile friends from Wales, John Gay and Lee Tucker, both of whom were to become central targets for Bristol detectives. The two men found they could sell Welsh boys into the clubs on Spuistraat and then make more money by investing in child pornography. They bought video equipment, set up TAG Films, and visited Amsterdam regularly to make films, which they sold through distributors in the US and Germany. At the time, Dutch law punished production of child pornography with a maximum sentence of only three months.

By October 1990, detectives on the old obscene publications squad at Scotland Yard were picking up worrying signals. An informant told them that someone called Alan Williams was trafficking boys into Amsterdam and that Williams had asked him to smuggle a child porn video back into the UK. Another informant told how he had smuggled a dozen tapes in the opposite direction: they had been produced, he believed, in north London, equipped with a bondage room for boys. He had delivered the tapes in Amsterdam to "Alan from Cardiff" at Boys Club 21. The informant said he had visited the Gay Palace across the road, where he watched videos of boys in bondage, aged 11 to 14, being buggered by masked men.

Soon, other informants were offering more detail. One man said he had seen Warwick Spinks selling a special video for £4,000. It showed a boy whom he thought was only eight or nine being sexually abused and tortured by two men. But the most startling allegations came from a gay man, "Frank", who had gone to Amsterdam in July 1990 and found himself caught up in this paedophile underworld. In 1993, he spoke to the same officers at Scotland Yard.

Frank told police that Warwick Spinks had invited him to come on a trip to the Canaries, where he had suggested Frank should help him sell videos and showed him a sample. Frank said he watched in growing horror as the video played out a murder - a boy who seemed to be no older than 12 was beaten and attacked with needles, before being castrated and cut open with a knife. The video seemed to have been shot in a barn, and detectives later learned that Williams and his friends had been talking about making a video in a barn that belonged to a German from one of the Spuistraat clubs.

Scotland Yard was in a difficult position: the informants were British and so was Spinks, who by this time had left Amsterdam and was living in Hastings, East Sussex. But everything else in the story was scattered round Europe. After long negotiations within Scotland Yard and with their counterparts in the Netherlands, the detectives set up Operation Framework, and, as the Guardian reported in 1997, they recruited an undercover officer to pose as a child abuser and befriend Warwick Spinks in England.

In a series of meetings, Spinks described how he picked up boys in Dresden, in Bratislava in the Czech Republic, and in Poland, where, he claimed, they cost only 10p. The undercover officer asked Spinks if he could get him a sado-masochistic video featuring boys as young as 10, and Spinks replied that he knew people in Amsterdam who could: "I know, well I knew, some people who were involved in making snuff movies and how they did it was, they only sold them in limited editions, made 10 copies or something, 10 very rich customers in America, who paid $5,000 each or something like that".

Spinks divulged no more about the video and failed to produce a copy of it. Without more evidence, Scotland Yard could not justify the expense of keeping the undercover officer or of sending officers to Amsterdam, where, in any event, they lacked police powers. They arrested Spinks in Hastings and charged him with adbucting and raping two homeless boys from the streets of London and selling one of them into a Spuistraat brothel. He was jailed for five years. But the allegation of murder would not go away. As the Guardian reported in 1997, another gay man, Edward, claimed to have seen five Amsterdam videos, each featuring the sexual torture and death of a boy. Dutch police investigated and said they could find no evidence.

Now, Terry had offered the Bristol detectives more evidence about life on Spuistraat. He explained how John Gay and Lee Tucker set themselves up as video pornographers, first taking a group of boys to an isolated farmhouse in France, and then making visits to Amsterdam to film with the boys there. And dealing with snuff movies he told how, in 1989, he had been alone in a flat which belonged to one of the key figures in the Amsterdam paedophile scene, whom he named; he had found a video and watched as it played out a murder - a boy was beaten before being castrated and cut open with a knife.

At first sight, Terry might have been describing the video Frank saw but its details differ: Frank described a video shot in a barn; Terry says his was shot in a flat. Frank described the abuse and murder of one boy; Terry says there was a second boy, who was also being abused and who was alive at the point he turned off the tape. And yet, the overlap is striking: the specific nature of the violence is identical; and Terry names the man who actually committed the killing - he is the same German whose barn was allegedly picked as a porn studio by the child porngraphers.

Terry, Frank, Edward and Spinks certainly mixed with the paedophile colony in Amsterdam in 1989/90 and all four separately claim at least one boy was killed on video. Spinks told the undercover officer that a German boy was killed; Frank says Spinks once hinted to him that a German boy named Manny had been murdered; we have confirmed from talking to boys who worked in Spuistraat at the time that a boy of that name and nationality, then 14, did disappear. Terry, however, says he thinks the victim of the video which he saw was Dutch, named Marco and probably 16.

Currying favour
At one end of the scale of possibility, every one of these men may be lying in an attempt to score favours with the police or to cause trouble for others on the Amsterdam scene, and certainly it was not unusual for boys to disappear from Spuistraat simply because they had had enough of being exploited.

At the other end of the scale, the truth is that one or more boys was killed in a snuff movie - and the murderers have got away with it.

The Bristol detectives can get no further. The Dutch say they will not investigate, and Avon and Somerset police have neither the funds nor the legal power to run their own inquiry in the Netherlands.

There have been successful paedophilia operations between British and European police. Scotland Yard detectives recently have twice arrested wanted men and extradited them to the Netherlands for trial on child sex offences. Within their borders, the Dutch paedophilia unit have arrested several of the key British paedophiles, and, since January 1996, the Netherlands has introduced a tougher law, which threatens up to six years for production of child pornography. The clubs on Spuistraat are no longer the paedophile playground they were. But the wider picture is of police trapped within their borders with the result that the European trade in boys for sexual exploitation has been allowed to grow without restraint.

A couple of years ago, I sat in the Blue Boy club on Spuistraat, amid the dry ice and the boys in thongs, and flicked through the catalogue on the bar, offering "truly the best boys in town", and watched a Japanese businessman make his purchase. In search of their origins, I went to Berlin, to the Bahnhof Am Zoo, where the trains arrive from all over eastern Europe, bringing the destitute in search of a dream. A specialist social worker there, Wolfgang Werner, told me there were some 700 east European boys, aged from 11 to 17, who had ended up in the sex industry in Berlin. But, to his knowledge, many hundreds of others had been taken off on a kind of underground railroad which fanned out to Zurich and Hamburg and Frankfurt, and, most of all, to Rotterdam and Amsterdam.

Werner told me, for example, about the Romanian boys who had been sold by their parents to a wandering Polish criminal, who had paid cash for some and a bottle of vodka for another, before putting them on to the streets of Berlin.

I followed the trail of two men, Peter Goetjes and Lutz Edelman, identified as traffickers in the Berlin press. Eventually, I spoke to a friend of theirs, who said that, of course, they had been trafficking. They must have sold 150 between them, before Goetjes was caught on the Polish border in the summer of 1992 with a boy in his boot. Goetjes was charged with smuggling, released on bail and then drove away and never came back for his trial. About that time, he and Edelman stopped trafficking, not so much because of Goetjes's arrest but because they had been told some of the boys were being used in snuff movies. fields.bodyText: A year after Bristol detectives finally started to unravel the ring of paedophiles who had been abusing children there for up to 20 years, they found an informant with an alarming story. The man, whom we will call Terry, had a long history of sexually abusing boys. He did not come from Bristol but, by chance, he had come across some of the paedophiles the detectives were investigating - in Amsterdam, where he said they had become involved with a group of exiled British child abusers who had succeeded in commercialising their sexual obsession. The exiled paedophiles were trafficking boys from other countries; running legitimate gay brothels and selling under-aged boys "under the counter"; they had branched out into the production of child pornography. And they had killed some of them. One boy had simply been shot through the head, Terry said: he had been causing trouble and had been executed in front of several pae dophiles. Another, he believed, had been thrown into one of the canals. But the one about whom he spoke the most was a boy who had been tortured and killed in the most painful fashion in the course of producing a pornographic video. Terry said he had seen most of the video himself and had vomited before he could reach the end. The few detectives who specialise in the investigation of child abuse invariably say the same thing about "snuff" movies: they have often heard of them, sometimes pursued them but never found one. The videos remain one of the great unsolved mysteries of the burgeoning underworld of international sexual exploitation. Twice told tale Terry's account was so hideous as to invite disbelief. It was clearly possible that he was inventing the story in an attempt to curry favour with the detectives as they turned over Bristol's paedophile subculture. And yet the detectives discovered that the allegation had been made before. Not just once but repeatedly, evidence had come to the attention of police in England and the Netherlands, that, for pleasure and profit, some of the exiled paedophiles in Amsterdam had mur dered boys in front of the camera. Some of the evidence had been pursued. Some of it had been ignored. None of it had led to a murder charge. For a short while, the Bristol detectives thought they might be able to make progress in tracking down the truth; but when two of them flew to Amsterdam in the autumn of 1998 to pass on their information to Dutch officers, they hit a wall. Terry had described the flat in Amsterdam where he had seen the video; he had named the owner of the flat who was, by implication, also owner of the video; he had provided the name of the man who carried out the killing; he had described events on the video in detail; he had provided the approximate age and the first name of the dead boy. Dutch police said it was not enough: without the full name of a victim, they would not begin an investigation. Having fought their way through the swamp of inertia which surrounds British policing and prosecution of child abuse, the Bristol detectives had now hit the deeper swamp of virtual paralysis that afflicts its international policing. Within their own jurisdictions, there are now specialist paedophilia detectives - for example, in London and Amsterdam - who will work relentlessly to lock up predatory child abusers. But when they try to move abroad, the potentially powerful machine starts to misfire. The result is that there is now a flourishing underground trade in boys who are being exported from the economic chaos of eastern Europe, as well as from the streets of London, to be put to work in the sex industry of western Europe. And no effective police operation to deal with it. Predatory paedophiles cross whatever borders they like in order to pursue their obsessions; the police who might follow them are almost always trapped within their own narrow jurisdictions, partly by differences in law and procedure, partly because they lack the manpower and money to work internationally. There is an exception to this rule of parochialism, in the highly funded war against drugs, but in the perverse world of modern policing, the trafficking, rape and alleged murder of children has a far lower priority. We have uncovered an international paedophile ring whose roots spring from Amsterdam, where, in the late 1980s, a group of British paedophiles set up a colony, exploiting the freedom of the city's gay community as cover to make a business of their fantasies. Legal front One of the first to do so was Alan Williams, the "Welsh Witch", who already had a vicious history of abusing boys in south Wales. Williams arrived in Amsterdam in 1988, aged 21, and soon set himself up as the manager of a gay brothel called Boys Club 21 at 21 Spuistraat, near the central station. Across the road at number 44, another British paedophile, a chubby Londoner named Warwick Spinks, then aged 25, was running a similar club called the Gay Palace. Both clubs had a legal business, running a bar and offering the services of adult male prostitutes. But Williams and Spinks had much crueller interests. Williams had fled to the Netherlands after being convicted in Britain of indecent assaults on boys. In Amsterdam, he boasted of the day in south Wales when he had seen a 10-year-old boy on his bike, grabbed him, raped him, and, when he cried, strangled him. From Boys Clubs 21, he organised the importing of boys from Cardiff and London, inflicting intense violence on any who defied him. Spinks had been running a mail order pornography business from Brighton, before he moved to Amsterdam, where he pioneered the trafficking of boys as young as 10 - first, from the streets of London, and, after the collapse of the Soviet Union, from the poverty of eastern Europe. Having brought them to Amsterdam, he used these "chickens" himself, sold them into the brothels or through escort agencies and put them in front of the camera. But the most startling allegations came from a gay man, "Frank", who had gone to Amsterdam in July 1990 and found himself caught up in this paedophile underworld. In 1993, he spoke to the same officers at Scotland Yard. Frank said he watched in growing horror as the video played out a murder - a boy who seemed to be no older than 12 was beaten and attacked with needles, before being castrated and cut open with a knife. The video seemed to have been shot in a barn, and detectives later learned that Williams and his friends had been talking about making a video in a barn that belonged to a German from one of the Spuistraat clubs. Scotland Yard was in a difficult position: the informants were British and so was Spinks, who by this time had left Amsterdam and was living in Hastings, East Sussex. But everything else in the story was scattered round Europe. After long negotiations within Scotland Yard and with their counterparts in the Netherlands, the detectives set up Operation Framework, and, as the Guardian reported in 1997, they recruited an undercover officer to pose as a child abuser and befriend Warwick Spinks in England. webTitle: Four slightly injured as Virgin train derails at low speed

fields.headline: Four slightly injured as Virgin train derails at low speed
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: A Virgin train carrying around 400 passengers derailed south of Glasgow last night, but there were no serious injuries.
fields.body:
A Virgin train carrying around 400 passengers derailed south of Glasgow last night, but there were no serious injuries.

Four people were injured, according to Dorothy Fenwick, Railtrack's head of corporate affairs. The train, which was seven miles short of its destination, had taken 8 hours from Euston station, London.

She said two passengers had suffered shock, one had a slight neck injury and one was reported to have cuts and bruises.

The nine-coach train was travelling at 15mph through Mossend South junction when four carriages went off the rails at 7.05pm.

The coaches remained upright, but passengers had to disembark from one of the carriages that remained on the tracks before being taken by coach to a community centre. Virgin Trains' media relations manager, Jim Rowe, said taxis had been arranged to take them home.

A Railtrack Scotland spokeswoman said the line was not subject to the speed restrictions imposed on tracks throughout Britain following the Hatfield rail crash last month in which four people died.

"It was not a site identified as having gauge corner cracking, so it wasn't a site with emergency speed restrictions. The train was travelling at a slow speed through the junction, as trains normally do at that particular point."

The Scottish secretary, John Reid, said that railway inspectors from the health and safety executive were on their way to the scene.

The train, the 10.30am express, had been diverted from its usual route while Railtrack carried out repairs.

Railtrack workers replaced 20 miles of track over the weekend, one mile more than expected.

Nearly one-and-a-quarter miles of track was being replaced at Gamston, south of Retford, Nottinghamshire, with almost a mile of new line being laid at Knebworth, Hertfordshire.

About six miles of track was being replaced on the northern section of the West Coast main line, while more than a mile and a half of track was being put in place from Bow to Bethnal Green in east London.

Railtrack said this would lead to more speed restrictions being lifted although she could not say which ones or when.

So far 200 speed restrictions have been lifted, but 200 miles of track still needs to be repaired.

The health and safety executive was today due to publish figures showing that the number of signals passed at danger during October fell to 53, 17 fewer than the same month last year. The statistics appeared to contradict claims that speed restrictions had increased danger for passengers.

webTitle: A gem of a career

fields.headline: A gem of a career
fields.standfirst: Hannah Broke-Smith adores Cartier jewellery, and she admits that her job with the company has become an obsession
fields.trailText: Hannah Broke-Smith adores Cartier jewellery, and she admits that her job with the company has become an obsession.
fields.body:
The Cartier name has been associated with fine jewels since 1847 and there are many people who claim to have had a love affair with the company for years, whether or not they can afford to splash out on one of their distinctive pieces of jewellery. Hannah Broke-Smith, for one, can remember exactly when hers began. She joined Cartier as senior press assistant on Valentine's day this year and readily admits her job has become an obsession.

"My department is responsible for Cartier's image, so we organise events, plan all the advertising and deal with any charity requests," she explains. Cartier can claim some of the world's wealthiest people as clients, and the events that Broke-Smith organises must reflect this.

"I've just finished working on the Cartier racing awards. It's a very important date in the horse-racing calendar and was particularly special this year because the Aga Khan was there to receive the Daily Telegraph award of merit and the Queen was presented with the Cartier millennium award" - although she did not have to turn up to the ceremony, but was presented with hers in the privacy of Buckingham Palace.

The first event of the year is a dinner on the evening of the Chelsea Flower Show gala which marks the beginning of the social season. In June, Cartier has a marquee at the Goodwood Festival of Speed where it entertains clients with champagne and hosts a classic automobile design competition. The next big occasion is the Cartier International Polo where 750 guests, including a smattering of celebrities such as Helen Mirren and Minnie Driver, sit down to lunch prepared by Anton Mosimann in a marquee designed by leading interior designer Kelly Hoppen.

Such prestigious occasions do not occur without a staggering amount of hard work. "Looking after our database is one of the most important things I do," says Broke-Smith. "It's fundamental that it's kept up to date - it would be unforgivable to send out an invitation to someone with an incorrect title or address. I also have to make sure that replies to invitations are logged accurately. It would be very embarrassing if someone arrived for a dinner and there wasn't a place for them because we'd entered their details incorrectly."

Together with communications director Pilar Boxford, Broke-Smith is responsible for the whole of each event from the design of the invitation to the seating plan. "Fortunately we have a computer program to help us build the table plans," she says, "but it's still time-consuming."

The careful and detailed planning behind the events is executed from beautifully appointed offices in New Bond Street in London, although Broke-Smith spends a good deal of time out of her office. "In addition to our annual event, we organise lots of other occasions and I'm always looking for suitable locations. For instance, in May we launched a new watch and had a launch party at the Light Bar in St Martin's Lane. I'm currently busy organising a party for China White members [an exclusive members-only club]. We'll have cock tails in our new boutique and then there'll be a party at China White."

Broke-Smith has a degree in English and worked for a year for a PR firm dealing with home and lifestyle clients before joining Cartier. "I've always wanted to work with luxury goods and it's a real privilege to work with such a fabulous product. When you come to work here you have the most amazing induction when you learn about all aspects of the company and go to the warehouse to see the jewellery being mended and polished. The hours that go into polishing a Cartier ring to show every diamond to its full potential makes it an art form in itself.

"The company also has an amazing history and the most incredible archives. In our showroom, we currently have an exhibition of our mystery clocks, which are truly spectacular and very rare pieces."

Having worked for a PR company with a wide range of different clients, Broke-Smith relishes the high degree of involvement of working in-house. "Everyone here works very much as a team. For example, if I'm working on an event that I think might make quite a good feature, I'll suggest it to someone in our press office."

Cartier is, of course, a French company and Broke-Smith was able to attend the launch of the new Cartier bag at the Petit Palais in Paris in October. "We took Sophie Ellis-Bextor along, too, and she modelled the bag."

Although the jetsetting, name-dropping life sounds very glamorous, Broke-Smith insists that her ability to do the job well is dependent on her fixation with detail. "Everybody here strives for perfection - and luckily that's how I am, too."

Having worked for a PR company with a wide range of different clients, Broke-Smith relishes the high degree of involvement of working in-house. "Everyone here works very much as a team. For example, if I'm working on an event that I think might make quite a good feature, I'll suggest it to someone in our press office." Cartier is, of course, a French company and Broke-Smith was able to attend the launch of the new Cartier bag at the Petit Palais in Paris in October. "We took Sophie Ellis-Bextor along, too, and she modelled the bag." Although the jetsetting, name-dropping life sounds very glamorous, Broke-Smith insists that her ability to do the job well is dependent on her fixation with detail. "Everybody here strives for perfection - and luckily that's how I am, too."

webTitle: Planning Christmas parties

fields.headline: Festivities and frugalities
fields.standfirst: Whether your employer is Santa or Scrooge when it comes to paying for the Christmas bash, wise planning can pep up the party.  Dolly Dhingra  reports
fields.trailText: Whether your employer is Santa or Scrooge when it comes to paying for the Christmas bash, wise planning can pep up the party. Dolly Dhingra reports
fields.body:
The title of Scrooge is so abhorred during the countdown to the festive season that even Ken Livingstone, London's mayor, was forced to reconsider his decision not to pay for the booze for the Greater London authority's Christmas party. "After seeing myself described as Scrooge," said Livingstone, who had previously agreed to pay only for food, "I have changed my mind."

Love them or hate them - at some point, someone somewhere in the workplace is going to have to decide who pays for the Christmas do and how much the knees-up will cost. But don't assume the boss will always foot the bill. According to the Institute of Management's most recent survey on Christmas parties, only 44% of organisations were offering to pay for the staff festivities. So what about the rest? Are they a bunch of mean-spirited curmudgeons?

Not necessarily, it seems, since not all organisations have the ability to pass off a work party as expenses, or to squeeze it out of the budget under the nebulous category of "special projects". Take school administrators. "Our staff have to fund Christmas celebrations themselves. It's always been the same," explains Sue Baskill of Grafton infants school in Dagenham. "We organise dinners at restaurants, or in the past we've had after-school buffets. This year it's costing us £25 per head. The only freebies we are ever likely to get are a couple of glasses of orange squash after an Inset [training] day."

It doesn't get much better in the public health sector either, where sensitivity over the use of public funds means that merry-making is rather limited. "I don't go to our Christmas parties, because I live in Southend so catching a train back late is always a bit of a problem," says Christine Baldwin, 54, of Tower Hamlets NHS Trust in London. "We never have parties in work time and never spend NHS money on them. I see my colleagues enough at work and we've all got our lives to be getting on with. But the rest of the staff always say that they have a jolly good time."

Such frugality is not the traditional fare for those in the business sector, where the Christmas bash is the expected end to a year of hard work. And employees aren't keen to fund the treat themselves. "It's usually the company that pays for the event, but sometimes it comes from a social club budget that people might have been paying into on a regular basis," explains Gavin Parkhouse of party organisers William Bartholomews.

Whether you're dipping into your own pocket for the party hats and crackers, or enjoying it courtesy of the firm, the organisation of the Christmas party remains fraught with difficulties. Vallie Watson, director of Party Professionals, has been arranging them for 16 years, and knows a thing or two about the minefield that the office get-together presents. "Often you'll get employees groaning inwardly and not wanting to go because it's usually a thrown-together affair, allocated as yet another chore to an already overworked secretary. It's very important to surprise those attending - make the party a civilised affair so that it doesn't turn into a bunfight," she says.

So what is the key to a good office party? "It's important to treat people like guests and not like employees," stresses Watson. "Aim high, and don't go for the lowest common denominator: resist cheap booze and a disco in the basement of a club somewhere. Make sure the atmosphere isn't so terrifying that everyone hits the bottle.

"Also, try to get your Christmas party in early so that everyone hasn't become jaded by all the other parties they've been to. I would say early in December, since Christmas seems to be getting earlier each year."

Reminding yourself that the Christmas party is a way in which employers hope to make work colleagues feel rewarded is often hard to grasp as you stand desperately clutching your Lambrusco and nibbling a cheese straw while trying to improvise an ice-breaking line with someone who rarely makes eye contact with you in the office. But, say the experts, do try.

"Basically, Christmas parties are a big thank-you from employers to workers. So just make sure that you don't behave in a way that you may regret the next day. It's a fine line between relaxing and enjoying yourself and overdoing it," says Parkhouse. And that means no photocopying of bums, quick snogs in the stationery cupboard or getting tipsy with the MD - even if he has paid for all the booze.

webTitle: The reality of a career in television

fields.headline: Behind the screens
fields.standfirst: If you dream of a career in TV, fame and glamour are no doubt uppermost in your mind. But what's it really like?  Mabel Msonthi  finds out
fields.trailText: If you dream of a career in TV, fame and glamour are no doubt uppermost in your mind. But what's it really like? Mabel Msonthi finds out.
fields.body:
We've all been there - you're on your daily commute, day-dreaming about that perfect job in television. Perhaps you rehearse a scenario in your mind involving the director catching sight of you one morning and suggesting you fill in for a reporter or weather person who has failed to turn up. After all, it happened to the likes of Jonathan Ross and Anthea Turner, so why not you?

Sadly, the reality could be a lot closer to a bit-part scene in which you have to endure the endless grind of tea- and coffee-making in your role as the office lackey. So how is life for those working behind the scenes in television and is glamour really part of the job description?

Being a secretary is only one of many possible choices when it comes to a TV career. Career Moves, a London recruitment agency specialising in media and advertising appointments, for example, is looking for producers, production coordinators, editors, schedulers, compliance officers, promo producers, traffic and bookings managers, all of which fall under the media remit.

Rebecca Milligan, 28, has worked her way up from presentation assistant at UK Gold, to a research and co-ordinating job at the BBC. "After graduating with an English degree I didn't have a specific job in mind but I was adamant about working in the world of media," she says. The cliche about "contacts getting you everywhere" is definitely true, she adds. "The key attributes you need are an ability to keep abreast of changes in the business and the nous to make the right moves at the right time."

Milligan is philosophical about the back-stabbing that is notorious in the competitive media world. "It's obvious that with a hugely popular profession you're going to have to develop a tough attitude to survive. When I was a production assistant I worked beneath people whom I knew were far less qualified than I was, but nevertheless earned considerably more than me simply because they joined the company's graduate trainee scheme. I couldn't protest about this as it was up to me to seize opportunities as and when they presented themselves." Her ascent to her current role has seen her juggling positions as diverse as live gallery PA, responsible for timing introductions between live broadcasts, to directing promotional trails between advertisements.

Julie Harrington also had her heart set on a job in TV after graduating. "I'd always toyed with the idea of becoming a news presenter," she says. "But when I found out that you needed to be a trained journalist to present news at a national level, I decided to investigate other positions.

"I started as a PA to the head of production within an independent TV production company which was a good starting point for learning how the business worked. Two years later I landed my current assistant producer role with a major independent company. The job is fantastic but I work incredibly long hours and constantly have to think on my feet. I do see famous people regularly, but I am so engrossed in making everything run smoothly that there is little time for being starstruck."

Harrington confesses that a certain ruthlessness permeates the TV business as chief producers won't acknowledge the words "no" or "can't". "I've been asked to find six contestants for a Blind Date-style broadcast and devise a children's activity for a kiddies' slot for a cable TV show, all in less than 48 hours. I tend to live on my nerves a bit so it suits me, but I've seen others completely crash and burn under the stress of it," she admits.

A willingness to endure long working hours on a moderate salary is vital, especially when set against the dream salary packages offered to graduates entering the traditional corporate workplace. Whatever glamour does exist is put sharply into focus by the frenetic deadlines, and success can be guaranteed only for those shrewd enough to know when to make the right moves. But if you do so, you won't look back.

webTitle: The inside track: Events management

fields.headline: The inside track
fields.standfirst: Events management
fields.trailText: Events management.
fields.body:
The events industry is comparatively new, but growing rapidly. The mutant offspring of public relations, it has a life and, more importantly, a career path of its own. Even the car rental industry has an annual awards ceremony, at which figures in evening dress stagger to the stage to collect a plaque for van renter of the year. Yes, event organisation can be a full-time job, with never a dull moment.

The industry has its own trade press, led by Event Organiser, a mine of information on the hiring of marquees and portaloos. It also has its own trade association, the Corporate Hospitality & Event Managers Association, which, naturally, organises its own annual awards ceremony, and works to ensure professional standards.

As a new industry, there is still great scope for promotion from scratch. And it is a career path that suits a secretarial background because much of the work requires fulfilling outrageous requests at short notice, especially at this time of year. Where do you find a choir, plus fake snow to drop on them? Where can one hire Stars in their Eyes winners for a Christmas party?

But the work is far from seasonal. Every business requires a little razzmatazz now and again. Annual reports are "launched" these days rather than mailed out. Sales conferences are spiced with a murder mystery dinner. There is a strong element of competition because companies want to be more adventurous than their rivals. As with PR, some organisations have in-house events teams. With so many to be entertained - employees, clients, customers and shareholders - it's a full-time job.

It is also a job that requires a certain temperament. For a start, you must enjoy parties. Commitment is required, too, because events people are busiest outside office hours. But this is not to disguise the fact that the job is great fun, because that, after all, is the object of the exercise.

webTitle: How to network

fields.headline: Sec's tips
fields.standfirst: 13. Networking
fields.trailText: Networking
fields.body:
How would you like to get help looking for a new job, find out how other PAs run their lives, discover better work systems, ask opinions on office kit before you buy, share problems, pick up new ideas, find out about your industry sector, and maybe even have a laugh while you're doing it? Well you can - if you start networking. All these benefits, and many more, are available when you talk to other secretaries and PAs. There's a world of experience and information just waiting to be tapped into. So how do you do it?

 Rule number one: leave your desk. Contacts won't come to you - you have to seek them out. Look at events aimed at secretaries, or in your sector, and go to them. Try a secretarial group or network, attend an exhibition or conference, use the internet, do a training course...

 Get your own business cards. No self-respecting PA jots down her (or his) professional contact details on a train ticket or supermarket receipt. Even cards from the "print-your-own" machines at railway stations are better than that.

 At a function where there are several people you'd like to meet, set yourself a target. Aim to come away with, say, six business cards. Don't spend three hours with one person and miss all the other contacts in the room.

 Be bold. At business events, it's expected that you will mingle and make contacts, so approach a friendly looking group and say, "Hello, my name's Katherine, I'm from XYZ plc". Now how hard is that?

 Don't be afraid to ask for help or information. After all, if someone asks you for help, you're pleased to give it, right? So is everyone else. In fact, any reasonable request is flattering.

 Follow up contacts within a few days. Ring and say how nice it was to meet them. If you promised to do anything, ensure you do it promptly. Try to keep in touch regularly but briefly - an email once a fortnight and a phone call once a month is enough.

 Make contact even when you don't need anything. Don't fall into the "she only rings when she wants something" trap. Offer them something: "I saw a good training course today and thought you might be interested."

 Forget reservations about networking "using" people. If done properly, it offers a mutual benefit to both parties and can foster life-long business relationships - even friendships. So, where are you going next week...?

Penny Cottee is editor of Executive PA magazine.

webTitle: Mobile phones to carry health warning

fields.headline: Mobile phones to carry health warning
fields.standfirst: Special report: mobile phone fears
fields.trailText: All mobile phones sold in Britain are set to carry health warnings about the dangers of excessive use, particularly for children.
fields.body:
All mobile phones sold in Britain are set to carry health warnings about the dangers of excessive use, particularly for children.

The warnings, expected to be launched in the run up to Christmas, are aimed at parents buying mobile phones for their children as presents.

The move, which phone manufacturers believe is unnecessary, comes amid con cern at the possible effects of cell phone use on the brain because of microwave radiation.

In May an official inquiry found no evidence that mobile phone use damaged health, but neither could it prove it was harmless.

The inquiry, chaired by Sir William Stewart, said the widespread use of mobiles by children should be discouraged, but left it to parents to make an "informed choice".

Last Christmas mobile phones were one of the most popular presents with 4m sold. Nearly half the population has one, with 25m being bought since the product hit the market.

The wording of the leaflet is being finalised and it is unlikely it will state how much time a day it is safe for a child to use a mobile.

A source said: "This will not be a cigarette packet style warning. We think consumers need advice on how to and how not to use a mobile phone."

Mike Caldwell, from the Vodafone network, said: "It's a precautionary approach aimed especially at children. In broad terms it will say if children have to make a call, they should be kept to a minimum. The Stewart report did not give any guidance on how long should be applied, but common sense is the best bet."

The Consumers Association welcomed the "better informing of consumers about mobile phones".

A British industry source said: "The health scare has not slowed the market in the slightest. People are of the opinion that there is more chance of being run over by a bus."

Tapio Hedman, spokesman for the mobile phone manufacturer Nokia, said he believed warning leaflets were unnecessary. Fears about the health risk to children were so unfounded that he would be happy to let his children aged eight and 10 use mobile phones all day.

He added: "All the mobile phones available fulfil all the safety standards and limits set by authorities in the given country and internationally."

In the US, fears over the risks of mobile phones to children's health last week led the Disney company to stop licensing its cartoon characters for cell phones.

Professor Colin Blakemore of Oxford University, a member of the Stewart inquiry and an expert on the brain, last week told American television: "If there is a hazard from this technology, then the kids are more vulnerable. And I think if the industry were to behave truly responsibly, they would play their part in discouraging children from unnecessary use."

Prof Blakemore said children would be more at risk from any health risks because their heads are smaller, making them more vulnerable to microwaves. A child's thinner skull is also less resistant to radiation penetration.

webTitle: Prescott: French sank deal on climate

fields.headline: Prescott: French sank deal on climate
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: John Prescott was embroiled in an extraordinary international slanging match last night after accusing the French environment minister of scuppering 12 days of talks to agree legally binding reductions in greenhouse gases.
fields.body:
John Prescott was embroiled in an extraordinary international slanging match last night after accusing the French environment minister of scuppering 12 days of talks to agree legally binding reductions in greenhouse gases.

The deputy prime minister singled out Dominique Voynet for blame after his European counterparts had refused to accept a compromise he personally negotiated at the Hague world climate change conference.

Using typically blunt language, Mr Prescott declared: "She got cold feet, felt she could not explain it, said she was exhausted and tired and could not understand the detail and then refused to accept it. That is how the deal fell."

Ms Voynet was unrepentant yesterday, accusing Mr Prescott of giving in to US demands.

"Britain had conceded too much to America. It was not acceptable," she said.

Mr Prescott's outburst on BBC radio followed the collapse of the discussions intended to agree ways of implementing reductions in potentially harmful carbon dioxide and other gases agreed at the Kyoto summit three years ago.

Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman, issued a statement praising Mr Prescott.

"The prime minister believes John Prescott did an extraordinary job getting so close to an agreement," he said.

"Kyoto would not have happened without his drive and determination, and these talks only got as far as they did because of similar drive and determination."

Mr Prescott's outburst, however, could make an agreement difficult when talks resume next year, and his relations with the French minister will be strained.

One possible way out of the impasse being canvassed by French, German and Danish greens is for Europe to ratify the Kyoto protocol, by including the Russians and Japan but excluding the Americans in a bid to shame them into action.

Mr Prescott denied he had walked out of the talks, insisting he left the Hague at Saturday lunchtime to catch a flight home.

But after talks through the night with the Americans had produced what he was convinced would be an agreement at 6am on Saturday, he admitted he was "gutted" when he had to concede defeat six hours later.

The deputy prime minister criticised other European ministers for failing to show what he claimed was enough political courage to make the deal happen.

"It failed in the European area," Mr Prescott said. "There comes a time when politicians have to use their own guts, their own judgment."

He had persuaded the Washington delegation to accept, after consultations with the White House, that the US could not buy "carbon credits" by planting forests abroad to offset domestic emissions.

The French, Germans, Danes and Swedes, however, were suspicious of the detail and unhappy that a second big stumbling block - US insistence that forest or agricultural changes at home be accepted as carbon credits - remained unresolved.

Mr Prescott is thought to have overestimated his ability make a deal, failing to fully understand that the political landscape has changed in Europe in the three years since he was able to claim credit for brokering a similar last minute agreement that rescued the Kyoto climate talks from a similar disaster.

In Japan he was able to talk to the US vice-president Al Gore directly across the table. Mr Gore in turn talked on the telephone to President Clinton who told him to accept compromises.

Last week it was different. First the Americans had asked for ever larger and more impossible loopholes. This had begun seriously to damage the credibility of the agreement and angered many in the European governments, which have become greener in the past three years.

The most notable was Ms Voynet, a fiery green party minister in the French coalition.

Many environmental campaigners backed Mr Prescott yesterday, saying that he was right to try to make a deal with the Americans, however bad, because under a Bush presidency any agreement might be impossible.

The environment minister Michael Meacher remained hopeful that the European environment ministers meeting on December 17 might salvage something out of the Prescott compromise and come to a political deal with the Americans before the end of the Clinton presidency in January.

But that possibility looks remote.

The next opportunity comes in May. Jan Pronk, the Dutch environment minister and president of the Hague talks, officially adjourned the discussions until then.

But the next big political meeting is not until this time next year, by which time Mr Prescott's climate deal days may be over.

webTitle: Rights Act could overturn loans law

fields.headline: Rights Act could overturn loans law
fields.trailText: Three senior judges are poised to make the first ruling under the Human Rights Act that a statute passed by the UK parliament is incompatible with the European convention on human rights.
fields.body:
Three senior judges are poised to make the first ruling under the Human Rights Act that a statute passed by the UK parliament is incompatible with the European convention on human rights.

Ministers and judges had predicted the controversial power would be rarely exercised. Yet the court of appeal is threatening to use it less than two months after the Human Rights Act came into force - to protect the rights of pawnbrokers in a claim over a £5,000 loan.

Three judges headed by the vice-chancellor Sir Andrew Morritt, head of the high court's chancery division, adjourned an appeal last Thursday to notify the government that they propose to declare the Consumer Credit Act 1974 incompatible with the convention.

The judges have taken the unprecedented step on their own initiative. Neither of the parties to the case, a pawnbroking firm, First County Trust (FCT), and a woman who borrowed £5,000, relied on the Human Rights Act.

UK judges have no power, as they do in Canada under similar legislation, to strike down a statute. Ministers decided such a power would be inconsistent with parliamentary sovereignty and would politicise the judges too much.

As a compromise they were given the right to make a "declaration of incompatibility". The act lays down a fast-track procedure whereby parliament can amend the offending statute quickly.

A court proposing to make a declaration of incompatibility must first give notice to the government minister involved, in this case the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, to give him a chance to brief a legal team and join proceedings.

The judges were concerned that the pawnbrokers were left without a remedy when a Mrs Wilson, who pledged her BMW convertible for a six-month loan of £5,000, successfully argued that the agreement was unenforceable. That entitled her not only to keep her car but to reclaim the £5,000 plus interest she paid to the pawnbrokers.

FCT had made a mistake in drawing up the agreement required by the Consumer Credit Act. Mrs Wilson was charged £250 for preparing the document, which she asked to have added to the loan. The document stated "amount of loan £5,250" but under the act the £250 counts as part of the charge rather than part of the loan. The agreement did not state the full amount of credit (£5,000), as required by the act.

Mrs Wilson failed to pay up and FCT threatened to sell her car unless she paid more than £7,000, including interest. She responded by suing FCT in the county court, representing herself and arguing that the agreement was unenforceable. The judge disagreed but decided the interest, at more than £300 a month, was too high and substituted £175 a month. She eventually paid £6,900 a few months later and got her car back.

In the meantime, she appealed against the judge's ruling. The appeal court ruled that the agreement was not enforceable because the Consumer Credit Act states that "the court shall not make an enforcement order unless the document contains all the prescribed terms". So she was entitled to have both her car and her £6,900 back.

The appeal court judges said the pawnbrokers had been denied a fair hearing under article 6 of the convention because the Consumer Credit Act placed an absolute bar on their right to have the agreement enforced by the court. The act also seemed to breach their right not to be deprived of their property - £5,000 under article 1 of protocol 1 to the convention.

webTitle: Climate change: Leave US out of deal, propose greens

fields.headline: Leave US out of deal, propose greens
fields.trailText: The collapse of talks at The Hague sent shock waves round the world yesterday and left 160 nations wondering how best to proceed when the only fact on which they appear united is that climate change remains the most serious threat facing mankind.
fields.body:
The complete collapse of climate talks at The Hague sent shock waves round the world yesterday and left all 160 nations which took part wondering how best to proceed when the only fact on which they appear united is that climate change remains the most serious threat facing mankind.

A last-minute deal stitched up by John Prescott, deputy prime minister, in his self-appointed role as mediator between the US and EU, fell apart when France, Germany, Denmark and Sweden rejected it - leaving him "gutted", as he put it.

Yesterday, however, he bounced back, saying indications he had received since returning to the UK were that "with a little more work" the negotiations could successfully conclude. He hoped talks would resume at the end of May in Bonn in preparation for a political settlement in Marrakesh next year, the next scheduled full meeting of the parties.

He said the developing countries that would have got a $1bn dollar (£700m) aid package out of it "were happy" and the EU dissenters were "coming round".

But other observers thought that with the still largely hostile US senate and the prospect of a Bush administration, the chances of a deal look slight.

One alternative being canvassed is to cut the US out of the deal altogether. This is openly being discussed because most EU states are committed to ratifying the Kyoto agreement whatever the Americans do.

Technically, if developed countries with emissions amounting to 55% of the world's total ratify the treaty, then it comes into force.

The US has 36% of the world total and the European Union only has 24%. But with the help of Russia with 17%, Japan with 8.5% and a few smaller states like the Ukraine to make up the numbers it would be possible to freeze out the US and its allies, Canada and Australia.

Although everyone accepts that cutting the huge US pollution tally is vital in the long run, this ploy would put enormous pressure on the administration to take part. If the US did not sign up to the treaty, it would be banned from international trading on carbon credits, and technology transfer trading deals with the developing world. And the new technologies to deal with global warming - wind, solar, hydrogen-fuel cell cars and the like - would be developed in Europe and Japan, not the US.

Dominique Voyet, the French environment minister, said before the talks failed last week: "If all goes wrong here then we will have to consider all the alternatives."

Tony Juniper, campaigns director of Friends of the Earth said yesterday: "Since the US has taken no domestic action to combat climate change, there is nothing to lose by excluding them altogether."

Although to prevent global warming getting out of control the US is vital, the idea of naming and shaming the US seemed to be taking hold yesterday. A number of calls were already going out on the internet to boycott US goods.

Around the world the US took most of the flak for the collapse of the three years of talks. Most of Europe and the developing world decided early last week that the Americans were making unacceptable demands to create loopholes in the treaty.

The two most contentious were to allow unlimited carbon "credits" for growing trees and changes in agricultural practices at home, and more credits for planting or buying forests in developing countries. The US moderated the claims as the talks progressed, but not enough to satisfy critics.

These concessions were described by Ms Voynet as "so unacceptable as not even worth discussing". Since France has the presidency of the EU she was talking on behalf of all 15 member states.

Ironically this came after Mr Prescott's last minute deal to block the second big loophole - one that meant the US could get unlimited credits if they planted or bought forests in developing countries. The claim was dropped entirely.

But by this time ministers had been up all night. They had been grinding through 200 amendments put up by the Saudis aimed at scuppering the talks. Most were exhausted and bad tempered, and according to Mr Prescott, "simply would not accept a political deal."

webTitle: Albanians flee as Serb deadline nears

fields.headline: Albanians flee as Serb deadline nears
fields.standfirst:
Refugees fear new offensive as tanks arrive at buffer zone.
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Hundreds of Albanian refugees were fleeing from south-eastern Serbia to Kosovo yesterday fearing an offensive by Yugoslav forces. A ceasefire between Serbian interior ministry police and a rebel Albanian group is due to end tonight.
fields.body:
Hundreds of Albanian refugees were fleeing from south-eastern Serbia to Kosovo yesterday fearing an offensive by Yugoslav forces. A ceasefire between Serbian interior ministry police and a rebel Albanian group is due to end tonight.

Dozens of cars and tractors carrying mainly women and children were queuing at the Kosovan border late last night. The UNHCR office in Kosovo said that at least 1,200 people had crossed into the province during the day.

Tension has increased in the region since fierce fighting occurred last week between the Serb authorities and the Preshevo, Medvedja and Bujanovac Liberation Army, an offshoot of the Kosovo Liberation Army

The guerrilla group, which receives arms and men from Kosovo, wants three Albanian-speaking towns in south-eastern Serbia to become part of an independent Kosovo. Last week's clashes were the most intense that the area has seen since the fighting began in February.

There are consistent claims that the Yugoslav army has deployed tanks and troops in the region and local people are afraid that the Serbs are preparing for a new offensive.

"There are lots of army, tanks and people digging trenches. We are all surrounded," said Burim Sylejman, 17, from the village of Oslare, who was taking 18 members of his extended family by tractor and trailer to Kosovo.

He said that Yugoslav interior police and regular army troops were being sent to Bujanovac and the surrounding villages. Some families were unable to leave.

"They've put sandbags in the streets and they have blocked the roads out of Ternovac, and they are turning people back."

Behind him in the trailer his sister Amire Sylejman, 22, tried to comfort a boy. Both were crying. "Everyone has left their houses, we were forced to leave ours, too," she said.

Near Konculj, the key village captured by the guerrillas last week, another man driving a tractor said he had seen seven tanks near by.

Using tanks to retake ground lost to the Albanians would breach Serbia's agreement with K-for, the peacekeeping forces in Kosovo. The Yugoslav army is banned from entering a three-mile zone on the Serb side of the provincial border.

A spokesman for K-For said it was unable to confirm or deny whether there had been any troop movements, because it was too far away.

The refugee influx comes at an awkward time for the UN chief administrator in Kosovo, Bernard Kouchner. He was due to meet the new Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, in Vienna today. They are both attending a summit held by the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe.

Belgrade has been putting more pressure on the UN in Kosovo to clamp down on the guerrillas. On Friday afternoon it announced its own three-day deadline - due to end today - for attacks to cease.

Earlier last week Zoran Djindjic, one of Yugoslavia's most senior politicians, warned that if the international community continued to tolerate the situation it would lead to "full-scale war".

K-For's spokesman, Flight Lieutenant Mark Whitty, said that the guerrillas and the Serbian authorities held talks at the weekend. K-For officials helped to broker the ceasefire signed on Friday.

The guerrillas showed no sign of relinquishing any territory as the deadline approached on Sunday.

Groups of soldiers carrying an assortment of machine guns and mortars manned the hilltops around Konculj.

A local commander, Vullnet Ibishi, said nine tanks and 10 armoured personnel carriers, plus two trucks carrying paramilitaries, were seen on Saturday afternoon near Lucane, the next village down the valley.

"We'll have to see what will happen. We are not going to do anything but we don't trust them," he said.

On a hillside track dozens of men and boys equipped with spades were filling the potholes.

"We have to improve it in case of casualties," one of the men said. The track led to guerrilla headquarters in the village of Dobrosin.

webTitle: Countdown to January 20

fields.headline: Key dates in US election battle
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Countdown to January 20.
fields.body:
Today Florida appeal court opens hearing into whether Palm Beach county should vote all over again because the "butterfly ballot" confused some people into voting for the wrong candidate

A court in Seminole county will decide whether to exclude 4,700 absentee ballots sent out at the instigation of Republican officials, instead of the voters themselves

Gore side expected to ask Florida supreme court to order Miami-Dade county to restart the hand recount it stopped when officials realised they could not finish by last night's deadline

All this week Bush side sues a number of Florida counties for ruling out some overseas military ballots

Friday December 1 US supreme court hears lawyers from both sides on the Bush camp's submission that none of Florida's hand recounts should be included. Result not expected before December 5

December 12 Deadline for appointment of members of electoral college which will choose the president

December 18 Electoral college members meet in each state capital and send votes to Washington

December 27 Deadline for arrival of electoral college votes

January 5 Senate and house of representatives count electoral college votes in joint session, and hear any objections. Both houses must approve the outcome; the house has a Republican majority, the Senate is likely to be split 50-50; the casting vote is held by Al Gore

January 20 New president sworn in and takes office

webTitle: Analysis: Labour and the Liberal Democrats

fields.headline: The poodle gives a nip
fields.standfirst:
Cooling relations between the Liberal Democrats and the government may lead to long-term problems after the next election.
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: After last week's byelection victories for Labour, May becomes even more the bookies' favourite for a general election. In the run up at least some electors will again consider whether to vote "tactically", so it becomes important to understand the identity of the party in the middle, the Liberal Democrats.
fields.body:
After last week's byelection victories for Labour, May becomes even more the bookies' favourite for a general election. In the run up at least some electors will again consider whether to vote "tactically", so it becomes important to understand the identity of the party in the middle, the Liberal Democrats.

Ever since they abandoned their policy of "equidistance" from Labour and the Tories after the 1992 election, their relationship with the party led by Tony Blair has been central to their definition of who they are. Paddy Ashdown's recently published diaries showed just how close that relationship became before the last election. Since May 1997, the Liberal Democrats moved to share power with Labour in Wales and Scotland, as well as to sit on cabinet committees at Westminster. But at the same time claims that the party is becoming too cosy with Labour have become more frequent.

The claims are wrong. Evidence from Liberal Democrat voting in both the Commons and the Lords shows exactly the opposite. Indeed, as claims about the relationship being too close grow ever louder, so the Liberal Democrats have become less supportive of Labour.

The Liberal Democrats began this parliament just as they ended the last: voting strongly in support of Labour, on both the principle and detail of legislation. Despite sitting on the opposi tion benches, they were more often than not to be found on the side of the government. As well as their own MPs, the government could count on Liberal Democrat MPs in around six out of every ten whipped votes in the first session of the Commons.

Each succeeding session has seen the Liberal Democrats less and less likely to vote with Labour. By the second session they were backing Labour in just under half of all votes. The third session has seen support fall to just over 40% of votes.

On the basis of their voting in the first session the Liberal Democrats had a view of the Labour party similar to the old Chinese communist view of Stalin: that he was 60% right but 40% wrong. They have now reversed their stance: Labour is 40% right and 60% wrong.

Not only that, but the Liberal Democrats have become more willing to vote with the Tories. In the first session, they voted with them in just over a quarter of votes (it was, as one of their MPs said at the time, "difficult to vote with the Tories, because they are so awful"). The second session saw the Liberal Democrats back the Tories in 40% of votes, with a rise to 43% in the third session.

The Tories have clearly become less awful and Labour more awful, because as the chart shows, the Liberal Democrats are now more likely to be voting with the Tories than with Labour. Either way, the result has been that the Liberal Democrats are now beginning to vote the way we might expect opposition parties to: against the government. If the Liberal Democrats ever were Labour's poodles, they are not any more.

Yet this cooling of relations is not evidence of the abandonment of the Liberal Democrats' policy of "constructive opposition". Breaking these figures down reveals that the decline in the frequency with which the Liberal Democrats vote with the government is not constant across all types of vote. When it comes to votes on the principle of government legislation - at second or third reading - the Liberal Democrats are still almost as supportive of the government now as they were in 1997, voting with Labour in more than seven out of ten votes. The problem comes with the votes on the detail.

Of course, we might expect the Liberal Democrats to be less supportive when it comes to votes on the fine print of bills. Indeed, proponents of constructive opposition would argue exactly this: that that Liberal Democrats should support the broad thrust of government policy whenever possible - not opposing bills for the sake of opposing them - but then try to improve the detail by proposing and voting for amendments wherever possible. And this always happened, even when the relationship with the government was at its strongest.

But the decline in Liberal Democrat support for the government has been sharpest on these votes. When it comes to votes on the detail of legislation, we now find the Liberal Democrats voting with Labour in just a third of votes. They have in effect increasingly begun to stress the "opposition", while retaining the "constructive".

With the largest Commons majority since 1935 - and Labour's largest ever - the Labour whips will not lose much sleep worrying about the way the Liberal Democrats will vote. Even on free votes, where the outcome is sometimes less certain, it is unlikely that the votes of Liberal Democrat MPs will swing many issues this parliament.

But this cooling of relations is still both a short-term and a long-term problem for Labour. While the Liberal Democrats may not hold the balance of power in the Commons, they frequently do in the reformed House of Lords. The recent rash of defeats in the Lords have all been on issues where the Liberal Democrats have opposed Labour, such as the privatisation of air traffic control, pensions reform, jury trials and the football disorder bill. In the long-term it is a problem because the more the two parties disagree, the harder it will be for them to form a coalition, should that be necessary after the election.

webTitle: Bush presedential bid

fields.headline: Rivals plot next moves to win the presidency - and public opinion
fields.standfirst:
'Victor' must appear decisive but not presumptuous

Special report: elections 2000
fields.trailText: George W Bush had always believed that when the votes were counted and certified in Florida, he would be able to claim the presidency. But his camp now tacitly accepts that the certification by the Florida secretary of state, Katherine Harris, is far from being the end of a long and tangled process.
fields.body:
George W Bush had always believed that when the votes were counted and certified in Florida, he would be able to claim the presidency. But his camp now tacitly accepts that the certification by the Florida secretary of state, Katherine Harris, is far from being the end of a long and tangled process.

"I'm just not going to speculate about what might happen, given the way that events in this environment swirl," a Bush spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said over the weekend.

But while victory in the certification process is no longer seen as the last word, it is still important, and Republicans were aiming to make the most of it as yesterday's deadline drew near. The party's main hope now is that certification will give Mr Bush a political boost, making the public more impatient for an end to nearly three weeks of manoeuvring.

"This will be the fourth win of George Bush in Florida," an ally, Governor John Engler of Michigan, said at the weekend. "The fact that these electoral votes put him over 270 [in the electoral college] is quite decisive."

Decisive or not, Mr Bush still faces some delicate issues of judgment as he tries to cement his claims to the presidency. Shortly after the November 7 election, Mr Bush sat down in Austin with prospective members of his administration and was promptly accused of presumptuous behaviour and arrogance. The team promptly abandoned any further premature public claims to victory.

With his victory in Florida officially certified - even though it will be challenged - Mr Bush and his running mate, Dick Cheney, plan new moves to lay claim to the White House. One important initiative open to them is to ask the federal government's general services administration for the keys to office space in Washington that has been set aside for the incoming administration.

"If he is certified, then I think it's over," Texas senator Kay Bailey Hutchison said as the deadline approached yesterday. "If Bush wins again that would be the time the American public would say this has been settled in the fairest possible way."

However, Mr Bush and Mr Cheney have themselves taken legal steps which ensure that the election result remains in the balance for some time to come. The most important of these was the appeal to the US supreme court, which is unlikely to rule before next week after holding oral hearings on Mr Bush's case on Friday.

Mr Bush cannot easily ignore the supreme court or pretend that it does not matter. He is therefore likely to move forward as decisively as he can, while always being careful not to appear over-hasty.

One factor that has complicated an already tangled web is Mr Cheney's heart attack last week. Mr Cheney had been appointed by Mr Bush to head the presidential transition effort on his behalf, but every time the vice-presidential nominee appears in public, he is likely to face questions about his health which will further muddy the waters of the public relations effort.

In practice, Mr Bush seems likely to continue to rely on surrogates and lieutenants to make his case for him most of the time.

After a slow start in the hours following the election, the Republicans are now deploying their "A-team" of public figures, including the former US secretary of state James Baker, former presidential candidate Bob Dole, and governors such as George Pataki of New York.

Conspicuous by their absence from the frontline are the party's leaders in the US Senate and House of Representatives, Senator Trent Lott and congressmen Dick Armey and Tom DeLay. All three are playing crucial behind-the-scenes roles but are deemed too divisive in the public mind to be given much exposure on the airwaves.
