webTitle: The US election has provided plenty of fodder for humorists

fields.headline: Crazy counts and pregnant chads
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The longest election battle in US history has provided plenty of fodder for humorists.
fields.body:
The longest election battle in US history has provided plenty of fodder for humorists.

Since both the presidential candidates are from the southern states, the home of country music, the chances of a song commemorating recent events seem high. Singers looking for a title could do worse than "You Screwed with My Vote and Now I've Got A Pregnant Chad" which was on a placard outside the recount taking place in Palm Beach.

Listeners to National Public Radio's Morning Edition have been entertained by Barry Gordemer and the Electoral College Tabernacle Choir who have come up with Doin' That Crazy Hand Count which has a tune that will be familiar to anyone who remembers Willie and the Hand Jive by Eric Clapton.

California-based satirist Harry Shearer has come up with Butterfly Ballot Blues in honour of the ballot forms that have led to such confusion and which many in the Gore team feel may have cost them the election: "I found myself the ballot/I just could not find the hole," goes the song.

Capitol Steps, a Washington comedy group, has come out with a parody of the old Melanie hit from the 70s, Brand New Key. The new version, Brand New Candidates, suggests: "Tell them in Nashville and Austin, I don't like what I've seen/Oh, buy me a brand new pair of candidates, someone like Martin Sheen." (Sheen plays a president in the hit television series West Wing.)

webTitle: Crowd gathers at Capitol building for crucial result

fields.headline: Final push to meet recount deadline
fields.standfirst:
Crowd gathers at Capitol building for crucial result
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Crowd gathers at Capitol building for crucial result.
fields.body:
From early morning, as church bells rang from nearby St John's Episcopal church, Republican and Democrat supporters converged on the Capitol building in Tallahassee in anticipation of Florida's long delayed result in the presidential election.

At the centre of attention was the Republican secretary of state, Katherine Harris, who made clear her intent to announce the certification of the vote some time after 5pm yesterday once the results had all been delivered to the 18th floor of the Capitol building and then taken to her office.

The building has been staked out by camera crews for nearly three weeks to the delight of local newsagents and taxi drivers, and some of the press even had small Christmas trees on their fold-up tables yesterday as if in anticipation of a long haul.

Among those who flew into Florida at the weekend was George Mitchell, the former Democrat senate leader who helped to broker the peace agreement in Northern Ireland. He came to add weight to Al Gore's case and maybe because the vice-president believed that, for the man who could make a deal with the republicans of west Belfast, the Republicans of Florida would be a pushover.

Mr Mitchell, famous for his conciliatory and amenable manner, was clearly angered by what he believed was a procedure that robbed Gore of votes. "Democracy is by definition the rule of the people," he said, "and hand counts are the most effective and fair way [of counting the vote]. Up to now in this process no court - state or federal - has accepted the assertion that hand recounts are unfair or unconstitutional. The courts and the people know better." He was concerned at the decision by the Miami-Dade county canvassing board to abandon its recount following protests by Republicans who invaded its office and shouted at the board last week.

Other Democrats in Florida used less diplomatic language to describe events in Miami-Dade. One spoke of a "whiff of fascism" and Florida congressman Peter Deutsch accused the Bush campaign of illegal tactics to stop the count. He criticised "a bunch of paid, out-of-state political activists _ literally a mob determining the outcome". Alcee Hastings, another leading Florida Democrat, said it was wrong the count had reached such a pass that "bullies can override ballots".

David Leahy, head of the Miami-Dade canvassing board, said yesterday: "I was not intimidated." He said the decision to abandon the count was made purely because it would have been impossible to complete by last night's deadline. But unconvinced Democrats quoted reporters who said Leahy had admitted finding the atmosphere intimidating.

Three retired brothers from Illinois, Ron, Jim and Fred Rodgers, who had driven the 700 miles to make their point, were the first to arrive at the Capitol building with placards attacking the Democrats.

"We're not even Republicans," said Ron who was wearing a jacket with the Veterans of Foreign Wars logo and the legend "We'd do anything for this country". "We voted for Ross Perot last time. We came down because we saw what was going on, we saw that the Democrats were trying to steal the election. We hope to sway public opinion by being here. We don't want another eight years of political corruption and sleaze." Jim Rodgers, like his brothers wearing a "God's Country" baseball cap, said events in Miami-Dade had been twisted by a pro-Democrat media.

As protesters argued and el der statesmen from both sides pontificated on party lines - former Democrat president Jimmy Carter and former Republican presidential candidate Bob Dole were the latest two - the counting was continuing in two sites. Just before midnight on Saturday, Judge Robert W Lee announced that Broward county had completed its task early. With all 5precincts counted and 2,192 questionable ballots checked, Gore had gained 567 votes. It had not been without incident. Judge Lee threw out Republican lawyer William Scherer after he complained about the re-examination of absentee ballots.

In Palm Beach, the recount continued through the night as desperate attempts were made to complete it by the deadline. But at midday it requested that Ms Harris extend its deadline to this morning, declaring it would not be able to finish by 5pm.

Outside demonstrators with placards that read "Gore Regime, Holding America Hostage" protested at the counting. Inside counters had been working up to 17-hour days to try to meet the deadline imposed last week by the Florida supreme court.

Elsewhere in the state, there were devevopments that could also affect the final result. A judge in Seminole county had been asked to dismiss 4,700 absentee ballots which had been altered by Republican officials who had added voter identification numbers to them. Without the ID numbers, the ballots would have been illegal. Since most of those absentee ballots had been requested by Republicans, the votes, if dismissed, would be enough to swing the total to Gore.

Republicans picked up 45 votes from overseas military ballots over the weekend in Florida and announced they were withdrawing from one of their legal actions over the issue. They withdrew their statewide suit over absentee ballots and substituted five county suits on the issue. In one count, there was a three-hour argument over whether one absentee vote envelope should be opened; it turned out to be for Al Gore.

The memorial outside the Capitol building in Tallahassee commemorates those who fell in the civil war. Now Florida is witnessing what has been a more or less peaceful civil war. But like its predecessor, it seems to be rolling on much longer than anyone predicted.

webTitle: Air traffic revolt 'may hit rail plans'

fields.headline: Air traffic revolt 'may hit rail plans'
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The government's entire transport legislation could be at risk, including plans to revive the railways, if its plans to privatise air travel control are wrecked tonight, government sources admitted last night.
fields.body:
The government's entire transport legislation could be at risk, including plans to revive the railways, if its plans to privatise air travel control are wrecked tonight, government sources admitted last night.

The legislation, in the Transport Bill, could fall if peers again reject the National Air Traffic Services (NATS) plan.

The sources, close to John Prescott, deputy prime minister and champion of the privatisation, said the continued opposition of Tory and Liberal peers, backed by dissident Labour members of the Lords, could destroy three years of Labour's attempts to build an integrated transport policy.

This includes the introduction of congestion charging, which will curb car use in big cities, and the setting up of the strategic rail authority, the one big change in Labour's railway plan, designed to exert more control over Railtrack.

Some rail managers said last night that the collapse of the transport legislation would be a blessing in disguise after the Hatfield rail crash, but it would be regarded as a considerable political setback for Mr Prescott, leaving him with nothing after four years in the job.

Tonight's vote follows fresh safety warnings about the impact of a sale with a NATS briefing paper disclosing that cuts of up to £165m over five years could be imposed.

Pilots, air traffic controllers and the public oppose privatisation, but the government wants to sell off 51% of the service to one of three bidders, arguing that the system is badly managed and needs considerable investment.

Invoking the Parliament Act to force through the privatisation could postpone any sale until after the general election.

 The former Tory transport minister Steven Norris yesterday gave a powerful hint he could become chairman of Railtrack. Asked on BBC's Breakfast with Frost if he was going to take up the role, Mr Norris said: "Stranger things might happen.You never know."

webTitle: US elections: recount in Washington state

fields.headline: Another recount could also affect presidential race
fields.standfirst:
Millionaire's win would result in a tie
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Another recount commanding attention yesterday was the laborious verification of votes in Washington state, where a provisional victory by hi-tech millionaire Maria Cantwell has left the US senate tied 50-50 between Democrats and Republicans.
fields.body:
Another recount commanding attention yesterday was the laborious verification of votes in Washington state, where a provisional victory by hi-tech millionaire Maria Cantwell has left the US senate tied 50-50 between Democrats and Republicans.

If her election is confirmed, Ms Cantwell will become the fourth new woman in the chamber, taking the total number of women to a record 13 out of 100 senators. The 42-year-old former member of the House of Representatives spent about a third of her fortune - $10m (about£7m) - getting elected.

But what makes her victory significant is the extraordinary permutations it makes possible in the presidential election. If neither Al Gore nor George W Bush were to win a majority when the electoral college meets on December 18, Congress would gather in early January, the House of Representatives to select the president and the Senate to pick the vice-president.

webTitle: Gore's presedential bid

fields.headline: Party on vice-president's side as he plans new legal bids
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore's overriding aim, following yesterday's Florida certification deadline, is to keep open the possibility of further recounts and legal challenges while ensuring that his party and US public opinion do not lose patience with the strategy.
fields.body:
Al Gore's overriding aim, following yesterday's Florida certification deadline, is to keep open the possibility of further recounts and legal challenges while ensuring that his party and US public opinion do not lose patience with the strategy.

Last week, when the Florida supreme court set yesterday's 5pm deadline for recounts to be completed, the task of keeping the campaign going this week looked exceptionally difficult. But two events came to Mr Gore's rescue.

The first was George W Bush's decision to mount his own legal strategy, and to try to involve the US supreme court. At the end of last week, the court in Washington said it would hear arguments this Friday. That means that it is Mr Bush who has kept the ball in play for another week, making it easier for Mr Gore to pursue his remaining legal challenges without being accused of dragging things out.

The second new event was last Wednesday's decision by the Miami-Dade canvassing board to abandon its manual recount under pressure from Republican demonstrators. The scenes in Miami, repeated in Broward county, outraged Democrats and toughened the party's resolve to stand by Mr Gore against what it sees as a hired Republican mob.

As a result, Democrats are solidly onside for Mr Gore's attempt to contest the certification of the Florida results.

The big shift to Mr Gore in the recounts in Broward and Palm Beach counties has also been vital, making it much easier for Mr Gore to persuade his party that he would be president if the Miami-Dade recount had not been abandoned. Far from being a sore loser who doesn't know when to accept defeat, the vice-president can now present himself to his party as a martyr being robbed of the White House by a Republican conspiracy.

A week ago, there was real concern that Democrats would begin to abandon Mr Gore today if the certified results went against him. But over the weekend, intensive discussions between Gore advisers and senior Democrat officials around the US left the vice-president's camp confident that the party will stand by him for another round of actions in the courts this week.

"The Republicans have upped the ante. They have been so outrageous in their conduct that they have hardened resolve among the Democrats," said Democratic congressman Martin Frost yesterday.

"The Republican leadership is doing a lot to put steel into the Democrats' backbone," said party pollster Geoff Garin.

The mood in the Gore camp is sufficiently confident that there are even some advisers who positively want Mr Bush and his entourage to claim victory and to start behaving like winners this week. These advisers think that moves of this kind offend the public, as they seemed to do when Mr Bush tried - and quickly abandoned - the approach immediately after the election.

"I don't think the American people buy it one bit," said one adviser. "I think it aggravates them."

Whatever the difficulties, and they are self-evidently formidable, the Gore camp is driven from the very top by the unshakeable belief that their man won the election in Florida and in the nation as a whole. Mr Gore, advisers say, is sometimes embarrassed by the legal machinations to which he has had to resort, but he believes absolutely that more people went to the polls to vote for him than for Mr Bush. Unlike many of those around him, Mr Gore's determination to prove his point and claim his prize has been unswerving.

webTitle: Blair plans ministry for the poor

fields.headline: Blair plans ministry for the poor
fields.standfirst:
New cabinet post would spearhead revived anti-poverty drive on deprived estates

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is considering the creation of a Department for Social Inclusion, headed by a cabinet minister, to spearhead a revived anti-poverty drive in the most deprived areas if Labour wins a second term.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is considering the creation of a Department for Social Inclusion, headed by a cabinet minister, to spearhead a revived anti-poverty drive in the most deprived areas if Labour wins a second term.

The formation of the Whitehall ministry to coordinate policies intended to help the "underclass" is under discussion within Downing Street as the prime minister considers what should be in Labour's election manifesto.

Mr Blair plans to make poverty a key election issue, a commitment that would be welcomed in Labour's heartlands and establish clear blue water between the government and Tory leader William Hague.

A No 10 official said the new ministry would be carved out of John Prescott's sprawling Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions.

Hilary Armstrong, minister for local government and the regions in the department, who is highly rated by the prime minister, has been tipped in government circles for promotion to the post.

The department would take over and expand the role of the cabinet office's social exclusion unit and work closely with other ministries, including social security, health and education, as well as the Treasury.

The department would be named social inclusion rather than social exclusion to put the emphasis on positive efforts. It could be responsible for community regeneration and town hall affairs.

The environment department classifies 1,370 estates as "run down" and suffering from multiple problems including high unemployment, bad housing, low education standards and ill health.

Establishing the department would be seen as an acknowledgment that the social exclusion unit has not been as successful as the prime minister envisaged, as well as evidence of Mr Blair's commitment to tackling poverty.

Headed by Moira Wallace, a former Treasury high-flyer and Downing Street private secretary, the social exclusion unit is staffed by some 40 of the brightest civil servants.

A string of studies and initiatives, including an £800m neighbourhood renewal scheme, have been produced but the unit has been the vic tim of "turf wars" with departments.

A review last year by cabinet office officials and KPMG consultants concluded the unit's work "has been on the whole less enthusiastically received inside government than outside".

Appointing a cabinet minister to run a new department, said the No 10 official, would "send a clear signal to the rest of Whitehall as well as the country at large that Labour is serious about ending social deprivation and exclusion".

With an election expected in May after Labour's three byelection victories last week, a decision on whether to create the department could be taken early in the new year.

Mr Blair has shown a marked reluctance to reform Whitehall but setting up a social inclusion department would partly undo one of the changes he did introduce after merging the environment and transport departments.

Created specifically for Mr Prescott as deputy prime minister after the last election, it faces another shake-up after the next election. In addition to the possibility of urban affairs being transferred to a new department, Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, believes the eight regional development agencies would fit into the Department of Trade and Industry.

Some ministers in other departments believe the environment and transport portfolios should be separated to reduce the department to a manageable scale while others think they should remain united.

Ms Armstrong and Mr Prescott have clashed over English elected mayors, which she is keener on than he is, and regional government. She was slapped down by her boss in public early this year after voicing doubts about English regional assemblies.

Some advisers close to the environment department, who could see the logic of an all-embracing department when it was formed, now believe it is running out of time because it is too big.

One longstanding Westminster ally of Mr Prescott said: "John has had to deal with flak from N0 10, and its policy wonks, while pulling together a lot of other things, and frankly he's knackered. After the election we all expect he'll move on to something else, maybe the party chairmanship, while keeping his deputy's role in the cabinet."

webTitle: Kate Hilpern on the role of office mentors

fields.headline: Someone to watch over you
fields.standfirst: If you want to make it to the top, you need advice from someone who has already got there - a corporate godparent.  Kate Hilpern  explains how it works
fields.trailText: If you want to make it to the top, you need advice from someone who has already got there - a corporate godparent. Kate Hilpern explains how it works
fields.body:
Want to do more to further your career, but don't know how? Worried you'll get tripped up by office politics, or that you're not making the most of networking opportunities? Get a mentor. That's the message from the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development (CIPD), which is urging organisations to introduce the concept at support staff level.

In fact, although mentoring is traditionally associated with the advancement of managers rather than secretaries, the reality is already changing fast. Professor Alan Smithers, director for education and employment research at the University of Liverpool, believes there are two reasons for this. "First, the secretarial role has grown in leaps and bounds in terms of responsibility and status. With layers of middle management disappearing and with the recent downsizing of companies, the role now includes overseeing information technology as well as consulting, marketing, personnel and managing small projects. Not surprisingly, this increasing workload requires an increasing amount of training and development."

In turn, he says, managers rely on their support staff more than ever. "That's where the second reason comes in. If they want to be the best managers, they are recognising that they need to have the best secretaries which, again, comes down to training and development."

So what is mentoring? "An experienced person aiding the progression of someone less experienced," explains Alan Fowler, author of Get More - and More Results - From Your People (CIPD, £9.95). "The term originates from Greek mythology - Mentor being the friend to whom Ulysses entrusted the education of his son before he went off on his odyssey. In the 1970s, it started to become a formal component of forward thinking businesses and today creating a mentor/mentee relationship is recognised as one of the most effective ways of making a business competitive."

The theory is that competitive advantage is dependent on talent, and talent is best advanced through mentoring, explains Michael Robson, who helped to set up a mentoring network in south-east England. "A one-to-one relationship, usually between a senior and junior employer, mentoring isn't simply about training, coaching or friendship," he says. "A mentor is a 'corporate godparent' who teaches the business rules that aren't in the textbooks."

A good mentor will advise you on the ins and outs of office politics; will be a sounding board for your concerns and tensions; and will be your role model. Little wonder that research shows the relationship works best if you are relatively close in age and outside the mentor's direct line of command. A secretary, a top PA, or an office manager will serve the role best.

Meanwhile, a good scheme will put you in touch, advise you on how to get the best out of your relationship, and demand that you meet at least every six weeks for 15 minutes. Perhaps you'll choose to shadow your mentor for an hour or so a week, or maybe you'll just meet for lunch occasionally. Perhaps the relationship will last six months, or maybe you'll keep it up for a couple of years.

Rochelle Anderson, a 26-year-old PA from Buckinghamshire, whose employer is considering introducing a formal mentoring scheme, can see the benefits. "Outstanding administrative skills cannot be learned simply by doing the job. You need to watch, hear about and assess the experiences of someone who has already made it to the top. Since you also need to know what makes the particular company you're working for tick, that person needs to be working for the same employer as you."

Julie Withers, a 23-year-old PA who was mentored in her previous job, agrees. "You arrive in an organisation with a set of skills, but no experience in that particular business. An approachable, experienced voice can mean everything: improve your self-confidence, teach you how to cope with the organisational culture and help you to advance your career."

While the CIPD advocates formal schemes, it is quick to point out that for secretaries who work for a company that hasn't yet seen the light, all is not lost. "It's increasingly common for staff to create an informal scheme of their own," explains Angela Baron, adviser to the CIPD. "They simply find a good role model and ask if they can come and talk to them from time to time about the way they do things."

David Clutterbuck, author of Everyone Needs a Mentor (CIPD, £10.95), claims this is most likely to work where benefits are recognised as two-way. "Grooming a promising young employee can be a challenging and stimulating experience for a mentor, especially if his or her own career has reached a temporary or permanent plateau," he explains.

Irrespective of whether mentoring involves an official scheme or a natural process, Fowler claims a mentor should have certain key characteristics. "Apart from having job-related skills, they need to be fully committed to the role. That's why they should always be volunteers rather than being under any obligation. Communication skills are essential, but mentors should also be patient and avoid offering solutions too readily. After all, it is their job to help the mentee find their own solutions rather than plunging straight into, 'If I were you . . .' Finally, mentors should recognise that they, too, can learn from the process and treat it as part of their own continuous development."

Mentees, for their part, should be honest, open-minded and willing to learn. "They should also be prepared to explore their weaknesses and create a high level of self-awareness, while at the same time challenging their mentor's views where necessary," says Fowler.

Studies show that mentoring tends to be most effective when it involves women - both as mentor and protégé. Women are more likely to offer advice with the proviso, "don't feel you have to take it"; whereas men have a tendency to exaggerate their abilities and are less likely to take advice on board.

The problem is, of course, that since there are fewer women at the top than men, there are fewer female mentors available. Nevertheless, organisations in the United States believe they have found a solution - turning mentoring on its head. "Female secretaries are mentoring male executives," explains Clutterbuck. The idea is that the women, who are at the coalface of an organisation, teach the men, who spend all day in the corner office, what the nuts and bolts of the company are all about. "The result is that the secretary gets recognition and the executives are less isolated," says Clutterbuck.

Nevertheless, schemes such as this prove the fruitlessness of mentoring, according to sceptics from traditionalist organisations. Mentoring reveals the worst side of American corporate culture, they say, with a lot of buzzwords and PC ideas, but few bottom-line results. Indeed, even a diehard advocate would have to admit that it's difficult to quantify the benefits since there are no quick fixes or measurable rewards.

But management consultant Mike Williams is among those who believe that's changing. "Mentoring is the missing link in the recruitment and retention strategy of too many organisations," he explains. Alone, it won't bring in support staff, he admits, but it could swing the balance. "It's vital to identify potential and create a structure for developing. If an employee realises that it is a priority to an employer, it will increase their interest in working for them. That's a measurable reward."

webTitle: WPM

fields.headline: WPM
fields.trailText: More than half of Britain's workers would still report for duty the next day if they won the lottery, according to research for the Industrial Society released last week. And no, not just to make sure that the holder of the office syndicate tickets hasn't skipped off to Rio.
fields.body:
 More than half of Britain's workers would still report for duty the next day if they won the lottery, according to research for the Industrial Society released last week. And no, not just to make sure that the holder of the office syndicate tickets hasn't skipped off to Rio, but to work. WPM is disappointed. Anything more than a tenner and she'd be off, no question. A closer look at the study, though, makes it clear that those who do go back to the daily grind have certain incentives for doing so - the most keen were those earning more than £70,000 a year, of whom 70% would keep on working. A spokesman for National Lottery organisers Camelot confirmed that not all winners give up the day job: "51% of all lottery winners who won £50,000 or more have returned to work in spite of their win."

WPM's thoughts, however, are with the blithe-spirited 49% who'd jack in the nine-to-five for a five-figure cheque - she'd love to know how they explain away their year(s) of madness on the CV when they return (as, presumably, they must) to the world of gainful employment.

Contrary to popular images of the office (think Ally McBeal), non-attractive people do sometimes enter the world of work. And, for their efforts, these un-beautiful people are rewarded with lower salaries. An ugly man will earn just £17,000 a year compared with his more facially sorted colleague, who'll rake in £20,000.

But - and who'd have thought it - it's women, and particularly women in more junior roles, who suffer the most from not meeting attractiveness targets. Females in clerical and secretarial positions who are short and fat will earn around 15% less than prettier, skinnier administrators (and no, pretty, skinny administrators don't draft letters or file documents in a more attractive way). The study was based on a sample of 11,000 people aged 33; the age by which, WPM can only assume, the ugly ducklings have no chance of a late transformation to a swan.

The site is regularly updated, so you shouldn't miss out on any new schemes that you're entitled to have a share of.

WPM was tickled to hear of the rather exciting past of Gloria Nicholl, new PA to Tory shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe, and formerly a joint manager of the group Black Grape - whose lead singer, Shaun Ryder, would by his own admission have been short of a fair few bob had Widdecombe's on-the-spot drug fines been in place in the early 90s. webTitle: Police find clothing and shoe in search for killer of Sarah Payne

fields.headline: Police find clothing and shoe in search for killer of Sarah Payne
fields.standfirst: More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: The potentially crucial evidence was discovered in a hedgerow in West Sussex, about a mile from where the eight-year-old's body was found in a shallow grave.
fields.body:
Forensic scientists are carrying out tests on a fragment of a dress and a child's shoe believed to belong to murdered schoolgirl Sarah Payne.

The potentially crucial evidence was discovered in a hedgerow in West Sussex, about a mile from where the eight-year-old's body was found in a shallow grave. Police believe that the items were thrown from a moving vehicle by her killer some time on July 2 this year - the day after Sarah was abducted.

The breakthrough came after a woman telephoned detectives in October to say that she had driven over a child's dress in a lane within hours of the abduction. It was only a later appeal that led her to make the link with Sarah.

A search team was immediately dispatched to the Goose Green crossroads south of Coolham in West Sussex, but no trace was found of the dress.

Earlier this month another search of the area was ordered and this time police found a black shoe with a Velcro buckle discarded on a grass verge and a fragment of blue material lying in a hedge 100 yards away.

Police said yesterday that both items, which were covered in mud and well camouflaged, had been badly damaged, probably by a hedge cutter. It has been established that the hedge was trimmed on July 15, two weeks after Sarah disappeared and two days before her body was found.

Detective superintendent Peter Kennett said: "If they do turn out to belong to Sarah it is an extremely significant find."

Police said it could be up to two weeks before scientists have completed tests which will show whether there are traces of DNA on the clothing that could lead to Sarah's killer.

John O'Connor, a former detective, said the clothing had probably been outside too long to be of any real value. "They might just get lucky and find a sample of DNA, but in my opinion they have probably been too contaminated. Any number of people could have touched them by now," he added.

Sarah was abducted after she left her brothers Lee, 13, and Luke, 11, and her six-year-old sister Charlotte playing in a field near their grandparents' home in Kingston Gorse, West Sussex.

Her partially buried body was discovered 16 days later just off the busy A29 in Pulborough, 12 miles away. Officers believe Sarah was killed on the evening of her kidnapping and they think the killer was driving a white Ford Transit van which he used to transport the body.

webTitle: Milosevic prepares to stage his return

fields.headline: Milosevic prepares to stage his return
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Slobodan Milosevic is preparing to lead his Socialist party into the crucial Serbian elections next month, having put himself firmly back on the political stage by gaining re-election as party president.
fields.body:
Slobodan Milosevic is preparing to lead his Socialist party into the crucial Serbian elections next month, having put himself firmly back on the political stage by gaining re-election as party president.

In his first public appearance since his fall from power after the September elections and the October 5 uprising, the former strongman looked older and tougher at the Socialist party congress in the Sava Centre, Belgrade, on Saturday.

He described the forces that pushed his out as "traitors" in a war "waged with western money".

He said they wanted to send "patriots" to the "new Gestapo" - his name for the UN war crimes tribunal in the Hague.

Tribunal officials expressed outrage yesterday that Mr Milosevic - an indicted war criminal - should flaunt himself in the political arena while subject to an arrest warrant.

Florence Hartmann, spokeswoman for the chief prosecutor, Carla del Ponte, said his recent appearances could increase his chance of being arrested. "Everyone knows where he is and there is no reason not to arrest him," she said.

But some analysts say Mr Milosevic's best chance of survival lies in remaining active in Serbian political life, since his security ultimately rests on his ability to maintain his position as a power broker.

The whereabouts of the Milosevic family are not known. Sources in Belgrade sugges that he and his wife Mira Markovic are at an army post and that his son Marko is in Russia or Ukraine

Socialist party insiders say that Mr Milosevic has grown increasingly out of touch, and believes it is only a matter of time before he regains power.

webTitle: Clare Dyer on sex and race discrimination at the Law Society

fields.headline: Day of reckoning
fields.standfirst: Kamlesh Bahl says she was a victim of sex and race discrimination at the Law Society. It says she was a bully. The tribunal starts today.  Clare Dyer reports
fields.trailText: Kamlesh Bahl says she was a victim of sex and race discrimination at the Law Society. It says she was a bully. The tribunal starts today.  Clare Dyer reports
fields.body:
It was a surreal moment. Past the gilded lions and pillars we walked, into the Law Society's imposing hall, hung with portraits of past luminaries. Its president, leader of the 80,000 solicitors in England and Wales, was closeted behind the doors of his ground floor office. The assembled reporters were there not to see him but to answer the summons of a former president waiting in an upstairs room.

While the current commander shuffled his paperclips two floors below, his predecessor denounced him as "unsuitable to lead the profession". The once-august 175-year-old body was viewed by outsiders as a "humourless farce", said the ex-supremo, Rodger Pannone. It did not need Lady Thatcher's PR guru, Sir Tim Bell, called in to help mend its battered profile, to advise that its image was bad and had got worse.

Martin Mears, cooling his heels downstairs, had announced his intention to run for a second term and Pannone was urging others to come forward and stand against him. Mears, he said, had had "a whale of a time but I think the harm to the profession is very, very grave indeed". The year was 1996. Four years later the farce is still playing.

It started in 1995 when vice-president John Young was outed as a serial groper. Mears was elected that year by grass-roots solicitors to shake up what they saw as a bloated bureaucracy indifferent to their concerns. But his term sparked off an outbreak of bitter factionalism. There was a grassroots move to turf out the whole council, and in an open letter to the profession, council member Eileen Pembridge accused Mears and his vice-president Robert Sayer, of creating "a climate of fear and distrust".

In 1997, when Mears ran again for president, a leaked memo from his opponents' camp revealed that they had discussed hiring private detectives to spy on him and his running mates. Meanwhile, a £454m hole was discovered in the Solicitors Indemnity Fund, caused by underestimat ing the severity of negligence claims against the profession. Solicitors had to cough up for that, for a £7.1m overspend on a new computer and a £3.4m overspend on refurbishing the Chancery Lane headquarters. Complaints against solicitors soared, building up a huge backlog. Mears and Sayer had an acrimonious falling-out, with Sayer describing his former ally as forever turning up "like a piece of dog turd on your shoe".

Today, at a Watford employment tribunal, the curtain will rise on what the long-suffering profession must hope will be the final act. In a four-week hearing - unless the case is settled -Kamlesh Bahl, vice-president of the society until she was forced out last March, will accuse it of race and sex discrimination. Bahl, 44, had been expected to take over as the first Asian and first woman president in July, but resigned ignominiously in March after an inquiry found her guilty of bullying staff.

Her claim for compensation fingers five people: Sayer, whose term ended in July; Jane Betts, then secretary-general (head of staff); Jean Johnson, then head of human resources; Anne Coles, legal and constitutional adviser; and in-house lawyer Anthony Brookes. Sayer is still a member of the society's council. Betts' job has gone and she has been replaced by a new chief executive. Johnson has left too.

The scene is set for the protagonists, including Bahl, to tell their tales for the first time in public. The inquiry, headed by Lord Griffiths, a retired law lord, heard evidence behind closed doors. Only his report, which paints a highly unflattering picture of Bahl's people-management skills, was made public. Until the curtain goes up this morning, both sides are keeping their cases under close wraps. Bahl has been staying shtumm since she bared her soul a few months ago to radio shrink Anthony Clare, admitting she'd felt suicidal and sought therapy for the first time in the aftermath of the affair. Her GP husband, Nitin Lakhani, said: "She's preserving her end of it for the tribunal."

The Law Society is saying nothing, referring all media calls to a PR company, which is saying nothing on its behalf. Even the society's 75-strong council is being kept in the dark. Council member Anthony Bogan gripes: "Because the Law Society has become such a leaky institution, information given to council members is very limited. At the last two council meetings we've been told they can't say anything even in closed session." He is concerned at the mounting costs of the Bahl saga, thought to have reached £1m and expected to hit £1.5m by the time the tribunal finishes. "The people paying for it are hard-working legal aid solicitors."

Within days of being forced out, Bahl threatened a claim for race and sex discrimination, producing an opinion in her favour signed by Cherie Booth QC. Booth has since dropped out of the case, pleading breast-feeding duties. Bahl will be represented at the tribunal by a leading discrimination QC, Robin Allen, and Peter Herbert, president of the Society of Black Lawyers, which is backing her case.

Griffiths, who was assisted by two members of the employment appeal tribunal - one black and one female - upheld all the complaints of bullying and harassment against Bahl by five staff, most of them senior officials. He found she had been "at times demeaning and humiliating and at other times offensively aggressive."

An elected office-holder rather than a manager, she had usurped Betts's role as head of staff "and introduced an atmosphere of fear and confusion in the line of command". She subjected staff to verbal onslaughts "which we believe she used as a management tool to dominate staff and to stamp her authority on the organisation." The inquiry heard that other staff members had complained, but would not lodge formal complaints because they were afraid of Bahl and worried that they might lose their jobs if she became president.

Bahl argues that the Griffiths report fails to take enough account of the background against which she was working. The society, whose role in policing solicitors sits uneasily with its trade-union role, was riven by internal politics, mistrust and division. A survey had shown mass disillusionment among solicitors with their professional body.

Management consultant Lord Stephenson had pronounced in 1998: "The society does not work. Its very structure prevents effective decision-making, and when decisions are made there is no means of ensuring they are implemented." One decision had taken three years. He proposed a radical overhaul.

Bahl, then deputy vice-president, was put in charge with a tight timetable. She points out that Sayer admitted at the society's conference last year: "There is only one way to get a large organisation to improve and that is to shout very loudly. You can't be Mr Nice Guy all your life." She claims she would have changed her behaviour and avoided further complaints had concerns been drawn to her attention. Instead, she says, complaints were "stockpiled" and she first learned of some of them more than a year after the incidents concerned.

Why did no one take her aside for a quiet word? Sayer told the inquiry that after one verbal attack by Bahl on head of policy Russell Wallman during a meeting, he was "shocked and embarrassed", but said nothing at the time. "I cannot now recall why I remained silent but I think it was because I simply did not know how to deal with it," Sayer said.

A few attempts were made but no one seems to have laid it on the line firmly enough to get the message across. Michael Mathews, president at the time, told Griffiths: "I tried to have an informal chat to get her to see what was happening, but I just did not get through."

Once the axe fell, it fell swiftly. Six days after the Griffiths report was delivered, the council voted to suspend Bahl. She claims she was told the decision would be postponed and lost the opportunity to address the meeting. The following week she resigned, pre-empting a special general meeting of the whole profession to decide whether to expel her.

This week she and the Law Society are back in the headlines again. But a new regime has taken over in Chancery Lane, with a new chief executive determined to turn it into an efficient and effective body. It looks like the Law Society may become boring again - a denouement its members must fervently desire.

webTitle: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: The stars before they were famous
fields.standfirst: Will Smith in Six Degrees Of Separation (Fred Schepisi, 1993)
fields.trailText: Will Smith in Six Degrees Of Separation
fields.body:
Who? Mickey Mouse-eared singer and star of some of the biggest blockbusters ever. Smith started rapping as Fresh Prince, with DJ partner Jazzy Jeff, and had a hit TV show with the Fresh Prince Of Bel Air. Movies seemed the logical next step, but early efforts at artistic integrity went by the wayside - he wound up kicking ass (1995's Bad Boys) and then kicking alien ass (Independence Day, 1996; Men In Black, 1997). Unfortunately he's still managed to maintain his musical career, giving us catchy little numbers like Wild, Wild West (the theme song from the tragic 1999 film) and Just The Two Of Us - an oleaginous paean to his oldest son, Trey. He and his wife, actress Jada Pinkett, have two children - Jaden (a boy) and Willow (a girl). Whether Smith can get rid of his goofy image rests in part on the long-time-in-the-making Muhammad Ali biopic he's been trying to make - it's rumoured funding for the movie has been withdrawn. Still, Men In Black 2 is out soon.

The role: Paul, a gay hustler who cons his way into Manhattan's wealthiest families by saying he's Sidney Poitier's son.

webTitle: Is the EU a superstate in waiting or just an extravagant talking shop?

fields.headline: In search of the real Europe
fields.standfirst:
Is the EU a superstate in waiting or just an extravagant talking shop? And what, exactly, goes on in its labyrinthine corridors? Nick Fraser spent six months trying to find out
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Is the EU a superstate in waiting or just an extravagant talking shop? And what, exactly, goes on in its labyrinthine corridors?  Nick Fraser  spent six months trying to find out.
fields.body:
March 6 2000

In the grubby, smoke-filled basement of the Breydel building in Brussels, members of the European Union press corps gather at noon each day for their briefing. Each of the 20 commissioners has a spokesperson, and they skip up to the dais in turn. Today's subject is the imposition of a kerosene tax on every plane flying in Europe. I note details, but as I do so they seem to slip away. A film of dead language wraps everything - phrases such as "parallel effort" and "global approach".

I find a book listing the legislative achievements of the EU for 1999. Opened at random, page 406 shows a directive governing second-hand car prices in the Ukraine. A British spokesman rounds on me to complain about the behaviour of London newspapers. Nothing, it seems, will induce them to print positive stories. I can't think of what to say to him.

March 9

Back to the Breydel to visit Romano Prodi, commission president. The lift deposits me on the 12th floor rather than the fourth. I keep taking wrong turnings, and can retain my bearings only by means of a poster representing the triumph of the treaty of Maastricht, which I pass again and again. Prodi's suite of offices is surprisingly banal and he apologises for the ugliness. Prodi is smallish, dapper, soft-voiced. He was appointed with the task of making the EU commission believable after the mass resignation of commissioners that marked the end of Jacques Santer's tenure in 1999. In recent weeks Le Monde has attacked him for irresolution, alleging that he is an "Anglo-Saxonist". Under his tutelage, it is said, the prestige of the commission has fallen further still.

Prodi suggests to me that Europe means so little to its citizens because they are essentially contented, and not fighting a war. Somehow Europeans must be led to realise that they are all members of minorities now, whether they are French, Italians or Bosnians. "Europe is a union of minorities," he says. "There is no majority in Europe." Prodi appeals to me as an anti-politician. He's the sort of professor I always wanted - someone with a developed sense of irony who enjoys speculative chat. In public, however, stumbling over boring speeches, he comes across as a modern-day Wizard of Oz. It is easy to see why the slick énarques - graduates of the Ecole Nationale d'Administration - don't rate him.

March-April

Brussels days. Mistaking fire hydrant cupboards for conference rooms, I bumble Hulot-style around the parliament building. Outside, the ugliness of Brussels overcomes me. I cannot think of such a place as the capital of Europe. But I notice a kind of solace in the vast, mall-like spaces. Here MEPs are afforded all-weather shelter from the prospect of nonexistence.

The buzz this month concerns the creation of a declaration of fundamental human rights for Europe. I walk into the plenary session to find great-and-gooders, summoned from every country, discussing what constitutes a fundamental right. Everyone wants to add to the list - one hyper-PC Frenchman wishes two mentions to be made of women's rights - except the Brit, who would prefer to see a distinction made between so-called "ordinary" rights and more important ones. Politely, because he is not a Eurosceptic, the Brit wants to make the point that rights are guaranteed in European democracies and that this airy superstructure of verbiage may not be necessary. A Finn appears momentarily to derail the proceedings by speaking of "horizontal issues".

I take away from the meeting a poignant sense of the difficulties implied by translation. It is hard to force concepts into languages in which they have had no previous existence, and we end by either minimising differences or exaggerating them. Eurenglish, which has displaced French as the EU's everyday language, is not much help - it merely gives the illusion of comprehension. Later, the amiable Greek head of translation fills me in on the problems arising from the arrival of 10 more EU members. She suggests that there will have to be a double system of translation from, say, Hungarian or Latvian into English, and thence to Finnish, because the most obscure permutations are likely to prove prohibitively expensive. There is resistance to this scheme, because no one wants their language to join the second tier.

Meanwhile, I am becoming uneasily aware of the depth of orthodoxy in Brussels. It is as if everyone repaired each day to some secret place where they were issued blue-and-yellow pills enabling them to believe in something called Europe.

The most flamboyant federalist is the red-haired, sharp-suited Green, Daniel Cohn-Bendit, who keeps a paving stone from 1968 on his desk. He lectures me on the need for a strong Europe to protect us from the ravages of international capitalism. When I ask him whether it will be possible to stay British or French and be a New European, he becomes angry. "You British always want to have it both ways," he shouts. "Keep your pound. Decide. Leave Europe."

On another floor of the parliament building, a Brit is busy editing a Eurosceptic magazine entitled These Tides. His name is David Wilkinson and he is taking photographs of a young woman in a tight T-shirt inscribed with the word "never". Dressed in brogues and a very English suit, Wilkinson is charming and witty, but he reminds me of what is ultimately wrong with the Eurosceptics. Wilkinson believes that the EU is doomed to fall apart as a consequence of its contradictions, in much the same way that Marxists used to say that capitalism would end by destroying itself. He doesn't see that anything done in Brussels might be useful. In London, such views are rehearsed daily by a large part of the press, and it is even possible to think of them as being reasonable. Here we may see them for what they are - quixotic.

April 9

More Brussels days. In one shop near the Grand Place, I acquire a bathroom towel in EU colours. The portly assistante assures me that it is not unusual to find couples buying entire sets " pour se mettre en Europe ". Who can these compulsives be?

I meet a man who may be the ultimate federalist. Thierry Béchet is Belgian, and he is chef de cabinet in the overseas aid directorate. For him the New Europe means escaping Europe's past. The European nation states did not ensure the survival of democracy; more often, they destroyed it. Composed of laws offering the prospect of citizenship regardless of one's ethnic origins, a federal Europe will indeed represent a higher stage of civilisation. Look at the Yugoslav war, Béchet says. There, people were slaughtered because of who they were: Croats, Bosnians or Serbs. In Europe, everyone will choose. Remembering how bored my 87-year-old French mother is with the prospect of enduring national differences, I experience a brief quasi-revivalist rush of internationalism.

April 17, Poland

Joining the EU is proving more difficult for Poland than eliminating the last vestiges of socialism. I am told that there are at least 30,000 regulations that must be adopted before membership is possible. The legislative programme is stalled, and many Poles have begun to complain about what they must do. I am given a 15-kilo boxed set of the acquis communautaire - the EU in paper form - and I take this to Bronislaw Geremek, the Polish foreign minister. Geremek is depressed by the lack of progress. For him, Poland is part of Europe anyhow - centuries of Polish struggles against enemies to the east demonstrate this. "Europe for us is a community," he says. "It shouldn't be about jealously guarding a rich man's club."

But I begin to realise that things are not so simple in Poland. A deal is being done, though it bears little relation to the lofty talk about values in Brussels. On the Belarus border, the Polish guards have been equipped with Land Rovers paid for by the EU. At the checkpoint, cars with Belarussian plates are backed up for 2km. Soon these Belarussians are to lose their easy access to Polish markets. So the real border of Europe is already in place.

May 9, back in Brussels

Long ago, in the 1970s, I suppose I considered myself an enthusiast, but I veered towards scepticism around the time in which it became apparent that the EU could not or would not do anything about the war in the Balkans. Now I find myself somewhere between rage and resignation. I know that the practice of contem porary democracy is meant to involve a certain degree of banality. But I had not realised that banality, like rain-washed concrete, can come in so many different shades of grey.

A pattern is established by now in my relationship with Brussels. I walk off the Eurostar into a cloud of mild anomie. What is this place for? What am I doing here? I am beginning to understand that there is something called real life in Brussels - far from being faceless or corrupt, the bureaucrats are often nice, and usually harried, as I discover when the ladies of the town-twinning department burst into tears while describing how their missionary work is frustrated by lack of funds. "They always want folk-dancing," the head of the department says. "We would be happier if they had conferences about xenophobia, but they like folk-dancing."

May 16, Strasbourg

I am off to the European parliament's other home. I take the train from Brussels, travelling for five hours through Belgium, Luxembourg and eastern France in the company of sleepy young wannabe Eurocrats. I find myself standing before an enormous, ellipse-shaped building with a courtyard in which a young woman is assembling a giant bumblebee. This proves to be a prop for the day's Greenpeace demonstration against genetically modified food. A first walk around the Louise Weiss building - no one seems to know who she was - makes it clear that pseudo-reality has been allowed to flower here into an extravagant bloom. MEPs, their aides and secretaries scurry in all directions. They hate being here and the grumbling is noisy and pervasive.

My head becomes lighter and lighter as I try to struggle ontologically with the existence of this building. At the Edinburgh summit of 1992, the new parliament was given the green light at the same time as the British and Danish secured theirvarious opt-outs. So this elaborate, foolish building, costing as much as the Millennium Dome and used only four days a month, should be named not after Louise Weiss, but John Major.

June 18, Feira, Portugal

More limousines, more journalists - this is an EU summit. We assemble in a hangar designed for trade fairs. I am told that participants are working on an agenda leading to another summit, culminating in a treaty.

In Porto, I stand outside the 18th-century banqueting hall, taking Polaroids of EU leaders. Tony Blair looks terrible; the rest are merely numb with fatigue. Prodi is smiling, but this may be because we have by now learned to recognise each other. Later, I corner Prodi, who tells me that I shouldn't worry about the lack of progress because the timescale for Europe is so long. "Ten years, 50 years!" he exclaims, throwing up his hands in amusement. "Why not?"

September 28, Copenhagen

It is stifling in Christiansborg, the Danish parliament building. Everyone who is anyone in the Danish political elite is crammed into two small, smoky rooms. I watch the exit polls fluctuate until the size of the no vote becomes clear. Then the mood changes rapidly. "It's not quite a fuck-off-and-die vote," a friend tells me. The prime minister is ashen and bursts into tears during a rendition of a Danish version of The Red Flag.

I ask the former commissioner Ritt Bjerregaard whether there is anything the EU could do to make itself more loved by Danes. "I don't know," she says. "I really don't." Befuddled by free Tuborg, I try to calculate how many countries, given the opportunity to vote this night, would have delivered a different result. Surely not Germany, where support for the currency is running at 25%, or France, where Chirac is sinking in the wake of a scandal involving a videotape and envelopes containing millions of francs from building contractors. Perhaps Belgium would have voted yes, and the Netherlands - perhaps, too, Luxembourg, Ireland, Finland . . . But a majority of Europeans? Surely not.

October 6

I am in the air, over the Alps, when I read Tony Blair's speech, just delivered at the Polish stock exchange and billed as his most important yet about Europe. Blair wants Europe to be "a superpower, but not a superstate". But this is the day after the fall of Milosevic, and the Middle East is blowing up. No one will be listening.

At the self-proclaimed heart of Europe, I can see little but a busy void. The EU will neither break up nor become a receptacle for the dreams of Europeans. If it does reform itself, this will not be in a spectacular or even especially engaging fashion. Those who believe in grand visions, or think that the EU can suddenly mature into a supranational democracy, are deluding themselves. For the moment, it should be enough to think of Brussels as a place to which it is sometimes necessary to go, in order to bring things back.

webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Reservoir Dogs | Saving Private Ryan | An Angel At My Table
fields.body:
Reservoir Dogs

(Quentin Tarantino, 1992)

10pm, FilmFour

The heist botched, the gang assemble in a warehouse, a traitor among them. Macho rage bounces off the walls: Tim Roth lying in a slick of blood, Harvey Keitel and Steve Buscemi at each other's throats, and Michael Madsen dancing a comic-Gothic torture scene to Stuck In The Middle With You. Tarantino's potent debut is a brilliantly stylish and witty thriller - with characters called Mr Orange and Mr Pink and all, but wearing cool black suits, and deconstructing a Madonna song before the hit.

Saving Private Ryan

(Steven Spielberg, 1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

Reactions to Steven Spielberg's second world war epic ranged from "best war movie" ever right down to cliché-ridden failure. And the truth, inevitably, is somewhere in the middle. Yes, the plot - a platoon is sent to find Matt Damon's Private Ryan and bring him back home safely, because his three brothers have died in combat - is contrived comic-book stuff, but there are extremely vivid and emotionally jolting scenes in the film's near three-hour running time: for example, the opening battle, which pitches us headfirst into the chaos and horror of the Omaha beach landing on D-day; a knife fight in a ruined house where you can almost smell the sweat and fear; and, more peacefully, the young GIs' faces angel-like in candlelight. Tom Hanks is a quietly noble platoon leader, and Tom Sizemore his granite-like sergeant.

An Angel At My Table

(Jane Campion, 1990)

3am, FilmFour

A moving and uplifting account of the hard early years of New Zealand novelist Janet Frame. The film covers a series of traumatic events in Frame's life: a twin's death; a sister's drowning; and the horror of electric shock treatment in a mental institution where she was diagnosed as schizophrenic. Kerry Fox is by turns awkward, troubled and effervescent as a talented woman who is, above all, a survivor.

webTitle: Weekend TV: Blonde ambitions

fields.headline: Blonde ambitions
fields.trailText: Take A Girl Like You | Kiss Me Kate | The Natural World
fields.body:
She has bouncy hair. She gets whistled at. She literally stops traffic. (And not in a lollipop lady way.) People say things to her like "You are quite unnecessarily pretty, aren't you?" and "You were just about the loveliest thing I'd ever seen." Could this young lady be the heroine of Take A Girl Like You (BBC1, Sun)? The "You" in fact? Surely she is.

Blonde and svelte with a wireless in her handbag (cheeky jazz music strikes up whenever she appears, which can't be a coincidence), Miss Jenny Bunn has come for your heart, her slightly comedy name only underlining the gravity of her beauty. Everyone else in this most engaging and delightful of ensemble dramas is simply after her virginity. Place your bets...

As Jenny, Sienna Guillory has found a role which tests her acting talents without overstretching them. She does wounded well, coquettish even better and strikes just the right balance between naïve and knowing. She is a star around which the other players orbit and she deserves their attendance.

Sometimes, she looks drunk, even when she isn't.

As the suave and sex-mad Patrick, Rupert Graves is perfect. A man who's always looked as if he belonged in another time, he - and hopeless sidekick McClintock - are more than stereotypical blokes with one thing on their minds, though they do only have one thing on their minds. A player about to be played, Patrick may not be likeable but he is enchanting. And one assumes that was the idea.

The others, too, are equally entertaining. Emma Chambers is a particular revelation as the embittered Martha ("volatile, inflammable"), who stalks her home like a rankled lioness. Dick, her nasally and anally retentive husband, meanwhile, circles Jenny with all the stealth of a drunken warthog.

In fact, the whole milieu of Take A Girl Like You is transfixing. From the growling boiler (no, not Emma Chambers) and the candlewicks on the beds to gloves, steam trains and Bakelite telephones, it evokes a past which is another continent, never mind another country. This was a glimpse into a place where there was no contraceptive pill, and no feminism, and where misogyny may well have been a government policy. That isn't to say the drama itself is misogynist - it merely reflects what was happening at that time, albeit through the distorted mirror of literature. In truth, in Andrew Davies' sharp, sensitive adaptation, it's the men who are exposed as idiots, buffoons and generally wretched. Au contraire , as the pouting Anna might say, the women are quite dignified.

Not only is Take A Girl Like You perfect Sunday night drama (once you've come to terms with the imminent release of an album of the - occasionally intrusive - soundtrack), it's great period drama. Period.

In Kiss Me Kate (BBC1, Sunday), Kate, played with apparent effortlessness by Caroline Quentin, may be slightly unhinged, and Mel may be stuck with the endearingly dopey Craig but, again, it's the men who are the most unfortunate.

Douglas loves Kate but can't tell her, despite sleeping in her spare room; Craig insists a Mr Paint runs the paint shop bearing his name (he'd doubtless have had Miss Bunn down as the baker's daughter); and Gordon Kennedy pops up as an ex of Kate's who ends up wearing his dinner.

Its subject matter may be the usual stuff of sitcom - paint colours, cakes and libidinous ex-lovers - but thanks to razor-sharp timing, economical, almost spartan, writing, and some of the best comic acting on television, it's a superior British sitcom.

Amanda Holden is at her very best playing Mel, co-writer Chris Langham is a wonderful pessimist and Darren Boyd's Craig steals scenes with bizarre lines like "When paint dries, it's stronger than elephants."

Obviously, in BBC-Land, that means it should be on near 11pm on a Sunday, after Panorama, and not scheduled to lure viewers from ITV immediately after Cold Feet has finished. That would be far too sensible.

There are sensible folks in Madagascar. As The Natural World (BBC2, Sun) told us, the people who live on the island believe lemurs are ghosts, living bodies of ancestral spirits, so shouldn't be harmed, and that to touch a chameleon is to court adversity.

Quite right too. Any animal that can lick its own eyeballs is not to be trusted.

webTitle: Leak story is load of old rubbish, says aide

fields.headline: Leak story is load of old rubbish, says aide
fields.trailText: Jonathan Powell discovered his jottings on Downing Street headed notepaper had found their way to a public print five days after he threw them out with the remains of suppers and empty wine bottles.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's chief of staff yesterday insisted that a front page story in a Sunday newspaper was absolute rubbish - quite literally.

Jonathan Powell discovered his jottings on Downing Street headed notepaper had found their way to a public print five days after he threw them out with the remains of suppers and empty wine bottles.

The No 10 aide left the hand-written notes, a list of things he had done and to do, in a black plastic bin bag outside his south London home at 11.30pm last Wednesday.

Leaving for No 10 at 7.30am the following day, Mr Powell noticed four sacks and a Southwark council green wheelie bin left for the refuse collectors had been opened.

Suspecting a fox, he thought nothing of it until the Sunday Times dropped on his doormat yesterday. There, over two columns on the right-hand side of the front page, were his notes published under the byline of the Insight investigative team.

His nocturnal visitor had been not a fox but a professional muckraker, an odd cove who steals the waste of public figures to sell it to newspapers.

The finger of suspicion im mediately points to Benji the Binman, aka Benjamin Pell of north London, who has made a good living from the Sunday Times and other News International titles, and has seen the fruits of his labours appear in most national newspapers.

Mr Pell, who has his own overalls and van, and has been known to leave replacement bin bags to stop householders becoming suspicious, is believed to have been behind a series of leaked Tony Blair-Philip Gould memos earlier this year.

The notes hinted at what has been occupying Mr Powell. One read "Arsenal Dome - what say CS?" CS is believed to refer to Chris Smith, the culture secretary, though the notes did not reveal what he did say.

Another said "mini-reshuffle" though yet again there were no details, nor were we enlightened as to why a large tick was through the name of Bill Gates.

Alastair Campbell, the No 10 official spokesman whose name appeared on one of the sheets, was not amused. "I have seen some dross on front pages in my time but they might have got a better story if they had produced the contents of one of his kid's nappies," he said.

webTitle: Mark Lawson: Musical youth

fields.headline: Musical youth
fields.standfirst: An opera aimed at teenagers? It sounds like a barmy idea but Channel 4's Zoe is compelling even if the subject matter doesn't entirely lend itself to the medium
fields.trailText: An opera aimed at teenagers? It sounds like a barmy idea but Channel 4's Zoe is compelling even if the subject matter doesn't entirely lend itself to the medium.
fields.body:
Any teenage viewers channel-hopping or flicking listings pages are likely to assume that Zoe (Saturday, 7.20pm, Channel 4) is a new chat show hosted by Fatboy Slim's wife. Tuning in, they'll be disappointed to find a modern opera but the channel hopes they'll stay because this is an opera optimistically aimed at the viewers and listeners of Ms Ball.

Zoe - with music by John Lunn and libretto by Stephen Plaice - was commisioned and staged by Glyndebourne's education department. Rewritten for television and filmed on location, it follows the career in a rock band of the title character, the daughter of a famous film star who gave her up for adoption.

The year 2000 has been an unusually good one for contemporary opera. London revivals of Harrison Birtwhistle's Gawain and John Adams's Nixon In China met warm appreciation from critics and audiences previously hostile to post-Schoenberg music. Mark Anthony Turnage's The Silver Tassie and Michael Berkeley and David Malouf's Jane Eyre were both new operas with popular appeal and Poul Ruders's setting of Margaret Atwood's novel The Handmaid's Tale received such ecstatic reviews in Denmark that it seems sure to have an international future.

Lunn's and Plaice's Zoe doesn't quite belong in the previous company, ranking rather as a compelling oddity. But its commissioning - and the ambition to make opera work for the pop music generation - confirms the sudden confidence around the composition of the highest and hardest form of musical drama.

Zoe also demonstrates in an extreme form the problems of writing modern opera. The first of these is setting and the search for an idiom which isn't made ridiculous by singing. It's no coincidence that of the five recent works listed above - Birtwhistle, Adams, Turnage, Berkeley and Ruders - none is a contemporary story. Nixon In China is the closest to the present and even that uses characters - Nixon, Kissinger, Mao - who have now been given by history the heft of legend.

The reason that the past is easier to set is that composers and librettists struggle with everyday dialogue. Giggles spread through the opera house stalls when banalities are exchanged in that sonorous semi-recitative:

- Do you want a cup of tea-eee? - Yes, please. I tay-ay-ake one sug-aaaar."

For words to sound comfortable being sung deep from the chest, the sentiments need to be large or (the traditional solution to the artificiality of opera) in a foreign language.

Taking place largely in a school and the office of a private detective, Zoe is often hobbled by the cup-of-tea problem. Late for class, Zoe (Emily Gilchrist) warbles in the corridor for directions from another student: "Do you know the way-ay to Film Stu-uu-dies?" The libretto inevitably works best when the language has a flash of poetry, as when the film studies lecturer commends to his students "a classy example of 50s film noir", a sentence euphonious enough for music.

The second problem with Zoe is that it breaks the usual rule of opera composition which is that rival and more populist forms of music must be ignored. Adams, Birtwhistle and Turnage work strictly within their own sound-world. If anyone would like more tunes, they should go to Puccini or the Broadway musical. The recent operatic version of Fitzgerald's The Great Gatsby was careful not to use popular jazz tunes during the party scenes in case they clashed with the more austere tone of the piece itself. A vegetarian restaurant never wheels out a crown of roast beef.

But, because the central character in Zoe is a singer in a rock band, Lunn has to give her pop tunes. Plaices libretto tries to make sense of this by depicting her stern father as an opera buff. Some scenes become a conversation between two musical forms, with the Royal Opera House sound of the older characters constrasting with the Wembley Arena crooning of the younger ones. Permission To Kiss, a duet between Zoe and her boyfriend lists the arcane information each knows - "Marco Polo learned to speak Chinese" - and builds to the chorus:

- I can't remember who taught me this

- But what I can't remember is

- Who gives permission to kiss.

It's a knockout song but could easily be covered by any girl or boy band. The only opera it belongs in is a rock opera.

The drawback of this mixed-music approach in a piece supposed to turn the young towards Turnage is that the audience's ears will cleave to the familiar, simply waiting for another pop song to come along and tuning out of the moments when someone opens their throat and sings against orchestral complexity.

Modern opera is probably the hardest of all forms to sell on television. This is partly because of the level of concentration required and partly because the close-up is cruel to the effort required for vocal projection.

This year's BBC Annual Report actually boasts about 100,000 viewers watching a new opera, an audience which would have any other programme hauled off air. Zoe has the merit of looking and feeling like TV drama but can never quite decide if it's an opera, ending up as a sort of Fame with A-Levels.

A right royal farce

A few weeks ago, I wrote here about the problem of programmes which feel like repeats but aren't: the result of the medium's tendency to copy previous successes. The Windsors (Thursday, 8pm, Channel 4) is a strange and disgraceful example of the reverse: a programme which claims to be new but is in fact a repeat.

Billed and publicised as a fresh view of the Royal Family - the first time television has dared to submit the Windsors to serious scrutiny - this historical series seems from the beginning to be having problems with its chronology. Two of the early contributors on the reign of George V - Barbara Cartland and Lord Charteris - are now dead. And, as the viewer wonders how long the filming schedule might have been, Lady Longford clearly speaks about Diana in the present tense.

The explanation for these oddities is that The Windsors was first transmitted by ITV six years ago. The end has been extended to reflect the death of Diana and other Royal events but the opening programme is almost unchanged. Yet any viewer trouble by deja-vu while watching receives an explanation only from the discreet 1994 copyright line at the end. There is no other admission in the presentation of the series that this is a repeat.

The material - beginning with George V's reinvention of his Germanic clan as The Windsors because his country was at war with his cousins - is as compelling now as it was then. Indeed, The Windsors was a particularly bad choice for this trick because Phillip Whitehead's series was genuinely memorable.

It has now, though, been tarnished by this clumsy passing-off as new. With too many repeats already on television, Channel 4 should surely not be using the scheduling equivalent of techniques banned from second-hand car lots.

webTitle: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: China Evening | In Animals That Changed The World
fields.body:
Carrie Gracie, former Beijing correspondent, joins Christopher Cook for a second China Evening (7.30pm, Radio 3), showing how the enduring spirit of the Middle Kingdom is painfully getting to grips with the 21st century. A major element is Ms Gracie's account of a newly-recorded Chinese rap record (the country's first) winding its way through the serpentine Communist censorship. The official insistence on one-child families has produced a self-regarding 20s generation which is starting to flex its muscles.

None of which would have happened, according to Elwyn Hartley Edwards, if humans had not managed to tame a particular beast 5,000 years ago. In Animals That Changed The World (9.0pm, Radio 4) he asserts that domesticating the horse enabled mankind to abandon tiny riverside settlements and embark on civilisation. Having an engine capable of transporting heavy loads and moving armies around at 20mph did the trick. And it widened the accessible gene pool no end.
