webTitle: Architecture: The building blocks of life

fields.headline: The building blocks of life
fields.standfirst: Steve Rose on an awards scheme designed to change the way Britain thinks about home design
fields.trailText: Steve Rose on an awards scheme designed to change the way Britain thinks about home design.
fields.body:
Behind the flattering words for architects in this month's white paper on urban regeneration lurked the withering spirit of Richard Rogers. His Urban Task Force, which provided the raw material for the white paper, complained that years of neglect in architectural education had left Britain's cities "the worst in Europe".

Rather than a slight, these comments actually represent a challenge to Britain's architectural and design communities. In this light, this year's National Homebuilder Design Awards (NHDA), sponsored by the Guardian, is an arena for immediate response. Though the awards are not directly related to the white paper, they address similar issues to those the government has prioritised: ecological and energy-efficient design, preservation of greenfield sites and redevelopment of brownfield sites, as well as promoting good housing design in general.

So is the time for change finally ripe? From the architects' point of view the will to change has long been there, particularly in the housing sector - traditionally the most conservative field of the most conservative art form - but while architects struggle to improve standards, nobody seems to want anything "too new". The government's emphasis on higher urban densities, reversal of the exodus from city centres, and conservation of undeveloped land, all indicate that the old methods will no longer suffice.

"People say nobody wants modern architecture, and it's simply not true, it's just that they've never really been offered it," says Michael Manser, former president of the Royal Institute of British Architects and chairman of this year's NHDA judging panel. "The planners won't allow it, and you couldn't expect the developers to build it because it's tremendously expensive - even though there is a market wanting something up to date."

The debate goes deeper than mere aesthetics. There are demands for energy efficiency, and for built-in information-age technology. Changes in family structure have seen the average household reduced to two or three people. Demographic shifts have created a demand for less formal, more flexible spatial arrangements from young homebuyers, as well as a growing elderly population with its own specific needs.

"Higher density, tight-knit communities are needed, and these will require homes with ingenious planning, low-energy consumption and high flexibility," says Manser, who cites last year's winner, the Huf House in Weybridge, Surrey, as a successful example.

So at a time when architecture is receiving the attention it deserves, these awards represent an opportunity for property developers to prove their commitment to innovative design, and for talented architects to make their name, enhance their reputation, and affirm Britain's capability when it comes to solving its own design problems.

 For an entry pack call: 01483 202001 or visit www.nationalhomebuilder.com. Closing date Friday December 8 2000.

So at a time when architecture is receiving the attention it deserves, these awards represent an opportunity for property developers to prove their commitment to innovative design, and for talented architects to make their name, enhance their reputation, and affirm Britain's capability when it comes to solving its own design problems.  For an entry pack call: 01483 202001 or visit www.nationalhomebuilder.com. fields.headline: Wire we waiting
fields.trailText: What a strange lot builders are. Rosemary's tiler has failed to turn up twice. Once because he was stuck at "a meeting in the city", once because he'd spent a weekend in Las Vegas, his flight had been delayed, he needed to sleep off the jet lag, then he'd be round. Rosemary is still waiting.
fields.body:
What a strange lot builders are. Rosemary's tiler has failed to turn up twice. Once because he was stuck at "a meeting in the city", once because he'd spent a weekend in Las Vegas, his flight had been delayed, he needed to sleep off the jet lag, then he'd be round. What upmarket excuses. Rosemary is still waiting. Also, her sensitive builder has disappeared, the one who felt money and possessions were unimportant. She last saw him outside her bank, where she handed him a huge wad of cash. Builder made jokes about drug dealers and promised to come back and finish the shelving. Rosemary is still waiting.

I know how she feels. Our builder also lost interest towards the end of the job. We have dangling wires and we don't have plugs yet, nor the missing cupboard door nor the bit of skirting nor the tile edging. To be fair, Builder offered to return after the summer holidays, but by then Gardener had taken over.

I notice that builders often start dynamically, then wilt and long to be off on other jobs, where the whole ghastly cycle begins again: the burst of enthusiasm, the slowing down, lack of interest, short disappearances, long disappearances. Are they gone forever? No one knows.

But at least these builders are polite. Years ago I complained to the gutter mender. He had mended the gutter, which then poured water the next day. "Could you please come back and mend it?" I asked. "Fuck off," said the gutter man.

Then there was the decorator who nearly throttled me. I banned woodchip, he slapped it on while I was out, I came back and insisted he take it down, so he grabbed me by the throat. His little joke. Now I always try to find builders recommended by friends. Then they leave the friend's job to come and look, make a start, go back and finish the friend's job, or perhaps fix up the next job, make a start there, come back to me, possibly . . . Now where's Gardener gone?

webTitle: Marcel Berlins: Writ large

fields.headline: Dead certs and other winners
fields.trailText: There are a couple of intriguing postscripts to my assertion a couple of weeks ago that a dead man can't be elected to our Parliament (as one senator just has been in the US).
fields.body:
There are a couple of intriguing postscripts to my assertion a couple of weeks ago that a dead man can't be elected to our Parliament (as one senator just has been in the US). Patrick Hannan writes to tell me that in July 1945 Leslie Pym, contesting Monmouth, died between polling day and the declaration of the result (he won), which had been delayed for three weeks while waiting for the postal votes from the forces abroad. The same thing, L Raphael informs me, happened to Sir Edward Campbell, winner of the Bromley seat in the same election (who, astonishingly, died on the same day as Pym). He adds the name of Noel Skelton, still alive when the votes were counted for the Combined Scottish Universities seats in 1935, but dead when he was announced as MP for one of them.

Yes, but all those chaps only "won" their seats because of delays between voting day and the result being known. That's not the same as the Missouri experience, where they voted for their senator knowing that he was no longer.

I'm worried about a Liverpool judge's decision to abort a rape trial last week because, he believed, a television programme might have prejudiced the jury. On Monday, BBC2's Newsnight showed an item about a 71-year-old Merseyside man who admitted raping and abusing his three step-daughters when they were children. In last week's trial the 54-year-old accused had allegedly raped his stepdaughter and indecently assaulted his daughter. There was no link between the two cases, and Newsnight didn't refer to any cases other than the one they featured. But the judge thought that there were too many similarities, and that the accused might not get a fair trial at the time. The trial will take place next year. I don't know of any trial before being stopped because of media coverage of an unlinked case.

In 1988 a TVS documentary, "The New Rachmans", exposed the nasty and fraudulent activities of slum landlords in Reading. At the time one such landlord was standing trial at Reading Crown Court for defrauding the DHSS . The programme didn't mention him or the trial, but there were clearly recognisable pictures of him. The trial was aborted and TVS fined for contempt of court. That was very different from the Liverpool example. In Reading the man on trial had been implicated in the activities exposed by the programme. The Liverpool judge must have believed that jurors seeing a programme about one abusive stepfather might have thought: "If that stepfather on TV did those wicked things, it makes it more likely that the stepfather in the dock is also guilty." That's surely going too far and, what's more, an insult to the jury.

There's another aspect. The law rightly allows the media to raise issues of public interest and importance even though someone somewhere might be standing trial for a crime linked to the issue. It's OK provided we don't draw attention to the particular trial. I don't think there's any question of contempt of court by Newsnight, but still the media are being blamed for stopping the Liverpool trial. That can only hinder future exposés.

I know you want to be better informed about life in judges' lodgings. Here are some extracts from parliamentary answers: "Stocked wine cellars are not provided for judges. Any wine purchased for consumption during periods of judicial occupation is purchased at retail prices and is paid for from the judges' weekly allowance". "Entertaining should generally not exceed one formal lunch party and one dinner party per week... numbers invited to lunch parties are... expected to be modest." But here's good news for the taxpayer - judges have to pay for booze and entertaining out of their weekly allowance of £310, which we pay for. But "should the judge exceed the allowance allocated, for whatever reason, the additional expenditure will be paid for by the judge." What a relief.

webTitle: Deborah Bee: Does being pretty bring you power?

fields.headline: The beautiful and the damned
fields.standfirst: Does being pretty bring you power?  Deborah Bee  faces a few facts about looks
fields.trailText: Does being pretty bring you power?  Deborah Bee  faces a few facts about looks
fields.body:
Is beauty an advantage? Does it make the beautiful individual powerful? Does it, as researchers at London Guildhall University revealed last week, result in substantially better pay and opportunities in the workplace? "Looks are always talked about as if they're power, when what it is of course is that power has to be about action, and beauty rests on other people's reactions," said domestic goddess Nigella Lawson in a recent interview. "One has no control over other people's reactions, therefore it seems to me to be wrong to talk about power."

Lawson has become a talking point of late. But it's not the likeness of the cheese crust to the one pictured on page 116 that forms the topic of conversation. It's Nigella's eyes, her hair, her body, her sticky licky fingers. She is beautiful. Men love her. Some women are beginning to loathe her. Advantage or disadvantage, beauty still provokes an unruly range of emotions, from pure lust to sheer envy.

It is 10 years since feminist author Naomi Wolf pronounced on the beauty myth. "Beauty is a currency system like the gold standard," she wrote. "Like any economy, it is determined by politics and in the modern age in the west it is the last, best belief system that keeps male dominance intact."

Wolf decried society's obsession with female beauty and challenged us to place more value on intelligence, complexity, empathy and humour. But your sneaking suspicion that Nigella's face counts for more than her talent with a hand whisk would suggest that in the past decade we haven't taken up Wolf's challenge. Television, newspapers and magazines are as beauty-obsessed as ever. Across the board, the visual diversity of women's looks is under-represented. How often do you see grey-haired women presenters? How often are they bigger than a size 12? How often have they got a big nose?

The media may not be entirely to blame. True, the constant bombardment of images of flawless models creates unrealistic expectations of women, but according to an evolutionary psychological analysis, we are only behaving as we always have. David Buss, of the University of Texas, believes women's desire for beauty stems from men's mate preference. The results of his and other studies into this area have led Buss to believe that, over evolutionary history, men have imposed their desire for attractiveness on women because physical attractiveness provides a set of proximate clues to health and youth, and therefore fertility.

In the book Sex, Power, Conflict, Buss states: "A woman enhances her own beauty at the expense of other women because she improves her own odds of attracting a desirable man at a cost to her competitors."

How we actually judge what is beautiful, though, is the subject of other important scientific research. We know that babies respond more to "pretty" than not so pretty faces. But further studies have revealed that the more regular and symmetrical the features, the more likely we are at any age to judge a face to be beautiful. Model good looks, then, are all about averageness equalling attractiveness.

But do those model good looks bring other advantages? My model agent friend Helena is equivocal. "People outside of the modelling industry think that somehow the very fact of being a model will bring you instant self-esteem. We generally pluck these girls from relative obscurity - the school or community where they are quite clearly the prettiest. We pop them on a headsheet next to 59 other beautiful girls and sometimes the competition becomes too much. Even some of our most well-known, successful girls are paranoid about their weight, their spots, their cellulite. The real joke is that while the general public are busy trying to look like the girls in the ads, the girls in the ads are busy trying to look like another girl in another ad. I could tell you stories of really famous girls who can barely get through the day because their self- esteem is so low. Being beautiful actually makes them miserable."

My own modelling career was similarly demoralising and thankfully shortlived. Kindly (or not) overlooking a certain heaviness about the backside, a model agency put me on its books when I was 18. Overnight, I turned from an attractive (if a little pudgy) teenager into a too-fat failure of a model. I slogged around London with my portfolio of three pictures and suffered the humiliation of being not beautiful enough, not slim enough, not good enough. I don't think anyone was sorry when I gave up, but the rejection still chills my bones.

It's doubtless the same feeling Cindy Crawford will be suffering, now she's been dropped from her Revlon cosmetics contract. It was alleged that her image was considered "too boring" to shift products, though it was hard to ignore the implication that - at 34 - she was also too old. It has since been rumoured that Estée Lauder may now consider dropping 35-year-old Liz Hurley as their main model, having already hired the younger Uma Thurman to assist their fight for a bigger market share.

But surely that's just the crazy world of cosmetics. I spoke to my friend who works in publishing, very lovely Rosemary. Without the bizarre aesthetics of the fashion industry to deal with, perhaps she would have found her beauty an advantage?

"The men around here are easy," she tells me. "If I want to get my own way, I pretty much know what will make them respond positively."

Should we approve of such tactics? "I'm not doing anyone any harm," Rosemary insists. "If they're daft enough to fall for it, they deserve it. I don't consider myself to be any great shakes but there are women in this building who took a dislike to me on sight. No matter how nice I am to them, how many times we go out for a drink after work, they always take a swipe at my looks. My immediate boss, who's not as attractive as me, brings me into meetings with male colleagues with the words: 'Ah, Rosemary - there you are, looking beautiful as ever.' She may as well hold a placard over my head, saying: 'Pretty? Yes, but don't ask her anything.' Women don't like beautiful women, particularly not as their subordinates. It upsets the natural balance when men are around. It's a predatory thing."

Nancy Etcoff would agree. In her book Survival of the Prettiest, she stated that beauty is no asset to an ambitious woman. "There is an assumption that beautiful women are too flaky, too sexual and unable to lead the troops, and they often fail to reach the top. For women wanting to climb the corporate ladder, there is evidence that they must conceal their beauty in order to get ahead."

Nor does working with men make a difference. "Beauty? An advantage?" laughs my friend Rebecca, who works in an almost exclusively male environment. "I'm not sure how much longer I can deal with this schoolboy 'phwoar' mentality. I try to have sensible conversations with colleagues and find myself having to ignore their silly innuendo. They think it's flattering, but it's not. It's degrading."

Meanwhile, scientists maintain that feminism will never achieve any great success in eliminating our obsession with female beauty. While Buss believes Wolf may have altered our values to a small degree, those changes will only cause women to compete with each other in a different way. "If all men were suddenly persuaded to value physical strength in a mate," he has said, "and to be indifferent to other dimensions of physical attractiveness, then women would, over time, compete with one another to build muscles."

The fashion industry, by its very existence, perpetuates an idealised image. But, perhaps surprisingly, it is also the best place to learn the true value of beauty. As a journalist, you are never part of the beauty currency because there is always someone younger, slimmer, more beautiful than you. As you stand by and watch another 19-year-old having her 15 minutes, you realise that although we are seduced by it, beauty has a very limited value in the real world. Of course it can be an advantage, but unless you're model material, it won't make you money.

In the real world, beauty is a marketing tool that can occasionally open doors and occasionally slam them in your face. And on TV it can turn a very dull subject into a ratings success. How much more interesting did gardening become when Charlie Dimmock began pushing the wheelbarrow about? Good for her. As Simone de Beauvoir said: "To make oneself an object, to make oneself passive, is a very different thing from being a passive object."

So if, by any chance, there's a boring TV genre left after cooking, gardening or home improvement that needs a bit of sex interest, I'd like to offer myself up to it. The Carpet Bowls show? Ready, Steady, Knit? Or maybe we could do a programme that extolled the virtues of housework. We could call it How to be a Domestic Slave and I'd get to wear a French maid's outfit. If nothing else, it may mean a few more men would discover where the Hoover is kept.

webTitle: Pass notes: The Turner Prize

fields.headline: No: 1769
fields.standfirst: The Turner Prize
fields.trailText: The Turner Prize
fields.body:
So what's going to win tomorrow - dung, sliced cows, Tracey Emin's tent embroidered with the name of every journalist she's given a quote to?

That is a deeply philistine remark, typical of the British hostility to modern art bemoaned by Turner jury chairman Sir Nicholas Serota in his Dimbleby lecture. And anyway, there's nothing scandalous this year. The only controversy has been whether it's too boring or - and you have to see this from Tate's point of view - just boring enough.

Shouldn't that be the Tate?

No, just Tate these days.

They want it to be boring?

Let's just say the students bouncing on Emin's bed last year are not what Tate thinks the Turner is about. Steve McQueen's film of a tape recorder playing in a field is more the thing.

Steve who?

Last year's winner - but that bed became bigger than the prize itself. So this year they've shortlisted four artists guaranteed not to cause controversy: two painters, Glenn Brown and Michael Raedecker; a photographer, Wolfgang Tillmans; and Tomoko Takahashi, who makes installations out of junk.

Aha! Rubbish Takes Top Art Prize! Art Junk-et!

Enough of your carping anti-modernist headlines. Just as Picasso changed perceptions with cubism and Michael Craig-Martin convinced us that a glass of water can be an oak tree, so Takahashi's piles of discarded office supplies are relevant to life today.

It's working - I'm bored already.

I haven't told you about Brown's canvases that ironically mimic the brushwork of senior British painter Frank Auerbach or Tillmans' photographs of drains and Tupperware.

I don't really care, but is anyone tipped to win?

Tillmans is theoretically the favourite, but Brown might pip him to it.

Do say:

"This is the most thoughtful Turner shortlist for years."

Don't say (unless you want to be quoted in next year's Dimbleby lecture):

"Dung it all before - this year's Turner is like being savaged by dead sheep."

Especially don't say:

"Frank Auerbach. Now there's a painter."

I don't really care, but is anyone tipped to win? Tillmans is theoretically the favourite, but Brown might pip him to it. Do say: "This is the most thoughtful Turner shortlist for years." Don't say (unless you want to be quoted in next year's Dimbleby lecture): "Dung it all before - this year's Turner is like being savaged by dead sheep." Especially don't say: "Frank Auerbach. Now there's a painter."

webTitle: Foreign secretary to go offensive against eurosceptics

fields.headline: No surrender at EU summit, Cook vows
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Robin Cook made it clear yesterday that the government would go on the offensive against the eurosceptics in the run-up to the Nice summit next week.
fields.body:
Robin Cook made it clear yesterday that the government would go on the offensive against the eurosceptics in the run-up to the Nice summit next week.

The Foreign Secretary rounded on critics of the European Rapid Reaction Force as Downing Street advisers said they were winning the argument.

A Mori opinion poll in a Sunday newspaper found that 55% of the public backed the new force, and 38% opposed it.

Nevertheless, the eurosceptics may seize on a Russian welcome for the force as a sign that it does indeed pose a threat to Nato. On Saturday the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, said in Berlin:"In a crisis situation we are ready for constructive cooperation. The possibility of a Russian contribution in the conduct of European Union operations in regulating crises will be studied."

Mr Cook tried to allay fears yesterday that Britain would give in to pressure to surrender its EU council of ministers' veto on issues such as tax, defence, border controls,treaty changes and social security. He said the government had outlined six areas where it would refuse to budge, including tax and social security.

"Particularly, to take the case of tax and social security, we believe that these are very important parts of the national characteristic. It is important that they should be resolved by national parliaments and their governments," he said.

Gordon Brown, in Brussels last night for a meeting of finance ministers, made it clear that he would not accept French demands for the veto on bank supervision being replaced by qualified majority voting.

The French want the European Central Bank to take over control. Mr Brown wants enhanced cooperation instead.

webTitle: Third attack by Hizbullah guerrillas prompts Tel Aviv's first cross-border reprisal

fields.headline: Israeli jets hit south Lebanon
fields.standfirst:
A third attack by Hizbullah guerrillas prompts Tel Aviv's first cross-border reprisal in the six months since its forces left the 'security zone'
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A third attack by Hizbullah guerrillas prompts Tel Aviv's first cross-border reprisal in the six months since its forces left the 'security zone'
fields.byline: Virginia Quirke and agencies in Jerusalem
fields.body:
Israel made its first reprisal raid on south Lebanon since pulling out in May. Its fighter planes and artillery went into action yesterday after Lebanese guerrillas exploded a roadside bomb in Israeli-held territory, killing one soldier and injuring two.

Hizbullah, backed by Syria, claimed responsibility for the attack, its third since Israeli forces left the southern zone on May 25. Tel Aviv made no military response to the earlier two.

A Hizbullah statement said the roadside bomb was part of its quest "to liberate our usurped land, and to confirm that jihad [struggle] is the only way" to achieve this.

It referred to the bombers as "a group of al-Aqsa fighters", thus inking their action with the Palestinian uprising which began two months ago when Ariel Sharon, the hawkish leader of the Israeli opposition party, the Likud, blew the peace process apart by marching with hundreds of riot police into the site of the holiest Islamic site in Arab East Jerusalem, al-Aqsa mosque.

Israeli troops and Hizbullah fighters exchanged fire after yesterday's explosion in the area known as Har Dov, near the place that Hizbullah calls Shebaa farms, which Israel captured in the 1967 war.

Lebanon and Syria say that the area, which lies at the foot of the Golan Heights, was taken from the Lebanese; Israel insists that it was captured from Syria. The UN backs the Israeli interpretation.

Until Israel withdrew its forces from south Lebanon after 22 years of occupation, it fought a war of attrition with Hizbullah, the Shi'ite Muslim "Party of God".

Israelis have been on edge since Hizbullah guerrillas stormed across a border fence and captured three Israeli soldiers on October 7. Last week the group exploded a roadside bomb while an Israeli tank was passing.

The prime minister, Ehud Barak, described the situation on the Lebanese border yesterday as "extremely sensitive" and said that while Israel would respond, it would not be "dragged into adventures".

In Israel's other area of conflict - the one with the Palestinians - skirmishes in various places yesterday reached a climax last night with army snipers shooting dead four Palestinian gunmen in or near the West Bank town of Qalqilya, which is under the control of the Palestinian Authority.

The military spokesman said that the four were armed and had left the town for an area under Israeli control.

They were suspected of preparing to attack something or someone, he said. Earlier they had opened fire on an Israeli car driving to a Jewish settlement.

Meanwhile yesterday, contacts were renewed in Cairo, where the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, met Danny Yatom, Mr Barak's political and security adviser. The two were expected to discuss how to stop the two months of violence in which more than 280 people have been killed, most of them Palestinian.

In another search for common ground on which peace might be restored, an Israeli cabinet minister, Amnon Lipkin-Shahak, is reported to have held a meeting with the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, on Saturday night but nothing concrete seems to have come of it.

Elsewhere on the diplomatic front the former US senator George Mitchell, who won respect for his mediating role in Northern Ireland, assembled his team in New York for a fact-finding mission to Israel and the Palestinian territories.

This was the first meeting of the group, which is operating under UN auspices and charged with sorting out the causes of the current violence. Palestinians pushed for this investigation, Israeli leaders objected, saying the committee could not operate fairly until the violence had ended.

Critics suspect that Tel Aviv's real reason, as was the case in Lebanon, where it was often at odds with UN monitoring forces, is that the multinational team may get first-hand experience that will count against Israel, whose forces are doing most of the killing.

webTitle: Comment: Labour stabs the unions in the back

fields.headline: Enemies of the workers
fields.standfirst:
Labour asks for support from the unions but stabs them in the back.
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour asks for support from the unions but stabs them in the back, argues Jimmy Reid.
fields.body:
The British government is celebrating a victory in Europe, according to a report I read last Monday from the European editor of the Press Association, Geoff Meade. Britain has fought and argued that the European Union's Charter of Fundamental Human Rights should not be made legally binding on member states.

Originally the charter sought to guarantee the legal right of workers to organise in trade unions; the right to negotiate with employers; the right to withdraw their labour when deemed by them to be right to do so. It also included the legal right of employees to be consulted by employers on all matters affecting their interests as employees.

It's well known that Tony Blair and Gordon Brown were bitterly against such legal provision. They argued that the protection of workers as workers was a matter of social policy while the protection of workers, as individuals, outside their employment, could be considered a question of human rights.

This convoluted and somewhat abstruse reasoning that absurdly compartmentalised human rights for workers was but a cover for their real concern. Such European laws would supersede Thatcher's Law that made British trade unions the least free in the developed world. As a consequence of the Blair government's strenuous efforts, it looks as if our unions will remain the least free.

The latest draft of the charter will go for endorsement to the Euro-summit in Nice next month and as it stands will not be legally binding. The European TUC including the British TUC will be lobbying in force, insisting that workers' rights are human rights and should enjoy the full authority of the law in free societies.

The European TUC supported the charter as envisaged at the EU council that met in Cologne in June 1999, which concluded that the "protection of fundamental rights is a founding principle of the (European) Union and an indispensable prerequisite for her legitimacy".

The European trade unions made their opinions clear. "A real 'protection of fundamental rights' implies the legally binding incorporation of these rights in the treaties." The British Government opposed such proposals.

It is incredible, but none the less true, that this British Labour government is now seen as the arch enemy of trade unionism in Europe. How can it be that a political party - the British Labour party, founded and funded by trade unions - should now, in government, bite the hand that fed and still feeds it?

In this respect the writing was on the wall before the 1997 general election. In April 1997, Larry Whitty, then general secretary of the Labour party, spoke at a meeting of Labour party members in Brussels. These included Labour MEPs, their staff, Labour party members who happened to be employees of the EU and others who were employed in the private sector and domiciled at that time in Brussels.

In his speech Larry said: "One of [his] worries is the number of IOUs being pocketed by the CBI and pledged by Tony Blair." Now whatever electoral promises he has broken there is no doubt that Blair honoured these pledges.

Shortly after the general election, as Britain's new prime minister, Blair assured businessmen that however he might tinker with employ ment laws and trade union rights in the UK, they could be certain that at the end of the exercise Britain's trade unions would still be the least free in Europe.

This became part of the sales pitch for encouraging inward investment in the United Kingdom. Come to Britain, under New Labour, and get yourself a shackled and tamed workforce.

Yet New Labour now has the gall to ask British trade unions to give an additional eight million quid to its war chest for the next election. It stabs them in the back; it stabs them in the front, while taking their money. That's mugging by another name. For the unions to give this lot a penny would be an act of masochism and not trade unionism. To give them eight million would be lunacy.

 Jimmy Reid, now a writer and broadcaster, led shop stewards in the 1971 Upper Clyde Shipbuilders dispute.

Jimmy_Reid@email.msn.com

webTitle: Victims to be told of attackers' release dates

fields.headline: Victims to be told of attackers' release dates
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Victims of all serious crime will be given the right to know when their attackers are being released from jail, under plans announced yesterday by the government.
fields.body:
Victims of all serious crime will be given the right to know when their attackers are being released from jail, under plans announced yesterday by the government aimed at neutralising Tory claims that it has been soft on crime.

Probation officers are expected to administer the scheme and were last week told that victims would also be entitled to know conditions of release, such as where offenders might stay.

Last night this sparked fears of possible vigilante action, with the Tories and probation officers urging Jack Straw, the home secretary, to ensure the plans do not become a green light for retaliation.

Mr Straw chose to make the announcement in a Sunday tabloid and wrote: "In the new year I will be announcing proposals so that the victims of all prisoners serving a sentence of 12 months or more are notified of their release date.

"And that will not be just for violent crime but for burglaries and thefts too. That will give victims better protection and also ensure their peace of mind."

A bill going through parliament gives victims of sex offences the right to know when their attackers will be released.

Probation officers have been told that the widening of victims' rights will be in place by April 2001, in time for the general election.

Mr Straw's plans follow the former Beatle George Harrison's demand to know the release date of Michael Abram, who attacked him with a knife at his home.

Explaining his thinking behind the move, Mr Straw wrote in the People: "When I read and hear of the experiences of those like George and Olivia Harrison it intensifies my determination.

"Victims are understandably concerned that even if their attackers have been sent to prison, there is no way of knowing when they will be released.

"Few things could be more distressing than suddenly facing your attacker at the local shop or pub when you thought they were behind bars.

"And I intend to end the horror of a rape victim suddenly coming face to face with her attacker in the street because she did not know he had been freed."

Last year 28,700 people serving sentences of 12 months or more were released from jail.

Harry Fletcher, of the National Association of Probation Officers, said: "If the offender has to live at a hostel, and that information is given to the victim, that could lead to retaliation. We'll be looking to clarify that with the Home Office.

"We accept that times are changing. The probation service in the past was solely about the rehabilitation of offenders and didn't take victims into account.

"It's important to understand how the victims feel as part of the rehabilitation process."

It is expected that most victims will be informed by letter, though probation officers may visit those who have suffered more serious crimes.

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, said: "We will not oppose any sensible measures brought forward by the government which are to the genuine benefit of victims of crimes.

"It is quite clear that victims should not be expected to live with the threat that they will wake up one morning with their perpetrator living next door.

"At the same time any such proposal should not be a licence for a vigilante society."

webTitle: Leader: The US must act on domestic pollution

fields.headline: Sins of emission
fields.standfirst:
The US must act on domestic pollution
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: The US must act on domestic pollution.
fields.body:
The collapse of the UN negotiations on climate change in The Hague is a moment of inexcusable shame for the few nations, led by America, who refused to change their polluting habits for the sake of the long-term survival of the world. Unless there is a change of heart this meeting will go down in history as the moment when governments jettisoned the concept of global cooperation when it was most urgently needed: to save the planet itself. Ostensibly, the meeting broke up because European countries, led by France, refused to accept a last minute compromise brokered by John Prescott. If agreed, it would have required the US to give up its plans to offset forests planted abroad (or simply saved from extinction) against its domestic targets for the reduction of carbon emissions. It could be argued that in terms of practical politics - not least, the imminence of an ungreen, isolationist Bush administration - that it would be better to accept a slice of bread rather than no loaf at all. And it could certainly be argued that Mr Prescott was ill- advised to raise premature hopes of a settlement. But that's not the point.

Even if the compromise had been accepted, it would have done little or nothing to tackle the main problem - the refusal of the US, the wealthiest nation on earth, to curb its ravenous appetite for gas guzzling. The US has 4% of the world's population but is responsible for almost 25% of the carbon dioxide unleashed into the atmosphere, which is the main cause of global warming. The US wants to meet its target, agreed at Kyoto, of 7% cuts in emissions by creating "carbon sinks" under which tree planting and changes in ploughing methods would help to absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Such initiatives undoubtedly have a place but they are no substitute for government action to curb US profligacy, including the ludicrously cheap price of gasoline at the pumps, which encourages the use of large, energy guzzling cars. If Americans can't be persuaded to curb their excesses then what moral authority will they have to dissuade the world's most populous country, China, from following the same path of conspicuous consumption?

There are some straws in the wind. Subtle changes are taking pace in American public opinion. In a recent poll 56% of Americans expressed a willingness to see taxes rise to preserve the environment. Corporations are realising that to be excluded from the Kyoto project could be bad for business, because they won't have a stake in the booming opportun-ities conservation will bring, of which emission trading is a key part.

It is possible, even under a Bush administration, that public and corporate pressures will wring changes where external pressures have failed. Meanwhile, the rest of the world must push ahead to ratify the Kyoto agreement with or without the US and the other "umbrella" countries, including Japan, who have argued that they cannot reach their targets without counting carbon sinks. The Kyoto programme for the survival of the planet is too important to be torpedoed by the parochialism of the US. Now that the cold war is over there is no area of policy that would benefit more from US leadership. Americans have a very strong self interest in changing their habits. If the world's biggest consumers were to cut down on gasoline use, it would postpone the time when diminishing world oil supplies push prices up and restore political control of energy to the Middle East. And, as the recent forest fires in the US reminded everyone, global warming knows no geographical barriers.

webTitle: Sugar multinationals blamed for blocking help to poorest nations

fields.headline: Short fears for EC trade reform
fields.standfirst: Sugar multinationals blamed for blocking help to poorest nations
fields.trailText: Sugar multinationals blamed for blocking help to poorest nations.
fields.body:
An effort by the European commission to allow in goods from the world's poorest countries is in danger of being killed off by Europe's powerful multinational sugar firms and forces of protectionism across the continent, according to Clare Short, the international development secretary.

Ms Short will intensify a full-scale campaign across Europe this week in an attempt to secure support for the initiative proposed by the EC's trade commissioner, Pascal Lamy, under which tariffs into the EU would be scrapped for the 48 least-developed nations.

The proposal has been strongly backed by aid agencies, but the development secretary fears that it is in danger of becoming bogged down after an outcry from the sugar multinationals. The government now fears that the offer may be withdrawn unless the opposition is faced down and the deal agreed by the end of France's presidency of the EU in just over a month's time.

Ms Short said: "The countries who would be helped by duty free access are the poorest of the poor, yet their voices are being drowned out by vested interests."

Britain's attempt to press ahead with the initiative has led to clashes in the Commons, where the Conservatives have opposed the plan on the grounds that it will harm sugar producers in the Caribbean, who have traditionally had preferential ac cess to Europe, the biggest and richest market in the world.

While the government is offering help to Caribbean producers to help them adjust to the new regime, it believes the impact would be modest. Ms Short believes the plight of Caribbean sugar producers is being used as a smokescreen by the big sugar companies, which have long benefited from inflated European sugar prices and do not want to see cheaper imports from the least-developed countries disturbing this arrangement.

European sugar beet farmers, who are offered three times the world price for their produce, are also concerned about their ability to compete with the LDCs, and are being backed by the EC's agricultural directorate. According to British and aid agency sources, agricultural officials in Brussels are using delaying tactics to thwart Mr Lamy's proposal, primarily by sitting on impact studies needed for member states to take a final decision on the duty-free plan.

Ms Short said she sympathised with sugar producers in the Caribbean, but said they would have time to adjust to the new regime, because capacity to export in the LDCs was so limited. According to Whitehall data, the average GDP per head in the 48 countries that would benefit was $287 a year in 1998, compared to $4,809 in the Caribbean.

"Mozambique, a competitive sugar producing LDC with GDP per head of $204, does not have access to the EU sugar market," Ms Short added.

webTitle: Obituary: Rayner Stephens Unwin, publisher

fields.headline: Rayner Unwin
fields.standfirst: Publisher of the old school who saw the demise of his family firm and the painful upheavals of an industrial revolution
fields.trailText: Publisher of the old school who saw the demise of his family firm and the painful upheavals of an industrial revolution.
fields.body:
Rayner Unwin, who has died aged 74, was born into the publishing business, being a son of Sir Stanley Unwin, whose dedication to the trade was total. He also witnessed the collapse of a style of publishing which, notably in the 1980s, became no longer able to survive.

After education at Abbotsholme school, Uttoxeter, and leaving it aged 17 with, as he later wrote, "no conspicuous qualifications", Rayner sold books for Basil Blackwell of Oxford. As this was wartime, and paper rationing was severe, the customers were often asked to cut back their optimistic orders, thus providing curious training for a future publisher. After military service in the Royal Navy, which mainly entailed rounding up Japanese after the conflict was over, he went to Trinity College, Oxford, and Harvard. In 1951, as had been presumed all along, he joined the family firm of George Allen & Unwin, at 40 Museum Street, Bloomsbury.

It cannot have been easy working there, on £34 a week. His father read all the mail, both incoming and outgoing. The place was Dickensian, its ledgers and orders written by hand. Employees complained of bed bugs, left over from the building's wartime use as a public air raid shelter. The offices, never elegant, became yet more labyrinthine after numbers 40A and 41 were purchased.

As recreation for the 50 staff, there was deck quoits on the roof, and darts in the basement, with darts often preferred, as it was tedious retrieving a quoit after it had fallen five storeys to the street. There were spy-holes for Stanley to see what was going on, and visitors could be come lost, perhaps straying into the packing department, where labels were glued on to secondhand cardboard boxes which were tied up with string.

But the place lived within its means, never being overexcited about a major profit. It had good authors, including Lancelot Hogben, Bertrand Russell, Julian Huxley and then, most amazingly of all, Thor Heyerdahl, after Stanley's nephew, Philip Unwin, stumbled upon the Kon-Tiki story while visiting Scandinavia. JRR Tolkien was acquired shortly afterwards, Rayner, having cabled his father (then selling books abroad) that The Lord Of The Rings was worthy of publication but might lose £1,000. Back came the famous reply: "If you believe it is a work of genius, then you may lose a thousand pounds."

Despite the infusions of cash which the various best- sellers produced, there was never much sign of affluence. Allen & Unwin's fame partly occurred for its astonishing turnaround in book dispatch, almost all orders being dealt with on the day of their arrival, but their authors' contracts could create merriment (as I knew personally) and also envy if shown to other publishers.

I f advances were modest, as indeed they were, the writers at least knew their books would stay in print if possible, and never be remaindered when sales stayed small or microscopic. There were some 2,500 titles extant on its lists when Rayner took over as chairman after his father's death in 1968.

That profligacy, plus a wide-ranging interest, was largely to blame for Allen & Unwin's later troubles. It seemed to have covered every kind of book - academic, popular, railway engines (Philip's fancy), exploration, philosophy (often from India) and fiction. The name of Allen had been retained from the firm's earlier history, which meant that, in records of titles, the company seemed to be top on every form of list.

As in the old days, the business was editorially led, but a consultant was introduced in the 1960s who then, after joining the board, became managing director. He pushed through reforms which, as Rayner himself wrote, "would have been entirely sensible in the competitive climate of a public company". Some could hardly be called objectionable, such as a two-thirds pension from the age of 60 or formal contracts of service, but power politics was getting in the way of editorial choice. The new broom was not content with a gentle upward drift of profitability, but wanted to spend more - and therefore to make more. This was anathema for the old school, among whom Rayner counted himself.

Allen & Unwin's major problem, acute in the mid-1980s, was being middle-sized, neither large enough to absorb overheads easily nor small enough to be quirky and buoyant. The company showed its first loss in 1985, and the decision was taken to join Bell & Hyman, thus forming Unwin Hyman, with A&U having a 40% stake in the new company and with Rayner as chairman. Five years later that firm was bought by HarperCollins, and Rayner performed the melancholy task of collecting by van a few personal relics.

The new owners retained in print no more than a few highlights, such as the Tolkien books, and only employed half a dozen members of the Unwin Hyman staff. The asset-stripping operation, as Rayner wrote (in a privately published book called A Remembrance) was "messy, depressing, and, at times, outrageous for those at the receiving end".

Rayner Unwin, who was awarded the CBE in 1977, was a senior figure with the Publishers Association, notably for the 23rd International Publishers Association Congress of 1987, the first to be held in the UK since 1936, when his father had been in charge. He published five books of his own, including The Defeat Of John Hawkins and A Winter Away From Home, the latter about the extraordinary over-wintering in the arctic by William Barents in the 16th century.

In 1952, he married Carol Curwen, a childhood friend and daughter of Harold Curwen, owner of Curwen Press. They had three daughters and a son, Merlin, who now looks after Merlin Unwin Books.

 Rayner Stephens Unwin, publisher, born December 23 1925; died November 23 2000

webTitle: Your questions answered

fields.headline: Economics made easy
fields.trailText: Your questions answered.
fields.body:
What do commentators mean when they say the US economy is heading for a soft landing?

A soft landing is when policymakers successfully steer an overheating economy back down to a sustainable level of growth without causing a recession.

How do they do that?

Usually, the central bank raises interest rates to slow the economy. Increasing taxes or cutting government spending will also curb growth but it is a less popular means of controlling the speed of the economy.

What is the effect of raising rates?

If the monetary authorities get it right, growth will slow down to below its long-run average, and unemployment may rise slightly, but inflationary pressures will ease.

And if they get it wrong?

The economy could experience a hard landing - ie, a recession.

What is likely to happen in the US?

The economy is definitely slowing down, but commen tators are divided about whether it will have a soft landing next year. As the Bank of England observed recently, sometimes it is hard to a tell a soft landing from the beginnings of a hard landing.

What are the signs so far?

US consumers have borrowed large amounts to finance their spending habit. If the slowdown in the economy convinces them to tighten their belts and start repaying debts, that would hit demand for goods and services and a much harder landing could be in the offing.

There are also signs that the financial markets are pricing in a harder landing. Borrowing costs for riskier companies are rising. Ana lysts at JP Morgan estimate there is a 30% chance of a hard landing in the US next year.

And if the US economy goes into recession?

It is bound to be bad news for the rest of the world. The US consumer kept the world afloat in the aftermath of Asian crisis by buying foreign imports at a rate which has sent its trade deficit rising to record levels.

A US led slowdown could have a severe impact. Growth in much of the rest of the world has been driven by exports to the US. If the US is no longer acting as the importer of last resort, Asia would be hardest hit, but Britain and the rest of Europe would also suffer.

webTitle: Plane's landing ordeal

fields.headline: Plane's landing ordeal
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: A passenger told yesterday of his 90 minute air ordeal after the captain announced he was unsure whether the wheels had come down for landing.
fields.body:
A passenger told yesterday of his 90 minute air ordeal after the captain announced he was unsure whether the wheels had come down for landing.

Kenneth Skates, 24, said he did not know whether he was going to live or die when the pilot walked down the aisle and lifted up the carpet to try to lower the landing gear by hand.

He said one terrified passenger tried to call his loved ones on his mobile telephone and others prayed when they were told to brace themselves for a crash landing.

Problems on the EasyJet flight began on its approach to Liverpool airport after a flight from Amsterdam on Saturday.

Mr Skates, a reporter, said he knew there was something wrong when they started to circle Liverpool airport. "The captain said there was a problem and a light which indicates that the landing gear has not come down was on.

"He came into the passenger cabin and pulled up the carpet to find the manual workings for the wheels but he didn't find it. He went back into the cockpit and said we would now have to make an emergency landing and could people assume the crash position.

"People were starting to get hysterical and as we came into land they then said we were now going to go to Manchester instead. On the way the captain kept rolling the plane from side to side and bouncing it to try to get the wheels down." The plane landed safely and a spokesman for Manchester's airport police said nothing was found to be wrong with the landing gear.

There was no one available at EasyJet to comment.

webTitle: Leader: Labour must consider honest tax increases

fields.headline: Fresh fiscal thinking
fields.standfirst:
People will pay more - if they see results
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour has to put its 1992 defeat behind it and think afresh about the acceptability of honest and open tax increases.
fields.body:
A Fabian report published today claims that the anti-tax era inaugurated by Margaret Thatcher's election in May 1979 and Ronald Reagan's in the US in 1980 is over. Policy-wise, Labour has to put its 1992 defeat behind it and think afresh about the acceptability of honest and open tax increases: income tax, that is. Indirect taxes can be regressive, like Vat, or like petrol duty have already reached the end of the road. People will progressively pay more of their income to the state, if they are convinced spending is necessary and is administered effectively. The first part of that is easy: public decrepitude is all around. The second is up to ministers. If they can now focus on delivery and the practical management of public services as the fruits of spending increases flow through, people will believe again.

Ah, the Philip Gould tendency will say, but people speak with forked tongue; they punish high-tax parties in the polling booths. Of course the government runs that risk - even though the UK remains distinctly undertaxed compared with the rest of Europe. Higher-rate taxpayers are small in number but they have powerful allies in the media who would pull out all the stops to drown the case for fairer tax on earnings.

The Fabians' big idea is to make the tax system much more transparent by setting up an independent body to review what government takes and gives. This would establish in the public's mind a clearer identity between the two. We have long needed a source of expertise outside Whitehall to expose the sleights of hand and subterfuges wily chancellors get up to - apart from the marvellous work done by the Institute for Fiscal Studies. By linking this with a revamped audit office/commission, the Fabians say, the public gets in on the fiscal act.

Being Fabians, they say wait a while, to see how the spending splurge announced by Gordon Brown this year issues into public services. But sooner or later big questions loom into view. A key to raising UK productivity is improved education. Yet education spending in this country is low as a proportion of national income and will not be much higher in 2004. Public affluence that matches private affluence will - the Fabians are right - require significant increases in the tax take. Labour seems now to realise the principal divide in our national politics is fiscal and the sooner it admits this in public the better.

webTitle: South African corruption agencies  to investigate  government arms deal

fields.headline: Graft inquiry into ANC and BAe
fields.trailText: South African corruption agencies are to investigate a £4.3bn government arms deal with European companies, including the British firm BAe Systems.
fields.body:
South African corruption agencies are to investigate a £4.3bn government arms deal with European companies, including the British firm BAe Systems. Their inquiry will he an unprecedented test of the probity and accountability of the African National Congress government in Pretoria.

Signed at the end of last year, the deal has prompted numerous allegations of corruption and conflict of interest on the part of senior ANC politicians and civil servants.

BAe has denied impropriety, saying it had "meticulously abided by the rules".

"It was one of the most rigorous negotiating processes we have encountered".

The parliamentary public accounts committee opened the four-pronged inquiry into how the contracts were awarded after the auditor general found serious flaws in the procurement process. Committee members were alarmed to discover that the cost rose by nearly 50% in a year.

Last week the committee convened a meeting with the auditor general, the office for serious economic offences, the public protector of government ethics, and a special investigations unit headed by Judge Willem Heath.

There was a "need to prove or disprove once and for all the allegations which cause damage to perceptions of government", a spokesman said.

Accusations of irregularities were first made by an unidentified group of "concerned ANC MPs" unhappy that some sub-contracts had been awarded to companies associated with senior government figures, past and present.

The auditor general singled out the way in which a contract for 52 Hawk and Gripen fighter planes went to the Anglo-Swedish consortium of BAe Systems and Saab. The Hawks were ranked second of the four contenders in the overall evaluation but the armaments acquisition council decided not to take cost into account and gave the contract to BAe.

The public accounts committee voiced concern that the Hawks and Gripens were being sold at double the basic price, "apparently for necessary extra features".The committee said an inquiry was needed to see if "improper influence" decided whichfirms got the contract, and "the possible role played by influential parties in determining the choice of sub-contractors".

The allegations have been raised in parliament by a Pan-Africanist Congress MP, Patricia de Lille, who called for an inquiry into the actions of the head of defence acquisitions, Chippy Shaik.

Critics of the deal, including the South African churches, have argued that the money would be better spent on alleviating poverty, and that South Africa faced no military threat justifying such a large expenditure. The other elements of the package are four submarines from Germany and 40 Augusta helicopters from Italy.

webTitle: Online brands and offline advertising

fields.headline: Starting up
fields.standfirst: It pays to advertise - but online brands find they get more for their money offline, say Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison, the co-founders of Rools, an online payment service allowing teenagers to make purchases.
fields.trailText: We are stunned by some of the sums that other dot.com businesses are spending. Last week we met an online start-up just six weeks after its launch. With some pretty healthy investment funds behind it, this business has committed spending of £1m on advertising between Christmas and new year. It is the sort of marketing that fresh, unknown internet businesses were spending 12 months ago but is virtually unheard of in today's climate.
fields.body:
We are stunned by some of the sums that other dot.com businesses are spending. Last week we met an online start-up just six weeks after its launch. With some pretty healthy investment funds behind it, this business has committed spending of £1m on advertising between Christmas and new year. It is the sort of marketing that fresh, unknown internet businesses were spending 12 months ago but is virtually unheard of in today's climate.

With a view to our own marketing campaign, we inquired about which activity had delivered them most benefit to date. They were categorical - TV advertising. The strength of offline media in helping build new online brands has been a consistent theme in the feedback we have had from companies already out there, particularly those in our sector. By contrast we have struggled to find anyone - beyond the sellers of online media space - willing to extol the virtues of online advertising.

It seems that many companies have dipped their toes in the rather murky water of online advertising but have not been convinced of the benefits. This sceptical attitude was backed up by a National Association of Advertisers survey earlier this year that revealed that 49% of potential advertisers were put off by the lack of evidence that their money would be well spent online.

This finding addresses the problem of accurate mea surement of effectiveness, but this should be one of the main strengths of online advertising. In principle, everything can be measured.

A big problem is that few people have faith in many of the reported measures. As potential advertisers, we need to understand the popularity of different websites with teenagers. For a start, how many unique visitors do they have?

An impressive 1m each month according to one marketing manager last week. It was rather telling that he felt it necessary to add that these were "real figures", however. Without external audit, there is little consistency in the method of measurement between different websites.

User panels also give a consistently inconsistent view of the world. Two of the leading research agencies differed by over 50% in their estimates of the number of British visitors to AOL in the summer.

It would be foolish to say that no online advertising works. You can tell how popular it is by the ubiquity of the banner ads at the top of websites and the creative energies being invested in new online advertising techniques.

Online, we have had the greatest success in attracting visitors and registrations with other activities, such as sponsoring newsletters and producing funky games.

When the time comes to spend some more substantial cash on marketing Rools, the majority of it will certainly be on offline media.

webTitle: Debate: the issue of measuring productivity

fields.headline: Something's got to give to close gap
fields.trailText: One of the government's priorities is to narrow the productivity gap between Britain and other leading industrial economies. This objective has, however, thrown up some tricky questions about how to measure that gap and about the links between the government's analysis of the problem and the impact of its policies.
fields.body:
One of the government's priorities is to narrow the productivity gap between Britain and other leading industrial economies. This objective has, however, thrown up some tricky questions about how to measure that gap and about the links between the government's analysis of the problem and the impact of its policies.

In July the Treasury and the Department of Trade signed up to a target of narrowing the productivity gap with the US, Germany, France and Japan, but, by the time of the pre-Budget report in November, Japan had been dropped from the analysis.

The answer relates back to the issue of measuring productivity. The Treasury has been insisting that there are two ways: output per worker and output per hour worked. In fact it is the latter that is the strictly correct measure; one would only use output per worker as a proxy in the absence of data on hours worked.

However, the OECD provides such data and, although there is a significant margin of error around all international statistics, there is no reason why the Treasury could not present proper measures of productivity. The problem is that output per hour worked across the Japanese economy was only 83% of the UK level in 1998. So the Japanese have worse productivity than us, a fact the Treasury appears only to have realised some time between July and November.

Output per hour worked was 24% higher in France, 22% higher in the US and 10% higher in Germany relative to Britain in 1998, according to the OECD. However, in France and in Germany this productivity gap is offset by much lower employment rates so that GDP per head of the population is not significantly different. As this is the ultimate headline measure of material welfare it is unclear why we should focus on productivity per se . The US, and Norway and Denmark, are the only countries with higher productivity and higher employmentthan Britain.

So what are the causes of the productivity gap? In a paper published with the pre-Budget report, the Treasury quotes research that suggests that the biggest cause of the gap against the US and Germany is the lower physical capital stock in Britain following decades of relative under-investment.

In terms of solutions, the government places emphasis on a range of policies that would attract broad support. They include tackling market failures that, for example, lead to too little research and development activity or allow firms with market power to stifle competition. Estimating the likely impact on productivity of such policies is hard and the Treasury has recently exercised caution.

What about the key problem, that of capital investment? The pre-Budget report has a graph showing business investment as a proportion of GDP rising strongly between 1994-99 to an all-time high.

The report goes on to say that this rise would have to be sustained over a long period for Britain's capital stock to reach the levels of comparable countries. Unfortunately, in 2000, business investment is forecast to grow by only 1.75% and by 1.5% to 2% in 2001, after 7.5% growth in 1999. Business investment as a proportion of GDP will dip slightly.

This is a consequence of the government's laudable ambitions to boost public spending. Even with further downward pressure on unemployment, real GDP cannot grow faster than 2.5% to 3% a year. If we want public spending to grow by 5% in 2000-01, then consumer and or investment spending has to grow more slowly than GDP. In practice it is business investment that is expected to slow significantly to create the room for higher public spending.

What this illustrates of course is that all the debate about the size of the government's budget surplus and the room this makes for spending increases or tax cuts decisively misses the point. Public spending always carries with it a real opportunity cost and if we want it to grow faster than GDP something else has to give.

Most people will welcome the planned increases in public spending. But the Treasury cannot have it both ways. The more public spending we have the less business investment spending we can accommodate, unless consumer spending slows. The Treasury appears to be clear about what is needed to close the productivity gap - more investment - but does not yet appear to have worked out what we are going to have to give up to accommodate it.

 Peter Robinson is senior economist at the Institute for Public Policy Research

webTitle: Brown ready to ban French beef

fields.headline: Brown ready to ban French beef
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: The government was braced for a "beef war" with France last night after Nick Brown made clear he was ready to ban imports as the number of BSE cases uncovered across the channel continued to grow.
fields.body:
The government was braced for a "beef war" with France last night after Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, made clear he was ready to ban imports as the number of BSE cases uncovered across the channel continued to grow.

He promised to act swiftly if an investigation by the food standards agency this week decides that French beef poses a risk to public health after last week stepping up spot checks at ports.

Aware that a ban could be later ruled unlawful, Mr Brown said: "If Sir John Krebs [FSA chairman] says new measures are needed, then we will do that now and then argue it in the EU afterwards.

"What everyone else is doing is to take action and then justify it later."

He appeared to suggest that any action might in part be in retaliation for the French ban on British beef despite the European commission's decision to allow exports to resume.

Little French beef is imported into Britain and a ban could have more diplomatic than health implications, increasing pressure on Paris to end a boycott of UK beef.

The shadow agriculture minister, Tim Yeo, said: "The doubts about the safety of French beef are now so serious it is the only responsible action the government can take."

French farmers fear the discovery of BSE in their herds, after the number of cases detected trebled this year to more than 100, could be catastrophic for sales.

Mr Brown hinted yesterday that the government is to spend £19m helping British farmers meet higher bills due to stricter hygiene standards at abbatoirs licensed to process beef for export.

The National Farmers' Union warned against a hasty ban on French beef.

Ben Gill, NFU president, said: "If a ban is justified, then that is what we must do. But it would be folly if we tried to interfere with the FSA in its infancy as it tries to establish itself.

"It is important that we listen to Sir John Krebs and do not overreact. The imports of beef from France into Britain are minimal."

webTitle: Monday briefing

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

British Nuclear Fuels is lobbying for permission to build a new generation of nuclear power stations which, it claims, would help fight climate change and reduce the plutonium stockpile. The state atomic energy group would use technology it acquired through buying reactor-building businesses to construct plants in place of its obsolete Magnox stations.

British Airways and American Airlines are to relaunch their global partnership within weeks and could make fresh plans to merge their transatlantic operations. The companies intend to make a "declaration of renewed commitment" to each other and to their global Oneworld marketing alliance of airlines after months of uncertainty while BA was attempting to buy Dutch airline KLM.

Drinks giant Allied Domecq has been spurned by rival Diageo over an approach to carve up Seagrams £7bn spirits and wine empire.

Sunday Times

Legacy, the consortium picked as preferred bidder to buy the Millennium Dome for £125m has recruited two new shareholders, Bank of Scotland and Sir Robert McAlpine, the building group, and each will hold a 5% stake.

Britain is set to stay out of the euro for at least five years, analysts believe, amid increasing signs of voter and business hostility. A Mori survey for Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, published this weekend, showed public opposition to British membership of the euro at its highest since Labour took office in May 1997.

Sunday Telegraph

Emap, the magazine publisher and local radio operator, is considering the sale of its business publishing arm for an estimated £750m. The move would eliminate debt and allow the company to emerge as a pure consumer media group. Media executives say the group has received several approaches for the business, known internally as Emap Communications. Kevin Hand, the chief executive, has told associates he would consider a reasonable offer for the business though he is not in active negotiations.

CSS Stellar, the sports and entertainment management group which represented the striking England rugby squad last week is to be valued at £30m and raise £10m in a stock market flotation that will make it the country's first quoted sports and entertainment management company.

Coral, Britain's third biggest bookmaker, is seeking a buyer after abandoning plans for a £1bn stock market flotation last month.

Sunday Business

Nasdaq is to undergo a corporate restructuring to create a separate London subsidiary that could pave the way for the US-based share market to renew its plans to link with the London Stock Exchange.

Marks & Spencer is considering pulling out of continental Europe. The stores company has instructed estate agents Healey & Baker to conduct a thorough review of its property holdings in France, Spain, Portugal and Germany.

Mail on Sunday

The government is ready to make concessions to high street lenders to secure their backing for a universal bank which will operate throughout the Post Office's 18,000 branches.

Some of Railtrack's City shareholders are threatening rebellion over plans to leaves lame duck chairman Sir Philip Beck in place until next summer.

webTitle: Obituary letter: Harold Jackson on Emil Zatopek

fields.headline: Letter
fields.trailText: Harold Jackson on Emil Zatopek
fields.body:
Harold Jackson writes: Three days after the 1968 Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia, Emil Zatopek (Obituary, November 23) appeared in the lounge of a small hotel in central Prague. He was anxious to assure western journalists that his compatriots were not taking the invasion lying down and told us of an extraordinary network of clandestine radio stations which had sprung instantly to life.

Small parabolic FM transmitters had been scattered around the city to beam virtually untraceable signals from point to point. Within hours of the invasion, they had been taken over by dissidents. Using a cellular web of phone contacts, the resisters tracked Russian military movements and actions, and reported on Czech responses around the country.

The reports were taped by broadcasters with easily recognisable voices and beamed to powerful main transmitters. In the early days, they gave the Czechs and the world an unprecedented picture of the Soviet clampdown.

Zatopek claimed no part in this operation, but his military rank, and his obvious familiarity with the technical details, left few of us in any doubt that he was a leading player.

webTitle: Obituary: Edith Halmos, social worker

fields.headline: Edith Halmos
fields.trailText: Edith Halmos, who has died of cancer aged 83, was one of the postwar pioneers of professional psychiatric social work.
fields.body:
Edith Halmos, who has died of cancer aged 83, was one of the postwar pioneers of professional psychiatric social work, replacing the "lady bountiful" image of earlier days. After training at the London School of Economics and Southampton University, she started work just before the Children's Act of 1948 came into force.

Specialising in child care, her first post was in Ealing, west London. Later, she worked in Stoke-on-Trent, Cardiff, and at the Hospital for Sick Children, Great Ormond Street, from where she retired in 1979. She was also a JP and a prison visitor.

She regretted the post-1974 development of generic social work because she felt that the loss of specialisation, and the particular expertise it created, was detrimental to the care of the individual client.

Edith (known to all her friends as "Dit") was born in Budapest to a Viennese mother and a Hungarian father. Her love of working with children was nurtured under Freud's daughter, Anna, at the nursery she had set up in Vienna. Dit was a student there during the failed revolution of 1934, thus gaining firsthand experience of the turmoil to come in central Europe. She and her husband moved to London in 1939.

Dit was instrumental in the development of three organisations founded at Great Ormond Street. Since the 1970s, Heartline has provided help and guidance to families of children with heart disease. In retirement, she helped to launch the Sick Children's Trust in 1982, raising funds to purchase and equip family accommodation at or near children's hospitals. From 1990 until earlier this year, she continued to share her wealth of experience by contributing regularly to the training of bereaved parent volunteers who staff the Child Death Helpline.

She is survived by her son, Tony.

 Edith Halmos, social worker, born January 11 1917; died November 3 2000

webTitle: Romanians ready to turn left at the polls

fields.headline: Romanians ready to turn left at the polls
fields.trailText: Doffing a smart black trilby to his admirers, Ion Iliescu swept into the high school in Jean Monnet street, in an elegant suburb of the capital Bucharest, to cast his vote in the presidential and parliamentary elections yesterday.
fields.body:
Doffing a smart black trilby to his admirers, Ion Iliescu swept into the high school in Jean Monnet street, in an elegant suburb of the capital Bucharest, to cast his vote in the presidential and parliamentary elections yesterday.

He appeared in good spirits. The 70-year-old politician who lost the presidency in 1996 now seems about to recapture it.

The son of a railway worker brought up by his grandparents, Mr Iliescu joined the Romanian Communist party in 1955 and rose rapidly through the ranks until he fell out of favour with the then dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu, in the 1970s.

He was demoted in the party, becoming director first of the water board in an eastern county, then of a printing house.

But in 1989 he bounced back, playing a key role in the revolution which ousted Ceausescu. In 1990 and again in 1992 he was elected president.

His Party of Social Democracy (PDSR) lost power to a loose coalition of Christian-Democrats, Liberals, rival social democrats, and ethnic Hungarians in 1996. The coalition, riven by personal and political disputes, now looks likely to be turned out by the electorate.

The opinion polls suggest that the PDSR will win a parliamentary majority, but it may choose to invite the Liberals to share power, alleviating fear in the international community that leftwingers such as Mr Iliescu will oppose privatisation.

The presidential election is less clear cut and may go to a second round run-off on December 10.
