webTitle: Hi-tech nose to nail bugs

fields.headline: Hi-tech nose to nail bugs
fields.trailText: A bacteria-sniffing "electronic nose" developed by British and US scientists is to be tested on patients, it was disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
A bacteria-sniffing "electronic nose" developed by British and US scientists is to be tested on patients, it was disclosed yesterday.

The device is designed to detect bugs in urine samples, making it possible for infections to be diagnosed in minutes instead of days.

It was developed by Crewe-based Osmetech experts in e-nose technology for healthcare, and the US company Cyrano Sciences, of Pasadena, California, which makes similar instruments for industry.

Sensors made by Osmetech are to be incorporated into the Cyranose 320, a device now used by food and perfume producers.

The trials taking place at the Brigham and women's hospital in Boston, Massachusetts, will finish in mid-2001.

Their aim will be to see if the hand-held device can successfully detect bacteria present in urinary tract infections.

If the results are favourable the two companies plan to negotiate a commercial licensing deal.

The e-nose is expected to cut the cost of urine tests dramatically. Worldwide around 500m urine tests are carried out each year, costing more than 1.5bn.

A collaboration agreement was signed by Osmetech and Cyrano Sciences last week.

Gordon Hall, chairman of Osmetech, said the global healthcare market had reached a point of diagnosis and treatmentwhere rapid e-nose technology would be of value. "This venture could add significant value to e-nose technology providing faster and cheaper methods of detecting infections."

webTitle: Obituary: Carole Rosen, singer, broadcaster and writer

fields.headline: Carole Rosen
fields.standfirst: Singer whose talents flowered through radio, print and biography
fields.trailText: A singer whose talents flowered through radio, print and biography.
fields.body:
The singer and broadcaster, Carole Rosen, who has died of cancer aged 66, was a mezzo-soprano of style and verve, whose love of music led her into print and radio journalism, and biography. She undoubtedly had the voice, poise and presence to become a top diva, but it conflicted with her desire for family life.

The only child of a cultured Jewish family rooted in Russia and Romania, Carole inherited her voice from her paternal uncle, Sam Rosen, noted for his Caruso-style tenor but also for his dissolute lifestyle; he gained, and later lost, a scholarship at the Guildhall School of Music, and ended up in vaudeville.

Her father, Abel Rosen, himself a pianist child prodigy, won a first in mathematics at Imperial College, London, and became an electrical engineer. The seeds of performance were in his daughter's nature, though he feared that she might emulate her uncle's louche lifestyle. She herself was more philosophical: Uncle Sam simply had a typical tenor's faults - overeating, laziness and womanising.

Carole graduated in politics, philosophy and economics from Somerville College, Oxford, in the mid-1950s, and joined the BBC as a studio manager. She studied singing with Helen Isepp, Lucy Manette, Otakar Kraus, Dame Eva Turner and Erich Vietheer, and made her London debut at the St Pancras arts festival in 1962, appearing in two television operas the following year.

A scholarship from the Austrian government was followed by an Arts Council grant to study at the Vienna Music Academy. In 1964, she was offered a contract to sing with the Flensburg City Opera in Germany, where she took part in two performances of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony.

By this time she had met her future husband, the journalist-barrister Peter Marsh, whom she married in 1965. He was attracted less by the glamourous operatic world than by her sense of vulnerability, and her "very rich, bawdy humour". He admired her exuberance, seriousness and generosity of spirit.

With the German contract already in her hand, Carole opted instead for domestic compromise, and returned to England to seek concert work. She sang with Janet Baker, with the Handel Opera Society and as guest artist at Sadler's Wells. She gave recitals and broadcast for the BBC and Austrian and Israeli radios.

In the 1980s and 1990s, she made radio programmes on Byron's works, and documentary features. She was a critic and contributor to the BBC World Service, and to arts programmes like Music Works and Kaleidoscope. As a singer, she toured the United States for Columbia Artists and English National Opera, and served on the jury of the international singing competition in Rio de Janeiro. Her operatic roles included Carmen, Azucena in Il Trovatore, and parts in The Tales Of Hoffman, The Rape Of Lucretia, and The Consul.

Musical biography proved another route for Carole's expression. Her book, Opera, was published by Blandford Press in 1983, and while she was thwarted in her attempts to write Jacqueline du Pre's life story, her exhaustive work, The Goossens: A Musical Century, was published by André Deutsch in 1993, and won the Yorkshire Post prize for best musical biography of the year.

An interest in political and Jewish activities led her to join the Labour party, and participate in the West London Synagogue's care-in-communities satellite groups to promote inter-communal fraternity.

Carole entertained widely, and was a true literary chatelaine, a sharp and avid networker, as keen to promote the interests of others as her own. At events run by the Society of Authors and the Royal Society of Literature, where she was a member, her elegant, imposing figure was a familiar sight, always gesturing some useful introduction.

Her richly modulated speech could sound patronising if you did not know her. But the very reverse was true; her ironic, gently chiding manner was familiar to those whose work she valued. Her friend, the textile designer Althea McNeish, recalls her as a journalist of rare empathy, who could coax out the individual within the shy, tongue-tied young artist, and convey to her listeners the colour and texture of her designs.

Carole freelanced for national newspapers and produced many arts programmes for Radios 3 and 4. A recent favourite was No Son Of Ours Will Be An Usherette, made by 1994 with the impresario Stephen Wichhusen, about the survival of small cinemas. Never an arch-feminist, she was moved, towards the end of her life, to begin a documentary about Sylvia Pankhurst. During her final illness, she got out of her sickbed to complete her recording for the programme, which was broadcast on Radio 4 in June. Also in the pipeline was a book about Jenny Lind.

She is survived by Peter, their daughter Katie and son Matthew.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText:
Data bill nears completion
The government's freedom of information bill faces one of its last parliamentary hurdles when it returns to the Commons today.
fields.body:
Data bill nears completion
The government's freedom of information bill faces one of its last parliamentary hurdles when it returns to the Commons today.

MPs are due to discuss amendments made by the Lords. The bill is then expected to be given its final approval. It seeks to reduce secrecy in the public sector and open up information to the public.

Long Kesh army base closes
The army yesterday closed the Long Kesh military base that has stood guard over Northern Ireland's top security Maze prison for nearly 30 years. Closure became a certainty when the prison was closed in the summer.

Inquiry into car rental firm
The office for fair trading said yesterday it was investigating whether easyRentacar's refund policy breaks consumer laws. Consumer groups have received complaints about alleged excess charges by the firm.

Voice box op 'in four years'
The first fully functional "voice transplant" could be carried out in Britain within the next four years, researchers in Bristol said yesterday. A £1.2m programme will research the transplant of a voice box from a dead donor to a living person.

Two win £7.5m lottery jackpot
Two people shared Saturday's £7,578,132 lottery jackpot. They matched balls 3, 6, 20, 42, 43 and 48. The bonus number was 30. Three people won £250,000 in the Thunderball game. The numbers were 9, 15, 16, 18 and 24. The Thunderball was 8.

webTitle: Architects urged to go for the 'wow factor' in designs for Britain's new public buildings

fields.headline: Architects urged to go for the 'wow factor' in designs for Britain's new public buildings
fields.trailText: Architects   are to be encouraged to "delight" the people who use, work in, and live with new buildings in an initiative designed to help sweep away the legacy of souless municipal architecture and improve the quality of Britain's public buildings.
fields.body:
Architects are to be encouraged to "delight" the people who use, work in, and live with new buildings in an initiative designed to help sweep away the legacy of souless municipal architecture and improve the quality of Britain's public buildings.

Under a new set of performance indicators being produced by the Construction Industry Council, architects and bodies commissioning new buildings will be encouraged to consider whether the planned building has "the wow factor" as well as the more traditional concerns of function and cost.

The project, being developed at Sussex University, will ask interested parties to consider the "effect on the mind and the senses" of new developments. In an attempt at produce a "delight rating" for a given building architects, clients and the intended users of the building will be encouraged to ask: "What do passers-by think of the building?", "Does it provide a focal point for the community?", and "Can you have a party in it?"

The move is an attempt to encourage local authorities and spending bodies to move beyond a cost-only consideration of new buildings and consider the wider implications. It is also a response to public perception that many modern structures are overly functional and somewhat souless, intended to be of use and pleasure only to those that work in them.

The "delight detector" project coincides with government initiatives to try to ensure that the promised increase in public sector spending will leave a legacy of high quality public-friendly buildings.

Last month, Tony Blair stressed the need for architects and public sector clients to consider more than cost and pure function when reviewing the quality of designs, in a foreword to a Department of Culture, Media and Sport report, entitled Better Public Buildings.

The report concluded that thoughtful high-quality public buildings could bring about dramatic social benefits. On housing estates crime and vandalism could be discouraged, while quality school and hospital buildings could help reduce truancy rates and improve recovery from illness.

Robin Nicholson, deputy chairman of the CIC, said that even potentially mundane structures can bring a little pleasure.

"There is always room for delight, whatever that may mean. In education and health buildings it is an absolutely fundamental economic benefit - a good, well-designed school enables kids to be more social and provides a better environment for learning," he told the trade magazine Building Design.

"That is not always immediately apparent to those buying hospitals and schools. The government is extremely keen on having something like this; they realise that least-cost projects leave long-term cost consequences.

"The project is about raising awareness among clients of the things that really matter but are not immediately apparent. Lots of people dismiss measuring but we are not trying to measure, we are trying to raise awareness," he said.

One project widely praised both for having a positive effect on its immediate environment and community is the new Peckham library in south-east London, commissioned by Southwark council. Designed by architects Alsop & Stormer, the library is an example of the community-minded municipal building the government has in mind. Attractive, innovative and distinctive it lies at the heart of the regeneration of the centre of Peckham, and public consultation was a crucial part of the design process.

Jonathan Leah, an associate director at Alsop & Stormer, welcomed the CIC initiative. "Often one finds that price is at the top of the list of requirements and architecture way down at the bottom," he said.

"We have striven as a practice to get the question of quality and image considered more by clients, as was the case in Peckham. Value for money is always going to be a concern whether you are dealing with a public sector or a private client but that is no reason why you have to create dull, grey buildings that are only of use to the people who work in them.

"We welcome the view that says quality of design is important, but it can be a difficult area. We are dealing with subjective judgments here."

Comment, Jonathan Glancey

No one can measure the pleasure or delight buildings give in precise, mathematical terms.

Maybe we could all be wired up and our body heat or heart rate measured to see by what degree these rose or fell when faced by the raw concrete Brutalism of London's Hayward Gallery or the super-refined Sainsbury Centre for the Visual Arts at the University of East Anglia.

But, what if the art on display in the former, normally considered a beast, was very much better than that on show in the latter - by general acclaim, a modern beauty? Surely our experience of the two buildings would then be very different from the way we might have perceived them when empty?

For better or worse, buildings are normally containers for a range of human activities. We judge them as much by the way they look as how they behave. So many elegant Georgian and operatic Victorian buildings have gone the way of the bulldozer and been replaced by soulless modern office blocks because their looks were never enough to make society care for them in their old age.

In any case, one generation's eyesore is another's delight. Could anyone, aside from a few be leagured architects and wilful critics, have imagined that Trellick Tower, Erno Goldfinger's pugilistic west London tower block, completed in 1973, would have been considered an achingly hip place to live today?

One thing we can all agree on is that new buildings should not be mean-spirited. They should be well and generously built.

But if some future official "delight factor" measurement led to the end of radical design that might appear to offend the public's eye before it, finally, wins its fickle heart, then it is to be given as wide a berth as any post-modern office block of the 1980s or dismal distribution centre or call centre of today.

 Jonathan Glancey is the Guardian's architecture critic

Delightful

Guggenheim Museum, Bilbao (Frank Gehry)

Voluptuous, clad in titanium scales and fronted by Jeff Koon's potty flower puppy.

Great Court, British Museum, London (Foster and Partners)

Supremely refined new covered public square at the heart of one of the world's busiest museums

Jewish Museum, Berlin (Daniel Libeskind)

A three-dimensional bolt of lightning that has had queues waiting to see inside its deconstructivist zinc skin.

Kansai International Airport, Osaka Bay (Renzo Piano/Building Workshop)

A tidal wave of a building, airy and light. Breathtaking.

Peckham Library, London (left) (Alsop & Stormer)

Jaunty winner of this year's Stirling Prize; a local authority building with wit and intelligence.

Dismal

The great British executive estate (housebuilders nationwide)

Dreary rows of cynical, mean-minded pseudo-vernacular and neo-Georgian stuff

MI6 Building, London (below) (Terry Farrel and Partners)

The baddies in the latest Bond film had the right idea, although one mustn't encourage real terrorist groups.

Canary Wharf Tower, London (Cesar Pelli)

Priapic symbol of Thatcherite enterprise.

Portcullis House, Westminster (Michael Hopkins and Partners)

Lumpen monument to the arrogance of today's out-of-reach parliament.

Metro Centre, Gateshead

Dumbed-down cathedral of commerce.

webTitle: Just how private is your genetic blueprint?

fields.headline: Privacy - the last frontier
fields.standfirst:
Just how private is your genetic blueprint, if scientists, police and insurers all get to see it?
Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Just how private is your genetic blueprint, if scientists, police and insurers all get to see it?
fields.body:
People feel strongly about their genes. In particular, it seems that slightly more than half the population feels that information about their genes is private, and that if others know it, then they know too much.

The overwhelming majority of people - 90%, according to the sample recently questioned by the Human Genetics Commission - feel that one should only have one's genetic information included on a database if one has given consent. And, rather significantly, only one in three people believes that insurance companies should have the right to see the results of genetic tests already taken.

These figures, of course, are the result of only one survey. But they do underline the concern that many people feel over whether informa tion about their DNA is adequately protected against possible abuse. This concern is our business in the commission, and we are taking it very seriously. We intend to start a public debate in order to ensure that if people are worried about the broader implications of the genetic revolution - which they clearly are - then we can do something about it at this relatively early stage.

When we sat down to produce our new consultation document, Whose Hand on your Genes? we were faced with an initial question which at first seemed very theoretical but which was eventually to show itself as relevant to a number of very immediate and practical issues. This was the question of whether there is anything particularly special about genetic information as opposed to other forms of per sonal information. As we looked more closely at this issue, it became clear that there were respects in which genetic information was different.

It is, in some cases, of considerable predictive value, and so it can be considered to be information about the future rather than the present or the past. It is also information about the inmost physical essence of an individual. It is our human blueprint, and it is entirely understandable that people should feel that their blueprint is a personal matter.

This conclusion has practical implications. For example, insurance companies may wish to know about your health before they extend life insurance cover. That seems reasonable enough, as insurance is a contract about risk, and if one party is going to hide information from the other, then that hardly makes for a fair bargain. We do not object to insurance companies seeing our health record or asking when and from what cause our parents died, but it appears that we are rather more sensitive about letting them see the results of a genetic test. Why should this be so, unless it is the case that we feel there is something special about DNA?

I t is not only insurance companies who may be interested in finding out genetic information about individuals. The police may be interested in your DNA in order to assist with the detection of crime. There is currently a growing forensic database in the United Kingdom, and the government recently announced that it was allocating increased funds for the expansion of this database. This is, of course, a very useful tool in the detection of crime, but it requires that a lot of people have their DNA information lodged on the database.

Those suspected of a crime may be asked to give a sample to allow identifying genetic information to be placed on the database. If they are convicted of a recordable offence, then they may stay on it. But how do they get off? Some countries, such as France, have rather stricter rules about this than we do, and this is an issue which we have raised in our document and which we shall be watching closely.

Of course, the real benefit of genetic progress is going to come in the form of advances in the understanding and treatment of disease. This is going to require the setting up of large research databases, in which the DNA of individual volunteers is compared with their health records. This has to be done, but it will be necessary to reassure people that matters such as consent and confidentiality are very carefully addressed. Again this is an issue which we raise in our paper and which we shall be taking further.

If, as our Mori poll suggests, there is a fair degree of public distrust about the security of genetic information, then we need to deal with this so that people can volunteer for this research in full confidence. The alterna tive - a situation where people were frightened to participate because they thought they would be in some way compromised or disadvantaged - is not an attractive option for the United Kingdom.

We live in a world of few secrets and little privacy. What was previously quite tucked away - the inmost workings of one's very cells - is now accessible. We have to ensure that this information is controlled by the individual, and made accessible only in circumstances which he or she chooses. This is perhaps the last fence of privacy, but it is one which is worth defending.

Professor Alexander McCall Smith is vice-chairman of the Human Genetics Commission.

webTitle: Leader: King Constantine of Greece won't easily get his estates

fields.headline: The rights of royalty
fields.standfirst: Constantine won't easily get his estates
fields.trailText: The decision of the European court in Strasbourg to order the Greek government to compensate former King Constantine for the confiscation of his royal palaces has established an intriguing, democratic precedent for disestablished monarchs.
fields.body:
The decision of the European court in Strasbourg to order the Greek government to compensate former King Constantine for the confiscation of his royal palaces has established an intriguing, democratic precedent for disestablished monarchs. The court dealt with a man who is the son of the late King Paul, the Duke of Edinburgh's cousin and Prince William's godfather, as a commoner like any other. He was obliged to pursue his claim in Strasbourg as a private individual and EU citizen, rather than as a blue-blooded ex-head of state.

Such republican spirited, forensic levelling, such legalistic lese-majesty is rooted in the sans-culotte tendency in European history, owing more to the modern concept of human as opposed to divine rights. This approach may prove to be a cautionary one next time Britain's royal family is tempted to do legal battle with its intrusively disrespectful subjects within the third estate. Thanks to the Human Rights Act, we are all citizens now, Liz. Equally, this wise and learned magistrature, these enlightened despots of Euroland, opined that even superannuated sovereigns have equal rights.

Constantine the Not-so-Great reckons the Athens mob owes him a cool billion (quid not drachmae). But hoi polloi, assorted plebs and Hellenic socialists say he has as much chance of getting the dosh as Richard III had of getting a horse. Elisavet Papazoi, the Greek deputy foreign minister and plainly no fan of fairytale endings, says (roughly translated) that if he gets the palaces and estates back, then she's the Queen of Hearts. But since the court is insisting on some form of compensation, what can Greece offer by way of barter? The Elgin marbles? Not available right now. They could give him Constantinople. But the Turks would be sure to object. Perhaps they should put him in charge of organising the 2004 Athens Olympics. The way things are going on that front, somebody certainly needs to be.

webTitle: Letters: Byelection apathy

fields.headline: Apathy: still stirring it
fields.trailText: It was certainly not "voter apathy" which kept people away from the polling booths, but the knowlege that there is no clear choice between the main political parties.
fields.body:
Jeremy Hardy (The bitter end, November 25) answers all of those people who imagine the low turnouts in last week's byelections were regrettable. It was certainly not "voter apathy" which kept people away from the polling booths, but the knowlege that there is no clear choice between the main political parties.

It seems to me the 30% who have not bothered to consider this and decided to perpetuate this state of affairs are the apathetic ones.
Ronald Williams
Runcorn, Cheshire ronnie@redandblack.freeserve.co.uk

Stuart Waterworth has a point (Letters, November 25) about devising a system for voting them out. Better still, why not a system for not voting them in in the first place? How about an extra box on the ballot paper saying "None of these" and if "None of these" gets the majority, all candidates are disqualified for five years? It certainly might encourage a larger turnout.
F Harland
Appleby-in-Westmorland, Cumbria frank.harland0@tinyonline.co.uk

The real reasons for the poor turnout in the byelections are too sophisticated for most of the professional analysts. They are: 1 the government is doing well enough for most of us.; 2 it has a byelection-proof majority; 3 the Tories are as attractive as cold custard; 4 the weather has been, still is, so terrible that no one would put his/her nose out of the door without a lot better reason than civic piety.

I am being serious.
Harold Lewis
Cobham, Surrey
lewis@cobham.u-net.com

Regarding Alastair Campbell's reported comments on the Tory game plan for the next election (Byelection victories pave way for May 3 poll, November 25), how do you "stir up apathy" exactly?
John Pritchard
Basingstoke, Hants

webTitle: Letters: Beyond the old firm

fields.headline: Beyond the old firm
fields.trailText: You reinforce the stereotypical view of Glasgow football consisting of just Rangers and Celtic. There is only one team in Glasgow, and it is called Partick Thistle
fields.body:
You reinforce the stereotypical view of Glasgow football consisting of just Rangers and Celtic (Blue and green tribes keep the divide, November 25). There is only one team in Glasgow, and it is called Partick Thistle.
Alan Kerr
Bidford-on-Avon, Warks

What Richard Williams fails to point out (Market force, November 25) is that to play for one's club is a job, while to play for one's country - or in the case of rugby league players someone else's country - is an honour.
Andrew Rose
Clitheroe

Construction of the Channel Tunnel cannot be called a success for Margaret Thatcher (Letters, November 25); she delayed the project by insisting no UK government money should be committed to it. As a result, the first stage of the new line is due to open in 2003, and the full route to London not until 2007.
Rod Prince
London

webTitle: Letters: Climate change

fields.headline: Hot air continues to rise
fields.trailText: Exactly one year ago, Uncle Sam was using strongarm methods to try to railroad through trade liberalisation measures at the Seattle conference of the World Trade Organisation.
fields.body:
This weekend, stonewalling tactics by the US caused the collapse of the international conference on climate change. Exactly one year ago, Uncle Sam was using strongarm methods to try to railroad through trade liberalisation measures at the Seattle conference of the World Trade Organisation.

No one should be in any doubt by now that the US government is intent on overcoming any obstacle to US corporate interests, regardless of the impact on the world's poor and the global environment. The Washington consensus on management of the world economy is clearly not shared by the majority of the world's people, as shown by huge popular demonstrations at both conferences and on numerous other occasions.

As global citizens, we can show our disapproval of US diplomatic thuggery by declining to purchase goods and services supplied by US corporations, and instead choosing alternatives provided by suppliers with an ethical and environmental conscience. And while we're at it, let's elect politicians to represent us who have the courage to stand up to the US and break the links which have for so long made Britain corporate America's most uncritical ally.
Peter Burt
Rustington, West Sussex

The talks breakdown is not only disastrous for the global environment but also for public health. Rising temperatures, linked with the increased risk of flooding, are likely to enlarge the geographical zone of malaria transmission, increase heat-stress mortality and spread non-vector borne infectious diseases, such as salmonellosis, cholera and giardiasis.

Such risks are threatened during this century because politicians from the world's richest country don't want to risk their friendly relationships with the corporations which so generously fund their electoral campaigns. If there was ever a need for unifying international campaigning of people working in both the environmental and health fields it is surely now.
Dr Geof Rayner
United Kingdom Public Health Association

If the Americans can't negotiate a reduction in environmental pollution, then they must be forced to do so. From today, we are starting a one-family stand against all things American, to bring them to their knees. So, it's goodbye Barbie, Coca-Cola, McDonald's, Starbucks . . .
Jonathan and Emma Cross
Bradford-on-Avon

How ironic. They ran out of time and had to hand over to the next bookers of the hall: oil industry executives.
Mark Walker
London

What a terrible indictment of humankind that we cannot agree how to stop ourselves destroying the planet we inhabit.
Mike Worthington Newcastle upon Tyne
mike@worthington1.supanet.com

The opening of the gigantic shopping mall in Beijing, and the description of the vast Volkswagon showroom as "a sign of the future", was depressing (Chinese shoppers glimpse scenes from a mall, November 25). The prospect of 1.3bn Chinese joining western style consumerism and becoming a car-owning society indicates a massive increase in global warming.
David Buckingham
Exeter
d.c.buckingham@clara.net

Now that the floods are subsiding, heat pours from open shop doors and streets are festooned with Christmas lights. Global warming? Who cares?
SMJ Kill
York

webTitle: Corrections and clarifications

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In our front page lead, General caught in Euro conflict, November 24, we referred to an article in the Daily Mail by the Tory MP Edward Heathcoat Amory. Edward Heathcoat Amory was, indeed the author of the Daily Mail piece. The Tory MP, however, is David Heathcoat-Amory.
fields.body:
In our front page lead, General caught in Euro conflict, November 24, we referred to an article in the Daily Mail by the Tory MP Edward Heathcoat Amory. Edward Heathcoat Amory was, indeed the author of the Daily Mail piece. The Tory MP, however, is David Heathcoat-Amory. The error originated with an agency and we failed to pick up its correction.

In our report, Reckless bush clearance may cost Australia the earth, page 21, November 24, we referred to a couple who acquired 790 hectares of land and said this was equivalent to 320 acres. We should have said they had acquired 320 hectares which was equivalent to 790 acres.

In a report headed Four-day weekend to mark Queen's golden jubilee, we referred to HM's coronation on June 3 1953. It was actually on June 2 that year.

A heading on page 47, Education, November 21, read, "One theatre is running a practical course for budding ... playwrites."

fields.headline: Off course

fields.body:
David Blunkett says something must be wrong when over 30% of students are leaving their courses (Politics, November 24). As the parent of a student, I can enlighten the minister.

Students are leaving because they fear the debts they are accruing, or feel likely to fail due to the hours they must spend in paid employment to keep the wolf from the door, instead of studying.

Milton Keynes

webTitle: Letters: Faithful fight back from the threat of extinction

fields.headline: Faithful fight back from the threat of extinction
fields.trailText: In his prediction that Christianity faces extinction, AN Wilson draws his material from church people who are predominantly privileged and affluent. He should look at the inner cities and council estates.
fields.body:
In his prediction that Christianity faces extinction (The poisoned chalice, Saturday Review, November 25), AN Wilson draws his material from church people who are predominantly privileged and affluent - like himself. He should look at the inner cities and council estates.

Our local church has grown from a handful to over a hundred. There are Christians who take seriously Christ's identification with the oppressed and his injunction not to accumulate money and possessions, and in return they enjoy a sharing and fellowship which stimulates growth.

Perhaps the church of Oxbridge professors, bishops and elitist choiristers is dying. But in other places it is very much alive.
Bob Holman
Easterhouse, Glasgow

While sharing with AN Wilson his love for the beautiful language of TS Eliot or indeed of the Book of Common Prayer, may I remind him that few of those for whom Christ died share this appreciation? Indeed it is even reported that the Queen Mother could not stop giggling, much to Eliot's bewilderment and consternation, when he, at her request, read to her from the Four Quartets.

As for saying the Crescent will replace the Cross because of the consistency of Islamic teaching - open your eyes Mr Wilson, and travel a little to Muslim lands and experience the variety of interpretation of the Koran. Surprisingly like Christians, some Muslims are allowed to wrestle with God!
Rev John Wheeler
Hereford

One thing AN Wilson failed to tell us was the actual date when he will convert to Islam. Could I have it, please, purely for my own sense of relief.
Rev Aled Jones Williams
Porthmadog, Gwynedd

AN Wilson should get out more, to North and Latin America, Africa, eastern Europe and to Asia, and see that there are more Christians in the world now than there have ever been.
Peter Davies
Caldy, Wirral pdd3044@liverpool.ac.uk

As a priest in the Church of England who has dared to rock the boat over matters of church doctrine, I enjoyed AN Wilson's article. Many of us promote faith as a human creation thereby enabling its powerful symbols to remain life-enhancing and inspiring. For us there is no blasphemous arrogance in revising liturgies or doctrines.
Stephen Mitchell
Barrow-upon-Soar, Leics
smitch4517@aol.com

The trouble for some is that they just cannot understand that the vibrant churches of the world, including those in Britain, do not express their faith in 17th century English
Eddie Shirras
Winchester

The visceral fury of his attack leaves me feeling that AN Wilson's soul is alive and well (and kicking). Although it may infuriate him still further to know it, I am encouraged!
Rev David Thomas
Manchester

Surprisingly like Christians, some Muslims are allowed to wrestle with God! Rev John Wheeler Hereford One thing AN Wilson failed to tell us was the actual date when he will convert to Islam. Could I have it, please, purely for my own sense of relief. Rev Aled Jones Williams Porthmadog, Gwynedd AN Wilson should get out more, to North and Latin America, Africa, eastern Europe and to Asia, and see that there are more Christians in the world now than there have ever been. Peter Davies Caldy, Wirral pdd3044@liverpool.ac.uk As a priest in the Church of England who has dared to rock the boat over matters of church doctrine, I enjoyed AN Wilson's article. Although it may infuriate him still further to know it, I am encouraged! Rev David Thomas Manchester

webTitle: American interest is shifting away from us

fields.headline: Bush or Gore, it will be tough bananas for Europe
fields.standfirst:
We must accept that American interest is shifting away from us
Special report: US elections
fields.trailText: We must accept that American interest is shifting away from us.
fields.body:
The saddest war memorial in the world is the Wall in Washington. Some 150 metres of black granite from Bangalore slashed through a grassy mound just below Constitution Avenue and, carved on it in their tens of thousands, the names of the Americans who died in Vietnam. No triumphalism, because there was no triumph. Just the Hanks and Marvins and bright, smiling Billy Joes who perished long ago.

For what? For a deluded war against an enemy of the imagination. For a world, 35 years on, where the president of the United States wanders grinning among their - still communist - heirs and successors. Have you, he ritually asks his hosts, any news of the missing, the disappeared? There is no news. There is never any news.

Away, beyond the Wall, stands the monument to those who went to Korea and did not return - and there, just across the Potomac, is Arlington cemetery, a forest of battles past. Foreign policy is no board game. Foreign policy offers up its human pawns and hacks their memory in stone. And - the vital, the different thing about this country - America does not forget.

We talk glibly enough about the perils of isolationism and a president in waiting, once the legal farrago of Florida is over, who may - perhaps in his Texan ignorance - turn his back on us and our European dilemmas. The old soldiers of cold war diplomacy chunter their wis dom of decades past to the Daily Mail. But there is another dimension to this debate, an American dimension. The question for us in a new century filled with new challenges is what we may rightly ask for and what it is reasonable to expect that Washington will do.

It's easy to bash the United States, especially on the morning after the weekend of Hague collapse. Welcome to a slowly frying planet in which corporate power and loot come first. Welcome - soon - to $70bn or so strewn on missile shields just below the ozone layer. Welcome to more billions poured over Colombia as the war against drugs turns to war on the ground. Welcome to a land where the industries who make hi-tech weaponry and the generals who use them live in each others' pockets.

All these strands, and more, are part of the mix; yet they are not the whole story. The Wall is part of that story, too.

The history Americans remember is full of wars which need not have been fought, wars in far countries and continents where filial duty - rightly or wrongly perceived - finally called. The blood that was shed then was a debt of honour. And from that blood flows a mood and a fresh perception which shapes the politics of tomorrow, whether doled out by Bush or Gore.

The Bush people put it most clearly because they have had years of opposition to hone the line, but a hamstrung Gore, beleaguered in the Oval Office, would not be so very different. When Condoleezza Rice, the intellect who will guide Bush's national security way, says that "carrying out civil administration and police functions is simply going to degrade American capability to do the things America has to do", she merely enunciates the thinking that made Bill Clinton steer clear of armed commitment to the horror called Bosnia. When George W inveighs against "open-ended commitments and unclear military missions", he means that US troops will be out of Kosovo within a year - just as, in practice, they will be for Gore.

What we don't see from a Europe which is the centre of our world is how American views of that world have changed. The "things that America has to do" are greatly changed. Russia isn't reckoned the rival or the threat of old. The eyes in the state department, just the other side of Constitution Avenue, have swung to East Asia and China most of all; to the Middle East and the Persian Gulf where the gas to be guzzled flows; to South America, with its encroaching poverty and its drug baronies. That may or may not be sound judgment - but it is the judgment.

Christopher Layne, a visiting fellow at the Cato Institute, summed up the change best the other day in a piece for the Houston Chronicle. "The Atlantic alliance's original architects never intended that the United States would be responsible for Europe's security in perpetuity," he wrote. It was a "temporary shield" until western Europe could "resume the full responsibility for managing its own security affairs".

Now a Europe increasingly "peripheral to America's strategic concerns", less important both "geopolitically and economically", had to pick up its own slack. "The Bush-Rice plan is the first step towards establishing a new US-western Europe relationship based on equality... It should be seen as a potentially wise and far-sighted act of statesmanship."

You won't find the equation so clearly outlined today as secretary of state Albright or (Republican) defence secretary Cohen rally in rapid reaction to Tony Blair's standard. They can't say in terms that Europe counts for less and must expect less. They have to fudge a little, warning that "dangers to Nato and the transatlantic link are far more likely to come from European weakness than from European strength".

But don't misunderstand their essentially bi-partisan message. Nato, an unequal partnership of nations against an outside (Soviet) threat, is not the mechanism for dealing with ethnic strife in the Balkans now - or ethnic savagery in the Latvia or the Hungary of the future. If Europe wants to put its own house in order, Europe will have to do it for itself - not bleat on the steps of the White House. We have bigger, more urgent fish to fry.

Here's the great dislocation of this disjunct debate. Our froth about incipient "isolationism" is a precise mis-reading: this isn't isolationism, but a turning of gaze and effort elsewhere. The America of Bush or Gore, in this American world, will deal with the big picture and, within it, the things that seem most vital to its current interests or obsessions. But it will not, any longer, commit more lives - more names on more walls - to the task of persuading Europe's ethnic or rabid foes to live in peace. That may be a "moral responsibility", but it belongs - as pragmatic priority - in Europe's column.

Enter the Eurosceptics and the ancient mariners, squeaking. Enter the ultimate pipsqueak, Hague. Everything, in their perverted vision, is about Brussels and straight bananas. But it isn't. It is about the America we have and the America we shall soon have. It is about a world where, without recrimination, we must fend for ourselves. It is about what - in a European Union context or some different context - we have to do for our own security. And the writing is on the Wall.

peter.preston@theguardian.com

webTitle: Letters: British Library

fields.headline: Open book
fields.trailText: At Colindale we have the greatest newspaper library in the world. We face difficult decisions on resource allocation, but we take our responsibilities to protect the national library collection seriously.
fields.body:
I was disappointed to see the reference to "dumping" in your headline (British Library halts dumping of newspapers, November 24). At Colindale we have the greatest newspaper library in the world. We face difficult decisions on resource allocation, but we take our responsibilities to protect the national library collection seriously - as our decision to review our policy demonstrates.

The article suggests we have failed to disclose the library's policy on disposals to the public, yet we have, and we continue to be entirely open on this issue. Details of acquisition and retention policies were published in a report in 1989 and publicised in the national and professional press at that time. News of the decision to offer a number of overseas titles to other libraries was published in the Newspaper Library's journal, and a notice also appeared on the library's website.
Lynne Brindley
Chief executive, British Library

webTitle: Letters: Railway infrastructure

fields.headline: Wrong kind of bail-out
fields.trailText: Can John Prescott be serious when he proposes to bail out railway operating companies in financial straits? The railway industry has fecklessly neglected its infrastructure.
fields.body:
Can John Prescott be serious (Rail chaos threat to car curbs, November 25) when he proposes to bail out railway operating companies in financial straits? The railway industry has fecklessly neglected its infrastructure. The sudden introduction of countrywide speed restrictions by Railtrack reeks of management by panic, and shows utter contempt for the convenience of travellers.

With complete justification, passengers are deserting the railways in droves; the consequent financial loss to the industry is entirely self inflicted. Companies that neglect their assets, mismanage their business and alienate their customers should be exposed to the cold winds of market forces, not rescued with taxpayers' money.
David Cooper
New Malden, Surrey david.e.cooper@talk21.com

Can anyone explain why different rules apply to highly paid executives who resign, which is their own choice, and still get a very large pay-off (Railtrack chief to get £400,000 after quitting, November 18)? If a typical Guardian reader were to make a series of misjudgments which brought their company into disrepute, he or she would be required to resign and would not get a penny in compensation.

I would also be interested to hear just what Railtrack has been doing about the state of the tracks in the years since it took over responsibility. The subsidy from the taxpayers has not been used properly - it has just gone straight into the pockets of the shareholders.
Beryl Billington
Rotherham, South Yorkshire

It's a shame, but Richard Branson's flair for publicity seems to have deserted him since around the start of the rail chaos. Are the two by any chance related ?
Trevor Hopper
Brighton

webTitle: Canada votes: Liberal prime minister's lead slipping

fields.headline: Liberal prime minister's lead slipping
fields.trailText: The veteran Canadian prime minister, Jean Chrétien, will almost certainly win today's federal election, but may end up leading a minority government.
fields.body:
The veteran Canadian prime minister, Jean Chrétien, will almost certainly win today's federal election, but may end up leading a minority government.

That could increase party pressure on him to step aside, as many former loyalists were urging when he defied them and called a snap election to block his leadership rival, the finance minister Paul Martin, and catch the opposition off guard.

At first the gamble seemed to be working. The polls showed support for the Liberals standing at more than 40%, while the rightwing Canadian Alliance (formerly the Reform party) lagged behind on 25%.

In the past week, however, their support has slipped: people seem to lose trust in the prime minister, who has been accused of helping a friend with a criminal record to get a government loan for a loss- making hotel bought from a company Mr Chrétien partly owns.

But the Alliance, led by the newcomer Stockwell Day, has slipped too. Such radical-right movements, related to the Ross Perot phenomenon in the US, have a long history in Canada.

But Mr Day, who tried to cut a charismatic figure by arriving at a press conference in a wetsuit on a personal water craft known as a Sea-Doo, has had a difficult campaign.

Critics suspect him of planning to privatise the health service and outlaw abortion. Possibly just as damaging, he became a joke figure to many after a television comedy show started an internet petition urging a change of name from Stockwell to Doris. At least 500,000 people signed.

Mr Day had hoped to win 20 or more seats but he will be lucky to get a handful, as will the centre-left New Democratic party. A former prime minister, Joe Clark of the Progressive Conservatives, has gained ground: he is seen as honest and intelligent but, at just 15% in the opinion polls, his party is doomed to a minority role.

webTitle: Dozens die in fire at Bangladesh factory

fields.headline: Dozens die in fire at Bangladesh factory
fields.trailText: A fire in a garment factory in Bangladesh killed at least 45 people, most of them in the stampede to flee the four-storey building in an industrial town near the capital.
fields.body:
A fire in a garment factory in Bangladesh killed at least 45 people, most of them in the stampede to flee the four-storey building in an industrial town near the capital, the police said yesterday.

Most of the dead were women and children.

More than 100 others were taken to hospital with injuries after the fire and stampede on Saturday night at Chowdhury Knitwear Garments factory in Shibpur, 25 miles east of Dhaka. Some of the injured were in critical condition and the death toll could rise, a police official said.

At least 900 workers, many of them women, were at the factory when the fire broke out on the fourth floor. They scrambled to get out down narrow stairwells, and many of them fell on each other, officials said.

Nearly all the victims died in the stampede and many of the injured had jumped out windows trying to escape, Sitish Ranjan, the area's chief government administrator, said in a telephone interview.

Witnesses told newspapers that workers were trapped because the only exit door on the ground floor was locked for security reasons and had to be broken open by firefighters. The factory owner, Sagar Chowdhury, disputed their accounts. He said the fire was caused by a short circuit on the fourth floor.

Bangladesh has nearly 2,000 garment factories, employing at least 1.5m workers, most of them young women. Children also work in the factories.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Race murder claim examined | Hotel deaf to Pavarotti | Pinochet takes responsibility
fields.body:
Race murder claim examined
Chancellor Gerhard Schröder has urged the police in eastern Germany to solve the case of a six-year-old German-Iraqi allegedly drugged, beaten and drowned by neo-Nazis.

Three people were arrested last week, but the authorities in Saxony, who reopened the 1997 case under pressure from the boy's family, said that although it might have been a hate crime there was no evidence of links with the far right.
AP, Berlin

Hotel deaf to Pavarotti
It is hard not to recognise the Italian tenor Luciano Pavarotti, but a hotel in Padua, northern Italy, refused to let him check in because he had no identification papers. He went elsewhere.
AP, Rome

Pinochet takes responsibility
The former Chilean dictator General Augusto Pinochet made a hesitant admission of responsibility for atrocities committed during his 1973-1990 rule.

"As a former president of the republic, I accept all the facts that they say the army and the armed forces did," he said on a taped message to supporters.
AP, Santiago

Eunuch elected as mayor
Voters in Gorakhpur, Uttar Pradesh state, made history by electing as mayor a eunuch - a historical hate-figure in India.

Asha Devi, 45, was elected by a 65,000 margin after promising to fight corruption and keep good roads, drainage and drinking water.
Reuters, Lucknow

webTitle: Brazilians' gifts to saint leave a body of evidence

fields.headline: Brazilians' gifts to saint leave a body of evidence
fields.trailText: Earlier this year Maria Teresa de Barros was taken ill and spent several days in hospital. "I couldn't see. I didn't know where I was. I thought I might even die. So I asked St Francis and, thank God, I got better."
fields.body:
Earlier this year Maria Teresa de Barros was taken ill and spent several days in hospital. "I couldn't see. I didn't know where I was. I thought I might even die. So I asked St Francis and, thank God, I got better."

Three months later Mrs De Barros, 63, travelled to St Francis's church at Caninde, north-east Brazil, dressed in a brown cassock of the type worn by the 13th-century Italian saint and carrying a carved wooden head to symbolise her return to health.

She deposited the head - together with two wooden legs from relatives whose ailments were also cured after they prayed to St Francis - on a pile of several thousand similar representations of parts of the human body.

Every year more than 10,000 are left in Caninde by people of the rural north-east, a Catholic practice dating back to the Middle Ages.

Most of them are heads and legs, but the pile also contains breasts, hands, torsos, hearts, kidneys, and even babies. The gifts are called "ex-votos", from the Latin ex voto suscepto, meaning "for a wish fulfilled".

If St Francis answers someone's prayer for help, the supplicant will travel to Caninde with an ex-voto. Often the pilgrim will promise to wear a brown cassock and only take it off when he or she eventually arrives at the church.

The offerings reflect regional medical and social problems and are often used by academics to formulate public health policies.

"The ex-votos provide you with statistics - naturally, cheaply and spontaneously. You don't need to do lots of surveys," said Adalberto Barreto, professor of social medicine and psychiatry at Ceara University in Fortaleza. "All you need to do is look at this."

Dr Barreto, who has catalogued 216,552 of them in a period of 11 years, says the pilgrims come from an area the size of France in the nine drought-prone north-eastern states. "The ex-votos reflect the social reality of the north-easterner. In each ex-voto there is a story of a victory, of a problem being overcome," he said.

"For example, when we noticed a reduction of polio legs, it showed that the anti-polio campaigns are getting better.

The most striking con clusion was derived from the increase in heads, from less than 10% in the mid 1980s to about 25% in the 1990s.

Dr Barreto attributes this to a rise in stress linked to the government's failure to respond to social needs.

"We researched 1,500 pilgrims who donated heads: 65% were women. The symptoms were headaches, insomnia and family worries. Our conclusion was that the excess of heads reflected the 'headache' of the state.

"People come to Caninde to ask for what they should be getting from social institutions."

Even though there are trained doctors available, many north-easterners prefer to put their trust in St Francis.

Maria de Nazare, 59, was at Caninde with a model head with a black circle on one cheek. The growth on her face was removed by surgery but she still wore a brown cassock, because she attributed her recovery to the saint. "I asked him to help me so I would be well again."

Often the pilgrim will promise to wear a brown cassock and only take it off when he or she eventually arrives at the church. webTitle: Classical review: Gidon Kremer

fields.headline: No ordinary virtuoso
fields.standfirst:
Gidon Kremer
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Gidon Kremer
Royal Festival Hall, London.
fields.body:
Even from the encores violinist Gidon Kremer chose for his Royal Festival Hall recital, it was clear that this was no ordinary virtuoso programme. Nino Rota's Improvisation, voluptuously romantic though it may be, is hardly a hackneyed old warhorse. Yet Rota's work seemed conservative beside the next party-piece that Kremer offered: Giya Kancheli's Rag-Gidon-Time, written, as its title suggests, by the Georgian composer for Kremer himself. A halting deconstruction of cliched ragtime melody, the work was a weird game of musical co-ordination between Kremer and his pianist, Oleg Maisenberg, who stood warily at the keyboard.

This exploration of the uncharted regions of the repertory is typical of Kremer, who has long refused to conform to a conventional solo violinist's career. Although the main part of the concert presented more standard works - sonatas by Ravel and Brahms - Kremer's playing revealed the unfamiliar, even bizarre, aspects of the music.

Brahms's First Violin Sonata was an essay in twilit, ominous colours. If the surface of this performance was an intimate continuity, Kremer and Maisenberg hinted at darker undercurrents in the first movement's flickering transitions and the lugubrious melancholy of the second.

Where the Brahms was subtly discomfiting, Kremer's interpretation of Ravel's Violin Sonata illuminated the music's surrealist core. The sonata is a succession of musical contradictions. The first movement's flow is offset by the quixotic relationship between the two parts. Kremer and Maisenberg caught the poise of Ravel's elegant discontinuity, as they did the stark rhythmic experiments of the second movement, Blues. Kremer projected the finale - a paradoxical perpetuum mobile whose swirls of notes are trapped in incessant circular patterns - with brilliant imagination.

In any other concert, Beethoven's variations on Se vuol ballare - Figaro's subversive aria from the first act of Mozart's opera The Marriage of Figaro - would have functioned as a traditionally extrovert curtain-raiser. But in Kremer and Maisenberg's hands, the work approached the explosive fragmentation of modernist composition.

Kremer and Maisenberg deliberately eschewed beauty of sound in favour of vivid characterisation; whether in Kremer's grotesque parody of a courtly menuet, or Maisenberg's splashily virtuosic cadenza. They realised superbly Beethoven's testing of their instrumental limits - and the far from genteel spirit behind the piece.

The Romanian composer Georges Enescu's rarely heard Impressions d'Enfance completed the programme, with nostalgic, if over-long, fantasy.

webTitle: Pop review: Craig David

fields.headline: Craig David and his incredible hair wax
fields.standfirst:
Craig David
City Hall, Sheffield
****
fields.trailText:
Craig David
City Hall, Sheffield
fields.body:
People are divided on Craig David. For some, he is the spearhead of UK garage, whose pioneering "two-step" music has swept him to two number ones and a record three Music of Black Origin awards (best single, best newcomer, and best R&B act). But others point to the man's ludicrous two hours every three days in the barber's chair (getting his hair waxed), and his musical similarity to 1980s smoothies Shakatak. What nobody has considered is that Craig is one of the most remarkable teen phenomena since Donny Osmond.

He is in Sheffield City Hall for only his sixth ever gig. The crowd is almost exclusively female, many under 14. It is a shock to realise that the much trumpeted UK garage "massive" is individually so diminutive, including minuscule muscleman Prince Naseem, who takes his seat to screams. But they're nothing to the whistles that greet David. When a similar enthusiasm emanates from the stage itself, even a David-sceptic like me is swept along by the show.

David is an extraordinary vocalist, with glorious, honeyed tones. He smiles warmly throughout and excels on his singles: Fill Me In, Seven Days and the lovely Walking Away, which never carries out its threat to mutate into U2's One. Predictable, maybe, but he is not afraid to throw in curve balls, such as acoustic renditions of the Human League's Human and the Artful Dodger's Re-Rewind (Bo! Selecta_).

If there is any doubt about David it centres on his lyrics - those cheesy exhortations suggesting that "beautiful laydeez" follow him to his bedroom. But then you remember that he is 19, wrote most of this stuff in that very room, and lives at home with his mum. The David boudoir has probably not been exactly heaving with lascivious females, so it seems churlish to grumble over his adolescent fantasies.

Then again, with thousands of young laydeez queuing up hear his sweetly warbled invitations already, his mother's household could soon be getting rather crowded.

 Craig David plays the Newport Centre (01633 662666), tonight, the Royal Albert Hall, London SW7 (020-7589 8212), on Wednesday, then tours.

webTitle: Getting your own back

fields.headline: Getting your own back
fields.standfirst: Revenge is sweet - but be careful what you say at your leaving do. In a fast changing world old colleagues can always resurface, says Judi James
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: Revenge is sweet - but be careful what you say at your leaving do. In a fast changing world old colleagues can always resurface, says Judi James.
fields.body:
Are you a simmerer, seether, plotter, or revenger? Do you tend to take every atom of excrement that your job cares to throw at you right beneath the jutting chin without a murmur of complaint? Or do you spend quiet moments at your desk surfing the net in the hope of finding a website titled ExecutiveHitman.com?

British culture has always been one of turning the other cheek, but all that seems to be changing. Once upon a time people who refused to go without a fight were reviled as heinous whinge-bags and jolly bad losers.

Revenge is this season's new emotion, then. But exacting it in your job can be harder than you would think. Whether you are hell-bent on immediate retaliation, or you are saving the best bits of action for the day you finally tell your boss where to stuff his/her job, some calm reflection might not come amiss if you want to be on the winning end of the encounter:

Virtual revenge

This is the safest type. You sit at your desk, stare at the screen-saver and dream.... No holds are barred in this encounter and no-one ever gets hurt. You get to visualise your boss in any number of torture or humiliation situations while everyone in the office thinks you're working on that overdue spread-sheet. Less imaginative but more IT-skilled types can work on scanning a shot of the boss onto the screen and inflicting their own choice of torture with the aid of the mouse. Mind you don't leave the programme on-line when you dash off for a fag, though.

Silently but deadly

One of the oldest and most painful forms of revenge is the silent snub routine. Kids do it at school and it stinks. People do it in business and it is known as acting with constraint. I have had reports of colleagues behaving like rowing married couples, asking other members of the team to act as message-carriers between warring factions.

The problem with this type of plotting is that it tends to stressful on both sides. You look childish and this can put the other person at the advantage, especially if he/she is the boss. Colleagues get fed up with passing messages and start telling you to grow up and get a life.

The barbed wittticism

Books could be filled with all the wonderfully clever, cutting comments we all would have said - if only we had thought of them at the time. We each have an Oscar Wilde wit inside us, just waiting to get out, but unfortunately it's never around when we need it.

I have a colleague who memorises famous one-line put-downs, just in case the occasion should arise. In calmer, lucid moments she can rival Anita Loos at her most acerbic best. Unfortunately, under pressure from a dressing-down from the boss, the best she can come up with is a one-word riposte that rhymes with merchant banker.

Well-honed put-downs can be both clever and humbling. The longer you rehearse them, though, the more stale they tend to sound. If you can't perform ad-lib style then don't bother.

The horses head in the bed

There is a touch of the Sicilian Don in all of us when it comes to planning real big-time revenge. A passive response may be all that's allowed when the boss starts throwing his/her weight around in the office, but for some it is easier to bear when they know they can take quiet delight in the knowledge that they will get their own back later on.

This type of hard-nosed revenge can range from petty pilfering from the stationary cupboard to well-planned, more long-term acts of retaliation. Coins scratch the sides of the executive Jag, kippers are nailed under desks overnight, cress is sprinkled over boardroom rugs and watered regularly, teas are spat into, spouses are posted items of underwear or fake mail-outs from the clap clinic, and toilet seats are superglued. For the more viciously-inclined this type of overt revenge might be therapeutic. The increased use of security cameras in business means you are likely to get caught red-handed, though. Remember that court appearances for letting down the boss's tyres always tend to give a negative message when added to a cv. The last word

Leaving dos tend to be the traditional place for having the last word. What could be better than slagging your boss from hell off in public a mere ten minutes before he/she quits the building for good? If you're lucky you could volunteer to do the leaving speech, which will give you a full twenty minutes or so for some unfettered insults.

The trouble is, leaving dos bring out the maudlin in all of us, especially after a few plastic cups of warm chardonnay. One sight of that Freddie Kruger-style boss standing suddenly misty-eyed and sniffing as he/she clutches a sherry in one hand and a carriage clock in the other, and even legendary avengers have found themselves blubbing and saying how sorry they are to see them go.

And you never know where you might bump into that person again. One company's redundancy is another's new-hire. The face that wilted under the barrage of withering wit from your own tongue may be the one waiting to interview you in your next company.

webTitle: Opera review: La Traviata

fields.headline: La Traviata at full throttle
fields.standfirst:
La Traviata
Royal Opera House, London
****
fields.trailText:
La Traviata
Royal Opera House, London
fields.body:
Now on its umpteenth outing, The Royal Opera's production of La Traviata has matured somewhat. Richard Eyre's staging has been reworked by Patrick Young, who has restored to it the sharpness of focus, the scrupulous clarity of observation and the penetrating moral awareness that have slipped from view a bit during previous revivals.

In many respects, this is Traviata as it should be - a study of a transgressive passion that not only offends the bourgeois conventions that strive to constrain desire within marriage, but also flouts the demi-monde code that demands sex be divorced from love.

That the staging retained its force on opening night was even more remarkable given that a last-minute cast change was involved, with the Ukrainian soprano Victoria Loukianetz replacing the indisposed Elena Kellesidi as Violetta. Loukianetz avoids the victimised waif approach, suggesting sexual knowledge as well as physical frailty in the opening scenes. She is a woman aware that time is running out , avid for a depth of emotion that will free her from the arid "vortices of sensuality" (as the libretto puts it). In the brief moments before the opera's catastrophic turning point, she radiates contentment. At the end, she portrays Violetta's protracted demise with an excruciating literalness that avoids sentimentality. Vocally, she is impressive, if uneven. There are moments of harshness at full throttle, and the act one finale was marred by an unsteady lunge at an interpolated top E flat. On the plus side, we get coloratura of pin-prick accuracy, and a flawless, limpid smoothness in the great scene when she yields to Germont's moral pressure and gives Alfredo up.

Thomas Allen and Giuseppe Sabbatini tellingly play the father and son who destroy and create her emotional world. Sabbatini's Alfredo is no innocent idealist, but a refined sensualist who is knocked off balance by his own feelings, and whose rebelliousness and incipient violence are shown as being the product of his father's rigidity. Allen suggests both the repression and the brutality beneath Germont's bourgeois veneer. When Violetta begs him to embrace her as his daughter, he avoids her in embarrassed revulsion. His first reaction on seeing his errant son is to raise his hand against him, while Sabbatini cowers in terror. Both men are completely compelling, even though Germont lies a bit low for Allen in places. Sabbbatini, however, is in glorious voice, with every note and phrase perfectly shaded.

In the pit, things are regrettably less than ideal. Conductor Simone Young favours extreme speeds - dawdling in places and at other times taking the score at such a lick that the ensemble comes close to flying apart.

 In repertory until December 18. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

webTitle: Belts tighten over Christmas for New Year bills

fields.headline: Belts tighten over Christmas for New Year bills
fields.trailText: The average person can expect to spend around £437 on Christmas festivities and January sales, if findings from Goldfish, a UK credit card company, are anything to go by, while the new year promises increased bills.
fields.body:
The average person can expect to spend around £437 on Christmas festivities and January sales, if findings from Goldfish, a UK credit card company, are anything to go by, while the new year promises increased bills.

Goldfish says the figure is the lowest for three years Ð with Christmas shoppers spending £453.70 each last year and £572.80 each in 1998 Ð and is probably the result of consumers recovering from their millennium sprees.

The survey also showed a reluctance to go into debt this Christmas. Around 25% of spending will be put on credit cards. Most of this will be on existing credit cards as only 9% of respondents plan to take out a new card to spread the payments. The rest will be paid by cash, debit card or cheque.

And only 3% of overall consumer spending will be done over the internet. Around £7 will be spent per person online, pumping £241m into the e-economy.

Plans to cut Christmas spending may prove a wise move, with other household bills set to go up next year. Energywatch, the consumer watchdog, says gas and electricity bills could rise by 25% in the new year because of rapidly increasing prices for oil and gas on world markets. Increases could start as early as January and February.

Consumers may also see sharp increases in their motor insurance premiums. Rates increased by around 20% this year and will probably go up by a similar amount in 2001, although the surge in online buying of car insurance should help cap premiums.

Premium hikes on the home insurance front canÕt be ruled out either. A spokesperson for the association of British insurers said that while the weather damage we have seen to date should not result in across the board increases in home premiums unless the next few months bring more of the same, people in flooded areas might not be so lucky. They may already be facing higher premiums and, if flooding continues, will almost certainly face higher costs.

Motor insurers, meanwhile, say they are finally breaking even after a spate of intense competition in the early 1990Õs pushed premiums to unsustainable levels at a time when the number of claims made was rising.

The requirement that insurers pay the NHS costs of someone injured in a road traffic accident compounded the sectorÕs cash-flow crisis. It must cough up £354 for outpatient treatment and £435 per night for hospitalised patients, up to a maximum £10,000. The result has been a mass culling within the sector: Since 1996 some 70% of direct insurers have left the market. Unfortunately, the consumer has also had to bear some of the brunt, so if you plan on driving next year, expect premiums increases.
fields.bodyText: The average person can expect to spend around £437 on Christmas festivities and January sales, if findings from Goldfish, a UK credit card company, are anything to go by, while the new year promises increased bills. Goldfish says the figure is the lowest for three years Ð with Christmas shoppers spending £453.70 each last year and £572.80 each in 1998 Ð and is probably the result of consumers recovering from their millennium sprees. The survey also showed a reluctance to go into debt this Christmas. Around 25% of spending will be put on credit cards. Most of this will be on existing credit cards as only 9% of respondents plan to take out a new card to spread the payments. The rest will be paid by cash, debit card or cheque. And only 3% of overall consumer spending will be done over the internet. Around £7 will be spent per person online, pumping £241m into the e-economy. Plans to cut Christmas spending may prove a wise move, with other household bills set to go up next year. Energywatch, the consumer watchdog, says gas and electricity bills could rise by 25% in the new year because of rapidly increasing prices for oil and gas on world markets. Increases could start as early as January and February. Consumers may also see sharp increases in their motor insurance premiums. Rates increased by around 20% this year and will probably go up by a similar amount in 2001, although the surge in online buying of car insurance should help cap premiums. Premium hikes on the home insurance front canÕt be ruled out either. A spokesperson for the association of British insurers said that while the weather damage we have seen to date should not result in across the board increases in home premiums unless the next few months bring more of the same, people in flooded areas might not be so lucky. They may already be facing higher premiums and, if flooding continues, will almost certainly face higher costs. Motor insurers, meanwhile, say they are finally breaking even after a spate of intense competition in the early 1990Õs pushed premiums to unsustainable levels at a time when the number of claims made was rising. The requirement that insurers pay the NHS costs of someone injured in a road traffic accident compounded the sectorÕs cash-flow crisis. It must cough up £354 for outpatient treatment and £435 per night for hospitalised patients, up to a maximum £10,000. The result has been a mass culling within the sector: Since 1996 some 70% of direct insurers have left the market. Unfortunately, the consumer has also had to bear some of the brunt, so if you plan on driving next year, expect premiums increases.

webTitle: Banking world suffers new swirl of rumours

fields.headline: Banking world suffers new swirl of rumours
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Speculation about a fresh wave of mergers in the banking sector grew yesterday with rumours that Lloyds TSB was targeting Abbey National, currently in talks with the Bank of Scotland, while an Australian bank is targeting Alliance & Leicester.
fields.body:
Speculation about a fresh wave of mergers in the banking sector grew yesterday with rumours that Lloyds TSB was targeting Abbey National, currently in talks with the Bank of Scotland, while an Australian bank is targeting Alliance & Leicester.

The planned merger between Abbey National and the Bank of Scotland has hit rough water since they were forced to reveal their discussions in early November. The sticking point is said to be over who would get the top job at the combined operation.

Lloyds TSB declined yesterday to comment on reports in the Sunday Times that it planned a counter-bid for Abbey if the former building society bids for Bank of Scotland. The report suggested that Lloyds would offer Abbey shareholders a sizeable premium which might prove more tempting than Abbey draining its coffers to acquire Bank of Scotland. Some analysts have suggested that National Australia is also interested in snapping up Bank of Scotland, but weekend reports suggested its objective was Alliance & Leicester, one of Britain's smallest mortgage banks.

The highly acquisitive Sydney based bank, already Australia's largest, was tipped as a player in the consolidation of middle-sized British banks last week when it sold a US bank, Michigan National, for $1.1bn. Chief executive Frank Cicutto said it would use some cash to expand in Britain and Ireland, where it already owns four banks.

"What is definite is that we will use part of the funds from the Michigan National sale to pursue organic growth in the UK, and that's a real live opportunity for the National," Mr Cicutto said last week.

NAB is thought to be planning an agreed £4bn cash-and-shares merger with the A&L, with the new group listed in London and Sydney.

webTitle: Comedy review: Dylan Moran

fields.headline: A rare comic hero
fields.standfirst:
Dylan Moran
Dancehouse, Manchester
fields.trailText:
Dylan Moran
Dancehouse, Manchester
****
fields.body:
After two fairly successful TV sitcoms - the surreal How Do You Want Me? and Black Books - Dylan Moran is returning to the stand-up that earned him a Perrier win in 1996. This is hardly an unheard of about-face, and yet there is something reassuringly different about the amenable Irish comic. Far from taking the edge off his comedy (as usually happens following mainstream success), television seems to have renewed his sharpness. It is probably not a coincidence that one of the best bits in this show is where he disembowels the subject of celebrity.

As generations of traumatised hotel cleaners and personal assistants will testify, getting too close to stardom can have disturbing effects, and maybe Moran has been reminded to hold on to his roots. But there is another reason he is back on fearsome form. After dragging round the same jokes like a tired old greyhound in recent years, he now has acres of hot new material. A blistering exploration of the differences between male and female pornography, for example, has audience members laughing so uncontrollably it is a wonder Moran doesn't break off his act to call a doctor.

Instead, he cleverly builds the tempo and the creative tension. In the first half, wearing awkward trendy jeans he insists were bought for him, the mop-haired 28-year-old comes over like a student led astray by insobriety. He veers off at innumerable tangents, but is unrivalled at weaving seemingly unrelated asides into coherent, hilarious tales.

In the second 50-minute section - as the sparkling wine takes hold - he is dynamite: a rabid hybrid of Basil Fawlty and a younger Victor Meldrew, a man hilariously driven towards mania by the absurdities of daily life. However, Moran is no copyist; he is one of the few comics who fully utilise the possibilities of the times we live in. His essays on ambition, stress, breakdowns, charity, computers, culture and, pricelessly, Fatboy Slim's lyrics seek, at best, to educate as much as they inform. Lobbing humorous Molotov cocktails at everything from the rich to the way people and food are treated in restaurants, Moran instinctively understands and articulates the sentiments of the common man. Moran is the antithesis of the celebrities he spoofs. He is professional and entertaining on television, but something of a comic hero when you glimpse him live.

 At the Hawth, Crawley (01293 553636), tonight, Guildhall Arts Centre, Gloucester (01452 505089), tomorrow, then tours.
