webTitle: Pick of the week

fields.headline: Pick of the week
fields.standfirst: A bittersweet claymation tribute, one of the first and the best Star Wars tributes, a meter man in the madly mundane world of middle America, and shocking footage of the anti-globalisation movement
fields.trailText: A bittersweet claymation tribute, one of the first and the best Star Wars tributes, a meter man in the madly mundane world of middle America, and shocking footage of the anti-globalisation movement
fields.body:
Brother
(Atom Films)
Garlanded with richly-deserved awards, Australian animator Adam Benjamin Elliot's true-life claymation comedy is a bittersweet tribute to his bizarre upbringing and his eccentric brother, killed by a childhood asthma attack. Resolutely unsentimental, tender, and horribly funny all at the same time, it will move the most hardbitten viewer to tears. There is no better way to spend seven minutes 50 seconds online this week. Get out your handkerchiefs. (KS)
 View the film (7mins 50)

The Dark Redemption
(theforce.net)
Possibly the original imitation. Certainly one of the first of a flotilla of home-spun Star Wars movies. Set two days before the start of Episode IV: A New Hope (ie the original 1977 Star Wars), Jedi Mara Jade must escape the clutches of the evil empire. Others along for the ride include old friends Boba Fett and Jabba the Hut. Production values are surprisingly slick - expect the level of sophistication of a high-end computer game, and Dark Redemption even features Imperial Troops with hammy English accents. It takes ages to load, but then again we're used to waiting for new Star Wars films. (SD)
 View the film (in five parts, total running time 24 mins)

Meter Man
(Ifilm)
Baby-faced Brad Renfro (The Client, Apt Pupil) stars in this indie curiosity as Sal the meter man, whose backyard assignments make him a hapless but willing witness to All-American leisure pursuits like sex, forgery, and unexpected murder. Director Roger Bourdeau keeps this low-key, low-contrast character study either agreeably off-beat or strangely confusing, depending on your narrative tastes. (KS)
 View the film (17mins)

RIP WTO N30
A documentary highlighting the now infamous clashes between police and demonstrators during anti-capitalism demonstrations in Washington and Seattle earlier this year. It begins as a series of vox pops, but soon becomes a compelling representation of events as police move in and things get very ugly. Already one of the landmark videos of the anti-globalisation movement.
 View the film (18mins 11)

webTitle: Bank chief under pressure to rescue  euro

fields.headline: Duisenberg is pushed to act
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Europe's central bank chief, Wim Duisenberg, is coming under mounting pressure from policymakers in the US and far east to prevent the continued weakness of the euro threatening a fresh global financial meltdown.
fields.body:
Europe's central bank chief, Wim Duisenberg, is coming under mounting pressure from policymakers in the US and far east to prevent the continued weakness of the euro threatening a fresh global financial meltdown.

With leadership crises in Washington and Tokyo preventing politicians authorising a repeat of September's coordinated intervention to rescue the euro, sources said America's top central banker, Alan Greenspan, has told Mr Duisenberg to take tougher action to shore up the currency.

There is intense speculation in the markets that the ECB's three unilateral interventions in the market over the past month were sparked partly by pressure from outside the euro zone, particularly from Asian countries.

The Japanese are worried that their debt burdened banking sector is over-exposed to the euro, while China and other Asian countries which peg their currencies to the dollar are concerned that the euro's slide is eroding their competitiveness.

"There probably is a campaign behind closed doors to get the ECB to back up its interventions with credible policies," said David Brown, chief European economist at Bear Stearns International. "This is a time when you cannot get coordinated intervention because you've got political hiatus in Japan and in the US."

China is believed to have sent officials to Frankfurt to express their alarm at the euro's slide since its launch nearly two years ago. When the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder visited Beijing earlier in the year, the euro was the main agenda item.

Senior financial officials warned over the weekend that the overvaluation of the dollar could be suddenly reversed, with destabilising consequences for the world economy.

Andrew Crockett, head of the Bank of International Settlements, said the growing US current account deficit was unsustainable and that a shift in market sentiment could lead to a sudden, damaging weakening in the dollar.

Mr Crockett said that at some point, America's record- breaking current account deficit would have to be closed. "It could be unwound in a benign way in which there will be a reversal in exchange rates," he said.

"Or it could be reversed in an abrupt way and we do know that when adjustments in the market begin to take place, they often do so not in the benign way," he said.

Officials in the Financial Stability Forum, an umbrella group of financial and banking officials from leading industrial economies launched in 1999 and charged with examining weaknesses in global financial structures, now worried about a sudden dollar shift, he said.

Bank of France chief Jean-Claude Trichet warned that the overall current account deficits among the world's biggest industrialised nations was unsustainable. "I am struck by the fact that the industrialised world is posing a permanent current account deficit. It used to be the contrary," he said.

"It is not possible to live in a world where the richest nations are unable to save and are asking the rest of the world to finance them," he said.

webTitle: Pop Review: Wyclef Jean

fields.headline: Endearing chaos from Wyclef Jean
fields.standfirst:
Wyclef Jean
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
***
fields.trailText:
Wyclef Jean
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
fields.body:
"Where Fugees at?" asks Wyclef Jean, one third of that very group (who may or may not still exist, depending on whom you ask), on his second solo album, The Ecleftic. A good question, and one that probably troubles many of the 11m people who bought the Fugees' 1996 album, The Score. The trio seem to have gone their separate ways, with Lauryn Hill blossoming into a Grammy-winning diva. But the will-they-won't-they persists, and Wyclef enjoys tantalising his public.

Barely two songs in, he says, "A lot of people ask if the Fugees really broke up. Well..." Rather than answer the question, he spends the next 10 minutes singing to tapes of the old hits Fugee-La and Ready or Not. Chalk it up to giving the people what they want. Even someone with the ego to call himself "the ecleftic" knows that you don't fill a venue on a Saturday night by virtue of your less-than-mesmerising solo records, the latest of which features a duet with Kenny "The Beard" Rogers.

The Fugees were this rapper/guitarist's high-water mark, and his solo act feels like one long tribute to them. He has adopted their practice of turning gigs into ebullient carnivals brimming with banter and cover versions, from Pink Floyd's Wish You Were Here to Satisfaction, a tribute to Mick Jagger, who wriggled in the balcony to his own song. Another familiar aspect was the mixing and matching of genres. It Doesn't Matter started off as a buoyant ska tune, metamorphosed into rap and finished as a growling soul jam, the last courtesy of Jean's sister Melky.

As the show went on (and on), Jean lost his few inhibitions, and the performance any sense of structure. Perhaps he had learned too well the lesson that hip hop gigs are generally intensely tedious, because he erred on the side of sensory overload, not a moment going by without a guitar solo or a homily about living the righteous life. It was both confusing and, because Jean is a wholesome version of badder, scarier rappers, endearing. Where Fugees at? No one quite knows, but for now Wyclef is keeping their spirit alive.
